HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1992
 
The Economy
The Bush Administration is promoting enterprise zones as the centerpiece of its plan to revive inner cities, but the zones that have sprouted under state programs have made only a slight dent in urban blight. Still, after a decade of criticizing the White House for neglecting the cities, many state and local officials and urban experts applaud the Administration's proposal, saying every little bit will help. [Page 1.] 
 Orders for U.S. machine tools fell 9.4 percent in April as orders from foreign customers sagged, according to the monthly report of an industry trade association. But orders rose from a year earlier, leading some analysts and executives to predict increased spending to modernize factories. [35.]
A web of zealously guarded beliefs and policies sets the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers apart from other unions. Critics say the U.E. is a relic, but admirers see it as a model for reinvigorating the labor movement by hewing to old-time principles under which workers fared better than they do today. [35.]
Just as New York was about to exhaust the last of its available transportation money, the state will soon begin receiving almost $16 billion in transportation funds. A tough political fight is breaking out in Albany over how to spend it. [21.]
Columbia University has suffered many uncomfortable moments in this year of hard times. At commencement, a flyer given out by angry students protested the adminstration's moves to limit student financial aid and make other cuts to help close a $50 million budget shortfall. [1.]
 
International
The scientists who will gather next month in Rio de Janeiro at the United Nations Earth Summit say action is needed now to limit global warming. Their science may be right, but their timing could not be worse. Burning less fuel to cut carbon emissions will be extremely difficult because fuel prices are now so low. [35.]
China's economic revolution may be dotting the countryside with new factories and electricity plants, but it is also having an unintended effect: China is contributing to global warming faster than any other large country, and there seems to be little awareness of the problem. [1.]
 
Companies
The French Government named a new chairman for Renault, selecting the managing director, Louis Schweitzer, to succeed Raymond Levy as head of the state-controlled auto maker. Mr. Levy will turn 65 next month, the mandatory retirement age. [35.]
 
The Media Business
Turner Broadcasting has created the Checkout Channel, a network of supermarket television monitors that display snippets of news, fashion tips, weather reports and advertisements to shoppers waiting to pay for their groceries. NBC, ABC and Whittle Communications are exploring similar ventures. These ventures are expected to give The National Enquirer serious competition for the attention of waiting grocery shoppers. [35.]
Growth came steadily over the last decade to Mendoza, Dillon & Asociados, the nation's largest Hispanic advertising agency. But now it and other Hispanic agencies are confronting a problem born of their own success: there are no longer many new big clients that are not already advertising in Spanish. [37.]
Genre and Out are trying to prove that gay publications can succeed without the sexually explicit ads that have repelled many major advertisers. But The Advocate, the oldest and largest gay magazine, will keep personal ads in a saddle-stitched section that must be pulled out of the magazine to be read. Advertisers are also reacting favorably to The Advocate's redesign, particularly its switch from newsprint to glossy paper. Deirdre Carmody: Magazine Notes. [37.]
Thousands of bookstore owners, managers and sales people are attending the annual American Booksellers Association convention in Anaheim, Calif., where they are previewing the books that will be published this fall and next year. [37.]

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
2,146 Students Graduate in Ceremonies for 122d Commencement at St. John's

 BODY:
St. John's University conferred 2,146 undergraduate degrees at three graduation ceremonies held over the weekend.
The Rev. Donald J. Harrington, president of the university, gave the keynote address at all ceremonies for the 122d commencement exercises. 
 Addressing the students at the campus in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday, Father Harrington told the students that "the quality of life in society rests upon the quality of education in our grammar and high schools and in our colleges and universities."
Referring to the rioting in Los Angeles, he said, "Regardless of how we interpret the events of the past month, regardless of where we seek to place the blame, I submit to you that an essential part of any solution must be the renewal of the educational system of our land."
 
Industry, Health, Banking
 At the first ceremony, held in Alumni Hall in the morning, an honorary doctor of commercial science degree was awarded to Michael E. Maher, an alumnus of the university who is chairman of Maher Terminals Inc. in New Jersey, one of the largest independent container terminal operators.
Sister Irene Kraus, president of the Daughters of Charity National Health System in St. Louis, received an honorary doctor of letters degree.
In the ceremony held in the afternoon, also in Alumni Hall, an honorary doctor of commercial science degree was awarded to Richard T. Greene, president of Carver Federal Savings Bank, one of the largest black-owned financial institutions in the nation.
Edward Mercado, director of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Health and Human Services, received an honorary doctor of laws degree.
On Saturday, a commencement ceremony was held on the Grymes Hill campus of the university in Staten Island. An honorary doctor of civil law degree was awarded to Josephine L. Gambino, president and senior member of the New York Civil Service Commission.
 
Cornell University
 Cornell University's 124th commencement took place yesterday in a cold rain with temperatures in the 30's, prompting the university's president, Frank H. T. Rhodes, to cut short his prepared remarks to the 5,900 graduates. University officials said it was the first time in 17 years that it had rained on commencement.
Each of the graduates of Cornell's 11 schools and colleges at the ceremony, which was still held outdoors on the campus in Ithaca, N.Y., was given a red rose. Mr. Rhodes used the occasion to remind them to "take time to smell the roses."
In keeping with a longstanding Cornell tradition, there were no other speakers or honorary degree recipients at the main commencement ceremony.
 
College of New Rochelle
 Robin Toner, national political correspondent for The New York Times, addressed the graduates yesterday at the 85th commencement of the College of New Rochelle. About 900 degrees were awarded to graduates of the school's undergraduate and graduate programs.
Ms. Toner received an honorary doctorate of humane letters, as did Dr. Ruth Watson Lubric, general director of New York City's Maternity Center Association and Sister Doris Smith, S.C., president of the College of Mt. St. Vincent in Riverdale, N.Y. Gordon Parks, a photographer, author and film maker, was awarded an honorary doctor of fine arts degree.
 
University of Rochester
 The 142d commencement of the University of Rochester was held yesterday at Fauver Stadium. All but one of the university's schools took part in the ceremonies, where 2,542 bachelor, master's and doctorate degrees were awarded. The commencement for the graduate school of business administration will be on June 14.
Paula P. Brownlee, president of the Association of American Colleges, addressed the graduates about the importance of liberal education. She was awarded an honorary doctorate of humane letters. Honorary degrees were also awarded to the artist Jacob Lawrence and to Dr. David H. Smith, who helped develop a vaccine for bacterial meningitis.
 
Vassar College
 Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District of Columbia's nonvoting delegate to Congress, addressed the 620 graduates at Vassar College's 128th commencement ceremony held yesterday on the campus in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
Ms. Norton, a civil rights and women's rights leader, was the first woman elected to represent the District of Columbia in the House of Representatives when she won her first bid for elective office in November 1990.

 
 
Brandeis University
 Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, told graduates at Brandeis University's 41st commencement yesterday that being a member of Congress had about as much appeal "as life in a leper colony."
But Nevertheless, Mr. Solarz urged students to be optimistic in the face of national crises like the riots in Los Angeles and unemployment.
"I won't be so bold as to suggest that you emulate my example and choose a career in elective office," said Mr. Solarz, a 1962 Brandeis graduate.
But, he said, the past 30 years have proved that individuals have the ability to bring about tremendous changes in society.
Brandeis conferred 732 undergraduate degrees, 107 master's degrees and 57 doctorate degrees at its campus in Waltham, Mass.
Mr. Solarz was one of eight people who received an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters. Other honorary degrees were awarded to The others went to Elena Bonner, the Soviet dissident and widow of Andrei Sakharov, the human rights activist; Natan Sharansky, the Soviet dissident, who will join the Brandeis faculty in September as a visiting professor,; and Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of Jerusalem.
Also receiving Other recipients of honorary degrees were Robert McCormick Adams, archeologist and a former secretary of the Smithsonian Institution; Charles R. Bronfman, chairman of the Seagram Company; Quincy Jones, the composer and entertainer,; and Robert Shapiro, a Brandeis trustee who graduated in the university's first class, in 1952.
 
Amherst College
 Robert Parker, an the astronaut, addressed 369 undergraduates at the 171st commencement yesterday at Amherst College at Amherst, Mass.
The college awarded honorary degrees to James W. Fernandez, professor of anthropology at the University of Chicago; William H. Gerdts, professor of art history at the Graduate School of the City University of New York; David A. Kessler, Commissioner of Food and Drugs; Douglas R. Lowy, chief of the laboratory of cellular oncology at the National Cancer Institute; Walter E. Massey, director of the National Science Foundation; Jessye Norman, the soprano; Donna Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, and; Hedrick Smith, author and former correspondent for The New York Times.
A special Medal for Eminent Service was awarded to H. Axel Schupf, president of H. A. Schupf & Company, an investment company in New York.
 
Mount Holyoke College
 Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, urged graduates at Mount Holyoke College's 155th commencement yesterday to change the country by taking part in public service.
"We have lost confidence in our government and in those who serve in it," she said. "But the power to change is only limited by the desire to act."
Mount Holyoke, a women's college in South Hadley, Mass., awarded about 450 bachelor's degrees.
 
Clark University
 Madeleine Kunin, a former Governor of Vermont and a special adviser to Gov. Bill Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, delivered the keynote address yesterday at Clark University's commencement exercises in Worcester, Mass.
 Reflecting on the trial of four white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of a black motorist and on the Senate's confirmation of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, Ms. Kunin told the graduates to use their "education, idealism and anger to change the United States."
 The university awarded 551 undergraduate degrees, 169 master's degrees and 21 doctoral degrees.

HEADLINE: New Support but Few Gains For Urban Enterprise Zones

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is promoting enterprise zones as the centerpiece of its plan to revive the nation's inner cities, but the more than 600 zones that have sprouted under state programs have made only a slight dent in urban blight.
Still, after a decade of criticizing the White House for neglecting the cities, many state and local officials and urban experts applaud the Administration's proposal, saying every little bit will help. They see a Federal enterprise zone program not as a panacea but as a catalyst, or perhaps a nucleus to build around. 
 Enterprise zones are designated areas, usually in rundown city neighborhoods, that offer tax credits and other incentives to attract investment and jobs.
 
 
Need for Related Programs
 The Federal tax credits will not by themselves turn around inner cities, government officials and urban experts say. But by tying the zones into a host of other programs, from job training and increased police patrols to street improvements, experts predict that the zones might make an appreciable difference.
"If you look around the country, there are very few enterprise zones that have a sufficient package of incentives to have had a pronounced impact on local development," said Robert Mier, a University of Illinois planning professor who used to be Chicago's director of economic development. "What you need is a mixture of business commitment and government programs, and you're going to have to spend a lot of money to make it work."
Some urban experts say that judging from the mixed record of the enterprise zones in 36 states, it would be naive to think that such zones can rescue urban America. The more than 600 zones include a few successes, but most have made only a minor mark.
The Park Circle Enterprise Zone, for example, which sprouted in a once-desolate Baltimore neighborhood, now employs 1,400 workers. But teen-age unemployment among blacks in the area still hovers near 40 percent.
In Miami, the enterprise zone in Liberty City, a community where a three-day riot left 18 dead in 1980, has helped create a safer, palpably more prosperous area by using tax incentives to attract a supermarket, new private housing and several manufacturers.
But downtown Gary, Ind., remains a mosaic of empty lots and boarded-up storefronts. A six-year-old enterprise zone there has failed to attract nearly as many businesses or jobs as anticipated.
"If you have an enterprise zone that makes life better for businesses, then you can perhaps encourage a little job creation," said Christopher Walker, a researcher at the Urban Institute. "You have to have very modest expectations for programs like these. But if the option is doing nothing, then I say go ahead and do it."
 President Ronald Reagan pushed for enterprise zones in the early 1980's to bring jobs and hope to inner cities. But Congress has failed to agree with the Reagan or Bush Administrations on setting up such a program. States took it upon themselves to create their own zones, partly to qualify for Federal benefits that never came.
When the Los Angeles riots catapulted urban problems toward the top of the nation's agenda, enterprise zones suddenly received a warm bipartisan embrace in Washington.
With the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack F. Kemp, sponsoring the idea, Republicans have endorsed the zones as a supply-side formula for resuscitating urban America -- not through more Federal spending, but through beloved Republican tools like entrepreneurship and tax cuts. Democrats have signed on, believing the zones offer some hope at a time when the Administration will not spend billions of additional dollars on cities.
"It makes a lot of sense, given that economic development is one of the urgent and most fundamental needs of urban communities," said Billy Tidwell, director of research for the Urban League. "Enterprise zones are an idea whose time has come."
 
 
Bush Plan for 50 Zones
 The Bush Administration is backing a $1.9 billion program to set up 50 Federal zones over four years, 15 of them in rural areas. For businesses expanding or locating in zones, the Administration would eliminate capital gains taxes on the sale of investments made in the zones and held for at least two years.
It would also give tax deductions of up to $50,000 a year for people who buy stock in small companies in the zones. Workers earning up to $20,000 would receive a 5 percent employment tax credit for the first $10,500 of wages.
To supplement enterprise zones, the Administration has called for programs to weed out criminals from inner cities, reform welfare and improve job training.
"Federal enterprise-zone legislation should provide meaningful incentives that will build on the successes of the states, which have fewer incentives to offer," Mr. Kemp told Congress recently. He said eliminating capital gains taxes on inner-city investments in depressed areas would spur a new generation of entrepreneurs and "set in motion a process of self-improvement and job generation."
Despite their aversion to capital gains tax cuts, most Democrats accept the proposed cuts in the hope that they will spur inner-city investment. Still, many Democrats say enterprise zones fall far short of the multibillion-dollar Marshall Plan they say is needed to rescue America's cities.
 
Hope for Broad Legislation
 State officials hope the proposed Federal program, when combined with state programs, will greatly increase the flow of investment into distressed cities.
Enterprise zones have not "worked well because there aren't enough incentives from the city and the state," said Sidney Haifetz, president of the American Street Corridor Business Association, which runs an enterprise zone in Philadelphia. "There must be Federal enterprise-zone legislation for urban America to begin to turn around."
In early May, President Bush visited the American Street enterprise zone, which politicians say is one of the nation's most successful. But Mr. Haifetz says that despite the boosterism and political oratory about the zone, it has not accomplished much.
 
 
Less Than Appearances
 Mr. Haifetz, whose wholesale company sells kitchen and bathroom furnishings, said the zone had an attractive appearance because state and local money had spruced up the streets. But he said few new businesses have located there partly because Philadelphia has had to raise taxes because of the recession and Federal aid cutbacks. This makes Philadelphia less inviting to investors.
The zone "has changed a lot since it started, but the changes have not created a lot of jobs for the people," Mr. Haifetz said. Not only that, the area's crime rate remains high, many nearby homes are still abandoned, and the black unemployment rate in the area remains above 15 percent.
State officials say the nine-year-old zone has created or retained 2,200 jobs, but many experts say it is impossible to tell whether the jobs were created because of the zone's benefits or the nation's expanding economy.
Pennsylvania offers companies that expand or locate in its 45 zones credits on their corporate income taxes, depending on the size of their investments. Companies that hire one low-income person for each $15,000 in investment receive additional tax credits. To attract investors, Pennsylvania also offers money for job training and low-cost loans.
"There is a history of business disinvestment from the cities for a quarter-century," said David Messner, coordinator of Pennsylvania's enterprise zones. "Business won't invest in the cities just because we wish it to happen. You have to offer incentives."
 
Different Conclusions
 There is considerable debate in government and academia about whether enterprise zones actually encourage job creation. Mr. Kemp says zones have saved or created 180,000 jobs and spurred $9 billion in private investment. But when the General Accounting Office studied Maryland's zones, it found the job gains "could not be attributed to the enterprise-zone program."
In surveying 350 zones in 17 states, Rodney Erickson, a professor of business administration at Pennsylvania State University, found that 215 jobs were created each year, on average, in each zone. Concluding that zones bring jobs to the inner cities, his study found that this was 10 percent above the job growth in comparable areas outside zones.
"The real question is whether zones can generate the number of jobs on a broad enough basis to make a big impact in an inner-city area," Professor Erickson said. His study found that 90 percent of the new investments in zones had come from companies that were already there.
In another study, Marilyn Rubin, an economics professor at John Jay College in Manhattan, found that only 32 percent of businesses in New Jersey's enterprise zones said the benefits had been the primary or only reason for expanding or relocating there.
She said the most successful zones usually shared three factors: strong development potential, like a good local work force and solid buildings; strong cooperation between government and business, and the availability of programs that supplement tax credits, like low-interest loans or public money to improve streets and sewers.
 
From Brooklyn to Miami
 Critics often say enterprise zones merely woo jobs from other areas, rather than create new jobs. Kantor Brothers Neckwear, a tie maker that moved to a Miami zone from the impoverished East New York section of Brooklyn, is an example of how zones can rob jobs from Peter and give them to Paul.
"The work force in Brooklyn was atrocious," said Scott Kantor, the company's general manager. "We found that South Florida has a much better pool of workers." He said his company, which has 100 workers, moved to the zone in the Liberty City area of Miami because of the work force, not the zone's tax incentives. But, he added, "that extra little bonus helps."
Enterprise zones face other criticisms. Apparel manufacturers or grocery stores outside zones often complain that competitors inside zones have an unfair advantage. The sprawling zone in Louisville, Ky., is criticized because it includes not just a depressed inner-city area, but also more fortunate suburbs.
Otis Pitts, president of a neighborhood development agency in Miami, said, "Often, the skilled jobs go to people from outside the area."
 
Debate on Hiring Policies
 Some state officials say requiring companies to hire a certain percentage of zone residents will discourage many from locating in zones, because they do not want their hands tied about whom they hire.
Even if companies hire few zone residents, zone supporters say, they help the neighborhood when employees spend money in nearby restaurants or shops. Everyone agrees, however, that more money for job training would encourage the hiring of local residents.
Richard Cowden, executive director of the American Association of Enterprise Zones, argues that the benefits of zones far outweigh their shortcomings.
"If enterprise-zone incentives cause a company to make an investment in a distressed area instead of a prosperous area, that's good for the nation," he said. "Enterprise zones help rebuild a city's tax base and reduce unemployment and welfare. That's good public policy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Enterprise zones have not "worked well because there aren't enough incentives from the city and the state," said Sidney Haifetz, president of a group that runs an enterprise zone in Philadelphia. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Price of Success for a Top Hispanic Ad Agency

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
Growth came steadily over the last decade to Mendoza, Dillon & Asociados, the nation's largest Hispanic advertising agency. With the Spanish-speaking population in the United States expanding rapidly, companies like Johnson & Johnson, Ford, Sears, Levi Strauss and General Foods flocked to the agency and allocated small but increasing portions of their advertising budgets to peddling their products to the Hispanic market.
But now Mendoza, Dillon and other Hispanic agencies are confronting a problem born of their own success: There are no longer many new big clients out there that are not already advertising in Spanish. 
 "Ten years ago, most of our time was spent convincing companies of the Hispanic opportunity," said Robert Howells, the president of Mendoza, Dillon, which is owned by the WPP Group, the parent of J. Walter Thompson. "Now, a majority of our time is spent with existing clients, telling them they should consider spending more against the Hispanic market or adding new products. The growth is going to be different."
 
Difficult Strategy
 Squeezing more business out of existing clients, however, is a difficult strategy for any agency. Most consumer-products companies are still feeling the recession and are seeking ways to cut ad spending. And it is particularly difficult for Hispanic agencies, even the large ones like Mendoza, Dillon, because clients generally do not attach nearly as much importance to Spanish-language campaigns as they do to campaigns aimed at the general market.
As a result, the growth in Mendoza, Dillon's business, and in Hispanic advertising as a whole, has slowed to 5 to 10 percent a year over the last several years, putting the agency's billings today at more than $60 million, up from $48 million in 1990. For a decade after its founding in 1979, Mendoza, Dillon grew an average of 20 percent a year.
Still, slower growth is better than the little or no growth at many general-market agencies and some of the smaller Hispanic agencies.
 
Part of the Marketing Mix
 Despite the slowdown, Mendoza, Dillon and its biggest competitors -- including Casanova-Pendrill Publicidad of Irvine, Calif., Font & Vaamonde of New York, Conill Advertising of New York and Sosa, Bromley, Aguilar & Asociados of San Antonio -- have convinced most large consumer-products companies that Spanish-language advertising should be a part of the marketing mix.
"It's become a routine thing," said Roger Sennott, the general manager of Market Development Inc., a San Diego research firm. "There are a lot of long-term players who are very committed to the market, and for them it's an accepted part of the marketing effort."
Indeed, industry executives said, the prospects for the top-tier Hispanic agencies remain bright. In part, they said, that is because the Spanish-speaking population in the United States, already 10 percent of the total population and more than 20 percent in crucial markets like California, is growing faster than any other large ethnic group.
In addition, they said, the quality of Spanish-language advertising and marketing has improved, making it more appealing for companies.
 
Mendoza's Strategy
 The key to Mendoza, Dillon's success, Mr. Howells said, has been a strategy of persuading clients to start by advertising on a small scale and then showing them the results in the form of increased sales.
The agency's first big client was Tylenol, which is made by the McNeil Consumer Products division of Johnson & Johnson. The company gradually started to advertise more brands in Spanish. Today, Mendoza, Dillon handles advertising for four McNeil products and several other Johnson & Johnson brands, including Band-Aids.
In some cases, the advertising that Mendoza, Dillon produces mirrors the English-language campaigns. Commercials for Band-Aids, for example, even use the same jingle.
But for the most part, the agency's campaigns are tailored to the Spanish-speaking market. Reebok advertises its shoes to the general market primarily in terms of how they help athletic performance. For the Spanish-speaking market, the commercials developed by Mendoza, Dillon portray Reeboks as shoes to be worn during leisure time, reflecting the agency's research into why Hispanic consumers buy athletic shoes.
And the agency's commercials for Levi jeans are much slower-paced than the English-language campaign, and show many family scenes, reflecting the strong emphasis on family in the Hispanic culture.
In some ways, advertising to Hispanic consumers is easier than advertising to the general market because there are fewer Spanish-language campaigns vying for the audience's attention.
"You're often introducing a product to the market for the first time," Mr. Howells said. "If you have a good campaign, advertising will move the needle quickly, more quickly than in the general market because there's less clutter."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Booksellers Reassert Their Role in Publishing

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 24

 BODY:
Magic Johnson is here, and so is Judith Krantz and Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf and P. J. O'Rourke and Jimmy Carter and Stephen King. And the publishers who bring out books by these celebrities and celebrity authors are out here, too, throwing fancy parties and cocktail cruises and dinners.
But illustrious as they are, these stars are not the reason that nearly 2,000 publishers and even more staff members have come here. No, they have come because of John Valentine and Christy Meisner and Bob Bresee and Roz Parr and Fern Jaffe and Lew Rosenbaum.
Who? 
 These people are the link between the readers and the publishers' star authors (as well as lesser-known or yet-unknown authors). They are a handful of the thousands of bookstore owners, managers and sales people who have come to the annual American Booksellers Association convention to preview books that will be published this fall and next year.
 
'Partners to Publishers'
 "We're not just customers to publishers; we're partners to publishers," said Chuck Robinson, owner of Village Books in Bellingham, Wash., and the new president of the Booksellers Association. "If we sell books, they sell books."
Despite the recession, booksellers have been selling books and selling them well. Statistics from the Commerce Department show that booksellers increased their sales last year more than any other sector of the retail economy, bringing 8.25 percent growth. Commerce Department analysts say the upward trend for booksellers has continued this year.
The convention is a time to check out publishers' lists, a kind of literary equivalent of the fall fashion shows in Paris and Milan. This year, big biographies are in, as well as books about race relations. But it is also a time for booksellers to pick each other's brains and to compare notes.
The booksellers gathered here, particularly the owners and managers of independent stores, say this success is not accidental. They say it is even more impressive considering that it occurred as rents and other basic costs rose and heavy competition from the chain and super bookstores threatened smaller establishments.
 
Coping With the Economy
 While the chain stores, like Waldenbooks, B. Dalton and Barnes & Noble, have problems unique to the way they sell books, they also have the financial support of large corporations and tremendous influence with publishers, who need their vast outlets. But most of the booksellers here own or run independent stores, and they have had to find their own ways to cope with the current economy.
John Valentine, an owner of the Regulator Bookshop, an independent store in Durham, N.C., said he and his partner started two "aggressive marketing programs" this year to compete with the chain stores.
They began offering 20 percent discounts on the top 10 hardcover books on the New York Times best-seller list for fiction and the top 10 on the Times list for nonfiction.
They also started a lifetime discount club, in which customers can pay $15 for an individual or $20 per household and get 10 percent off on all books for the rest of their lives. In the club, households include gay couples, an important audience for a store that prides itself on its extensive selection of gay titles.
Sometimes, booksellers said, they compete by not competing. Donna Pohlman, who owns Much Ado About Books in Redlands, Calif., said that rather than imitate the chains, she decided to distinguish her store from them. "We handle a lot of midlist books; not so much the best sellers," she said. "And we do special orders that the chains just don't handle."
Many booksellers said they needed much more cooperation from publishers. Kathleen Murphy, the manager of the children's department at Page One, an independent bookstore in Albuquerque, N.M., said publishers would benefit if they abandoned their efforts to push too many books on reluctant booksellers.
"The hard sell ends up costing everyone money and time," Ms. Murphy said. "Publishers should spend more time learning who our customers are so they can help us to promote their books better."
 
Other Complaints
 Sandy Wilson, the owner of Bookstore in Elko, Nev., said she wanted publishers to send her the same publicity posters and displays that they send to bigger stores "who have more clout with the publishers."
Mr. Robinson said he frequently heard complaints from booksellers about the lack of standardization in the industry. He wondered why, for example, publishers could not use the same abbreviations for common words in book titles, like American or history or collection.
"There has just got to be a more efficient way for all of us to handle the bureaucracy," Mr. Robinson said. "If we spend less time on paperwork, we can spend more time selling books to people."

HEADLINE: Cheap Fuel Hurts Goal For Climate

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The scientists who will gather at the United Nations Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro next month say that action is needed now to limit global warming. Their science may be right, but their timing could not be worse.
Taking the most important step in slowing climate warming -- burning less fuel to cut heat-retaining carbon emissions into the atmosphere -- will be extremely difficult because fuel prices are now so low. 
 Ten years ago, planners were predicting oil at $75 or $100 a barrel in the 90's. Now, said Lee J. Schipper, senior scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory International Energy Studies Group, the price is so stable that "there's nothing to predict."
"It isn't interesting any more," he added.
 
Unexpected Stability
 The price of oil -- now around $20 a barrel -- has proved in the last 18 months to be more stable than almost anyone had believed; even a war in the Persian Gulf did not move it higher for long.
In addition, the price of coal is low and has remained stable, and the price of natural gas is declining in some areas, most notably in North America.
None of this makes it impossible to cut fuel use; it just means that science and the energy market are completely out of step. And unlike a decade ago, when the world believed oil should be conserved because the supply was running out, any action today to limit fuel use runs against the economics of cheap energy.
 
The White House's Mood
 Conservation also goes against the mood in the White House, which would have to lend its support for any global conservation action -- like a consumption tax -- to take hold.
The world is like a patient with a cholesterol problem. Tofu and sprouts are available, but steak and lobster are plentiful, too. Consider the following:
*The price of driving a car has never been lower, in inflation-adjusted terms. Partly as a result, the number of miles traveled each year on American roads has quadrupled in the last 40 years. The car population around the world is rising far faster than the human population.
*Nuclear power, a source of energy that produces nearly no carbon emissions, will probably lose share in the world electricity market in coming years because of public unease with the technology and the low prices of other fuels.
*Solar power and wind power are still under development, but the low price of oil has blunted the urgency of research.
*Technology has improved the efficiency of the oil companies so that it costs far less now to find a barrel of oil than it did a few years ago.
In fact, in the last 10 years, the amount of oil that has been found and is waiting to be pumped has doubled, to about one trillion barrels; natural gas projects are proliferating, and in most parts of the world engineers have long since given up looking for coal. With advancing technology, those fuels can now be substituted for each other to a growing degree.
 
Plentiful Supplies
 The result is that fossil fuels, the "nonrenewable" energy sources, are hard to run out of. The May 15 issue of Science carries an article by three researchers from the Electric Power Research Institute, a utility research consortium based in Palo Alto, Calif., that states flatly, "There is little likelihood that a serious scarcity of fuels will develop during the next century on a global scale."
The conclusion is startling because of the growth in demand. The researchers -- Chauncey Starr, who founded the institute and is an elder statesman of the electricity world; Milton F. Searl, and Sy Alport -- project that by 2060, global population will nearly double, and average output of goods and services per captia will increase 2.8 times. That means that economic activity will be more than five times as large as today.
In the same period, the researchers say, energy consumption will increase slightly more slowly because of increased efficiency, rising to 4.5 times the current level if there are no major gains in efficiency, and 2.5 times if there are.
That energy equation resembles the dismaying prospects laid out by Malthus that the population will grow faster than the food supply. In this case, energy efficiency increases arithmetically, but energy consumption increases geometrically.
And prices will not help slow the growth of consumption.
"The market is giving no assistance whatsoever," said Geoffrey M. Heal, an economist and specialist in energy and natural resources at the Columbia Business School. "For all of the basic energy sources, as a trend over the last 10 years, prices have fallen."
Statistics collected by Conoco Inc., the oil company subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, illustrate the problem. Through the 1960's, America's oil bill was about 2 percent of gross national product, hardly worth worrying about. It jumped to 4 percent with the oil price shock of 1973, and 9 percent with the price shock of 1979-80. Now it is back down to about 2 percent.
"The price of oil will not be one that makes the world want to develop with less oil," said John Sauer, Conoco's chief economist. And oil tends to drag the prices of other fuels up or down with it.
Carbon dioxide output need not rise in lockstep with energy use; some energy could come from non-carbon sources. But the two largest such sources today -- hydroelectricity and nuclear power -- are growing only slightly because of environmental problems and public opposition.
Other sources, like the direct conversion of sunlight to electricity, or generation of liquid fuels from crops or organic wastes, are not financially attractive on a large scale.
The Earth Summit goal for limiting carbon emissions -- freezing emissions at 1990 levels -- seems ambitious. But even that goal is modest relative to the problem. Carbon emissions in 1990 were far larger than the earth's biosphere could absorb, so if emissions were stabilized at that level, the amount of carbon in the atmosphere would continue to rise.
 
Room for Change
 The economics of natural resources could change again, of course. Professor Heal of Columbia points out that the warming of the earth is measured in decades, and some time in a decade or two, the world could want to cut fuel use to save costs.
But if carbon emissions must be cut, there is a reason to begin with carbon-emission taxes now, he said. "From a government-policy position, it may be easier to start a tradition of raising prices with carbon taxes at a time of low prices," he said.
But no industrial nation is likely to embark on this course alone, thus handing an economic advantage to its trading partners. And so far, the logic of instituting a tax now does not seem appealing in the United States.

HEADLINE: Labor's True-Blue-Collar Union

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Their 24th-floor headquarters here gives the leaders of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America a panoramic view, much like that enjoyed by the powerful chief executives, influential bankers and wealthy lawyers in nearby skyscrapers.
But the U.E., as the union is known, goes out of its way to make sure its top officers are not too tempted to identify with their neighbors in the skyline. The union's constitution limits executive salaries to $32,494, helping to make sure that the U.E.'s president, John H. Hovis Jr., its secretary-treasurer, Amy R. Newell, and its director of organization, Edmund L. Bruno, do not lose the perspective of the union's 40,000 members. 
 In an era when huge salary gaps between executives and employees are attracting Congressional attention and when leaders of many other labor unions have compensation packages topping $100,000 a year, the electrical workers' union salary limits and quirks like treating the head of organizing on a par with the president stand out like a Model T Ford at the Indy 500. But these are only part of a larger web of zealously guarded beliefs and policies, like opposition to such worker-management cooperation programs as quality circles, that sets the union apart from others.
 
Relics of Class Warfare?
 In the eyes of critics, the U.E. is a relic. But admirers see it as a model for reinvigorating the labor movement by hewing to the old-time principles under which workers fared a lot better than they do today.
"There's no one like them," said Harley Shaiken, a labor expert at the University of California at San Diego. "They combine militancy with a broader ideological spirit that reflects an earlier time."
As a result, the U.E.'s health may well be the purest indicator available of the staying power of the battered Marxist view: that workers form a class of citizens with shared interests separate from those who own and control business.
"We don't talk about what is happening to workers in terms of class warfare these days," Mr. Bruno said, "but it's hard to look at the last 20 years and describe it otherwise."
Some U.E. policies that are derived from the class-warfare ideology, like opposition to free-trade agreements, are widely shared by other unions and by scholars of the labor movement. But others, like the belief that a shorter workweek is the solution to saving jobs that would be lost to automation, are dismissed by most other labor leaders as unrealistic.
"If we got a short week, it would just send more jobs to Mexico or Taiwan," said William Bywater, president of the 150,000-member International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers. "They are living somewhat in the past."
The very existence of the I.U.E. shows how dearly the U.E. has sometimes paid for its fidelity to the social values of those who founded it in 1936. When critics began attacking the union as Communist-dominated as the Cold War gathered steam in the late 1940's, the I.U.E. was formed by dissidents who eventually forced the U.E. out of the Congress of Industrial Organizations. The U.E.'s membership plummeted from a peak of 600,000 in 1947 to just 90,000 by 1956, an exodus encouraged by executives in U.E.-organized companies like Westinghouse and General Electric.
The two electrical unions have worked closely in bargaining since 1969, and Mr. Bywater has proposed merging, but the rift remains deep.
The years of the U.E.'s membership decline have also seen the fall of union representation in the industrial work force in general, from about 35 percent to less than 12 percent. The U.E.'s organizing successes have come largely at small plastics plants, where Hispanic workers, women or other minorities make up most of the work force.
Often, the union's officials complain, plant owners refuse to bargain for months after the union has won a representation election, secure in the knowledge that there are few penalties for resistance. And the spreading practice of firing striking workers has also undermined union clout.
"The right to organize really exists only on paper," Mr. Hovis said.
Nevertheless, the union continues to spend heavily on organizing and trying new approaches. In a recent failed attempt to organize workers at G.E.'s plastics plant in Parkersburg, W.Va., the United Electrical Workers welcomed help from the International Union of Electrical Workers.
 
A Hard Line Toward Management
 Industrial companies remain the U.E.'s prime target, but the newest local was formed this spring by employees of Ohio's turnpike system. The union also has welcomed approaches over the years by employees of radio stations like WBAI in New York and WBCN in Boston, which became U.E. locals.
Trade unionism U.E. style includes fervent opposition to company-sponsored quality circles, worker-team concepts and other forms of cooperation now widely used in American factories to raise productivity. In one case in 1986, members at a United Electrical local in G.E.'s Erie, Pa., locomotive plant removed eight officers and stewards from office for traveling with G.E. officials at company expense to Japan to see quality-improvement programs in action.
"If we thought the Japanese had anything to teach us, we'd pay for sending our members ourselves," Adam Fiorvanti, the local's business agent, told a visitor several months later. G.E. officials decline to be quoted about their relations with the U.E. Some of them, however, privately express admiration for its adherence to principle.
As the U.E. sees it, programs like G.E.'s are part of a never-ending effort by executives to get workers to identify their long-term welfare with company goals and to push independent unions to the sidelines.
The views of the United Electrical Workers are shared by substantial minorities in other unions and even, in some cases, by leaders. "We haven't had any success trying to convince people not to participate in quality circles, so our policy has become to try to take them over and make them union instruments," said Bob Wages, president of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union.
Critics say that the rigid view of managers as "them" will only hurt the United Electrical Workers and that the U.E.'s meager salary structure is also obsolete.
"I don't think a worker wants to be represented by another poor person," said Gabe Villareal, a former U.E. field organizer who now is a personnel executive in Sanger, Calif., for the General Cable division of Penn Central. "They want someone who's a visible success, who looks like they have the resources to help."
Union officials say they still prefer the formula laid out decades ago by the charismatic James J. Matles, a former union president who declared that union leaders should be paid so that they feel "like the members and not for the members."
Mr. Hovis, a quiet-talking 48-year-old Seattle native, has been elected president annually since 1987. He joined the union as a field official in 1972 after working as a machinist.
Ms. Newell, a chain-smoking 44-year-old daughter of U.E. officials, is a native of Pittsburgh. She studied political theory at the London School of Economics and drifted through a variety of what she called drop-out jobs before plunging into an unsuccessful effort to organize assembly workers in Silicon Valley in the early 1970's. She became a field organizer in 1974 and was first elected secretary-treasurer in 1985.
Mr. Bruno, also 44, grew up in Athol, Mass., and was impressed by the U.E. in his high school years when it organized a machine tool plant in his town. He joined the U.E.'s organizing staff in Boston in 1973 after working in a lens factory in New Hampshire.
They spend a large part of their time traveling. It was a rare occasion when all three were recently in Pittsburgh together for an interview.
The U.E. officials and many labor scholars note that American executives repeatedly rejected efforts by unions in the 1930's and 1940's to reach some of the same power-sharing arrangements companies are now proposing, like reductions in military-type supervision by foremen.
"They want them now that labor is weak, but the parties have to be a equal strength for these things to really work," Mr. Bruno said.
Shop floor concerns aside, U.E. officials said they were heartened by the number of other unions now working with them and nonlabor groups in organizations like Jobs With Justice to pursue a broader social agenda.
"There's a lot of things percolating," Ms. Newell said.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Off 9.4% in April

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools fell 9.4 percent in April, compared with March, according to the latest monthly report by an industry trade association. The report, prepared for release today, indicated that demand from foreign buyers had sagged.
But orders rose from a year earlier, leading some analysts and industry executives to predict increased spending to modernize factories. Machine tools are used to cut and form metal parts for a huge number of goods, from household appliances to supersonic jetliners. Because the auto industry accounts for about a third of the machine tool makers' output, Detroit's slump has hurt those companies. 
 "We're seeing some signs of life in the machine tool industry," said Eli Lustgarten, an analyst at Paine Webber.
The trade group, the Association for Manufacturing Technology, said machine tool orders fell to $219.9 million in April, from $242.8 million in March. But orders rose 13.6 percent compared with April 1991.
Orders for the first four months of 1992 were 6.2 percent higher than in the comparable period a year earlier.
Several industry analysts cited those increases as evidence that demand was picking up and that manufacturers in a wide range of industries were beginning to spend more to upgrade their plants and equipment.
"We have seen better automotive business through most of this year," Mr. Lustgarten said, "and that's because it's becoming more of a priority for auto makers to upgrade and improve their operations."
Dale H. Norton, vice president for planning and business development for Giddings & Lewis Inc., a leading machine tool maker, said increased purchases in recent months indicated that the recession was ending.
"We are certainly hearing from our customers that there is more activity in terms of inquiries and their own plans to buy," Mr. Norton said. "We are getting indications that the corner has been turned, and we expect that it will be a better year, although we don't expect it to be an ebullient year."
But the decline in exports sharply affected orders, at least in April, the association said. "In the last year to year and a half, export orders have offset declines in domestic orders," said Albert W. Moore, president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va. "Now export orders are down, reflecting the economic distress our trade partners are experiencing."
Mr. Moore said he expected more competition in the United States machine tool market because of an erosion of demand in many countries. That erosion will cause foreign machine tool builders to "look to offset domestic declines with exports to the United States," he said.
 
Shipments Down Sharply
 Shipments of machine tools plunged 32.6 percent in April, compared with March. Compared with April of last year, shipments were down 6.8 percent; they were down 3.3 percent for the first four months of the year.
Orders for metal-cutting tools, which account for nearly three-fourths of the industry, were down 13.9 percent in April from March's level. But for the first four months of the year, orders for metal-cutting tools were up 8.8 percent from the similar period last year. And orders were 15.7 percent higher than in April of last year.
Orders for metal-forming tools were up 4.5 percent for the month and down four-tenths of a percent for the first four months. Orders for metal-forming tools were 8.5 percent higher than in April of last year.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Faces Pressure To Allow Use of Gasohol

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 22

 BODY:
Prodded by the grain-alcohol lobby, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency is considering whether to force New Jersey to permit the sale of an ethanol fuel mixture commonly called gasohol.
While the lobbyists say ethanol can reduce emissions of carbon monoxide from motor vehicles, New Jersey says it can increase other pollutants, including ground-level ozone, or smog. And that's just about the last thing New Jersey wants to do. The whole state is out of compliance with Federal standards for ozone, and 18 of the state's 21 counties have severe problems. Only Los Angeles is worse. 
 "The economic interests of the ethanol industry should not take precedence over the health and environmental interests of New Jersey citizens," said the state's environmental commissioner, Scott A. Weiner.
He said he was particularly concerned that the introduction of ethanol could negate the effects of a state program to promote car pooling. This program, which affects businesses with 100 or more employees, is among the steps mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency to help New Jersey reduce its ozone levels 42 percent by the year 2005 to comply with the Clean Air Act.
 
'Promote Its Own Interests'
 "The ethanol industry has sought to promote its own interests by keeping steady pressure on the E.P.A.," Mr. Weiner said. "Now they seek to undermine clean air" by rule making, he added.
In the last decade, interest in gasohol has grown with national concerns about air pollution from oil and other fossil fuels. Gasohol's proponents say the ethanol-gasoline mixture would help reduce dependence on foreign oil because ethanol is made from a renewable source: corn. Political leaders like Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, have thrown their weight behind the farmers, lobbying for an industry that accounts for about 5 percent of the 115 billion gallons of motor fuel sold annually.
Ethanol in gasoline produces more complete combustion and thereby reduces noxious emissions. But because ethanol is so volatile, it can increase vapors, particularly nitrogen oxide, emitted from gas tanks or from under car hoods. These unburned hydrocarbons react with sunlight, particularly in the summer, to create ozone, a major source of respiratory problems.
Ethanol may be used in the winter under New Jersey's air standards, because the sun's rays are not as strong and ozone formation is not as serious a problem, but it is barred in summer. As a result, the ethanol industry says it cannot make a dent in New Jersey or the rest of the Northeast because petroleum companies, many with large refineries or storage plants here, cannot accommodate seasonal sales of gasohol.
 
Lobby Seeks U.S. Pressure
 "When you talk to companies like Amerada Hess or Getty or Sun you find these companies will tell you, 'We have to plan our supply storage, terminaling and contracts on an annual basis, not four months in, four months out,' " said Eric Vaughn, president of the Renewable Fuels Association in Washington, the main industry lobby for ethanol.
At a hearing in Manhattan on May 5, the fuels association asked the E.P.A. to require New Jersey to change its summer standards for gasohol evaporation. A few years ago the E.P.A. said it would permit such changes largely as an accommodation to the ethanol industry, said Richard D. Wilson, director of the agency's Office of Mobile Sources, which conducted the hearing. "We were stuck with either giving them a break or putting them out of business," Mr. Wilson said.
He said he expected the E.P.A. to rule by midsummer on whether to force New Jersey to grant a waiver for ethanol.
New Jersey's allowable vapor pressure is 9 pounds per square inch; the grain-alcohol lobby wants a waiver to 10, the Federal standard.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Jersey;
A Signature Is Not a Vote, but on Perot Petitions, It Comes Close

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., May 23

 BODY:
After leaving the supermarket with some holiday groceries today, Leonard Orr and his daughter Danae stopped by the table where people were signing petitions to get Ross Perot, the billionaire Texan, on the presidential ballot in the New Jersey primary this November.
Mr. Orr, 50-year-old owner of a construction company, signed eagerly. 
 Miss Orr, 22, who just returned home with a degree in comparative literature from Wesleyan University, refused.
That stirred a father-daughter debate on the merits of Mr. Perot and his independent presidential campaign.
Miss Orr said Mr. Perot was "absolutely irresponsible" for not formally declaring his candidacy while his volunteers around the country were circulating petitions to have him put on the ballot in all 50 states.
"It's a way for him to avoid answering questions on national issues," she said.
Mr. Orr argued with his daughter's view. "That's an opinion from the intellect," he said. "Mine's from the emotion."
He said he was not troubled by what he saw as Mr. Perot's lack of positions on issues.
"I'm ready to vote for Perot," Mr. Orr said. "I don't know what he stands for. But I'm to the point he can't do any worse than what we've got now."
Mr. Orr said he was frustrated by the "standard party line we're getting from the Democrats and Republicans." An example, he said, was Vice President Quayle's use of the TV sitcom "Murphy Brown" the other night to criticize unwed motherhood.
"That was just a charade to steer us from confronting the real issues," he said. "Let's get back to boring issues, like health care."
Between 9 A.M. and 1 P.M., 70 other shoppers like Mr. Orr signed at the Perot table, one of 23 that Perot organizers said they planned to set up around Somerset County, long a Republican bastion in New Jersey, this holiday weekend.
Almost overnight, the Perot petition tables have popped up outside train stations, malls, libraries and supermarkets around the state. On May 12, volunteers submitted petitions with 2,947 signatures to New Jersey's Secretary of State, well above the 800 needed to earn a spot on New Jersey's ballot.
"There are 3,000 petitions still out there, and we have a goal of getting 50,000 to 100,000 signed up," said Stephen Maynard, the Perot organization's spokesman in New Jersey.
The table here this morning was not exactly overwhelmed with business. Most of the shoppers who packed the store's aisles just wheeled their baskets past the table.
Those who stopped to sign talked of frustration about taxes and the recession and of weariness with President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination. There was a yearning for a wider choice in November and for fresh faces and fresh approaches.
 
'Scary Time for the Country'
 "Nothing's working now; that's why the country's in the mess it's in," said June Sturges, who described herself as an avid Republican. "It's time for a change."
Like Mr. Orr, few seemed troubled that they did not know Mr. Perot's stands on the issues.
"I'm not sure what he would do and I'm not sure he'll have a power base," said Constance L. Hermes of Basking Ridge. "But it's a scary time for the country now. The other guys will have to prove why Perot shouldn't have my vote."
Michael Panesis, a 29-year-old management consultant, said: "The other candidates are just not up to being President, including the President."

HEADLINE: John Gates, 78, Former Editor Of The Daily Worker, Is Dead

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
John Gates, who quit as a top American Communist official and chief editor of The Daily Worker after losing a campaign to democratize the party and free it from Moscow's control, died on Saturday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and lived in North Miami Beach.
He died of heart disease and a stroke, his family said. 
 Mr. Gates broke from the party in 1958 after much soul-searching, which began while he served a five-year prison sentence. He and other party leaders were convicted of advocating the overthrow of the Government, which they denied.
After his release in 1955, new revelations came of the abuses of Stalinism. In 1956, Nikita Khrushchev denounced Stalin and the Soviets crushed the rebellion in Hungary.
"For the first time, I feel ashamed of the name Communist," Mr. Gates said. He led a faction in intense infighting to change the party, but lost.
 
A Parting Rebuke
 He quit with a rebuke. "The ideals that attracted me to socialism still motivate me," his resignation said, but "the Communist Party has ceased to be an effective force for democracy, peace and socialism."
After writing a book on his experience, he became a senior research assistant at the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. He helped members with workers' compensation, unemployment and Social Security claims. He retired in 1987.
He felt vindicated by the recent collapse of Communism and the Soviet Union, "but it was an unhappy vindication, because it took so long and so many people suffered," his wife, Lillian, said.
Mr. Gates remained concerned about the issues that led him to Communism: poverty, discrimination, homelessness, hunger and inadequate schools and health care. He said that capitalism placed profit above the public welfare and kept power in the hands of a few but he grew wary of ideological prescriptions.
"After being so certain and dogmatic," he wrote after quitting the party, "I do not profess to have all the answers."
Mr. Gates, born in Manhattan and reared there and in the Bronx, joined the Communists at the age of 17 as an outgrowth of a protest at City College. In the Depression of the early 1930's, he left his college studies to mobilize jobless youths in Ohio. He ran for the Youngstown City Council and was jailed on a charge of making a loud noise without a permit.
He fought in the Spanish Civil War, becoming the commissar of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade at the age of 24, the highest-ranking American in the war. In World War II, he enlisted in the United States Army and volunteered as a paratrooper in Europe.
Resuming his Communist work after the war, he became one of seven national secretaries and the editor of the Worker. Despite his conviction in the nation's first Communist trials, he always maintained his loyalty to America. He said he favored peaceful, democratic change to socialism, and opposed force, violence and espionage.
In prison, he later wrote, "We talked endlessly, of what we might have done better in the past, what we could do in the future." His discussions and introspection eventually led him to say: "Today, the Communist Party has become irrelevant."
Surviving are his wife of 47 years, the former Lillian Schwartz; a brother, Nat Regenstreif, of Hollywood, Fla., and three sisters, Blanche Smiles of the Bronx, Irene Travis of Charlotte, N.C., and Marlene Seml of Boca Raton, Fla.

 BODY:
An article in Business Day on Friday about new Federal rules setting limits on bank interest rates and brokered deposits misstated the amount of brokered deposits held at the end of the year by the First Union National Bank, of Charlotte, N.C. It was $319.3 million.

LENGTH: 412 words

HEADLINE: Agreed. Peru Needs Democracy.

 BODY:
Peru's strongman President, Alberto Fujimori, bristled with his usual truculence when he appeared unexpectedly last week at a meeting of the Organization of American States in the Bahamas. But he also announced an accelerated timetable for new elections. That, and the O.A.S.'s cautiously encouraging response, raise new hopes for resolving the crisis ignited by Mr. Fujimori's dismissal of Congress, the judiciary and constitutional rule last month.
Mr. Fujimori continues to offend democrats and insult diplomats with belligerent words and deeds. His latest proposal would create a presidential dictatorship seductively disguised as "direct democracy." His plan excludes Peru's strongly rooted political parties and offers no effective checks against executive power. 
 O.A.S. diplomats neither accepted nor rejected Mr. Fujimori's plan. Instead, they encouraged him to take further steps in the direction of the "formal democracy" he scorns. They cited restoration of representative democracy and "full respect for the principle of separation of powers and the rule of law" as essential preconditions for unfreezing "international assistance and support."
Mr. Fujimori's modest concessions testify to the success of the Bush Administration's campaign to coordinate international financial pressure. Spain, Germany and Britain, though regrettably not Japan, have supported the O.A.S. stand. International development banks have put key loans on hold.
Apologists for the Peruvian regime cite polls showing strong support for Mr. Fujimori's coup. But the same surveys show that Peruvians now expect their President to keep his promises to revive the economy, defeat the Shining Path guerrillas and restore democracy.
After seven weeks of unrestricted power, Mr. Fujimori has little to show. By alienating international lenders he has jeopardized prospects for economic revival. An unprovoked air force attack against a U.S. intelligence plane has set back plans for cooperation against drug traffickers. Army brutality in Lima's shanty towns may even be creating new guerrilla recruits.
Peru's problems won't be conjured away by strong-armed rule or political stunts. But broadening a political system dominated by the white minority and pruning bureaucracy would help. Real reforms would quickly win hemispheric support. But so long as Mr. Fujimori prefers gimmickry and bombast, democratic states need to sustain, even heighten, their pressure.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Letter: On Defense Spending;
A Budget for New World Realities

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I applaud "The War Democrats, 1992 Style," your editorial of May 13 on defense spending. Let me apprise The Times and its readers of an effort to achieve precisely the dramatic and justifiable reductions in military spending for which you call, an effort that was debated on the House floor for seven hours on March 5.
Recognizing that the cold war was over, the Warsaw Pact had disbanded and the former Soviet Union had significantly receded as a military threat, the Congressional Black Caucus, in alliance with the newly formed House Progressive Caucus, introduced "A Budget for New World Realities and for Rebuilding America." The proposal, lauded on both sides of the aisle for its technical excellence, rested on four cornerstones. 
 First, take down the artificial wall that Congress and the President erected between military and discretionary domestic spending, thereby allowing military budget savings to be shifted to meet urgent domestic needs. Second, reduce the defense budget authority by one-sixth, or $50 billion, in the first year, cancel many of the programs that The Times justifiably criticizes, and place the military budget on a glide path toward a 50 percent reduction within four years.
Third, embark upon an ambitious program of national renewal by allocating Federal resources for economic conversion planning, job training and veterans' adjustments, as well as by making the necessary investments in housing, transportation, education and health care that would both solve national problems and generate jobs and economic growth.
This proposal, supported by 77 Democratic members of the House, reflected a deep commitment to meet the total national security needs of our nation, needs that include a vibrant economy, housing, education and health care for our people, and a commitment to reach out to all of our citizens and insure that we fully include them in all our economic, social and political institutions.
 
RONALD V. DELLUMS
Member of Congress, 8th Dist., Calif.
Washington, May 15, 1992

HEADLINE: New York City Fighting to Keep 4 U.N. Agencies From Moving

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Four United Nations agencies are considering offers to move out of New York City later in the decade -- three of them to Germany -- and Mayor David N. Dinkins and his top economic aides have mounted a major counteroffensive to stem the loss of thousands of jobs and millions of dollars to the city's hard-pressed economy, officials in New York and Bonn said yesterday.
City officials said the departure of the agencies could mean the loss of 2,300 jobs, more than a third of the United Nations work force in New York, and up to $200 million in salaries, rents, supplies and other spending in New York -- a fifth of the $1 billion the United Nations contributes annually to the local economy. 
 Germany's offer to lure away three of the agencies represented a major effort to turn Bonn into an international hub of the post-cold-war world in a few years, when the capital of reunified Germany, with all its ministries and employees, is itself moved to Berlin. The offer also posed a daring challenge to New York as the world's pre-eminent international city.
"It is our position that the United Nations should stay united," Jennifer Kimball, a spokeswoman for Mayor Dinkins, said last night in confirming a report on the prospective moves that appears in today's edition of Crain's New York Business.
"We are taking these proposals very seriously," Ms. Kimball added. "We think that we will have success in persuading the United Nations agencies that New York is the premier world city, the international capital of business and finance and government and commerce, not to mention culture and art."
 
An Offer From New Rochelle
 One of the agencies, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, which has 950 employees and spends $10 million a year for rent alone in New York City, is considering an offer from the city of New Rochelle, in Westchester County, for space in a new 20-story office building for a rental of just $531,156 a year.
Crain's said that, in addition to the offer from New Rochelle, Unicef, which has its headquarters at 331 East 38th Street, was considering another site in Westchester and two others in Long Island City, Queens.
Founded in 1946, the agency assists developing countries to improve conditions for children, providing health, nutrition, and social welfare aid.
Ms. Kimball declined to give details of New York City's counteroffers, except to say that they were competitive.
Officials in Bonn said that the German government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl had offered three of the United Nations agencies -- the Development Program, the Fund for Population Activities and the Development Fund for Women -- rent-free accommodations in Bonn, $184 million in relocation costs and a substantial increase in Germany's voluntary contributions to the world organization.
City officials said the Development Program was the largest of the agencies, with 1,050 employees, while the Fund for Population Activities had 250 employees and the Development Fund for Women 30 employees. All three deal mainly with third world development.
To cushion the impact of the move on employees, the German government has also offered free German language lessons for those who make the move, officials in Germany said.
The reunification of Germany and the prospective move of the nation's capital to Berlin later in the decade would deprive Bonn of a large bureaucracy that has sustained the city throughout the postwar era.
 
Empty Buildings
 It would also leave Bonn with dozens of empty government buildings -- including a new Parliament, whose construction was begun before reunification vote last year -- and with thousands of empty homes and apartments now occupied by government officials and employees, not to mention the loss of business ranging from restaurant meals to office supplies.
To fill that void, the German government has mapped ambitious plans to develop Bonn as a center for international agencies, including United Nations and perhaps even European Community agencies. Mr. Kohl's government has already decided to leave the German Ministry for Development Aid, its foreign aid agency, in Bonn when the rest of the bureaucracy moves to Berlin.
The date of that move has not yet been determined, but the government has said it would probably be in time for Germany's 1998 Parliamentary elections.
Chancellor Kohl is believed to have made the German offer to the United Nations agencies on May 5, when he was in New York to speak at a convention of American newspaper publishers. Mr. Kohl is scheduled to be in New York again from June 6 to June 9 to meet with Jewish leaders and attend to other nonstate business.
 
The Argument to Stay
 Crain's said the three agencies considering Germany's offer now pay a total of $14 million a year in rent to landlords in New York.
Ms. Kimball said that Mr. Sullivan was "personally charged with overseeing the efforts to keep the United Nations agencies in New York City." Mr. Sullivan replaced Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez-Pinero, who became chairman of the city Housing Authority, and assumed office on May 1, shortly before City Hall learned the city was in danger of losing major agencies of the United Nations.
That the city suddenly finds itself in competition with a foreign government is "not really surprising," she said. "New York City regularly competes with London, Paris, Hamburg, Bonn and other cities because we are an international city," she said. "And because we are an international city, we like to think the nations of the world look to New York City first."
