HEADLINE: For Women, Varied Reasons for Single Motherhood

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, May 25

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle issued a blunt reminder last week that after 25 years of cultural warfare over the American family, single mothers were likely to remain a divisive topic because their lives illuminate unresolved differences between the races and the sexes.
In a speech on Tuesday, Mr. Quayle argued that the riots in Los Angeles were "directly related to the breakdown of family structure, personal responsibility and social order in too many areas of our society." 
 But his remarks will be best remembered for the connection he drew between poor, unmarried black mothers and Murphy Brown, an affluent, white television character who he said mocked "the importance of fathers by bearing a child alone and calling it just another 'life style choice.' "
Census Bureau statistics and studies by social scientists suggest that there are few generalizations to be made about single mothers except that their numbers have been increasing for 20 years, although at a slower rate recently.
 
Varied Needs, Varied Choices
 Interviews conducted around the country with single mothers of varying races and economic conditions suggested that the decision to bear a child involves a mixture of practical, emotional and spiritual considerations and is usually not a straightforward moral choice.
For Jean Pollard it was not a matter of choice at all.
"He wasn't a planned child," Ms. Pollard, 34 years old, said of her 3-month-old son who lives with her in a shelter for homeless families in Houston. She was laid off from work, she said, and then the child's father reneged on a promise to marry her.
"I wanted kids, but I always figured when I had a child I would be married, the typical American dream," she said. "Sometimes it doesn't work out like that."
Like many single mothers, Ms. Pollard acknowledges the value of marriage. But she went on, "Marriage doesn't guarantee anything anymore because it's not like it used to be with our parents."
For Debbie Spain, staying married was not an option.
A 32-year-old medical secretary in Boston, Ms. Spain was beaten by the father of her first child and ended a brief marriage to her second child's father, who was an alcoholic. "Just because you have someone's last name doesn't mean that's going to solve any problems," she said.
Both of her children remain in close contact with their fathers, but Ms. Spain finds they are happier now that she is raising them alone. "I just decided I'm going to do it right as much as I can," she said.
For Patty Friedmann, having a child was more important than having a husband.
Ms. Friedmann, a 45-year-old writer in New Orleans, deliberately became pregnant when she was single and 28 because she wanted a child. In an autobiographical novel published last year by Viking, "The Exact Image of Mother," Ms. Friedmann, who is now married, described how women can assert their identities by making such choices.
Of her protagonist, Ms. Friedmann wrote, "She is unfocused in life and in conflict with her mother, and her decision to have a child brings her strength and her resources together and defines her."
The many different reasons that women give for being single mothers suggest that their lives reflect a variety of trends in American life.
"You can't isolate single parenting by women as a discrete phenomenon," said Barrie Thorne, a professor of sociology at the University of Southern California. "You have to see it in the context of an overall change in attitudes towards many sexual and family issues including the status of women, divorce and premarital sex."
Census Bureau statistics show a period of turmoil in the American family beginning in the mid-1960's, although the rate of change in family composition slowed markedly in the 1980's. Married couples with children, for instance, made up 40 percent of all households in 1970 but only 26 percent last year.
Single parenthood by unwed mothers rose quickly, and is still increasing. The number of families headed by mothers who have never married increased at annual rate of nearly 15 percent in the 1970's. Although the rate dropped to just under 10 percent from 1980 to 1991, this now constitutes the fastest growing category of family groupings.
Single mothers now head a quarter of all families with children, counting those have never married along with women who are divorced, widowed or are living apart from a spouse for any other reason. (There are single fathers, too, of course, but they head fewer than 4 percent of all families.)
Experts say that although economic circumstances have changed since the 50's, the "Father Knows Best" family -- two parents with only the husband working -- that typified that decade still exerts a powerful pull on American values and emotions. Large majorities in opinion polls consistently say they are committed to conservative views of the family like those articulated by Mr. Quayle, and the vast majority of children continue to live in households with two parents.
But, said Arlene Skolnick, a research psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley, "People often care deeply in opposing directions, such as believing in the 1950's family but also accepting the value or the necessity of women working outside the home."
Aside from this complex cultural context, Professor Thorne said, "there are structural and circumstantial problems that go beyond individual choices that help explain why families headed by single parent mothers are not only the most rapidly growing type of household but also the type most associated with poverty."
Felicia Bryant, 19, of Chicago spoke of the devastating impact an unwanted pregnancy can have on a poor woman.
On learning she was pregnant, Ms. Bryant said: "I was upset and shocked. I wanted to commit suicide. I felt that I was too young to have a child." Then 15 years old, she dropped out of school and went on welfare.
Although Mr. Quayle asserted that "marriage is probably the best anti-poverty program of all," Ms. Bryant did not see it as an antidote.
"Many of the homeless are whole families -- men, women and children -- and they are still in poverty," she said. "A man can lose a job anytime. A man is not always the best means of support. A woman can be just as independent as a man."
 
An Old Phenomenon
 The birth of children outside marriage, especially among the poor, is neither particularly new nor peculiarly American. Historians and social scientists note that industrialization and urban growth often coincide with changes in family structure.
These situations have often produced criticism similar to Mr. Quayle's. Social critics in 19th century Britain, for example, spoke of "the undeserving poor" and argued that out-of-wedlock births were a result of immorality.
In America the issue is complicated by race. While single parenting by mothers has increased quickly among both whites and blacks, it is far more prevalent among blacks. In 1991, women headed 58 percent of all black families with children, as against 19 percent among whites.
And there are major differences between blacks and whites in the reasons women head families.
Among white mothers, the major reasons are divorce and separation, although the number who have never married has increased rapidly, from less than 3 percent of one-parent families in 1970 to 19 percent last year.
Among black mothers, divorce and separation also used to be the major causes for single parenthood, but no more. Last year 54 percent of one-parent black families were headed by women who had never married. This was up from just 15 percent in 1970, according to the Census Bureau.
"Poverty, unemployment, welfare programs that penalize families: these things explain a major portion of the variance between blacks and whites in the number of female headed households, but not all of it," said Bonnie Thornton Dill, a professor of women's studies at the University of Maryland in College Park.
One explanation may lie with changes in the nature of urban poverty that have led to an increasing number of people cut off from the education or employment that might allow them to improve their status or give them the impetus to marry.
"Teen-age pregnancy among blacks has not increased so much, but the rate of marriage among teen-agers has dropped and the number of children born to married couples has dropped," Professor Dill said. "These things are related to perceptions of opportunity."
Perceptions of another sort also emerged as a major theme in interviews with single mothers, who argued that although their households may not be considered conventional they are nonetheless real families.
Grace Cox, a 35-year-old typographer in Houston, has one child from an early marriage that ended in divorce and another born to her as a single mother.
"When you have kids by yourself, you have to work harder at making sure they have what they need and at keeping the family together," she said, adding, "This is a family too."
Like several other women, Fran Ramer, a 42-year-old Chicago businesswoman who is a single mother, said she was deeply committed to the family as a social ideal and saw herself adapting that ideal to reality.
She said, "I don't disagree with Quayle about family values, but I think he is a little behind the times about what a family is."

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: Departure Leaves Yale In Uncomfortable Spot

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 25

 BODY:
The surprising news from Benno C. Schmidt Jr. that he plans to leave the presidency of one of the oldest universities in the United States to become the president of an untested venture shocked the few people here who learned about it today. The action left Yale in the uncomfortable position of having three of its top officers step down just as the university undergoes some of the most drastic changes in the last 40 years.
Mr. Schmidt gave the news to the university's trustees this morning and scheduled a news conference for Tuesday to announce it publicly. 
 Mr. Schmidt's resignation, after six years as president of Yale, comes just one month after Donald Kagan, the dean of Yale College, announced his resignation, and two months after Frank M. Turner, provost of the university, said he would leave office at the end of this academic year.
During this morning's hourlong commencement ceremony, Mr. Schmidt did not mention his plan to leave Yale to head a Whittle Communications venture designed to create a national network of private schools. But in an interview later he said he believed that so many thorny issues had been resolved over the last few months that it was an ideal time for the university to begin the process of finding a successor and for him to accept an offer he had first declined a year ago.
 
Pointing Out Progress
 He pointed out that Yale had signed a new four-year contract with its clerical workers, entered a new agreement with the City of New Haven to make payments in lieu of taxes, raised almost 40 percent of the $1.5 billion goal of its new capital campaign, begun crucial repairs to many old buildings and made significant progress in dealing its budget deficit.
"With all that its seemed it was responsible for me to be able to contemplate the possibility of leaving," he said.
But students and faculty members, engaged in confrontations with Mr. Schmidt over the budget problems all year, might not agree that things have gone so smoothly. Just after a ceremony in which he received his Ph.D. in philosophy, Christopher A. Dustin, of Worcester, Mass., said that in the decade he had been at Yale, the university had "become a more economically driven place."
He added, "It's a lot less happy here, less humanistic, and I trace a great deal of that back to this administration."
In spite of what has been a bumpy year for Mr. Schmidt and for Yale, there had been little speculation that Mr. Schmidt would step down.
"At this point in our history, part of what a university president does is he gets criticized," said Calvin M. Trillin, the writer, who is a member of the Yale Corporation, Yale's version of a board of trustees.
Several other corporation members said they were shocked when, at a breakfast meeting at his campus home this morning, Mr. Schmidt stood up, clinked a glass with his knife and said he had an important announcement.
"There were a lot of open mouths around the room," said Sid R. Bass of Fort Worth, a trustee since 1982. Only one member of the corporation, Vernon R. Loucks, Jr., who acts as chairman of the group, knew of Mr. Schmidts plans; he was told 10 days ago.
Kurt L. Schmoke, the Mayor of Baltimore, who is also a member of the Yale Corporation, said that Mr. Schmidt had the support of all the trustees and that there had been no attempt to force him out because of the university's financial troubles.
"All I can tell you is how much we are going to miss this man and his leadership," Mr. Schmoke said.
While no formal plans were worked out at this morning's trustee meeting, Mr. Schmidt said he would stay on until Yale had selected an acting president, an appointment that is expected to be made before the new school year begins in September. The trustees will also have to form a search committee to find a permanent successor, who would probably take over some time before the 1993-1994 academic year.
Mr. Schmidt's years as president of Yale covered an unusually turbulent period in the university's long history, a time not of political turmoil but of coming to terms with the institution's financial limits.
As president for six years, he served a far shorter time than many Ivy League presidents, like Derek Bok, president of Harvard University for 20 years. But Mr. Schmidt said he should be judged not just by time but by the intensity of the issues he had to deal with in that time.
"They say to judge a hockey player not by his age but by his mileage," Mr. Schmidt said. "I've actually traveled more miles, dealt with more problems, raised more money and faced up to more difficulties than most presidents."
 
Embodying a New Ideal
 When he took over Yale in September, 1986 Mr. Schmidt seemed to embody the new ideal of an Ivy League president. He was a lawyer, the former dean of Columbia University's law school and an expert on the First Amendment. He was 44 years old and Yale trustees hoped he would stay in office for a long, stable period.
His tenure never went long without some controversy. Early on, he overhauled the School of Organization and Management, opposing members of its faculty and students who thought he had overstepped his authority.
Mr. Schmidt also was Yale's first commuter president, living part of the time in New York with his wife, Helen Whitney, whose career as a documentary film maker was based there. In his first few years, Yale rang with the mocking taunt, "Where's Benno?"
The most explosive conflicts came this past year, as overall budget problems overlapped with union negotiations and soul-searching about the university's limits.
To get more people involved in determining Yale's future, Mr. Schmidt established a committee to set budget priorities. But when the committee's recommendations included eliminating, merging or diminishing six academic departments and sharply cutting faculty, many were incensed.
 
Support From Alumni
 The response to Yale's belt-tightening efforts was not all negative. Alumni gave donations in record amounts, and despite the mistrust that arose on campus, Mr. Schmidt was held in high regard by his colleagues at other universities, who believed they would have to face the same issues.
"He showed the courage to come to grips with budget problems and deal with them forthrightly," said James O. Freedman, the president of Dartmouth College. Mr. Freedman, in New Haven because his daughter Deborah was graduating from Yale's Law School, said he was surprised to hear that Mr. Schmidt had resigned.
One of Mr. Schmidt's most daunting obstacles when he took over Yale was succeeding A. Bartlett Giamatti, a very popular president, who also left Yale for an unusual position, the presidency of baseball's National League.
Mr. Giamatti once joked that he would be known in history as "Bart the Refurbisher," because he had focused attention on Yale's deteriorating physical condition.
Rocking in a wicker-backed chair in his office today, Mr. Schmidt said that his own sobriquet could be "Benno the Builder," but then he recanted.
"One of the canards I had to try to live down around here is that I care more about buildings than people," he said. "That's not the case at all."

HEADLINE: Haitians Expected to Snub U.S. Rules

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 25

 BODY:
While the Administration and advocates for refugees wait to gauge the effectiveness of the latest American efforts to slow the exodus from Haiti, both groups agreed today that few Haitians would use asylum review offices being set up here to replace overcrowded offices at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba.
For American diplomats and other officials, the Administration decision on Sunday to intercept refugees and return them to Haiti, where claims for asylum will be reviewed, amounts to calling the bluff of the Haitians who have been clambering aboard small boats in unprecedented numbers in recent weeks in the hope of reaching the United States. 
 The advocates for refugees, who have fought the Administration bitterly at almost every step of the crisis, say the new measures will have only a marginal effect on the number of Haitians who flee their country.
Would-be refugees will now have only one choice, presenting themselves to diplomats here in Haiti who both know the country and can verify their reasons for seeking refugee status. Until now, those who arrived at Guantanamo told their stories to immigration officers there who were unfamiliar with Haiti, officials said.
 
Claims Called Nonsensical
 "I am not convinced, based on the 2,300 returned boat people we've interviewed so far, that many people will be interested in applying for asylum here," an American diplomat said. "Among those interviews, we could not find a single serious claim for political asylum. The vast majority of these claims are nonsensical, and most of the Haitians themselves know this. That is why they are getting into boats instead of coming here to the embassy."
Since the violent overthrow of Haiti's first democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, last September Haitians have fled for the United States, which recognizies only political, not economic, factors in granting refugee status.
American officials said that for several weeks they had been spreading word of an office recently established here to handle asylum requests, but had got little response from Haitians.
Asked how poor Haitians in outlying areas could be expected to contact such an office, one official said: "They don't have to actually come here. They can write."
For Haitian immigration advocates and human rights experts, arguments like these represent a travesty of what they say are the United States' moral obligations toward a people mired in a situation of recurring violence and increasingly harsh economic conditions, due in good measure to a hemisphere-wide embargo imposed on Haiti last fall to punish the authors of the military coup against Father Aristide.
 
A 'Very Narrow' Offer
 "What they are offering to do for people at the embassy is very narrow," said Jocelyn McCalla, director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees in New York. "They are basically saying they are open to giving asylum to members of political parties, officials in the Aristide Government and well-known intellectuals. I can't imagine a peasant in the central plateau whose house was burned down by a section chief writing to the embassy to ask for asylum, much less receiving it."
Section chiefs are members of a rural police force who exercise an almost feudal control over peasant life in many areas in Haiti. Human rights advocates accuse them of being behind many recent rural abuses.
William O'Neill, deputy director of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, who recently completed a fact-finding mission to Haiti, said that even those who show up at the embassy to apply for asylum risk being given short shrift.
"We talked to three people who seemed to have very solid claims who went through this process," Mr. O'Neill said. "All three said they were intimidated. They said it felt like an interrogation as they were being questioned by two teams of three agents, who they said they felt were trying to trip them up. Afterward, these people, two of whom were very close to Aristide, were rejected by form letter. They said they felt they had been used for their information."
A United States Embassy official said of such assertions, "We are not ogres, and I am not going to bother trying to defend ourselves against those claims."
Joining the chorus of criticism today was Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who called the Administration's policy toward the refugees hypocritical after the long American practice of giving sanctuary to Vietnamese boat people.
"This is a presumptive violation of international law," said Mr. Solarz, who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific. "We must be the shame of the entire world. I can't believe it."
United States officials expressed hope that the tide of Haitian boat people would now soon abate.
"You've got to hope it slows things down," said Larry Meisel, a Coast Guard official who oversaw the arrival of the 72d American cutter to come here with a shipload of returned Haitians since the emigration wave began last October. "With this new policy, we could start returning people every day, depending on what the traffic is."
An embassy official said of the expected Haitian response to the new policy, "If getting picked up gives you virtually no chance of getting into the United States, then they are eventually going to catch on and stop."
For weeks, United States officials have complained that the relatively large numbers of refugees who had been allowed into the United States from Guantanamo -- approximately one-third -- had begun acting as a powerful magnet tempting others to flee.
In a seeming confirmation of this view, Willy Celestin, a 20-year-old returned refugee, asked why he left his country, sheepishly told a reporter on the docks this morning: "Everybody is trying their luck. I thought I'd try my luck too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Waiting behind the barbed wire fence of the Guantanamo Bay base in Cuba, two Haitian children are among a group that wiil get a chance to appeal for asylum in the United States. The Bush Administration has also set up asylum review offices in Haiti as an alternative to the dangerous sea voyage. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Are Lower; Dollar Is Flat

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower in Tokyo today after sharp gains yesterday, when stocks elsewhere in Asia and in Europe rose and the dollar ended little changed in thin trading.
The Nikkei index of 225 Japanese issues ended down 350.36 points, or 1.89 percent, to 18,204.64. Yesterday, the index gained 334 points, or 1.83 percent. Volume came to about 180 million shares yesterday, the lowest since March 31. 
 Worldwide financial trading was generally thin yesterday, with financial markets closed in Britain because of a bank holiday and in the United States because of Memorial Day.
Gold ended yesterday at $338.35 an ounce in Zurich, up 30 cents from Friday.
The dollar in Europe finished at 1.6160 German marks, down from 1.6180 on Friday, and at 129.33 Japanese yen, down from 129.40.
Currency dealers said market activity was restricted to the adjustment of positions, with few European operators willing to make big moves before seeing what the trend in New York and London would be when trading resumes today.
Some dealers said dollar activity would probably be light for most of this week because trading would be interrupted again on Thursday because of the Ascension Day holiday in much of Europe.
In stock trading yesterday, the French CAC-40 share index was up 1.13 points, at 2,046.25.
In Germany, the 30-share DAX index, which ended at a 21-month high on Friday, added 8.61, to 1,811.57, its highest close since Aug. 3, 1990.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was aided by an unexpected interest rate cut on Friday and a flood of money from overseas, particularly from Thailand. The index jumped 133.43 points, or 2.28 percent, to close at a record 5,993.11.
In Manila, Philippine shares closed at a record high on surging confidence that Fidel Ramos, the former military chief, would win the presidential elections.
The Manila Stock Exchange composite index settled at 1,432.84, up 53.15 points, or 3.8 percent.

The Economy
The Government plans to announce that foods developed through biotechnology are not inherently dangerous and, except in rare cases, should not require extraordinary testing and regulation before going on the market. The long-awaited new policy holds that genetically engineered foods should be regulated just like ordinary ones, unless they have been endowed with ingredients that are not usual for the product. [Page A1.]

International
Companies seeking to win over Poland's consumers face land mines. After being deprived of many goods for a generation, and inculcated to dismiss as propaganda almost any message on television or in newspapers, Poles are suspicious of advertising and wary of some products. Indeed, one researcher found that the best label for detergent was written in Polish, but with small grammatical errors that indicated foreigners cared enough to learn the language but were not smart enough to master it. [A1.]
The Thai Army's attack on protesters not only filled Bangkok's hospitals but emptied its hotels and cast a shadow over one of the world's most vibrant economies. Yet in some ways, what is most striking about the mood is the cautious optimism. [D1.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Recovery Oratory Is Recycled

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A year ago, as the nation returned to work from the Memorial Day weekend, officials in the Bush Administration and at the Federal Reserve, as well as a significant number of private economists, were trumpeting the end of recession and predicting steadily improving growth through the summer. Twelve months later, the oratory sounds remarkably the same.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said last week, for instance, that the White House would soon raise the growth forecast of 2.2 percent it made in January. Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, predicted that growth into 1993 would be around 3 percent. And through a leak to The Wall Street Journal last week, the Fed informed credit market participants that it felt further easing of monetary policy was not necessary for a moderate recovery. 
 Not everyone, though, is so sanguine. "The talk and some of the data look a lot like they did at the beginning of last summer, and that is one thing that worries us," said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting and consulting company in Lexington, Mass.
 
No Relapse Is Seen
 Still, Mr. Wyss and other analysts who voiced doubts in the summer of 1991 about the rebound say conditions have changed enough in a year to make it unlikely that the economy will lapse back into a recession.
"Compared with a year ago, I feel pretty confident recovery is here," said Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisers Inc. "But I don't think this will be anything more than a soft upturn."
A significant restructuring of corporate and household balance sheets, made possible by a steady slide in interest rates, is seen by analysts as the best insurance against another loss of momentum.
"Over the last year there has been a tremendous reduction of indebtedness -- on the order of $85 billion to $95 billion at an annual rate," said Roger M. Kubarych, a manager at Henry Kaufman & Company, a New York money management firm.
And Mr. Sinai observed: "Healthier financial positions of businesses and households are an absolutely essential part of any recovery. And they were absent last year."
 
'Banks Are in a Better Position'
 Debt reduction, in turn, has taken some pressure off the financial system.
"Banks are in a better position to withstand credit losses that are still coming at them," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "That is a plus. So, too, is the fact that there is more widespread recognition that balance-sheet and credit problems have been a bigger part" of the economy's malaise.
Despite some disturbing weakness in April housing data, and signs that consumer spending patterns are cooling a bit, analysts say the improvement in the economy is a bit more broad based now than it was a year ago.
Output in the second and third quarter last year "was heavily reliant on rising auto production," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. Currently, "production is taking place away from the auto sector."
"We are not talking about strength," Mr. Fine said. "We are talking about improvement. But signs of turning back down again are not there."
 
Consumers Not Very Confident
 After reciting the differences, the analysts noted that many characteristics that haunted the economy remained unchanged. Confidence has improved from earlier in the year, but is far from what is normally viewed as a healthy level.
Consumers continue to forgo spending much money on expensive items. Car sales, for example, have been stuck for 16 months in a narrow, low range of 5.6 million to 6.6 million units at an annual rate. Despite a rebound in housing, the construction industry remains in bad shape. Fiscal policy at the Federal and state levels remains restrictive. And employment, while slightly higher for a few months, is not showing the kind of growth normally associated with recovery.
 
Nettlesome Holdovers
 "Many, many corporations are still thinking of their roster of employees as a cost center rather than a productivity center," Mr. Soss said. "It seems to me that employment gains will be small."
Bond yields, which remain stubbornly high despite an improving inflation picture, are another nettlesome holdover from a year ago. If they stay relatively high, the recovery could be jeopardized.
"At this point there is no need for policy actions to lower short-term rates," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "But there is a need for market rates to reflect the fact that inflation is down. If we are to remain on a positive growth path, long-term rates have to continue to decline."

METRO DIGEST
 
MIGRANT POOR LINE UP FOR WORK
Across the New York metropolitan region, urban migrant workers -- most of them immigrants, nearly all of them desperate -- line up for hours each day, waiting for trucks or vans to pick them up for unskilled and bottom-dollar employment in construction, demolition, moving, landscaping, anything. No one is certain how many people are struggling to get by this way. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
SPOTTING THE BULGE OF A CONCEALED WEAPON
In 18 years on the New York City police force, until his resignation in 1986, Robert T. Gallagher became renowned in police circles for an uncanny ability to spot people carrying guns on the street. In an often harrowing record his superior officer describes as unbelievable, Mr. Gallagher disarmed more than 1,200 gun-toting thugs. B3.
 
A CONVENTION IN SEARCH OF A THEME
Three little words that television viewers watching the Democratic National Convention in July will not see behind Gov. Bill Clinton when the delegates' votes have been counted -- assuming, as the staff planning the convention does, that he wins the nomination -- are "we the people." The backdrop behind the podium, which is perhaps the most valuable square footage inside Madison Square Garden for capturing television viewers' attention, is being changed. To what, the Democrats have not decided. Reporter's Notebook, B3.
 
A 9-YEAR-OLD GUNSHOT VICTIM DIES
A 9-year-old boy who was shot while playing video games on his bed died on Sunday evening, two days after unknown assailants fired four bullets through the door of the family's apartment in Brooklyn, the police said. B3.
 
REGION
 
REBUILDING NEIGHBORHOODS TORN BY STRIFE
In the fresh surge of attention to the plight of inner-city businesses, Katie Selikoff may have clues to how the government can help. It was on the blocks surrounding Mrs. Selikoff's small furniture store that the Newark riots of 1967 and 1969 left an inner city in ruin. Now, as a survivor of those tumultuous days, she is also a beneficiary of the Urban Enterprise Zone Program, which the state set up to help businesses prosper in the most distressed neighborhoods. B4.
 
THE SOAP-BOX DERBY COMES TO TOWN
It started with the bang of a gun and a simple snap of a metal bar. LENGTH: 809 words

HEADLINE: With the Income Tax Achieved, a Legislator Leaves Hartford

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Even as Irving J. Stolberg prepares to return to private life at a time of intense anti-tax sentiment, the longtime income-tax advocate, one of Connecticut's most powerful politicians in the 1980's, remains an unabashed liberal and defender of public service.
"Others are packing it in because of the low pay and the aggravation," said Mr. Stolberg, referring to the rash of politicians in Connecticut and throughout the country who have opted not to seek re-election this year. But that is not his cause for announcing that he will not run for his 12th term as a state House member. 
 "In the last 22 years," he said, "I have accomplished most of my goals, especially now with an income tax in place for the 21st century in Connecticut."
Mr. Stolberg, 55, a New Haven Democrat and former geography professor, was state House Majority Leader for two two-year terms and ruled the 151-member General Assembly forcefully, leading some colleagues to call him "the emperor." Never one to shy from political battles or play down his accomplishments, he enhanced his reputation with flowery speeches and rulings.
In announcing his retirement, Mr. Stolberg pointedly differentiated himself from other legislators who are trying to avoid responsibility for last year's decision to enact Connecticut's first income tax.
 
Convincing His Constituents
 "The income tax has been my primary plank for 11 elections," he said. "When I came into office, most of my constituents were opposed to an income tax. But my polls show that I have convinced a majority that I was not using the income tax to increase taxes, but rather to raise revenues more equitably and efficiently than with sales or business taxes."
Arguing that sales taxes impose a disproportionate burden on low- and middle-income families and that business taxes hurt the state's economy, Mr. Stolberg's message has been that "a balanced tax structure should be an equal mix of sales tax, property tax and income tax."
Tom Scott, Connecticut's leading income-tax opponent, does not agree and has said that Mr. Stolberg was a principal target of his Connecticut Taxpayers' Victory Committee, which is raising money for 70 anti-tax candidates. Mr. Scott, who is running against Representative Rosa L. DeLauro for Congress, has taken credit for forcing Mr. Stolberg to bow out.
Mr. Stolberg is among several income-tax supporters in the Assembly -- including House Speaker Richard J. Balducci and the current Majority Leader, Robert F. Frankel -- who were the object of threats after the tax was approved last year, other legislators say. All three have announced that they will not seek re-election.
 
A Reduction in Debt Service
 But Mr. Stolberg emphatically denied that his retirement had been hastened by Mr. Scott. "Anyone with any sense in Connecticut knows that what Scott says about me is a joke," he said. "He's the only hatemonger I've encountered in Connecticut politics."
Mr. Stolberg said that he understood voters' frustrations and conceded, "There is legitimacy to the anti-tax sentiment because of legislators' pork-barrel projects."
Nonetheless, using his own career as a model, he challenged the notion that liberalism could automatically be equated with spendthrift big government.
"We reduced the state's debt service from 15 percent to 10.5 percent in four years," he said, referring to his tenure as chairman of the assembly's finance committee between 1979 and 1983. "I was more fiscally responsible than all these loud-mouthed conservatives who preach one thing and bring pork barrel back to their districts."
 
A 60's Recruit to Politics
 Mr. Stolberg, who was born in Philadelphia and grew up in Los Angeles, taught geography at Southern Connecticut State University and worked for several foreign-exchange programs before beginning his political career as a delegate for Eugene McCarthy in his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1968. Two years later, Mr. Stolberg was elected in what is now Connecticut's 93d Assembly District by five votes.
During his years in office, Mr. Stolberg introduced or supported legislation to convert defense industries to nondefense production, to increase housing and welfare benefits and to bolster services for the elderly and Vietnam veterans.
In 1989, after his second term as House Speaker, Mr. Stolberg was ousted by a coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats in favor of Mr. Balducci.
"He led the Legislature forcefully, but that forcefulness also turned out to be his downfall," said Representative Jonathan Pelto of Mansfield, an assistant majority leader under Mr. Stolberg.
But Mr. Pelto added: "Stolberg set out to do two things -- to professionalize the Legislature, getting it on an equal footing with the executive branch, and get an income tax -- and he's done both."

HEADLINE: Newark Offers a Model For Saving the Cities

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 22

 BODY:
In the fresh surge of attention to the plight of inner-city businesses, Katie Selikoff may have clues to how the government can help.
It was here on the blocks surrounding Mrs. Selikoff's small furniture store that the Newark riots of 1967 and 1969 left an inner city in ruin. Her building was nearly destroyed by fire, and several merchants across the street were firebombed into extinction. 
 Now, as a survivor, she is also a beneficiary of the Urban Enterprise Zone Program, which the state set up to help businesses prosper in the most distressed neighborhoods. Since the program was created in 1985, Mrs. Selikoff has received a wish list of tax breaks and financial help.
"I am not walking away," said Mrs. Selikoff, a native of Budapest whose parents founded Clinton & Bergen Home Furnishings in 1958. Her sales staff still includes her mother, her daughter and her best friend from childhood.
 
Good for Customers, Too
 But some things have changed. There are the large yellow-and-red signs over her door, paid for by the state. A smaller sign in the window announces a bigger boost to business: Customers need pay only half of New Jersey's 7 percent sales tax.
"The zone program has made a difference in Newark," Mrs. Selikoff said.
It has also attracted a surge of interest from Washington: In the month since the Los Angeles riots, President Bush has said repeatedly that he would seek approval of a similar Federal program. Details have not been spelled out, but Mr. Bush said he favored creating zones in 50 cities or poor rural areas.
While any Federal program would contain different incentives than those offered here, there may be no better example of the costs and benefits than the zones in Newark and 10 other New Jersey cities.
 
Setting an Example
 "New Jersey is representative of the nation," said Marilyn Marks Rubins, a professor of public administration at the City University of New York. "Now, with national attention riveted on the problems of the inner city, Newark provides a model."
In a report last week, the state Department of Commerce and Economic Development said more than 20,000 jobs had been created in its enterprise zones since 1985. The Newark zone, it said, has attracted more than $800 million in private investment and created 3,000 jobs.
Still, experts say critical questions remain unanswered, questions that also apply to a Federal program.
One is whether government, by drawing lines on a map to define its incentives, puts businesses just outside the zones at a disadvantage, forcing them to close or move. And no one can be sure how many of the businesses in a zone really need help.
"The net result of some zone programs could simply be lost revenue that is given away in tax breaks," said James Hughes, professor of urban planning at Rutgers University.
 
How the Program Works
 In Newark, the enterprise zone covers seven square miles, about 30 percent of the city. State officials said 329 businesses are in the program, including retailers, small manufacturers and service companies.
To qualify, a business must be in an enterprise zone, and at least 25 percent of its employees must live in the zone or have been unemployed for a year before they were hired.
For businesses that qualify, the tax breaks include the elimination of the sales taxes they pay on goods and services. State corporate taxes are reduced for each new employee who lives in the zone. And in six of the New Jersey zones, including the one in Newark, retailers are allowed to charge their customers only half of the New Jersey sales tax, which the Legislature has recently voted to reduce to 6 percent, from 7 percent.
"In and of themselves, the incentives are not the solution to our problem," said Raphael Zabala, administrator of the Newark zone. Indeed, many businesses received other breaks, including the opportunity to buy abandoned city-owned land and preferential treatment in applying for grants and loans from the state.
This has produced incentives suitable for some business people but not all. In interviews here, several merchants and entrepreneurs said grants and low-interest loans had been the most valuable, enabling them to rehabilitate derelict property or expand despite the recession and tight bank lending policies.
At Clinton & Bergen Home Furnishings, Mrs. Selikoff said she had received $30,000 in grants to fix up her store, but only after filing detailed applications and agreeing to be monitored by state officials. Her money was spent on new signs and repairs to her store and an adjacent warehouse, which were damaged in the riots and fires of 1960's.
 
Not a Cure-All
 "The zone approach is correct," said Cornell L. Adams, a chemist and owner of Accurate Set Inc., a small manufacturer of resins, coating and other products used by dentists. He purchased an abandoned city-owned building in the Central Ward in 1980, before the area was an enterprise zone, but has received low-interest loans and tax credits as a participant since 1985. The company employs 14 people.
"When you help business, business creates jobs," said Mr. Adams.
Still, some of his problems are beyond the scope of the program. The recession has cut deeply into his sales, for example, forcing him to lay off five workers.
And after he had purchased an abandoned building on his block for expansion, taking advantage of tax breaks to renovate it, a potential partner backed out. The problem, Mr. Adams said, was that the partner's wife, fearing crime and urban blight, refused to move to Newark.
 
Programs in 37 States
 New Jersey is far from alone among states with enterprise zones. Since the mid-1980's, 37 states have initiated programs, but they vary widely in the incentives and in the kinds of zones they try to help.
While Michigan has only one zone, Louisiana has 750. Several states have designated entire counties; others have limited them to single streets or blocks.
Connecticut has 11 zones. New York has designated 19, in communities ranging from the East New York section of Brooklyn to upstate Elmira, in a program that began in 1986. A commission appointed by Gov.Mario M. Cuomo recommended in December that eight more zones be selected.
Proposals for a Federal program have been languishing for years, despite support from Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. President Bush said as early as 1987 that he supported enterprise zones, but his endorsement this month was his strongest so far.
Any Federal incentives are likely to be in addition to state incentives, at least in some of the most troubled slums. One central element of the Federal proposal is the elimination of capital-gains taxes for businesses that invest in enterprise zones, effectively eliminating the taxes on properties sold at a profit.
But some business people in Newark say capital-gains taxes are the least of their worries. "The concern here is survival," said Mr. Adams, of Accurate Set. "We can talk about capital gains later, but for now that isn't going to help us one iota."

HEADLINE: The Burden of Debt -- A special report.;
Why Economists Fear the Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Spending more than $4 for every $3 collected, the United States Government is hemorrhaging red ink at a record pace this year -- about $1 billion a day, or $11,574 a second. By late summer, Federal debt, the accumulation of every deficit the Government has incurred over two centuries, will surpass $4 trillion.
All the personal Federal income tax paid by people living west of the Mississippi fails to pay even the interest on this staggering sum, which has quadrupled in scarcely more than a decade. Interest payments on the debt are 15 percent of the Federal budget, compared with only 10 percent a decade ago. And for the first time, the Government has not even set a target for halting the debt's growth. 
 In the past the national debt was rationalized away as money "we owe ourselves" and regarded as a necessary tool in managing the money supply. Indeed, Alexander Hamilton, the first Treasury Secretary, contended that the national debt was necessary to induce the rich to take an interest in the Government's policies because they would hold its securities. But the debt has grown to such size that most economists contend that it undermines American prosperity.
In the short term, they say, it has almost certainly contributed to the latest, not yet officially ended, recession. In the longer term, it puts at risk the nation's status as a top economic power.
By absorbing a huge share of the nation's savings, the Federal deficit has helped cripple the investment in new plants and machinery vital to economic growth. As the most creditworthy of all borrowers -- though some now find this designation a bit hollow -- the Government always gets what it needs, leaving others, if necessary, to be denied. The Government borrows by regularly putting Treasury securities up for auction.
"Because investment affects productivity growth and, hence, standards of living, the United States is inadvertently choosing a less competitive and less prosperous economy than it needs to," says Richard D. Rippe, a former economics professor who is chief economist for Prudential Securities Inc.
By increasing competition among borrowers, the debt also pushes up interest rates. And that feeds the apparent increase in the disparity of American incomes. Heavy borrowing "tends to benefit the holders of assets at the expense of other taxpayers," said William A. Cox, a senior specialist for the Congressional Research Service.
Few economists regard the debt buildup as having reached crisis proportions -- at least not the kind of crisis that might bring runaway inflation or economic collapse. Most describe it as termites eating slowly, not always invisibly, at the foundations of a house, or they liken it to a cancer that is not yet life threatening.
Yet the creeping pace of the erosion is itself a source of worry, because it can be difficult to persuade the electorate to support painful remedies in the absence of crisis.
"Sooner or later, the piper will have to be paid," said William Frenzel, a former Republican Congressman from Minnesota who served on the unproductive National Economic Commission, a bipartisan body created to study debt reduction during 1988.
There would be less of a problem, of course, if the Government's rising debt was matched by rising assets. But while some money the Government borrows is invested in physical or human capital, the bulk of it is not. It goes for a host of things, from military salaries to farm subsidies, that do nothing to make the economy more productive.
"We are clearly borrowing for consumption, and we can't keep on doing this," said Barry K. Rogstad, president of the American Business Conference, an association of rapidly growing midsized companies.
Until recently, flush foreign investors were eager buyers of Treasury securities. But with the collapse of the stock market in Japan, the rebuilding of eastern Germany and the relative paucity of surplus oil money in the war-torn Middle East, foreign investors can no longer be counted on to make up for the lack of domestic savings.
People who say the system may at last be receptive to changes point to stirrings on the campaign trail, in Congress and among business leaders.
"If you want to continue being leaders in the world, start by getting some of that debt off your backs," Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, told graduates of Johns Hopkins University last week. "Debtors can't be leaders. It's the guy holding the I.O.U.'s who calls the shots; the other guy is called a hostage."
And some analysts say the appeal of Ross Perot, who is considering an independent run for the Presidency, derives in part from concern he expresses about fiscal excesses and the spending of "our children's" money.
Meanwhile, a balanced-budget amendment is suddenly gaining widespread support in Congress -- although even its backers note that current lawmakers would get a cheap vote, permitting them to boast of their fiscal rectitude but leaving the hard task of cutting spending and raising taxes to the lawmakers who will be in office years from now.
 
The Effects
Diverting Savings, Stifling Growth
 The extent of the harm cannot be precisely determined, but most economists agree with Mr. Rippe that the economy is being damaged as some $200 billion a year is diverted from the nation's savings in order to pay interest to those who hold Treasury securities.
The savings rate in 1990 and 1991 was only one-third the rates of the 1960's and 1970's.
"We used to think the long-term growth rate was 3 percent," said William H. Branson, a professor of economics at Princeton University. "Now, an optimistic growth rate is 2 percent." The difference, he said, is the drag from debt.
The new Japanese Ambassador to Washington, Takakazu Kuriyama, said, "This is an issue that has to be dealt with somehow, if the American economy is to regain its strength."
For years, Japanese investors heavily underwrote United States debt. They now hold 2 to 3 percent of the total but are no longer able to afford to buy in such quantity. On balance, the Japanese actually sold Treasury securities in 1990 and bought relatively little last year.
To be sure, this year's record projected deficit is swollen by the recession and its aftermath, which has raised unemployment benefits and other outlays while curbing tax revenue. The deficit is also enlarged by the billions still being spent to discharge the Government's obligations to depositors of failed banks and savings and loans.
But most analysts who take the long view find little comfort in these special factors. They point instead to the ever-rising debt load -- the deficit is now 7 percent of national output after falling as low as 3 percent in the 1980's -- and to the grim budgetary demographics implicit in the eventual retirement of the baby-boom generation.
"It is a trend that is very serious, especially debt as a percentage of gross domestic product," said Carol Cox Wait, a former aide to the Senate Budget Committee who is now president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a bipartisan body financed mainly by corporations. "Each year we have to cut programs or raise taxes just to pay interest on the debt."
Some economists are embarrassed that the world's richest country has racked up a deficit every year since 1969, a fact leading to a certain incredulity among German policy makers when the Bush Administration criticized them recently for excessive deficits. Indeed, the White House and Congress, in a budget deal in 1990, abandoned as excessively inconvenient the deficit ceilings imposed under the 1986 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law; the annual growth in the debt is once again theoretically limitless.
 
The Extent
By Any Measure, A Staggering Load
 Early this month the Government sold bonds due in the year 2021 that required coupons of 8 percent. A decade ago, when inflation and interest rates were at stratospheric levels, it had to pay as much as 15.75 percent to sell long-term bonds.
"God help us if interest rates turn around and go up again," Ms. Wait said.
As a share of gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services on American territory -- the debt is indeed rising rapidly. After climbing above 100 percent at the end of World War II, the Government worked down publicly held debt to 50 percent by the late 1950's and to just under 25 percent by 1974.
Since then, however, this share has more than doubled to an estimated 52.5 percent this year. The Congressional Budget Office projects it to climb above 55 percent in 1994 and then to surge again around the turn of the century to reach 59.1 percent in 2002.
Some analysts, notably Alan C. Lerner, a senior economist for the Bankers Trust Company, assert that it is more relevant to compare the deficit with personal savings than with national output.
That calculation is even more sobering. Mr. Lerner found this ratio to have averaged 38 percent in the 1970's, 117 percent in the 1980's, 160 percent last year and likely to approach 200 percent in 1992. In other words, the Government needs each year to borrow more money than American households save.
In all, Federal debt is expected to total $4.1 trillion when the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30. Publicly held debt is projected at $3.1 trillion. The trillion-dollar difference represents government securities held by Social Security and other Government accounts.
In many eyes, the situation is worse. Even these staggering figures do not count trillions of dollars of contingent, or latent, debt arising from Federal guarantees for activities like student loans, rural electrification and corporate pensions. In 1990, these guarantees amounted to $5.8 trillion, although claims for anything approaching this maximum are highly unlikely.
In addition, direct debts of Government-sponsored enterprises like the Federal National Mortgage Association exceed $1 trillion, having jumped at a compound annual rate of 19.6 percent since 1970, said James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a newsletter. These bodies are not formally backed by the Government but are thought to carry an implicit Federal guarantee against possible default.
Yet some analysts, including Robert Eisner, a Northwestern University economist, say the picture is not so bleak. They note that Federal accounting, unlike that of corporate America, makes no distinction between outlays for consumption and outlays that would more properly be considered investments, like highways and other infrastructure.
Others go still further in their attack on the conceptual underpinnings of deficit and debt -- and they do not see the silver lining that Professor Eisner has glimpsed. An emerging group, which reflects the fears of the baby-boom generation, regards all the traditional calculations as largely meaningless.
They say a more accurate guide would be to calculate how much tax, minus benefits, governments at all levels will take from each generation. Such generational accounting shows that when obligations to future beneficiaries are added to the money due current bondholders, the size of future claims on the Treasury is downright harrowing.
The use of the various deficit numbers has repeatedly led Washington astray, says Laurence J. Kotlikoff, a professor of economics at Boston University. "We have repeatedly misjudged the true stance of economic policy," he said, "and have chosen policies that compound, rather than solve, our critical economic problems."
 
The Remedies
Forcing the Public To Face Hard Facts
 There is little disagreement that the United States consumes so much and invests so little that it is jeopardizing its future. Even where current investment appears adequate, economists say, fresh capital is necessary to exploit the technological advances that raise productivity and insure competitiveness.
"To the extent you can't borrow abroad, it comes out of the real capital stock," said Rudolph G. Penner, a former head of the Congressional Budget Office who is now director of economic studies for the accounting firm KPMG/Peat Marwick. "The cumulative damage to the American economy," he said, "will compound and will become very serious indeed" by the late 1990's as investment needs go unmet.
In the short term, high deficits tend to rob the Government of flexibility in dealing with recession, denying it the stimulative spending tool that traditionally has been available to counteract cyclical downturns. In the longer term, some specialists worry, heavy indebtedness could tempt the Government to take an expedient course and inflate away the problem.
The concern is that the Government would simply increase the money supply to make paying interest and retiring principal as painless as politically necessary. Some analysts say the relatively high rates on long-term bonds, which dampen investment, already reflect the markets' anticipation of some degree of accelerated inflation.
The only sound way to reduce the debt's drag on the nation's living standards, many economists and budget analysts agree, is to find a way to arrest Federal spending, probably combining this with some tax increases. Many of them point first to the cost of medical care, which now takes almost 15 percent of the nation's output.
"Soaring health costs are gobbling up both the peace dividend and the demographic dividend," Mr. Penner said, foreseeing "a nightmare" in about 2010 when today's huge group of baby boomers begin to retire and switch from productive workers supporting the elderly to retirees requiring increased medical attention themselves.
As for taxes, economists generally tend to favor taxes placed on consumption, thereby reaching the heart of the nation's economic problem. Though such taxes may unduly burden the poor, it is possible to ameliorate this effect, proponents say.
Because of the huge commitments to future generations and the shifting of liabilities onto their shoulders, the nation will need political leaders who can persuade today's voters to stop asking Government for more than they are willing to pay for through current taxes. As the system now stands, Professor Kotlikoff says, today's 33-year-old male will during his life pay governments at all levels $194,500 more in taxes than he receives in benefits
Although there was much talk of spending cuts in the Reagan era, many of them were not in fact reductions but only the elimination of increases that would otherwise have taken effect. In cases where the cuts were real, even severe, they came in only a small segment of the budget and therefore produced political howls but little of fiscal consequence.
What is now needed, said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, is an adjustment of such magnitude "that it's going to have to include a very broad and balanced package of spending cuts and revenue increases."
Otherwise, he warned, "We can continue on the road we are on for a good deal of time -- and have an economy that slips out of world-class status."

HEADLINE: Not Just to Repair Houses, But to Rebuild Community

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the urban disorders of the 1960's, Franklin A. Thomas grappled with racial animosities and economic decay in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
And after watching television coverage of the recent violence in Los Angeles, Mr. Thomas, who is now president of the Ford Foundation, recalled in an interview the tension-filled days in the Brooklyn neighborhood where he had grown up. 
 He also recalled New York's two Senators, Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits, leading a bipartisan drive in Congress and recruiting business leaders in a determined effort that led to the creation of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, the country's oldest community development organization.
Mr. Thomas, then the New York City Police Department's only black deputy commissioner, resigned to lead the experimental venture in urban renewal. He remained there for 10 years, until he joined the Ford Foundation. Ford was already deeply engaged in helping poor communities -- it has given $15.8 million to support the Brooklyn enterprise and millions more to help start other community organizations elsewhere.
 
The Federal Role
 "The weak partner in community revitalization in the last decade has been the Federal Government, which has retreated from participation," Mr. Thomas said. "The events in Los Angeles tell us we cannot continue to fail investing in our neighborhoods and our people. We are spending the capital we invested years ago, and that capital needs to be renewed."
As planners attack the needs of Los Angeles and other cities, Mr. Thomas urged that they listen to residents and involve them in the regeneration of their communities -- another lesson learned in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where he was raised the youngest of six children.
The 2,000 community development organizations that have sprung up across the nation since the Bedford-Stuyvesant effort have discovered local leadership, built or renovated housing, created social services for neighborhoods and encouraged local businesses, he said.
 
'Beyond Repairing Houses'
 "I would argue development goes beyond repairing houses," he said. "It should consider how sites are acquired and who does the acquisition and financing, or the rehabilitation and the design, who supplies the builders and how housing units are leased or sold, and who owns and supplies the local businesses.
"I would argue community development is emerging as a major revolution in the country, one that engages people in ways that affect their lives and their localities. It may not be glamorous, but it should stimulate an excitement in all of us regardless of our politics or background."
Mr. Thomas said he found startling parallels watching the riot scenes in Los Angeles and, minutes later, the televised violence of Serbs and Croatians shooting at each other.
"You cannot build walls high enough or strong enough to protect yourself and property in a society when a substantial number of people are led to believe they are not valued or not expected to participate," he said. "If, by some miracle, you could build walls to keep out such people, you would not like the life inside or outside."

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Blue Cross Breaks Its Business Cycle

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
APPARENTLY breaking a longstanding insurance cycle of three good years followed by three bad years, the nation's 73 Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations reported a combined surplus of $357 million for the three months ended March 31. Blue Cross executives say the good news should continue at least long enough to make 1992 the fourth year in a row with a sizable surplus.
Health insurance experts say the surprising extension of the string of surpluses may reflect smarter moves by managers and a trend toward less risk taking. But they caution that the picture is complicated. "Even if the first-quarter numbers were good, it is just one quarter," said Harvey Sobel, an actuary and principal in New York with the William M. Mercer consulting firm. 
 In past cycles, the insurers thrived when they raised their rates fast enough to keep ahead of rising hospital and doctor fees. After a few good years, however, there would be a slowdown in rate increases as the commercial insurance companies and Blue Cross plans jockeyed for market share. Then, with costs still rising, losses would inevitably follow, until the insurers again raised their rates and the cycle turned.
Fred Cue, a senior vice president in Chicago with the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said the combined surplus last year was $1.6 billion on $67 billion in sales. The gain peaked at $1.87 billion on $62.6 billion in sales in 1990, after a $1.16 billion 1989 gain on $56 billion in sales.
In the preceding years of the down cycle the loss had been $3 billion.
Mr. Cue said a shift to managed care -- health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, and discount deals with hospitals and doctors -- might have slowed the increases in costs, making it easier to adjust rates in time. About 30 percent of the nation's 67 million Blue Cross enrollees are in managed-care plans, compared with only 10 percent a few years ago.
Moreover, all health insurers are taking fewer risks, as growing numbers of employers self-insure and hire insurance experts just to supervise and handle the paperwork. The slowdown in the economy and in inflation generally may also be making it easier for the insurers to deal with medical cost increases.
Many commercial insurers have retreated from health insurance, which may also have reduced the pressure to cut prices. Allstate sold its business to Metropolitan Life, and Equitable sold its Equicor joint venture to Cigna. Meanwhile, Aetna, John Hancock, Lincoln National, Provident and Kemper also have pulled back in varying degrees.
"Everybody agrees that the cycle is late" in turning, said John T. Porter, a vice president in New York with the Towers Perrin benefit-consulting firm. But he notes that there have been variations in the past and that the results are not the same for every state. "The cycle is not a myth," he added. "It is also not a fact of nature."
Indeed, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York, the country's largest Blue Cross plan, "never followed the national cycle," said Jerry Weissman, Empire's chief financial officer. "We started the down cycle in 1991," he said, with a $150 million loss on $6.7 billion of revenues last year.
This was followed by a $62 million loss in the first quarter of this year, reducing reserves to $83 million, barely above the state's requirement of 1 percent of revenues. The New York Insurance Commissioner, Salvatore R. Curiale, approved a 14.2 percent rate increase, starting April 1, which should ease Empire's losses over the rest of the year, Mr. Weissman said.
"A lot depends on the legislation that passed the Assembly on March 30," he added. The state Senate has not yet taken up the bill, vigorously opposed by commercial insurers. The measure would require commercial insurers to accept all applicants, as Empire does, and would bar the charging of higher rates to individuals and groups that are regarded as high risks.
The New Jersey Legislature is considering a similar proposal backed by Gov. Jim Florio and some state employers. New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield came back from the brink of bankruptcy last year, reporting a $3 million gain on $2.45 billion of revenues. But it still must eliminate a $44 million deficit in reserves.
Fred Hillman, a Blue Cross spokesman in Newark, said enrollment had declined 46 percent since 1988, to 2.3 million, and the association has dismissed 450 employees. Nationally, Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans have lost nine million members, a 12 percent decline since 1989; much of the membership loss was in the economically distressed Northeast.
Mr. Cue said there had been improvement in troubled Blue Cross plans in New England and Maryland. Empire Blue Cross, along with Blue Shield of Western New York, a small plan in Buffalo, are the main remaining trouble spots. "We've had some pleasant surprises," he added. But he said a downturn still seemed probable next year, which would eat into $10 billion in combined reserves accumulated during the good years.
