HEADLINE: Physicists Step Up Exotic Search for the Universe's Missing Mass

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
THE strangeness of the universe obliges astrophysicists to heed the White Queen's words to Alice that she practiced believing six impossible things before breakfast. Without this kind of logical leap, they find they cannot begin to embark on answering one of the most challenging and fundamental questions in science today: what is most of the universe made of?
All the visible stars and galaxies, scientists now believe, account for less than 1 percent of the mass of the universe. The rest, then, must be some kind of invisible, or dark, matter that has so far eluded detection by the best instruments of astronomy or particle physics. 
 But the nature of this invisible mass has yet to be determined. Some of it may be very dim stars or those intense vortexes of gravity known as black holes. Most of it, though, is thought to be some form of exotic subatomic particles pervading the universe, such as fast, massive neutrinos or hypothesized slow-moving particles known as cold dark matter. All in all, it is a perplexing mystery, seemingly bordering on fantasy, that would tax even the White Queen's imagination.
Finding the stuff of this hidden mass could alter theories of particle physics and would be a major step in understanding the structure and evolution of the universe. It might also enable cosmologists to predict whether the universe is destined to continue expanding forever or eventually to collapse of its own gravity.
If dark matter does exist, and most of it turns out to be unlike the ordinary atoms of stars and people, the philosophical implications would be profound and humbling.
Pondering this prospect, Dr. Bernard Sadoulet, a physicist at the University of California at Berkeley and a leader of the search for dark matter, said: "It will be the ultimate Copernican revolution. Not only are we not at the center of the universe as we know it, but we aren't even made up of the same stuff as most of the universe. We are just this small excess, an insignificant phenomenon, and the universe is something completely different."
Scientists are redoubling their search for the hidden mass, inspired by the recent discovery by an American satellite, the Cosmic Background Explorer, or COBE. Its instruments detected slight fluctuations in the density of the residual radiation from the Big Bang, the explosive event thought to have been the start of everything.
These "ripples" in the otherwise smooth early universe are seen as regions with slightly greater mass and thus with a stronger than average gravitational field to draw in more and more matter. From these ripples eventually grew the stars and galaxies in today's universe.
Astrophysicists generally agree with Dr. George F. Smoot of the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, leader of the COBE research team, that the findings help explain how an initially smooth universe evolved its present large-scale structure, and also lend strong support to the idea that most of the universe's mass consists of the invisible dark matter.
"COBE tells us, yes, we do see fluctuations that can make the large-scale structure we see today, provided we have something else, namely dark matter," Dr. Sadoulet said.
The reason is that ordinary matter, known collectively as baryons, would not have coalesced quickly enough around the embryonic fluctuations, said Dr. Alan H. Guth, an astrophysicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Ordinary matter would not have immediately been attracted to the weak gravity of the primordial ripples; certain kinds of dark matter could have been.
 
Earlier Hints of Invisible Matter
 "Even before COBE there were strong suggestions that it would be impossible to build a universe made only out of baryons," Dr. Guth said. "COBE helps nail down that conclusion."
The first intimation that there might be more to the universe than accounted for in previous theory came in the 1930's. Dr. Fritz Zwicky, an astrophysicist at the California Institute of Technology, observed some galaxies traveling at unexpectedly high speeds in a cluster of other galaxies. Since the observable mass in the cluster was not sufficient to provide the gravity needed to pull galaxies at such speeds, he decided there must be a great halo of invisible mass surrounding the cluster.
Nothing much came of Dr. Zwicky's idea until the last 15 years. More observations of the speeds, rotations and shapes of galaxies made it increasingly clear to astronomers that there must be some extra, unseen mass in the universe.
But what did the extra mass consist of? The first suspect was the neutrino. These light subatomic particles are known to exist in abundance, which is more than can be said for nearly all other dark-matter candidates. In theory, they should also have been created in great number at the beginning of the universe.
Recent experiments by American and Russian scientists suggest that one type of neutrino apparently does have some mass. Even if its mass is no more than one ten-thousandth of an electron, scientists say, it is possible to conceive of neutrinos accounting for nearly all the dark matter in the universe.
Although neutrinos still have their partisans, astrophysicists point out a problem. Neutrinos are "hot," meaning they travel at velocities close to the speed of light. Such light, swift particles would presumably have careered away from the dense ripples, instead of falling in to form clumps and the makings of galaxies.
So scientists turned to thoughts of cold, or slow-moving, dark matter. In the early 1980's, particle physicists had already hypothesized the existence of exotic slow-moving subatomic particles with such names as axions and WIMP's, for weakly interacting massive particles.
Astrophysicists elaborated concepts of how cold, dark matter explained the universe's large structure and also conformed with the new modification of the Big Bang theory, the inflation model postulating a brief, rapid expansion of the universe immediately after the explosive creation. This anomalous expansion could have exaggerated tiny variations in density, creating the imprint of ripples.
Dr. Joel Primack, an astrophysicist at the University of California at Santa Cruz who was an early proponent of this concept, said the combination of inflation theory and cold dark matter yielded "a beautiful theory of galaxy and galaxy cluster formation that correctly predicts many of these structure's properties and their masses."
In the months before the COBE results were announced in April, however, the cold dark matter theory was beset by growing skepticism. Astronomers were reporting "great walls" of galactic clusters too large, it seemed, to have been formed by cold dark matter in the allotted time. It took the discovery of the density ripples to revive the theory.
At the Center for Particle Astrophysics at the University of California in Berkeley, astronomers, physicists and theorists have embarked on a wide-ranging search for dark matter, cold, hot or whatever.
"Now, with COBE, our work is more urgent than ever," said Dr. Sadoulet, director of the center. "But it's always been urgent, I suppose, when you don't know what at least 90 percent of the universe is."
On one front, the center is in a race with half a dozen other institutions to confirm the COBE results and look for density ripples even smaller than the satellite could detect. Further examination of the fluctuations should show whether the dark matter is more likely to be hot or cold, or possibly something else.
A research team at the center plans to loft an especially sensitive telescope with a high-altitude balloon this fall, searching for more detailed evidence of density fluctuations in the early universe. Previous flights failed to detect anything, but Dr. Mark Devlin, a physicist, said, "I think we will see something this time."
Similar balloon surveys are being directed by M.I.T. scientists. Dr. Philip Lubin of the University of California at Santa Barbara has looked for small-scale ripples using radio telescopes at the South Pole, where the dry air makes for especially clear viewing. Astronomers at Jodrell Bank Radio Observatory in England are optimistic that their ground-based instruments with improved sensitivity will soon be able to provide new details of the early universe's texture.
The center is developing a new generation of instruments for the direct detection of the hypothesized WIMP's. Such particles, if they exist, are by their nature difficult to detect. They do not interact strongly with other particles and so emit no radiation of any kind. They are not subject to the strong nuclear force that governs the behavior of ordinary matter.
But WIMP's should be everywhere, billions of the feeble particles passing through a human body each day, though only a few interacting with atoms in the body. Scientists assume that these rare collisions, if registered in solid materials, should produce detectable reactions. Several experiments have been done with detectors placed deep underground, away from interference from most ordinary cosmic radiation, to record any electric charges or weak flashes of light released by cold dark matter colliding with atoms in semiconductors like silicon or germanium.
 
Search for WIMP's
 The approach being taken in designing new detectors is to capitalize on the fact that cold dark matter striking the nucleus of ordinary matter in a crystal lattice will produce a kick, enough to give off vibrations or phonons. These are detectable as slight temperature changes, if the instrument is chilled to temperatures close to absolute zero. The Berkeley center is testing such super-cold instruments for a WIMP hunt.
Another possible form of dark matter, the hypothetical axions, are still a contender. These particles are believed to be even lighter than WIMP's, perhaps only one-trillionth the mass of an electron. A team of scientists from Berkeley, Livermore, the University of Florida, M.I.T. and the Russian Academy of Sciences is developing an experiment to tune in on axions that presumably permeate the environment. In their laboratory, superconducting magnets would magnify the strength of axion signals as they are stimulated into microwave signals for analysis.
Like so many others trying to identify dark matter, Dr. Karl Van Bibber of Lawrence Livermore Laboratory and Dr. Chris Hagmann of Berkeley, leaders in the axion hunt, think they finally will have instruments sensitive enough to find what they are looking for, it it is there. "We're partisans, of course," Dr. Van Bibber said. "In this business of dark particles, you have to be. It requires your sustained obsession."
Two other researchers at the center, Dr. Kim Griest and Dr. Charles Alcock, are checking out the possibility that much of the dark matter may simply be small stars in the halos surrounding galaxies that are not massive enough to shine. Such dim stars, sometimes called brown dwarfs, are among the ordinary-matter candidates for dark matter. These are called Massive Compact Halos Objects, or Machos, the antithesis of WIMP's.
The scientists have developed ultra-sensitive electronic detectors for use in looking for such dark objects through an Australian telescope. They are counting on a technique called gravitational lensing to reveal the existence of such dark matter out between galaxies. As light from a distant astronomical object, like a quasar, travels toward Earth, that light should be deflected by any mass lying between here and there. The intervening mass, though not visible, can thus be detected. Analysis of such observations could betray the nature of the dark matter, or at least its quantity and arrangement through space.
Quantity is of paramount theoretical importance. If the average density of mass of the universe is at a certain critical level, it means there is an equilibrium between gravity and the energy of expansion and the universe will remain stable. If the density is much greater, the result could be a closed universe, in which gravity would allow it to expand only for a certain period before it collapsed. If the density is much less, the universe would keep expanding forever, stretching out into thinness and coldness.
Dr. Anthony Tyson, an astrophysicist at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories, has already begun mapping the distribution of dark matter through gravitational lensing, confident that this will be a powerful exploratory tool.
While Machos may exist, astrophysicists say there are strong theoretical reasons to doubt that ordinary matter in the form of dim stars, undiscovered planets or black holes could constitute more than 10 percent of invisible dark matter.
 
Unhappiness With Theories
 Indeed, astrophysicists may have to think of a few more impossible things before their next breakfast, if they are to figure out what the universe is made of.
"All the theories are squirming," said Dr. Carl Fisher of the Berkeley center. "I was down at a meeting with all the gods of cosmology, and no one there felt really comfortable with any theory. Cold dark matter seems to work on the large scale. Hot dark matter works on the small scale. How do you combine the two?"
One more big discovery could change this. "One of us is going to find the dark matter," Dr. Alcock said. "That will be the great coup of the 90's in cosmology."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Diagram: "How Empty Is the Emptiness of Space?"
 
OBSERVATION:
 
The solar system conforms to Newton's law that planetary orbital speeds fall off steadily the farther the planet is from the Sun. But observations of distant galaxies showed no such change with distance, as well as other anomalies that scientists began to believe could only be explained if the galaxies were surrounded by vast but invisible matter. [Diagram]

THEORY:
 
Alan Guth's theory that a period of rapid inflation followed the Big Bang would solve some nagging cosmological problems. But it would also mean that there is almost 100 times more matter in the Universe than telescopes can see. [Diagram]

(Source: "Shadows of Creation," Michael Riordan and David N. Schramm [W.H. Freeman]) (pg. C1)
 
Chart: "Where Could the Dark Matter Be?" -- Scientists say that visible objects account for less than 1 percent of the mass of the universe, and there are a number of candidates for the missing matter, which does not emit or absorb light. Black holes are one candidate. Or the matter could consist of hitherto unknown particles.

Axions, WIMP'S, and other exotic particles
To overcome various problems raised if dark matter were made of ordinary matter, scientists have invoked the existence of exotic entities, named WIMP's or weakly interacting massive particles. Billions should pass through each human body every day. Axions, equally exotic, are another postulated candidate for the cold dark matter. Neither particle has yet been detected.

Ordinary matter and Machos
Instead of invoking unknown particles to solve the missing matter problem, other scientists prefer to look for ordinary matter in other places. The matter might be locked in stars in the halos of galaxies, the stars being too small to ignite nuclear reactions and emblazon their presence in the sky. These postulated small dark stars have been named Massive Compact Halos Objects, or Machos.

HEADLINE: Cost of High-Tech Fertility: Too Many Tiny Babies

SERIES: First of two articles on the boom in multiple births.

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
LATE last year doctors at Saddleback Memorial Hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif., held an emergency planning session to confront a happy problem: four sets of triplets, all due in one 10-day period.
"We had to have 12 respirators, extra nurses, extra lab techs, and we still had to accommodate the other high-risk births," said Dr. David Lagrew, the babies' obstetrician. 
 A decade ago, four sets of triplets due in a 200-bed hospital in such a short period might have qualified for the Guinness Book of World Records. But no longer. Thanks largely to the growing number of couples in fertility treatment, the number of twins, triplets and quadruplets is on the rise.
"Two decades ago an obstetrician might not have seen a set of triplets in his entire career," Dr. Lagrew said. "I delivered seven last year and have another three in progress." The Triplet Club of Cincinnati is adding 20 or 30 families a year.
For couples who have struggled with infertility, the arrival of these hard-won children is an occasion of joy. But since multiple-birth babies are almost always premature and frequently have medical problems, it is also a source of concern.
Health economists worry about the huge costs of caring for this recent increase of premature infants, who sometimes need months of intensive care, only to emerge with disabilities. And pediatricians say that the already difficult task of caring for more than one infant can become overwhelming if the infants are frail.
As a result, some doctors now feel that fertility specialists must be less aggressive in treating their patients, producing fewer successful pregnancies per try, but fewer multiple births as well.
"This is a public health problem because we are producing an incredible number of children who are at grave risk for prolonged stays in the neonatal intensive care unit and all of the complications of prematurity," said Dr. Louis Keith, professor of obstetrics at Northwestern University Medical School in Chicago.
In a case that is all too typical, Barbara and Scott Cameron of Cincinnati had triplet girls, born 15 weeks premature last August, after numerous attempts at in vitro fertilization, or I.V.F. All of the girls weighed less than two pounds at birth and spent more than 10 weeks in intensive care, most of that time on ventilators. Although the three girls are now home, they all have vision problems. One, who has some degree of brain damage, must stay tethered to an oxygen tank.
"You go through eight years of I.V.F. and think, 'I'm finally over all this torture,' and then you have to deal with prematurity," Ms. Cameron, an engineer, said in a recent telephone interview. "It's been a really difficult time and I can't see an end in sight." But she added, "We wanted children so badly, and I'm thrilled to death to have them."
Dr. Emile Papiernik, who until recently worked at the hospital that produced the first French test tube baby in 1982, calls the rise in multiple births due to fertility-enhancing drugs a "worldwide epidemic." In France, where pregnancies assisted by fertility drugs or in vitro fertilization are carefully tracked, there has been a 10-fold increase in the number of triplets and a 30-fold increase in the number of quadruplets in the late 1980's, he said.
Obstetricians like Dr. Papiernik, now professor of gynecology at the University Renes Descartes in Paris, are urging fertility clinics to stem the stream of multiple births by offering less aggressive treatments to infertile couples.
He suggests that infertility experts should use low doses of fertility drugs and place two or three fertilized embryos in the uterus during each I.V.F. attempt, rather than the four or five embryos now typically used.
Critics also say that infertility specialists are probably jumping in too quickly to treat couples who are more impatient than infertile. "When I have a mother come in who has had two sets of twins on fertility drugs and is now pregnant with quads, you have to think that she may not have had a problem," said Dr. Michael Katz, associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of California at San Francisco.
 
'Second Epidemic' of Multiple Births
 Overall, the number of twins in the United States rose 33 percent from 1975 to 1988, Dr. Keith said, and the number of triplets by 101 percent; the number of single pregnancies rose by 17 percent over the same period. Women over 35 contributed disproportionately to the increase; they are naturally more likely to conceive fraternal twins and are also more likely to require the fertility treatments that tend to yield multiple babies.
What Dr. Papiernik calls the "first epidemic" of multiple births began in the late 1970's when Clomid, a drug to stimulate the ovaries, became widely available. Women using Clomid frequently ovulate more than one ripe egg per monthly cycle and, when they conceive, have about a 10 percent chance of multiple birth.
Dr. Papiernik's "second epidemic," which he says began in the mid-1980's, is attributable to in vitro fertilization. In this technique, women are given high doses of Perganol, a powerful drug that induces multiple eggs to develop. Doctors then harvest the eggs in a simple surgical procedure, and they are fertilized in a laboratory dish, yielding embryos that can be placed in the uterus.
On average worldwide, 20 to 30 percent of the pregnancies conceived through this technique result in multiple births and 3 to 5 percent are triplets or more, Dr. Papiernik said. But these statistics vary widely and correlate with the number of embryos transferred.
At the Laguna Hills Clinic, where fertility experts generally place four fertilized embryos in the uterus, the multiple gestation rate is 28 percent. At the Genetics and IVF Institute in Fairfax, Va., where doctors have been placing only three embryos since 1988, only about 15 percent of women become pregnant with twins and only 1 percent with triplets. Because Ms. Cameron had not conceived using smaller numbers of embryos, her doctors implanted nine. Some clinics suggest that women pregnant with triplets or more should "reduce" the pregnancy through selective abortion, but many infertile couples find that option unacceptable.
Because birth certificates in the United States do not list how a child was conceived, no one is sure exactly what fraction of the multiple births in this country is due to fertility treatment. But in Belgium, where such information is available, an estimated 80 percent of the nation's triplets were conceived after fertility drugs were taken. And researchers in several European countries have found a direct correlation between the number of prescriptions for these drugs and the number of multiple births.
 
A Boon, Not a Problem
 In the United States, "the phenomenon is exaggerated in the upper-middle class who have the wherewithal to do it," Dr. Keith said.
For infertility specialists and their patients, the urge to use higher doses and more embryos is only natural. "To a point if you use more embryos you are more likely to get pregnant, but the price you pay is a higher multiple gestation rate," said Dr. Joseph D. Schulman, director of the Genetics and IVF Institute in Fairfax. The pregnancy rate for two embryos is 15 percent, for three it is 20 percent and for four it is 23 to 25 percent.
Although doctors say they discuss the risks of multiple births, infertile couples do not always absorb the message. "I knew statistically there was a chance, but I didn't think it would happen to me," said Holly Simons, a psychotherapist in Wellesley, Mass., who had twins on Clomid eight years ago.
And to couples longing for a child, the possibility of more than one may seem like a boon rather than a problem. "We decided with our doctors to put back four embryos to increase the chance of having one," said Randeleigh Harris, who had two boys and a girl in January after 11 years of fertility treatments. "I had panic attacks when I heard it was triplets, but I would rather have my hands full than empty."
Great advances in caring for high-risk pregnancies and infants have made the increase of multiple births possible. "My grandmother had triplets but they didn't survive," said Janet Bleyl, the mother of 8-year-old triplets and president of a thriving support group called the Triplet Connection, based in Stockton, Calif.
Today, with intensive and expensive care, twins have survival rates nearly comparable to single births. And with even more intensive and expensive care, the outcome for triplets is almost as good as that of twins. The average triplets stay in intensive care for four to six weeks at a cost of tens of thousands of dollars.
In a study this year by Dr. J. Milton Hutson of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, the average delivery time of 19 monitored triplet pregnancies was 34 weeks and no one delivered after fewer than 32 weeks; all women spent months in bed rest, underwent daily monitoring and had a stitch placed in their cervix to prevent the weight of the fetuses from forcing it open prematurely.
But not all women receive this kind of attention, and technology cannot always overcome the forces of nature. "I followed all the doctor's orders," said Ms. Cameron, who delivered at 25 weeks. "Even though you do everything, they can be born early and you just have to accept that."
Babies born before 32 weeks are at high risk for lung problems, brain damage, blindness or even death.
In addition to the three pages of birth announcements in the latest Triplet Connection newsletter, there is a two-page "Tender Hearts" column mourning dozens of trios that did not make it.
Dr. Papiernik said that at the hospital where he practices, half the babies transferred from maternity to neonatal intensive care are from fertility-enhanced pregnancies. The cost of such care has led countries with national health care like England and France to restrict the number of embryos placed during in vitro fertilization to three, to prevent multiple births.
Once home, parents often struggle to care for two or more infants who may have special medical needs.
Ms. Harris, 35, says she is having "the time of her life" taking care of her three 4-month-olds, with 15 feedings a day, three car seats and a stroller that looks like a stretch limousine. All were born healthy only three weeks early. But she added, "I wouldn't have had the emotional discipline to deal with this at 25."
And when the babies are born prematurely, the stress rises exponentially. All of the Cameron girls have had eye surgery, two have needed to be rehospitalized, and one needed resuscitation after she stopped breathing. Ms. Cameron makes almost weekly visits to pediatricians, eye specialists and physical therapists.
To try to minimize the number of multiple births, particularly triplets and more, experts urge prudence and a few infertility programs are now softening their approach.
 
Daily Injections Given
 Women undergoing fertility treatment are given daily doses of either Clomid or Perganol to stimulate ovulation. Ultrasound pictures of the ovaries showing how many eggs are developing generally determine the next day's dose, but the doses have slowly crept up over the last decade. Now, some programs have returned to lower doses and women who are developing too many eggs are told to use contraception to avoid a pregnancy that cycle.
The goal should be "a baby, not three or four or five," Dr. Keith said.
But I.V.F. programs live by their success rates and at prices upwards of $10,000 per try, many couples want to maximize their chance of getting pregnant with each attempt. And many women over 35 do not wait the traditional year of unprotective intercourse before deciding they are infertile.
"There is a tremendous drive to use the technologies rather than waiting and seeing and maybe getting no baby," Dr. Keith said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The boom in multiple births is delighting many couples who have struggled with infertility. "I had panic attacks when I heard it was triplets, but I would rather have my hands full than empty," said Randeleigh Harris, right, who had two boys and a girl in January after 11 years of infertility treatments. With her in Laguna Hills, Calif., were Pattie Brown, left, Cindy Shoop and their triplets. Though all of the babies are fine today, like many multiples all were premature and all spent days or weeks in intensive care. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)
 
Chart/Diagrams: Making a Baby: When Help Is Needed
 
If women do not conceive, doctors can use drugs or surgery to help them achieve pregnancy. Now a growing number of experts say some treatments are too aggressive, resulting in too many high-risk multiple births.

The drug clomiphene (Clomid or Serophene) is believed to work by stimulating the pituitary gland in the brain to produce hormones needed for ovulation. Sometimes it provokes release of more than one egg; about 10 percent of women who become pregnant using it have multiple births.

A more powerful drug,
Pergonal stimulates development of egg-containing follicles in the ovaries. About 20 percent of pregnancies achieved with the drug are multiple births.

Sometimes doctors surgically remove eggs for fertilization in the laboratory. This in vitro fertilization can result in
multiple births because doctors generally implant four embryos, to improve the chances of achieving pregnancy. [Diagrams]

(Sources: "Everywoman's Health," [Doubleday]; The Ciba Collection of Medical Illustrations: Reproductive System.)
 
Chart: "The Risks of Being a Twin or Triplet" -- New research is outlining just how dangerous it is to come into the world in a multiple birth. Because multiples are usually born prematurely, they are at higher risk for many problems, including bleeding in the brain, breathing difficulties and impaired vision. According to calculations by Dr. Barbara Luke of Rush Medical College in Chicago, triplets are almost three times as likely to have a severe handicap as babies born alone.

HEADLINE: Forgotten Central America

 BODY:
Whatever happened to Central America? The region has all but vanished from popular consciousness, along with Ronald Reagan's dire vision of a great red tide inching inexorably to Harlingen, Tex. Yesterday's cold war battleground is today's backwater. And Washington, after a decade of interventionism, no longer seems interested in Central America's precarious passage from war to peace, from militarism to democracy.
Yet in Nicaragua, despair haunts an elected Government struggling to disarm contra rebels and tame a Sandinista-led army. In El Salvador, old belligerents stare across an abyss of distrust as the United Nations strives to carry out a peace accord. In Guatemala, a new civilian President seeks to end the region's oldest civil war. 
 Should Americans care? Absent the overblown Soviet threat, does it matter if these small neighbors succumb to wars and revolutions? It does. In the coldest reckoning, turbulence swells a northward tide of refugees. Solidarity among democracies is not just an empty principle. And Washington cannot in good conscience abandon the victims of wars it fueled.
The Reagan Administration initiated the covert war against Nicaragua's Sandinistas. Ignoring Congress, risking scandal and flouting laws, the White House did its best to make life hell for a country perceived as a Soviet pawn. More flexibly, President Bush adopted a regional peace plan and supported the elections that brought President Violeta Chamorro to power in 1990.
At Washington's urging, she then imposed tough measures to end inflation and restore a market economy. But the human cost has been brutal. Half the population is jobless, factories are idle and farmers dirt poor. Breaking with a winner-take-all tradition, Mrs. Chamorro has striven for reconciliation with the Sandinistas. Though Washington may not like all her policies, it cannot deny that war left her country impoverished and polarized.
Nonetheless a big cut is likely in the $741 million in U.S. aid earmarked for Nicaragua this year. Washington will surely cite the hard realities of competing claims for scarce dollars. Still, it does the White House little honor to contrast the determination that led to Nicaragua's devastation with the low priority given to repairing the ruins.
The same reproach applies in El Salvador. To prevent a victory by leftist guerrillas, the Reagan team spent $6 billion on wobbly civilian regimes too weak to control a ruthless army.
When it became clear that the war was unwinnable, Mr. Bush wisely changed course and supported a U.N. peace plan. If fully carried out, rebels will be disarmed, the armed forces will be purged and notorious security units replaced by a National Civilian Police. The plan would also guarantee human rights, land reform and truly free elections.
Yet Washington's support has been tepid. Though it still owes U.N. peacekeeping dues, the Administration perversely seeks $65 million in new military aid for El Salvador, where a cease-fire is in effect. This is hard to reconcile with Mr. Bush's plea to other countries to volunteer more than their share to peacekeeping in their own regions.
What happens in El Salvador will assuredly affect neighboring Guatemala, where a parallel effort is under way to end a guerrilla war. President Jorge Serrano Elias needs Washington's active help to end the army's traditional immunity on human rights abuses. Progress is tenuous, adversaries are implacable, yet cease-fires elsewhere have built a momentum for peace.
What a triumph it would be for U.S. diplomacy to maintain that momentum. But the pity is that so few in Washington seem to notice, or to care.

HEADLINE: Canada's No Medical Model

 BODY:
Infant mortality runs twice as high among the poor as the rich . . . rates of tuberculosis among tribe members run 40 times the national average . . . health care costs are rising faster than anywhere on the continent.
Snapshots of the failing U.S. health care system? No. These findings describe Canada's vaunted national health insurance system, findings that demand notice from Americans who glibly advocate adopting the Canadian approach. 
 The point is not to ridicule the Canadians. They are justifiably proud of a system that guarantees everyone quality medical care at no direct cost. It's a humane system, superior in some ways to that in the U.S. But as appears increasingly clear, the system's reputation exceeds its performance. The United States will not solve its health care crisis by looking north.
At first glance, Canadians would seem to have it all: universal coverage and quality care at a cost of $700 less per person than in the U.S. Canadians pick their doctors and hospitals; the Government sets fees and pays the bills.
By one measure, the system appears to be working spectacularly. In the early 1970's, Canada and the U.S. each devoted about 6 percent of total output to medical care. Since then, as Canada's share rose to about 10 percent, the U.S. share zoomed to 13 percent.
But data analyzed by Health Policy International, a nonprofit research group in Princeton, N.J., show that this seeming success occurred because Canada's economy grew rapidly, not because medical costs rose slowly. Indeed, after adjusting for inflation, health costs in the 1980's rose faster in Canada than in the U.S.
There are other reasons to be wary of comparison with Canada. Proportionately, fewer Canadians are poor or old, the costliest patients. Homicide rates are a third those in the U.S. And the system saves money in ways U.S. patients might find intolerable -- by restricting access to advanced technology and quick treatment.
No Canadians wait for emergency surgery, but they routinely wait weeks for urgent surgery, like heart bypass operations, and up to a year for non-urgent procedures like hip replacements. Even so, Canadian costs by far exceed those of any industrialized nation except the U.S.
Many U.S. proposals for controlling hospital costs call for adopting Canada's system of global budgets -- setting annual payments independent of actual admissions and outlays. But recent studies should temper enthusiasm. They show hospital stays 70 percent longer than in the U.S. -- presumably because the system encourages hospitals not to release recovering patients rather than admitting expensive-to-treat new patients.
Beyond all such details hovers the question of innovation. Like most of the world, Canada freeloads off U.S. research and innovation. If the U.S. adopted the Canadian model, to whom would the world look for progress?
The United States will have to devise its own health care cost reform, if only for reasons of politics. The Canadian system works well in Canada's disciplined parliamentary democracy. Compare that with Washington, where 535 members of Congress compete for the political spotlight. The Canadian health care system is good, but not good enough to meet America's needs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Haitian Policy Is Mindless and Heartless

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As lawyers and citizens concerned about the plight of Haitian refgugees, we were deeply disturbed by your stories of May 16, "Flight of Haitians Suddenly Resumes," and May 22, "U.S., in New Policy, Will Not Pick Up All Haiti Refugees." Although it is true that Haitians recently have been fleeing their country in larger numbers, the May 16 story reflected only the United States State Department's explanation of why Haitians are fleeing and the consequences they face if they are returned.
It is our Government's position that the fleeing Haitians are economic migrants who therefore have no right to come to the United States to seek political asylum. This claim does not reflect the character of the exodus from Haiti and is refuted by the overwhelming evidence of deteriorating human rights conditions there. With the rejection of the Washington agreement in April, politically active Haitians resorted to their only alternative: flight. 
 Repression in Haiti continues unabated. Political beatings and jailings continue, and the country has no functioning judicial system, independent political parties, independent unions, or free press. Human rights monitors recently returned from Haiti characterize the situation as the worst they have ever seen in that country.
Your May 16 story accepted without question a study invoked by the State Department to justify its policy of forcibly returning many Haitians who claim to have fled for political reasons. The State Department reports that it interviewed 2,000 repatriated Haitians, none of whom had suffered reprisals upon their return.
That finding is highly suspect, however, since many of the interviews were conducted in public or in the presence of political section chiefs or military officers -- conditions under which the refugee's mere participation in the interview could provoke severe subsequent reprisals. It also is unlikely that repatriated Haitians would speak freely to U.S. officials representing the very government that had just returned them to the hands of the Haitian military. Indeed, many of the over 10,000 repatriated Haitians could not possibly have been interviewed because they are in hiding.
The State Department's claim is also contradicted by a report we have received by a plaintiff in our lawsuit who was forcibly repatriated to Haiti by the U.S. Government. On April 30 he was forced off a boat with a firehose, met at his house by armed military men and severely beaten until his arm was fractured.
Your May 16 article attributes the recent influx of refugees to "lawsuits." In fact, our lawsuit has simply focused much-needed attention on U.S. Government misconduct. The disturbing truth is that our Government is determining whether Haitians are credible candidates for asylum based on political expediency, rather than the merits of their individual claims.
Nor did this article mention the conditions on the U.S. Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, where thousands of Haitians are held behind barbed wire in concentration camp-like conditions, without any means of communicating with their families or relatives in the United States or in Haiti. Some, including two or three hundred unaccompanied children, have been there for months.
Although these Haitians have requested lawyers to counsel them about their legal rights, our Government repeatedly has refused to give attorneys -- or human rights organizations -- access to the base. Our lawsuit is an attempt to force the Government to comply with the law and permit those Haitians imprisoned on Guantanamo to confer with the volunteer lawyers they have retained as counsel.
Finally, we cannot fathom the Administration's decision, reported in your story of May 22, to discourage refugees from fleeing political repression in Haiti by refusing to pick them up. When conditions in Haiti become so unbearable that Haitians must flee their homeland, why does our Government respond by "encouraging" Haitians either to risk drowning or to return to the place of their repression? Whether or not such a policy helps stem the Haitian exodus, it is a mindless and heartless one that disgraces our national tradition.
What is the urgency of returning these Haitians to conditions where they face persecution and death? And what is the harm in allowing those refugees in custody to talk to their lawyers?
 
HAROLD HONGJU KOH
MICHAEL D. RATNER
New Haven, May 22, 19921
 
The writers, attorneys for the plaintiffs in Haitian Centers Council v. McNary, are, respectively, professor of law at Yale and visiting lecturer at Yale Law School and attorney at the Center for Constitutional Rights.

HEADLINE: Large Deficits Do No Economic Damage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Now that liberals and conservatives in Congress are poised to approve a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget as early as 1995 (front page, May 7), it is again time to examine the evidence.
* The Federal Government paid off a full one-third of the national debt during the 1920's, but this sound economic policy did not lead to sustained prosperity. 
 * The deficits of the Herbert Hoover and Franklin D. Roosevelt Administrations of the 1930's amounted to 3 percent to 5 percent of gross national product, but were too small to end the Great Depression.
* Federal deficits in World War II were 20 percent to 31 percent of G.N.P. but, contrary to economic principles, this emergency spending brought recovery and prosperity.
* Recent deficits, the same 3 to 5 percent of G.N.P. as in the 1930's, also have been too small to end the near-depression unemployment rates that have persisted since 1975.
* The new Federal spending to rebuild Los Angeles is also an emergency that takes precedence over the existing agreement of the President and Congress aimed at reducing deficits.
The economists who advise the President and Congress apparently believe that significant deficits are justified only by all-out war or warlike destruction within this country. The evidence of history suggests that large deficits do no economic damage, and that if the Federal Government greatly increased peacetime spending, wars and runaway civil disorders might well be averted. Why wait for disasters before acting?
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Lajes Field, Azores, May 15, 1992
 
The writer, professor emeritus of public and international affairs, University of Pittsburgh, is professor at Troy State U., Europe.

HEADLINE: Rappers Say the Riots Were No Surprise To Their Listeners

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
Long before the verdict in the Rodney G. King beating and the fires that engulfed South-Central Los Angeles, some black rap artists had been illuminating America's racial tensions. "Police think they have the authority to kill a minority," railed the rapper Ice Cube on "Straight Outta Compton," the 1988 debut album of N.W.A. (Niggas With Attitude).
These rappers distilled blacks' anger and prophesied its eruption to anyone who would listen. Millions of young blacks did. 
 Now, as South-Central residents rebuild, rappers differ on where their message will go from here. Some say their expressions of uncensored rage and anti-authoritarianism will not change. Others say they will call on blacks and other minority groups more insistently to organize against what they consider to be tools of white oppression, like television. But they all seem to agree on at least one thing: they are not to blame for the violence in Los Angeles.
 
'I Can't Tell Them to Stop'
 M. C. Ren, a member of N.W.A., said the message, "if that's what you want to take it as," of the group from Compton, Calif., had not changed and would not change. Critics of the group's second album, "Niggaz4Life" (Priority) said it advocated gang rape, forced oral sex and killing uncooperative prostitutes. They also said it was a self-parodying betrayal of the band and the stories of death and life in poor black neighborhoods that it once told. Still, it reached No. 1 on the pop album chart in June 1991.
"People listen to our music and realize what we talking about is right outside their front door or around the corner," said M. C. Ren, whose real name is Lorenzo Patterson. "Stuff we say on records we been saying since 1987 and 1988, telling about police brutality, but nobody wanted to listen. If the riots hadn't jumped off, that would have let people know it's all right to destroy black males. Everybody looks at black people different now; they look at it like black people are no joke. When the riots jumped off, an old white lady said, 'You got to tell them to stop.' I said I can't tell them to stop. They are mad."
Sister Souljah, a young New York rapper who has been featured on records and videos of Public Enemy and whose debut solo album, "360 Degrees of Power" (Epic) deals with police brutality, genocide, rape, sisterhood and global politics, said, "I think it would be a good idea for members of Congress and the Senate and all people who consider themselves policy makers to listen to the call for help that is generated by rap artists."
Organizing black people should now increasingly be the message, she said. Sister Souljah, whose real name is Lisa Williamson, said she and the rap artist KRS-One, whose songs and life outside music are characterized by social activism, were putting together a "10-point program that can be used to empower African youth in terms of business development, fighting for African-centered education and in terms of understanding how not to support racism." She said she hoped that the agenda, details of which are to be announced next month, would be incorporated into the messages of other rappers.
"We're going to call a meeting of other artists to see how much unity we can get from the points we're bringing," she said. "The only thing I can say now about the 10-point program is that it addresses all areas of African life, economics, education, culture, spirituality, defense and everything. It's not a militant message, but one of truth and common sense. We have to be educated on our own ethnicity. We have to have finance because without it, you become enslaved to another group of people, and we have to have defense. We can't continue to allow people who don't value African life to come into our community and shoot our people."
 
TV as Propaganda Tool
 Kam, a Los Angeles rapper whose first album, "No Justice, No Peace," is to be released this year, said his views were incorporated in his song "No Television," which attacks television as a propaganda machine.
"Rappers need to combat the negative portrayal of black people on television," said Kam, whose real name is Craig Miller. "Every time we turn on television, we're bombarded with black gang members and black dope dealers instead of positive aspects. Television programs are called programs for a reason: because they program the public. Everybody's got a television in the ghetto, and America knows this; the man and the system know this. But it's like music to black people has greater magnetism than TV, so if we can attack TV through strong rap songs, we would be inoculating our people."
The rapper Yo-Yo describes herself as a "feminist to the heart," and her message is intended for women. Her debut album last year, "Make Way for the Motherlode" (East-West/Atlantic) co-produced by Ice Cube, unveiled the organization she has created, the Intelligent Black Women's Coalition. It is meant to promote self-esteem among women, whom most male rappers dismiss in their lyrics as teases or sluts. She said she had just participated with other rappers in recording a single that deals with concerns of people in South-Central Los Angeles. A project of Mercury Records, it also includes Ice Cube, Cypress Hill, Nefertiti, Comptons Most Wanted, Kam, D. J. Quik, King T, Threat and the Lench Mob. Proceeds are to go to a relief charity in Los Angeles, which has yet to be selected.
 
Blaming Hostility, Not Songs
 "My message will remain the same," said Yo-Yo, whose real name is Yolanda Whitaker. "I have a new cut called 'Home Girl Don't Play That' that talks about survival in South-Central L.A., where I'm from. It talks about how, as a woman, you can't take no wooden nickels, no short cuts, no fast guy in a Cadillac because you'll fall into the system of being on welfare, of using drugs or getting pregnant or being a member of a gang. It's so easy to fall into that system because we're trapped in a vicious cycle."
After leaving N.W.A. in 1989, Ice Cube, whose real name is O'Shea Jackson and who declined to be interviewed for this article, released the solo albums "AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted" and "Death Certificate." The latter includes "Alive on Arrival," a song about a young black man who is shot, taken to a hospital emergency room and questioned by the police about gang activity before being treated; he subsequently dies. Another song, "Black Korea," Ice Cube's revenge against Asian shopkeepers who are suspicious of their black customers, suggests a nationwide boycott and arson.
"I know that because of 'Black Korea,' people are going to immediately pop off at Ice Cube," said B-Real (Louis Freese), a member of the Mexican-American rap group Cypress Hill from Los Angeles. "But it wasn't a song that influenced the burning of stores in South-Central. It was the hostility toward the verdicts."
D. J. Yella (Antoine Carraby) of N.W.A. said, "We just talk about what we live through in the streets."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture yesterday with an article about black rap artists' reactions to the Los Angeles riots was published in error. It showed Dr. Dre, not M. C. Ren, of the group N.W.A.

HEADLINE: The Hope Business

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
From the doorway of his formal-wear shop on Fulton Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Mortimer Roett has seen a lot of change in 25 years.
The surrounding streets, once home to crumbling brownstones and empty lots, are lined with freshly painted doorways and small apartment buildings. The old milk-bottling plant across the street has been turned into a six-story commercial complex with a supermarket, banks and a theater. And though many merchants have come and gone from the bodegas and boutiques around him, Mr. Roett and his business have prospered. 
 He and others discussing the changes in Bedford-Stuyvesant talk about hard work and hurdles overcome. Then they use a word that has long sounded in this central Brooklyn community as a beacon of hope, a symbol of progress: "Restoration."
The Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, founded by Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits in 1967, was born in an era galvanized by the civil rights movement and the specter of riot-torn cities. Hailed as the model for grass-roots community renewal across America, it has provided jobs, housing and low-interest loans to this mostly black neighborhood, serving as an anchor in a sea of urban woe.
Today -- at a time when the rioting in Los Angeles has forced the crisis of America's inner cities back to the center of debate -- Restoration, the nation's oldest community development corporation, will celebrate its 25th anniversary with a ceremony at Restoration Plaza, the former bottling plant. Proceeds from a special commemorative book will be used to start a $10 million campaign to help pay for new programs.
"In a context where urban poverty is becoming more severe, where jobs that allow a family to live above the poverty line are increasingly hard to find and where drugs have mushroomed, stabilizing a neighborhood is a real accomplishment," said Avis Vidal, director of the Community Development Research Center at the New School for Social Research, describing Restoration's work.
 
Successes and Failures
 To some, the recent violence and deepening urban poverty offer evidence that the liberal social programs of the 1960's have failed. In fact, the first 25 years of Restoration have seen both boom and bust.
But the corporation and many others that it spawned have survived, though in less ambitious form. And now its leaders and supporters say the time has come for Restoration to re-establish itself as a force for inner-city change.
Since 1982, when cuts in Federal administration aid devastated its budget, Restoration has been forced to make some changes of its own. No longer the sprawling organization that became the model for more than 2,000 local revival efforts throughout the country, Restoration has trimmed its staff from more than 300 to 36. Self-contained legal, construction and housing advocacy operations are gone. The five community outreach centers were closed. Even youth sports programs have been cut.
"We don't even have the money to do the kind of research that we need to do," said Restoration's president, Rockford Mitchell, a businessman who took over three years ago.
In dozens of interviews, local residents, community and church leaders and urban analysts agreed that Restoration's fight for self-sufficiency -- and survival -- has taken a toll.
"Restoration today is not what it once was," said Ronald Shiffman, director of Pratt Institute's Center for Community and Environmental Development and a member of the New York City Planning Commission. Because of the Federal cuts and stiff competition for private money, he said, "there has been a significant cutback, particularly in organizing."
"Consequently, there has been a diminution of its reputation within the community," he said.
But Mr. Mitchell, whose deliberate diction matches his management style, insists that Restoration is on the verge of a renaissance.
Today, he said, the organization derives most of its income from private sources, real estate and commercial investments. Several contracts have been renegotiated to improve services and profits. And last year, after 15 years of budget deficits, Restoration finished the year with an $81,000 surplus.
Plans include construction next year of another Pathmark supermarket, which will provide 200 jobs. Restoration Safe Haven, an education and drug-prevention program, will serve children ages 6 to 14 and their families. If it can find the money, Restoration will also develop additional housing for low- and moderate-income families and the elderly.
 
Problems Multiply
 Historically, the churches helped hold Bedford-Stuyvesant together.
But by the 1960's, problems were mounting faster than solutions: the level of employment had never fully recovered from the ravages of the Depression; single-family homes were subdivided to accommodate an influx of new arrivals, most of them black; absentee landlords let housing fall into disrepair; and police and sanitation services dwindled as white residents departed for the suburbs.
Though many professional and working-class families still owned their homes in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the neighborhood acquired a reputation as a ghetto.
But in 1966, inspired by a walk through the neighborhood and the work of local community advocates, Senator Kennedy pledged to try to change things. And in 1967, he and Senator Javits successfully proposed a bipartisan amendment to the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 that would provide the initial public money for Restoration.
Senator Kennedy's backing and the promise of Federal financing soon made Restoration the darling of liberal politicians and business executives across the country.
 
Influential Leadership
 With a cast of influential directors and Franklin A. Thomas, a highly regarded former deputy police commissioner, as Restoration's president, success seemed almost inevitable.
In the years that followed, Restoration built or rehabilitated thousands of housing units using local labor. A Restoration-run mortgage pool provided local residents with more than $80 million in mortgages. After considerable coaxing, I.B.M. built a plant nearby that employs about 400 people. Supermarkets General entered a joint-venture with Restoration to open a Pathmark, the first supermarket in the neighborhood in 20 years.
The bottling plant was transformed into Restoration Plaza, a 300,000-square-foot commercial complex that houses Restoration's headquarters. And a family health center, a Restoration subsidiary, was opened across the street.
But then came the deep Federal cuts. Having relied on the public support for about 70 percent of its budget, Restoration found itself on the brink of bankruptcy, compromised by delinquent mortgage loans and several poorly managed deals.
So, over the protests of many residents and some staff members, Restoration began amputating. Over the next several years, it would close its community outreach centers, sell off several subsidiaries and over $4 million in real estate, and switch from providing mortgage loans to revolving loans for businesses -- all to keep from having to shut down.
 
Fewer on Public Assistance
 Despite such cutbacks, there are few people in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where an estimated 300,000 Caribbean newcomers and long-time residents intermingle, who can say they have not been touched in one way or another by Restoration.
One of Restoration's most enduring legacies may be the emergence of half a dozen other community development groups in the area. And some statistics suggest that Restoration's neighbors may have fared better in recent years than residents of some other poor areas.
According to the New York City Human Resources Administration, the percentage of people citywide living on public assistance rose from 11.6 to 12.8 percent between 1980 and 1990. In central Harlem, the percentage rose as well. In Bedford-Stuyvesant, it dropped from 32.5 to 27.6 percent.
Standing between rows of dresses in his formal-wear shop, Mr. Roett talks of attending free weekly business classes that Restoration offered local merchants in the mid-1970's. On his cluttered desk in the basement are plans to expand his business four-fold in a space rented from Restoration Plaza. "They have been very helpful," he said.
Mary Banks, 58, who owns a fabric store nearby, was not so pleased. She acknowledged that her business has been bolstered by shoppers drawn to Restoration Plaza and that a storefront improvement plan had helped her replace her display window.
But a few years ago, when she went looking for a loan from Restoration, she said she was told she did not have enough money to qualify. "They said I had to have $10,000 before I could get a loan," Ms. Bates said as she whisked through bolts of cotton and rayon prints. "No, they didn't help me at all."
Still, those who walk along Fulton Street, past the Burger King that Restoration helped bring to the area, past the sidewalks filled with local vendors, say that if nothing else, Restoration has brought a sense of permanence.
"They have done a lot for the area," said Queenie Lawrence, a 46-year-old school volunteer, who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant with her son, Lamont. "It's a nice, safe place. But people still feel oppressed here for the simple reason that they want things for their children and there are no jobs. We all know there is still a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Announces Surplus Has Grown And Drops Tax Plan

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said last night that the city would finish the current fiscal year with a surplus somewhat higher than it projected last month. The larger surplus, he said, would enable him to withdraw a proposal for $115 million in new taxes that he had been seeking from an obviously reluctant State Legislature.
In a letter to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders that was released last night, the Mayor said that the city's surplus had grown to $515 million, because revenues from some business taxes were higher than estimated and because the city had spent less money than expected. 
 While Mr. Dinkins said the surplus had increased by $60 million from his previous estimate, City Council officials said he was still significantly underestimating the surplus, signaling a battle to determine how big the surplus is and then how to spend it.
Last month, in proposing his $29.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, the Mayor said that the city had run up a $455 million surplus during the current fiscal year. Mr. Dinkins said the money would enable the city to avoid borrowing money to cover its spending next year and to offset Federal aid that the city was unlikely to receive.
The Mayor also said at the time that he would continue to press in Albany for the $115 million in new taxes, including additional levies on cigarettes, tobacco and alcohol, and the first increase in the commuter-earnings tax in 21 years.
But in his letter last night, Mr. Dinkins said that "modestly improved revenues from business-related taxes and modest underspending" would allow the city to balance its budget for the coming fiscal year without the new taxes. The taxes required the approval of the Legislature, whose leaders had indicated great reluctance to support the measures while the city was running a surplus.
Specifically, city budget officials said that of the $60 million increase in the surplus, $25 million would come from lower-than-expected spending and $35 million would come from higher-than-expected business and corporate taxes.
The rest of the $115 million in the withdrawn tax package will be made up during the coming fiscal year, again in money from increased tax revenues and extra constraints on city spending, said Philip R. Michael, the city's budget director.
 
Complex Politics
 Given the complex politics that surround the city's finances, the announcement of the larger surplus was both good and bad news for the Mayor, who has spent nearly all his 29 months in office fending off dismal budget developments. The extra money shows that the administration has worked aggressively to rein in expenses and that budget officials were cautious in their estimates of the city's tax revenues.
But while the Mayor will no doubt receive credit for cautious budgeting and solid management, the extra money will also subject him to additional pressure from labor, the Board of Education, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and many others seeking part of the city's surplus.
The City Council is also likely to get into the fight over how to spend the surplus. Council officials said last night that they believed the size of the surplus would ultimately increase to nearly $700 million, and they indicated that they would want to decide how some of the additional money would be spent.
Of the Council's larger estimate of the surplus, Mr. Michael said, "We certainly don't see it."
Labor leaders immediately demanded a share of the surplus for their members, most of whom are working under contracts that have expired. Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest municipal union, said last night that when he begins a new round of bargaining with the city next week, "We will want our share of the surplus."
 
Credibility Questions
 Mr. Hill also contended that the Mayor's aides had made him look bad by allowing him to go to Albany earlier in the month to lobby for the tax package and then changing their estimate of the size of the surplus. "We're very concerned about the credibility of the Mayor's people," Mr. Hill said.
After the administration issued its budget proposal last month and acknowledged that it had built up a large surplus in the current fiscal year, Mr. Hill and other labor leaders angrily denounced Mr. Dinkins. They accused him of having previously distorted the city's fiscal picture to obtain labor concessions.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said that the expanded surplus would no doubt complicate the city's labor relations. "It's clearly more difficult for the city and labor leadership to ask for austerity from the rank and file if the city appears to be in a better financial picture than had been viewed before," Mr. Rohatyn said.
Mr. Rohatyn also called the Mayor's announcement "good news for the city's economy."
Late last week, many of those who monitor the city's finances said privately that they would not be surprised if the size of the surplus had grown.
But administration officials sought last week to downplay any possible growth in the surplus. David Smith, a deputy budget director, said in an interview on Thursday that some movement in the size of the surplus was inevitable.
"It is as likely to be down as up, but it is not likely to be very big," Mr. Smith said then.

HEADLINE: HAITIANS RETURNED UNDER NEW POLICY

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Coast Guard returned the first boatload of Haitians to Port-au-Prince today under President Bush's new policy of accepting no more refugees at the United States naval base at Guantanamo, Cuba, the White House announced.
The decision to return Haitians without giving them immigration hearings at Guantanamo has been bitterly denounced by human rights organizations. 
 The policy has been to grant refugee status only to those who can establish during interviews at Guantanamo that they are political, not economic, refugees. Human rights groups say the stricter policy is morally indefensible, runs counter to the identity of the United States as a nation of immigrants and will only encourage other countries to follow suit.
The change also drew criticism from Gov. Bill Clinton, who has all but locked up the Democratic Presidential nomination. Asked in Little Rock, Ark., today whether he approved of the Bush policy on Haiti, he said:
"If I were President, in the absence of clear and compelling evidence that they were not political refugees, I would give them temporary asylum here until we restored the elected Government of Haiti. I would turn up the heat and try to restore the elected Government and meanwhile let the refugees stay here."
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, said he would introduce either a resolution or a bill to require the Administration to interview Haitian boat people on the high seas to determine whether they were entitled to refugee status.
Mr. Bush's new guidelines were announced Sunday in an effort to stem the outflow of refugees. Haitians have been taking to sea in flimsy boats by the hundreds in recent days.
Today, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, announced at a briefing that "a handful of Haitians were rescued at sea this morning and are being returned." There were 38 Haitians on the boat.
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said that the refugees were told they could apply for asylum at the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince, and that 17 had agreed and were taken to the embassy to fill out forms.
 
'Most Rational Approach'
 Mr. Fitzwater said the Haiti issue was a "difficult" one but that President Bush's change in policy -- which seemed to take many State Department officials by surprise -- was necessary.
"We have thousands of people on the seas that are being threatened -- 18 died yesterday or the day before -- and people are dying every day on these little ships that they're trying to take out," he said. "The most rational approach in terms of safety and humanitarian concerns is to try to process these applications at the embassy, and those that are qualified are then granted asylum."
Nevertheless the new policy was roundly denounced by human rights organizations.
"I empathize with the Government," said the Rev. Richard Ryscavage, head of the Office of Migration and Refugee Services of the United States Catholic Conference. "They are in a difficult bind. But this policy is a national tragedy because it represents a turning of our backs on our very core tradition of receiving newcomers." Father Ryscavage's office is under contract from the Justice Department to provide social and legal services to Haitian immigrants.
 
'Short-Sighted Quick Fix'
 Father Ryscavage said the new policy was a "short-sighted quick fix that will ultimately backfire, because unless you deal with the core issues you will have continuing emigration, and the core issue is not migration -- the core issue is Haiti."
Lionel Rosenblatt, executive director of Refugees International, said the policy "only gives other countries license to turn back refugees from around the world without the right to assert political-refugee status."
Mr. Rosenblatt recalled that in 1980, tens of thousands of Cubans fled to Florida quickly by boat, and that President Jimmy Carter was was hurt politically because he was seen as having lost control of the situation.
"That was an election year and this is an election year," he said.
More United States officials are acknowledging that something needs to be done if Haiti is going to be stabilized, but they insist that they are caught between two fundamental problems.
On one side, they say, is the fact that the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the democratically elected President who was ousted Sept. 30, was an imperfect democrat at best. Father Aristide intimidated many opponents with threats to unleash his political supporters on them, and thus his return to Haiti is still looked upon with great ambivalence by many in the military, in business and in Parliament.
On the other side, officials say, is the fact that the coalition of army, business and parliamentary figures who ousted Father Aristide have not coalesced into a coherent political force that could run the country.
Power in Port-au-Prince today is so widely dispersed that many of the sanctions introduced by the Organization of American States have had little political impact but an enormously negative economic impact.
Therefore, some officials say that what is needed in Haiti is some sort of international apparatus or peacekeeping force. It could insure that Father Aristide's return would not unnerve the opposition or leave him feeling vulnerable to another coup. This could provide some time for the country to introduce the political and economic reforms needed for a long-term solution.
