HEADLINE: Jersey Shore: Booming but Hurt by Redistricting

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J., May 25

 BODY:
Long Island has its shores, North and South, but "the Shore" is New Jersey's coastline, a 127-mile state of mind that happens to have some of the America's finest sandy beaches, wide inland bays, fecund tidal estuaries and waterfowl flyways.
The Shore now also refers to the broad communities reaching inland that have been filling up with people, houses and shopping centers -- especially in Monmouth and Ocean Counties -- at a rate faster than anywhere else in the nation's most densely populated state. 
 Ocean, with the second-largest area of New Jersey counties, saw its year-round population mushroom from under 50,000 in 1950 to over 433,000 today, while Monmouth's population shot from 225,327 to 553,124.
Despite unchecked growth and issues of common concern to those who live along the ocean -- the environment, transportation and tourism -- the Shore is losing the Congressional district that until now encompassed most of Monmouth and Ocean Counties. Redistricting this spring carved the present Third District into pieces joined to three others.
 
A Cynical Move?
 Representative Frank J. Pallone Jr., a Democrat who has represented the Third District for two terms, now faces three party opponents in next week's primary in the reshaped Sixth District, which covers coastal communities in northern Monmouth.
"We'd be much better off having one Congressman in Washington looking out after the Shore's interests all the time than be split among three Congressmen whose interests spread across the state," said Ken Hershey, the Republican Mayor of Seaside Heights. The beachfront amusement resort, in Ocean County, is now part of a revamped Third District.
Robert Bennett, who owns Casino Pier -- a boardwalk complex here of 32 amusement rides, 10 food concessions and gaudy booths offering "games of chance" to 100,000 mostly blue-collar fun seekers on a typical sunny summer weekend -- added, "Pallone was on top of everything and was particularly good on the environment of the Shore."
The Atlantic has hacked away at the coastline, shifting sandbars and running the surf hard against bulkheads where condominiums have pushed past grass-topped dunes. Northeasters in October and January pushed tides into several communities, causing further erosion.
 
Signs of Change
 But if Rip Van Winkle had fallen asleep on the Seaside Heights beach on a summer afternoon in 1952 and awakened this week, it is questionable if he would immediately notice how much the world had changed during his 40-year slumber.
In that time the boardwalk was extended northward to the resort's full nine-tenths of a mile. Expensive electronic and pinball games with flashing lights and ringing bells filled the old catchpenny arcades. As for string bikinis, who knows what Rip might think?
But the salty air, the flat crump of waves on the beach and the rustle of shells washed by the foaming surf are eternal. A visitor can still play Skee-Ball and other games of chance in the warren of booths and canopied stands on the boardwalk, buy Sno Cones, sticky cotton candy and pizza by the slice and wolf down steaming Italian sausage-and-peppers sandwiches.
What would stagger the old fellow are the changes that transformed the land mass across Barnegat Bay, where sprawling subdivisions stand on spaces that were unmolested until well into the second half of this century, and marinas for fleets of recreational boats are dredged out of wetlands. Pastel-colored malls and strip shopping centers cramp tracts that until the 1980's were oak, persimmon and sweet gum groves, and cineplexes and fast-food shops squat on ponds and red cedar sloughs that have been filled and paved.
People with the means to take summer vacations have traveled to the Shore throughout this century from northern New Jersey, Trenton, Philadelphia and everywhere in between. But from Labor Day to Memorial Day, the area was left to the locals -- descendants of Tory refugees, ship wreckers, watermen and subsistence farmers -- who picked a living from bay bottoms, cranberry bogs and egg farms or worked in such local military installations as the Navy's engineering center at Lakehurst and the Army's Fort Monmouth.
 
Sudden Access
 The catalyst of change was the extension of the Garden State Parkway to the Shore area in 1954. Toms River, the seat of Ocean County, 75 miles south of New York and still a sleepy village four decades ago, was suddenly just a 90-minute ride from the Lincoln Tunnel. Cars streamed out of North Jersey to the beaches on day trips, commuter bedroom towns sprung up along parkway exit ramps, and when word got out that the Shore's winters were as mild as its summers were cool, older people poured into retirement villages. Now there are 65 age-restricted communities in Ocean County alone, housing the largest concentration of senior citizens in the Northeast.
There is still a lot of open space in Ocean County. Two-thirds of it is in public ownership and covered by the forests of the Pine Barrens. But most of the development has been on the waterfront or within easy reach of it.
A state development plan envisions 100,000 new housing units in Ocean and Monmouth Counties by 2010 and looks favorably upon continued development in areas that are already built up. It seeks to minimize the need for tax-supported infrastructure elsewhere and to avoid the erratic development that has scarred gentle landscapes here and in Florida and other Sun Belt states.
The old-timers complain about declining air quality and traffic congestion on the parkway and the main streets of dozens of communities like Toms River, Freehold and Bricktown. But much of the push on environmental issues has come from relative newcomers who escaped from decaying urban areas to the north.
 
'Not Much Left to Save'
 Pearl Schwartz, who moved to Toms River from Queens 20 years ago and now heads the Ocean County League of Women Voters, is one of those voicing concerns. "The barrier beaches have almost all been built up, and there's not much left to save," she said. "There is a clamor for millions in Federal and state funds 'to restore the beaches' after the winter storms, which would be okay if the money really went to protect the beaches. But it really will go to protect private property that never should have been built along the beach."
The state's coastal management plan is up for review, and conservationists hope to plug a major loophole in it that placed restrictions on new housing of 25 units or more, allowing a proliferation of 24-unit structures up and down the Shore.
"Only now are some people in this area asking what kind of community do they want to live in, and the dialogue is starting after a lot of damage has already been done," said Steven Pollock, the chief Ocean County planner. "The decisions made on development have been made by those people who directly benefited from it, which just wasn't the power structure but everyone who lived here, from the guy who put up Sheetrock to the fellow who pumped gas."
Elizabeth Morgan, a native of Ocean County and a staunch preservationist, agreed. "We've done a lot of things wrong," she said, "and the natural values that drew people here are quickly eroding. It's enough to make a preacher swear."

HEADLINE: Seattle Finds Good Intentions Cannot Defeat Economics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
When they talk about green cities, American environmentalists quickly turn their misty eyes in this direction.
Seattle has become "ecotopia" to many, a city where there are bicycle racks at nearly every street corner, where littering is considered worse than espionage and where recycling has reached its fullest flower. 
 No American city has been more vigilant -- some call it maniacal -- about recycling its trash than Seattle, which this year recycled more than 45 percent of its residential garbage. So why is everybody talking as if the program has been strangled by its own success?
"Recycling feels good," said Jan M. Glick, executive director of the Washington Citizens for Recycling Foundation. "We love it. But the whole American system has been designed for disposal and convenience. It's great what we do here, but if we have nowhere to put the materials, and business has no incentives to use them, it's also a little fruitless."
 
Fighting Economics
 Mr. Glick sounds an increasingly frequent alarm: Recycling has not solved Seattle's garbage problem, and, by itself, it never will. It cannot possibly solve the problem in New York City, the New York metropolitan region or the United States. Policy experts say that only forcing businesses to use recyclable instead of virgin resources can do that.
"We can recycle almost all our garbage," said Margaret Norton-Arnold, a consultant at O'Neill & Company here, who works with major corporations to develop markets for recycled waste. "But if the economics are not there, the stuff is just going to sit in a landfill somewhere."
And as Seattle has got better at sorting bottles, paper, newsprint, compost, plastics and many other commodities into ecologically perfect assortments, the economic advantages have been increasingly difficult to find.
 
Unloading Unwanted Trash
 Glass prices have dropped from more than $40 to less than $10 a ton in the last year, for example. Waste Management Inc., one of two companies hired to collect Seattle's recycled trash, has been unable to unload tons of the stuff.
The city, which used to earn $10 a ton selling mixed waste paper, now pays $5 a ton to get rid of it, largely because economic problems in East Asia, its biggest market, have shut down several mills that are usually eager to buy it. Used newsprint, a much bigger commodity, has begun to do well again after a glut, largely because California recently passed a law requiring newspapers to use at least 23 percent recycled paper. By the end of the decade that figure will rise to 50 percent, guaranteeing a large market in the region.
Environmentalists say that without laws requiring companies to use recycled goods and laws banning substances like Styrofoam, the program will be limited.
"If a business can pay less for a new fiber than for used print, you are just going to have a wicked time talking them into using the used goods," said David Dougherty, director of the Clean Washington Center, an economic development group trying to develop markets for recycled material. "We need to find good ways for companies to use what we can find, and we need to make sure it's not a waste of their money to do it."

HEADLINE: Giving New Futures to Refrigerators With a Past

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 26

 BODY:
Greg Slade worked in construction before the recession blew his small carpentry company off the map. Now he's into deconstruction. Old refrigerators to be exact.
He's seen them all: Clunky white Kelvinators with interiors of pure porcelain, geriatric General Electrics with round compressors on top that look like Navy Sonar, Philcos that saw action when TV dinners were a novelty and Tang was the drink of the astronauts. All once-gleaming symbols of the American century of affluence, they now glide by on steel rollers to be gutted for what Mr. Slade's company can reuse. What he cannot is shredded for scrap. 
Mr. Slade, Manny Sanchez, Terry Lee Mitchell and the 37 other people at Appliance Recycling Centers of America's Hartford plant -- the largest appliance disassembly line in the Northeast, company officials say -- work with the mundane kitchen artifacts of culture.
 
Out With the Old . . .
 At 40 minutes per appliance on average, they breathe post-industrial life into refrigerators and freezers that may have hidden silently in people's basements and garages for decades. Coolants are siphoned off; glass is crushed; metal is shipped out for melting; toxic chemicals that cannot go into landfills are sent to Texas for incineration.
The effort is conducted under contract with utility companies that are trying to reduce energy demand by taking old refrigerators out of the power grid. It is no mere grunt-and-crush chop-shop business.
From easing an old clunker out of its dusty corner, to coaxing from the owner some guess about the appliance's age, employees here find that they touch lives, or at least bear witness to objects that once touched lives in commonplace ways.
They have seen mass-produced refrigerators -- white goods in the parlance of the appliance industry -- arrive personalized with peace symbols, or papered over entirely with bumper stickers, or roofing shingles, or turned into art -- one was painted with a loving hand to resemble a giant beer can.
And occasionally there are small mysteries. One ancient General Electric model had only a single clue as to its age. On a small cap near the compressor, they found a handwritten note saying the machine had been "purged by Bill from Hartford" on Feb. 29, 1936. Workers could only guess what was purged, perhaps air trapped in the system. At any rate, the refrigerator still worked.
 
Remembering the Cool Times
 "We get all kinds of wild stuff in here," Mr. Slade said.
The undeniable truth, Mr. Slade and other workers here say, is that people mark their lives in small ways by the purchase of a refrigerator, as odd as that might sound. They say that while most people don't remember in vivid detail the sterling day that the old Coldspot was wheeled in the door, memories can be jogged, and in fact have to be because different eras and brands used vastly different refrigeration coolants -- some toxic, or even potentially explosive. Workers must know what they're facing on each machine.
The trick is to use memory association, based on the assumption that most people buy major appliances at turning points in their lives: a marriage, a move to a new house, the birth of a child. And most of the time, the associations, gleaned when people call up to offer an appliance, are positive, sending refrigerator-owners on small nostalgia trips about moments and kitchens past.
"It can turn into a fun call, no doubt," said Angie Amato, the company's customer service manager.
 
The List of Names
 The list of long-forgotten brands alone would be grist for an industrial history project. In the 19 months since this plant opened, workers have catalogued 99 brand names, saving the strangest nameplates for a shop floor shrine. Refrigerators made by Anheuser-Busch have ended up here, alongside old Supermalls, QuicFrezs, Supremacys, Chryslers, Marquettes, Crosley Shelvadors (complete with a radio in the door), and Ben-Hur Freezers that would appear to predate Charlton Heston. When a pristine General Electric from the 1930's with the owner's manual still inside turned up, it was spared and sent to the Hartford Stage Company as a prop.
There is clearly money to be made out of all this, or at least saved. Northeast Utilities, for example, which serves most of Connecticut and Western Massachusetts, wants to put off building another power plant because of the huge costs and uncertainties, and has collected more than 24,000 machines that were on and plugged in but not really needed. A running refrigerator, on average, adds about $100 a year to a home electricity bill, company officials say.
The other avenue of profit in marching a refrigerator back in time, industry experts say, is that eventually the manufacture of chlorofluorocarbon coolants, or CFC's, which have been used in most refrigerators since the 1940's, will be illegal under legislation intended to protect the earth's ozone later.
That will create demand for the old coolants collected here, said John H. Pence, an executive vice president of Appliance Recycling Centers, which operates five other plants like this in the United States and Canada.
Three other major utilities, United Illuminating here in Connecticut, and Con Edison and New York State Electric and Gas, serving Westchester, Duchess and Putnam Counties in New York, have also agreed to ship appliances here. In their service areas, customers with a functioning but unneeded refrigerator can simply call their electric company, and a crew from Appliance Recycling comes with a truck, at no charge to the customer. Most refrigerators are destroyed; those in the best condition are given to charities.
Some utility customers have been more than a little confused about the program.
United Illuminating advertises its refrigerator pick-up drive, for example, with a campaign called "The Beast in the Basement." One person called to accuse the company of frightening small children. Another man said he had a raccoon living in his attic. Could they come and get it?

HEADLINE: Consumer Bank Rates Are Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were down in the week ended today, The Bank Rate Monitor reported in its most recent survey.
On average, the decline was sharper for banks outside the New York market, which some analysts said might indicate lingering expectations of an easing by the Federal Reserve Board. 
 While rates at many New York commercial banks were little changed, some savings banks were cutting yields on their products in order to stretch the profit margin between their cost of money and what they charge on loans.
 
Treasury Yields Up
 At yesterday's closely watched auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, interest rates jumped to two-month highs. But as Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, noted, these higher rates might be only temporary. He said that while consecutive increases might indicate a pattern of higher rates, he did not believe that yesterday's Treasury auction would lead to such a trend.
The auction, held at the beginning of each week, is considered by many interest rate watchers as a good barometer of what many banks may be paying their depositors in the weeks ahead.
The average rate on a three-month Treasury bill rose 14 basis points, to 3.75 percent, and a six-month bill rose 19 basis points, to 3.90 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
New York Rates
 Yields at New York area banks were down somewhat, with the average money market account off 4 basis points, to 3.44 percent. Three- and six-month certificates of deposit were unchanged at 3.54 percent and 3.70 percent.
Commercial banks left most rates intact, with a money market account yielding 3.21 percent, and rates on three and six-month certificates at 3.37 percent and 3.45 percent.
Savings banks, meanwhile, cut the yield on money market accounts by 7 basis points, to 3.67 percent, and on three-month C.D.'s by a basis point, to 3.71 percent. Six-month C.D.'s were up by a basis point, to 3.95 percent.
The sharpest yield changes among the New York banks occurred at the Dime Savings Bank, where the money market yield was down 54 basis points, to 3.06 percent. Carteret Savings in New Jersey, reduced the yield on its three-month certificate by 10 basis points, to 4.10 percent, while Crossland Savings raised its six-month C.D. 25 basis points, to 4.25 percent.
For the 20 largest banks outside the New York market, yields were also down, with a money market account off by 3 basis points, to 3.29 percent, and a six-month C.D. off the same amount, to 3.64 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of Domestic Vehicles Increased by 9.3% in Mid-May

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
Sales of North American-built vehicles rose 9.3 percent in mid-May, car makers reported yesterday. Automotive analysts said the gain was an encouraging sign that the market might finally be perking up, but they hastened to add that a single 10-day period was not enough to conclusively call a turn in the market.
Still, the period was sweet for Detroit's Big Three, which continued to gain back a bit of the ground they had lost to Japanese competitors. 
 Sales of cars made in North America -- which are considered domestically built -- totaled 195,836 for the May 11-20 period, up 4.3 percent. Sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans, utility vehicles and pickups, rose 17.3 percent, to 138,230. Over all, vehicle sales were 334,066, compared with 271,616 a year earlier.
 
 
Annual Rate of 6.7 Million
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate was 6.7 million, compared with 5.7 million in early May and 5.9 million a year earlier.
The latest period had nine selling days, compared with eight days in the mid-May period last year. Percentage changes are based on average sales recorded for the selling days.
Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, called the report "some good news, even if long overdue." He said the group's surveys showed "that dealer optimism is at its highest level in eight years."
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said, "If the rate were to stay like this for a few periods we could definitely say it was a turning point." But Mr. Heinbach said he suspected that the rate was abnormally high because of large fleet sales to rental and leasing companies. Such sales do not normally reflect retail demand.
"I want to see a few more periods before declaring victory," said Mr. Heinbach, who noted that surveys of consumer confidence suggested that retail demand should be getting stronger.
 Dealers reported signs of retail strength, but little sustained momentum. "We had three good months in a row, and May started out fine, but it fizzled out," said Arne Anderson, sales manager of Highland Park Ford in Highland Park, Ill. He said showroom traffic consisted of "a lot of lookers, not serious buyers."
Jeff Clark, general sales manager of Koons Chevrolet, Geo, Chrysler in Tysons Corner, Va., said he was encouraged that the market for customized vans was picking up. "For people to spend on that type of luxury item means the marketplace is starting to come back a bit," he said.
At Pacifico Ford in Philadelphia, Bernard Henderson, the sales manager, said, "Sales are good, but they should be great, because we are in our season."
 
 
Ford Gains 11% in Cars
 The General Motors Corporation posted a 1.9 percent increase in car sales, to 94,323, and a 6.5 percent increase in light-truck sales, to 51,790. The Ford Motor Company posted an 11 percent increase in car sales, to 54,044, and a 16 percent increase in light-truck sales, to 45,739.
The Chrysler Corporation, which announces sales only once a month, sold an estimated 5.7 percent more cars, or 17,175, and 40.1 percent more light trucks, or 34,275, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
The Big Three sold 297,346 domestically made vehicles, or 89 percent, compared with an 88.4 percent share in the 1991 period. The Japanese companies with North American plants sold 11 percent of all North American-made vehicles, down from 11.6 percent a year earlier.
 
 
Big Gain for Toyoto
 Honda Motor Company suffered a 20.1 percent decline in sales of domestically built cars, to 12,732. The Toyota Motor Corporation raised its car sales 41.7 percent, to 9,897, on the strength of its redesigned Camry. The Nissan Motor Company's car sales fell 10 percent, to 3,327.
Among the smaller Japanese car makers, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation posted a 29.4 percent increase, to 1,694; the Mazda Motor Corporation gained 33.4 percent, to 1,357, and Subaru posted sales of 1,287, an increase of 8.8 percent.
Among Japanese auto makers that make light trucks in the United States, Nissan sold 3,220, down 14.9 percent. Toyota, in its first year of production, sold 1,257 for the period.

HEADLINE: Consumers More Bullish About Future

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumers are becoming decidedly more bullish about the next six months and a bit less gloomy about the present, the Conference Board reported yesterday.
The board's index rose to 71.6 in May from 65.1 in April and has jumped from 47.3 in February. 
 "People are grudgingly accepting that we're pulling out of the recession," said David Kelly, who forecasts consumer spending at DRI/McGraw-Hill, the Lexington, Mass., economic consulting firm.
Consumers' brighter mood, in turn, is cheering forecasters, who see the latest reading as another sign that the economic recovery is likely to last past Labor Day.
 
The 'Real McCoy'
 "I feel quite confident that this is the real McCoy," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the consumer research center at the Conference Board, a business research group based in New York. "An improvement of this magnitude over such a short time closely parallels past recovery experiences."
Mr. Linden, incidentally, was one of those most skeptical of last year's post-Persian Gulf war rebound in consumer spirits. That revival eventually died when the job market failed to improve significantly.
This time, economists said, consumers have also been spending handily. Retail sales have been rising for several months. Car sales perked up to a yearly rate of 6.7 million units in mid-May, the strongest pace this year, according to auto companies.
One confidence-inspiring aspect of the May Conference Board report is that the proportion of respondents who say that jobs are "hard to find," 40 percent, is down from 49 percent in February. What's more, the number who expect jobs to become more abundant now outnumbers, if barely, those who fear fewer jobs ahead.
"That's particularly encouraging," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "Historically, responses to the Conference Board's questions about jobs are highly correlated with the unemployment rate."
Together with recent declines in new claims for jobless benefits, he added, "the Conference Board report suggests that unemployment is easing somewhat." The Government's employment report for May is scheduled to be issued at the end of next week.
To be sure, the May consumer confidence reading, 71.6, is still in the so-so zone. Typically, Mr. Linden points out, very good times bring readings over 100. The board's consumer survey is a mail survey of 5,000 families.
The gain registered for May by the preliminary University of Michigan consumer sentiment poll was less robust than the Conference Board's. The weekly ABC/Money magazine survey has actually edged down a tad in the last couple of weeks.
"My impression is that the Conference Board index is playing a little bit of catch up with the University of Michigan index," Mr. Kelly said.
Still, the rebound in confidence has all the marks of a classic pattern.
"Historically, you get a strong burst of enthusiasm about the future while perceptions of current conditions remain uninspiring," Mr. Linden of the Conference Board said. "In each of the last three or four recessions, there's been a marked improvement in expectations long before the rest came to life."
 
Last Recovery's Performance
 In the last recovery, in 1982-83, for example, expectations rocketed over the 100 mark within three months of the recession's trough while assessments of current conditions continued to deteriorate.
Now, expectations are at 95.5, up 32 points in three months and almost back to where they were last summer. Meanwhile, the current conditions index is 35, up 13 points but nowhere near its level a year ago, much less its normal reading in the low 100's
"At any given moment, the consumer is slightly schizoid," Mr. Linden said. "Why there's so much enthusiasm about the future and such a shrug about the present is hard to explain."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Rising Consumer Confidence: Signal for Stocks?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Consumer confidence is rising, and while it may not be going up fast enough to assure President Bush's re-election, it nonetheless is providing a comforting indication for stock buyers.
In the more than two decades that the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, has been reporting on consumer confidence, the figure that has proved to be the most indicative of stock market behavior is the relative levels of consumer confidence: whether the 5,000 people interviewed think the future is likely to be better than they believe the present to be. Right now, the future looks much better than the present. 
 Those who buy stock do so, presumably, because they expect share prices to rise in the future, and it stands to reason that they would expect that to happen when they think things are likely to get better. But when they fear that things are likely to be significantly worse than the present, share prices may be vulnerable.
Sure enough, while no market indicator is perfect, that one has, over time, a good record as a forecaster. Moreover, because consumers' relative opinions of the future compared with the present show relatively little volatility, the indicator has given few buy and sell signals.
Yesterday the Conference Board, which has been measuring consumer opinion since 1967, reported that the overall level of consumer confidence rose to 71.6 in May, up from 65.1 in April and a low of 47.3 in February. That overall figure includes figures on consumers' evaluation of present conditions, which rose to 35, from 28 a month earlier, and a low of 22.5 in December, and on future expectations, which rose to 95.9 in May from 89.7 in April. [Page D7..]
Consumers' expectations of the future bottomed in January 1991, at 55.6, just before it became clear that the Persian Gulf war would end in a relatively quick allied victory. But after rising through last summer, expectations of the future began to fall again, reaching a recent low of 62.2 in February.
All the figures are indexes, based on the average of monthly readings in 1985 equaling 100.
Looking at the history, and applying a criterion stating that stocks should be bought when the index of future expectations rises to at least nine points above the index of current conditions, and sold when it falls to at least nine points below the current index, produces only a handful of buy and sell signals. But they have not been bad ones.
When the study was first conducted, in February 1969, it showed that consumers were positive about both the present and future, but more so about the present. By August 1970, when that had turned around, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 16 percent from where it had been when the first measure was taken. Over the succeeding years, the indicator would have called for selling at the end of February 1973, buying in December 1974, selling in May 1978, buying in June 1980 and selling in June 1987, shortly before the 1987 crash.
That crash shook consumer views of the future, and it was not until February 1991, well after the stock market had made up the losses from the crash, that it provided a new buy signal.
Still, from the time the Conference Board released its first consumer confidence poll through yesterday, the Dow has risen 272 percent. By contrast, a portfolio that was invested in the Dow stocks only when the view of the future was more rosy than the current view would be up 454 percent. The figures ignore transaction costs, dividend income and the money that could be earned on alternative investments when not invested in stocks.
Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center, noted yesterday that it was common for future expectations to rise sharply in the early months of an economic recovery, but he said the Conference Board had never studied the correlation between its study and stock prices.
For President Bush, the rising tide of consumer confidence is probably good news, but it may not be good enough. In the five previous Presidential elections for which the data are available, the incumbent party won three elections, and the challenger two, in 1976 and 1980. In both years, the overall consumer confidence rating was under 90 in the month before the election. In the years when the incumbent party was re-elected, the rating was always 99 or above. Now, it is 71.6.
In both years when the incumbents lost, the public thought the future would be significantly better than the present, as it does now. In the other three elections, the public either thought the future and present were about the same, or believed the present was better.

GRAPHIC: Graph: The Conference Board index of consumer expectations about future conditions, minus the Conference Board index of consumer attitudes about present conditions. The resulting figure shows when consumers think the future will be significantly better than the present, yielding the buy signals, and when the opposite condition prevails, creating the sell signals. The graph begins in 1969 and runs through the present.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower Despite Signs Of a Recovery in the Offing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in lackluster trading yesterday after the holiday weekend.
Gold prices rose. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.20 a troy ounce, up 30 cents from Friday, the last trading day before the Memorial Day weekend. The Republic National Bank said gold had risen 10 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $337.85. 
 Traders said the dollar had seen little movement despite a positive economic report that should have helped it. The Conference Board, a business research group, said its consumer confidence index had jumped sharply in May.
 
Contrary to Expectations
 "We have the hard economic data to support a higher dollar," John Nelson, a vice president and trader at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York, said of the Conference Board survey and other recent reports. "What we need is a subtle change in perception" by the market that the economy is in fact gaining strength.
The dollar tends to rise when the economy is strong, because of the increased likelihood of stable or higher interest rates.
In Tokyo the dollar closed at 129.15 yen, up 0.05 yen from Monday's close. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 129.30 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 129.45 yen, up from 129.20 late Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8280, from $1.8193 late Monday. In New York sterling cost $1.8250, up from $1.8160 late Friday.
In Europe, one dollar bought 1.6080 German marks, down from 1.6145 late Monday. In New York the dollar traded at 1.6120 marks, down from 1.6160 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4820 Swiss francs, down from 1.4860; 5.4190 French francs, down from 5.4265; 1,214.00 Italian lire, down from 1,216.75, and 1.20235 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1966.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.4785 Swiss francs, down from 1.4860; 5.4030 French francs, down from 5.4345; 1.8103 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8175; 1,212.25 Italian lire, down from 1,216.55, and 1.2021 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1988.

HEADLINE: Dominican Restaurants: A New Beat in Nueva York

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE

 BODY:
TEMPTATION, not rice and beans, is the specialty of New York City's flourishing new Dominican restaurants. At El Lina in Inwood, seductive aromas billow from the door, making the unassuming diner a cinch to find. Step down from the No. 1 train at the 207th Street station, then drift in the direction of the cloud of garlic, coriander and green pepper. El Lina, one block west, is the storefront with the percolating jukebox and Versailles hall of mirrors.
Inside, a Caribbean Lollobrigida sashays over with the menu in merengue rhythm, beaming a smile. Second-time diners rate a smile and a wink. Regulars, the lucky ones anyway, get the works: an exuberant "Hola, mi amor" and a big hug. 
 "Dominican waitresses are flirtatious, and the best ones can pack the lunch counter three rows deep with admirers," said Bruno Aguancha, a Lina regular, as he drizzled a mojito sauce of raw garlic, lime and olive oil over his platter of sizzling fried plantains. "But, of course, what keeps you faithful is the food."
With a shot of Caribbean verve, and some first-rate cooking, enterprising immigrants from the Dominican Republic have invigorated Latin cuisine in New York, upgrading familiar rice-and-beans joints in neighborhoods from Park Slope in Brooklyn to the Upper West Side in Manhattan. As they did with New York's bodegas and neighborhood supermarkets, Dominican entrepreneurs have been buying up sluggish local diners and lunch counters, then transforming them into shiny, successful establishments.
More than 500,000 Dominicans live in the New York region, making them the second-largest Hispanic group, after Puerto Ricans. The majority of these Dominicans arrived in the 1970's and 80's. Yvonne Ortiz, a chef and founding member of the Association of Hispanics in Food Service, said that many of these first-generation Dominicans were entering labor-intensive businesses that other more established Hispanic groups have outgrown.
"Most Puerto Ricans here are second-, third- or fourth-generation," she said. "The Puerto Rican who struggled in the food business for 20 years is now retired, and his sons and daughters are lawyers."
Dominican diners and lunch counters -- they're called fondas in Spanish -- are booming in all boroughs, and especially in Washington Heights, where Broadway seems to have become a glittery extension of Santo Domingo's main drag, the Malecon. But elsewhere, the Dominican takeover of the fondas has been a quiet one. Indeed, many of the customers, Hispanic and non-Hispanic, who crowd popular eateries like El Lina, or Casilda's or Las Marcias, both on Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan, have no idea that their creamy sancocho soups, breaded pan-fried steaks and peppery deep-fried chicken are Dominican, not Cuban or Puerto Rican.
"We don't call ourselves a Dominican restaurant because we want to appeal to all nationalities," said Humberto Pichardo, who with his wife, Marcia, owns Las Marcias at 588 Amsterdam Avenue (88th Street). Both Las Marcias' menu and its storefront sign bear the legend favored by most Dominican restaurateurs: Spanish and American food.
But there's no mistaking the Dominican touch. "You can almost feel the flavors of my country," said Andres Hernandez, a chef and owner of La Sarten at 564 Amsterdam Avenue (87th Street), rubbing his fingertips together as if to conjure them from thin air. "Ahh! the garlic, the onions, oregano . . ."
The Dominican repertory of savory stews, lightly sauteed steaks and fried and grilled seafoods, accompanied by rice, plantains and red beans, is similar to the cuisine found all over the Latin Caribbean, especially in Cuba, Mr. Hernandez said. But there is an important difference. "Cuban food is closer to Spain," he said. "Dominican cooking, like our people, is closer to Africa."
The Dominican Republic's African heritage can be savored in every hearty spoonful of sancocho, the rich yellow-orange soup made from chicken, beef, goat or pork (sometimes all of the above). Earthy, fragrant chunks of West African yams, along with several other related varieties of root vegetables (called viveres in Dominican Spanish) thicken this meal in a bowl. A serving of sancocho, garnished with white rice and fresh slices of avocado, is a Sunday afternoon ritual in Santo Domingo, and the custom is moving north.
Pablo Rosado, the head chef at Sugar Reef, the popular Caribbean restaurant in the East Village, has been teaching non-Dominicans to appreciate sancocho's exotic ingredients. "The yams, the names, the yuca and the yautia are strange to Americans, but delicious once you try them," he said. "So, for downtown, I cut the viveres into smaller pieces, so they're not so intimidating."
The 32-year-old Mr. Rosado, who prefers a baseball cap to the traditional chef's toque, is an example of another important Dominican culinary coup. Ten years ago, many of the Dominicans who immigrated to the United States found jobs in New York's restaurant industry. Like Mr. Rosado, a graduate of a Santo Domingo cooking school who began working in New York as a busboy, they started at the bottom and worked their way up. Today, many of these talented Dominican cooks have become key players in New York restaurants.
"Just about all New York restaurants have a Dominican in the kitchen," Mr. Rosado said, adding that the influence of his country's cooking has spread beyond the Latin community. Dominicans, he asserted, have a natural talent with food, no matter what the style of the cuisine. "I have never seen a bad Dominican cook," he said. "We're creative, we like to try new things. Give a Dominican chef a recipe, and he'll immediately begin to play with it, figure out how he can make it taste better."
Culinary inventiveness and skill shine forth even in modest Dominican restaurants. Some of these places, little more than coffee shops, produce astonishingly good meals, with original dishes that would not be out of place on the menu of a trend-setting Manhattan restaurant. And all at unbelievably low prices ($20 to $25 for dinner for two, with beer).
At El Lina, the basics, a sure test of any kitchen, fare well. White rice arrives in little plump-grained mountains that glisten with a light coating of olive oil. Beans, whether red, black or white, are garlicky and comforting. Pescado Lina -- broiled kingfish -- was fresh and moist, simply seasoned in a sauce of lime, butter, garlic and paprika.
El Lina's specialties, adventures in Creole cross-pollination, hold further surprises. The house chicken, for example, is lightly sauteed in an Oriental oyster sauce. And El Lina's special appetizer, a zesty fried ball of ground meat and flour called quipe, is a Dominicanized version of the Arabic kibbee. In El Lina's adaptation, New World Indian cornmeal replaces the traditional cracked wheat, and Iberian green olives provide an unorthodox stuffing. Eating a quipe at El Lina, diners ingest the polyglot colonial history of the Spanish Caribbean in a single bite.
As it turns out, El Lina is a Cinderella hiding behind a glass storefront and a Formica counter. The owner and chef, Santiago Quezada, and his brother Onesimo, the headwaiter, belong to the family that for 20 years ran the Pez Dorado, a well-known restaurant in Santiago, the Dominican Republic's second-largest city. Before they came to New York five years ago and opened El Lina, the Quezada brothers were schooled by their father, the chef at Pez Dorado, in the intricacies of Dominican cooking, which in Santiago maintains a strong Chinese and Syrian influence, thanks to immigration from those countries in the early part of the 20th century.
Though they've settled into 207th Street, far from the four-star precincts of New York, the Quezadas maintain their standards. "Our rice is never dry because we prepare it in a bano de Marie," Onesimo Quezada said proudly, referring to the double-boiler technique usually used for elegant Spanish custards. Mr. Quezada excused himself for a moment to replenish the water in the half-empty goblets of a nearby table, a move he executed with a matador's flourish.
Mr. Hernandez of La Sarten said it was hard for Dominican newcomers to obtain the capital necessary to open the kind of restaurants that would really provide a showcase for Dominican cooking.
"This is a rough business," he said. "Our food has the potential to be in midtown. I want it to be. It's just a matter of working our way down."
In the meantime, by keeping their eateries small-scale and informal and their overhead low, Dominican restaurateurs are prospering in New York's Latin dining market. And some, like El Lina, are already becoming legendary.
At El Lina's counter, Bruno Aguancha tells this story: "The other day, I was in a cab, and the driver suddenly turned around and said to me: 'Listen man, do you know what makes a woman happy? You take her out for Pescado Lina!' "
He laughed, and pointed out that in Spanish, the word for happy can also mean content, fulfilled or satisfied, an economy of language that begins to make perfect sense over the last sweet cup of espresso at the end of a Dominican meal.
 
Sampling The Fare
 THESE are among the most interesting Dominican restaurants in New York City, arranged here by neighborhood:
LA SARTEN 564 Amsterdam Avenue (87th Street), Manhattan; (212) 787-6448. With its pink table linen and tranquil brick walls, La Sarten is the most upscale and mainstream of the new Dominican spots. The food -- the owners call it "Spanish-Caribbean Cuisine" -- is a lighter take on the traditional Dominican fare, sometimes with a twist, like red snapper in a Caribbean-Oriental ginger sauce.
LAS MARCIAS 588 Amsterdam Avenue (88th Street), Manhattan; (212) 595-8121. Too shiny and elegant to be a coffee shop (a flower vase adorns each spotless, plastic-covered table, and there's a full bar), yet too informal to be a restaurant (there's a counter), Las Marcias typifies the new breed of Dominican restaurants. The rotating list of daily specials includes hard-to-find dishes like habichuelas blancas, white beans in a sauce thickened with pumpkin. The flan con queso, a velvety cube halfway between a custard and a cheesecake, is a typical Dominican dessert.
CASILDA'S 764 Amsterdam Avenue (97th Street), Manhattan; (212) 864-5648. On a Friday night, merengue and salsa stream from the sound system, while enormous platters of chivo guisado (goat stewed with tomato, green pepper and spices), rice, beans and plantains sail forth from the kitchen. The quality of the entrees varies from night to night, but Casilda's loyal, vociferous clientele doesn't seem to mind. Funky and bustling, Casilda's is not just a place to eat, it's a scene: the quintessential Latin diner.
EL LINA RESTAURANT 500 West 207th Street, Manhattan; (212) 567-5031. Only a trip to the Dominican Republic would provide a better introduction to that nation's cuisine. A plate of El Lina's boiled white rice, coriander-fragrant red beans and light, practically greaseless golden tostones (fried plantains) are an essay in Caribbean esthetics.
TU CASA RESTAURANT 4405 Broadway (188th Street), Manhattan; (212) 740-3245. A huge, disco-sized palace that has mirrors even on the ceiling, Tu Casa is the newest and most ambitious Dominican restaurant in Washington Heights. Nightlife, not food, is why Tu Casa is the talk of uptown; there's a full bar, a dance floor and live music. The kitchen and service, still a bit shaky, have to catch up with the ambience.
LA TERRAZA 82 Sixth Avenue (Flatbush Avenue), Park Slope, Brooklyn; (718) 783-5368. In recent years, several cheap and very good Dominican lunch counters have sprouted in this neighborhood, but La Terraza, a narrow room with a counter and five tables, is a standout. Among the top dishes is sopa de camarones, a generous serving of shrimp in a coriander-laced fish broth.

HEADLINE: Oversight at, and of, the Port Authority

 BODY:
During the booming 1980's, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey made investments that turned sour when the economy soured. Now Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York says he wants to make the agency more accountable. But reining in an agency that needs independence misses the point. The Governors of both states have enough oversight already. Indeed, they approved the very project that has earned so much criticism.
"JFK 2000" was a $3.2 billion plan to make Kennedy Airport more competitive, with a new central terminal, new roads, automated baggage systems and a control tower. A weak economy, combined with airline deregulation, doomed most of JFK 2000. Unfortunately, as New York Newsday documented, the project cost the Authority about $100 million in wasted construction. 
 Could the Authority have better protected the public? The current director, Stanley Brezenoff, says the agency was too optimistic. It got caught up in the building boom and failed to get written approval from five of the seven major airlines.
The airlines were supposed to finance the bulk of the project; going ahead without them was a blunder. But the airlines ran into such financial trouble that JFK 2000 might have collapsed anyway. And the Port Authority did cap spending at $150 million, pending approval from the holdouts.
Mr. Brezenoff concluded that the project was "a product of its time" -- ambitious, if well intentioned. Even so, Mr. Cuomo's first instinct -- to create an oversight panel -- could be destructive. The Port Authority has functioned effectively as the region's economic engine. Without some freedom from political bureaucracies, it would fall victim to governmental gridlock.
It's not as if the agency functions with total freedom, anyway. Mr. Cuomo and Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey each appoint 6 of the Authority's 12 directors. Each receives $200,000 a year to pay for a liaison staff. And each can veto any agency plans. Indeed, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Florio's predecessor, Thomas Kean, supported JFK 2000.
Mr. Brezenoff and the Authority's chairman, Richard Leone, plan to improve the way the agency reports to each Governor and how it assesses risks. Properly informed, the two Governors should be able to keep adequate watch. In any case, the goal is to strike a balance between the Authority's willingness to take risks and its accountability -- not to weaken one of the region's few effective development agencies.

HEADLINE: Backward Priorities on Haiti

 BODY:
President Bush's cruel decision to have the U.S. Coast Guard turn back Haitian refugees on the high seas marks the low point of a failing American policy. The American-supported trade embargo has failed to dislodge Haiti's repressive coup leaders and only harmed the Haitian poor. And now the order to rebuff refugees at sea without a hearing trashes American commitments to humanitarian treatment of political refugees.
Mr. Bush insists that he's acting out of concern for people who are risking their lives in makeshift boats. Besides, he says, the Haitians are fleeing poverty, not political repression. 
 But repression is fierce, and until the U.S. finds more effective ways to restore democracy, Mr. Bush's stated concerns ring hollow.
Haiti was economically desperate long before last September's coup overthrowing the country's infant democracy. Since then, its poor have been politically terrorized as well. And haphazard enforcement of a trade embargo, sanctioned by the Organization of American States and supported by the U.S., has only worsened their plight.
The leaders of Haiti's coup have capitalized on gaping loopholes in the embargo that allow oil to be imported from Europe. That has left them with little incentive to complete negotiations to restore the overthrown Government of Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
With violence and repression widespread, thousands of Haitians have tried to flee. Since the fall, the Coast Guard has picked up 34,000 Haitians. Of those, roughly 14,000 have been returned to Haiti after screening and 8,000 permitted to seek political asylum; 12,000 remain at the Guantanamo Bay naval base pending screening.
Now that the base has reached capacity, Mr. Bush orders the Coast Guard to halt all refugee boats and send them back. The Administration insists that anyone wishing to flee Haiti must apply at the U.S. Embassy in Port-au-Prince. But that would expose applicants to reprisals and exclude those who can't get to the capital.
The Administration's new policy has its priorities upside down. The U.S. turns its back on desperate Haitians but fails to do all it can to address the reasons for their flight. Instead of ordering the Coast Guard to intercept helpless boat people, the Administration needs to enlist European support for oil sanctions. A tight oil embargo could make the coup leaders compromise quickly. But if not, the O.A.S. and the Administration ought to consider a naval blockade. The best way to help the refugees is to oust their oppressors at home.

HEADLINE: For Young Black Men, the Trouble Starts Early

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I commend you for spotlighting the plight of young black men in urban centers across our country in "Young Black Men" (editorial, May 7).
"Cause for Alarm," a recent study commissioned by our organization and written by Walter Stafford of the Urban Research Center in New York University's Wagner School of Public Service, concludes that the economic and social problems of black and Latino men are deeply rooted in our institutions. 
 The study found that our systems start failing children, especially young black and Latino males, at an early age. Black and Latino boys are often separated within classrooms and labeled as special problems or suspended at an early age.
On the college level, the undergraduate enrollment of black males in New York metropolitan area colleges has declined in recent years despite an increase in the college-age population. In 1988-89, those colleges and universities awarded only 5 percent of their bachelor degrees to black males and 4 percent to Latino males.
Marginalization of black and Latino men continues in the labor market, with higher unemployment and wages inadequate to support families. Most important, the problems of black and Latino men seem directly attributable to a historical and current underrepresentation in good jobs. More than 4 of every 10 black and Latino men in 1990 were employed in low-wage industries.
Sadly, one can easily surmise that the only institution that welcomes young black and Latino males is the criminal justice system. And then, when it is time for them to re-enter the community, resources to help black and Latino males are grossly inadequate. The dearth of resources has often been cited as a failure of policy and service delivery.
Even before the current budget crisis, few resources were available to meet the specific needs of black and Latino males. Culturally relevant programs designed to channel creative energy and develop leadership talents in black and Latino boys are experiments of a visionary few, and even when demonstrated as successful, are not embraced and actively promoted.
 
MEGAN MC LAUGHLIN
Executive Director, Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies
New York, May 7, 1992

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:

Meditation on Death
 The subject of Lou Reed's recent album, "Magic and Loss" (RCA), a meditation on death and its ramifications, seems like tough going for a concert. Pop music, with its addiction to good news or at its most dismal, broken hearts, is meant to be a celebratory experience in concert. But Mr. Reed, who is performing the suite tonight at Radio City Music Hall, is onto something more complicated. Commentators, taken aback by the subject, forgot that the suite of songs has a light feel to it; death is examined in all sorts of ways.
"Look, this piece isn't called 'Loss,' it's called 'Magic and Loss,' " Mr. Reed said. "I think the record is a perfect example of transforming a difficult situation into something more positive. I wasn't making a dirge. Death is one of the great themes. Within a short period, two of the most important people in my life died from cancer, so the piece is about friendship and how does it transform things." 
 Mr. Reed will be performing with the three-piece band that played on the record and some of the instruments, keyboards for example, will come from the guitarist, Mike Rathke, through a synthesizer. The backup singer, Little Jimmy Scott, will perform in the concerts as well. The music, spare and precisely put together, will be reproduced in concert. And Mr. Reed, who is finishing a short tour doing the material, plans not to use it on a tour of Europe next month.
"This is something I just had to do," Mr. Reed said. "It is very elegant and I had to hear it live, to try and interpret it to see how it worked. When I made the album, I didn't want to have one extra note -- it's a cliche that silence is a note, but in fact it is. So I was restrained and didn't feel like I had to fill a void."
Though Mr. Reed has avoided the funereal, the suite still covers a topic rarely touched on seriously by pop culture. It is still music that requires attentive listening. Who will pay attention?
"People who like to listen to music where the lyric and music engage them intellectually, emotionally and spiritually will get something from the music," Mr. Reed said. "It's not a cheap thrill. It's for people who want to be able to relate to the music from their own experience. The more life experiences you have the more you can relate to it. I'm surprised that more people haven't done something like this, taking advantage of the length of a CD. With 74 minutes on CD, people could be doing musical biography: a musical version of the life of Malcolm X is an obvious example. Music, because it is so powerful, is an easy way to get across to other people your experience. And it hasn't been fully explored."
 
Radio Auctions
 For the next four days, WFMU-FM (91.1), the radio station at Upsala College in East Orange, N.J., will have auctions and performances in New York to benefit its legal fund. WFMU, which programs perhaps the widest variety of contemporary music in the New York area, is being threatened by adjacent radio stations that plan to increase their signal strength. WFMU is expecting enormous legal fees to defend its territory. Well-known artists and musicians have rallied to the station's cause.
Over 300 items, including artwork by Cindy Sherman, Red Grooms, Jenny Holzer, Sue Coe, Gary Panter and William Wegman, will be up for auction. Musical items ranging from a smashed guitar used by Sonic Youth to rock posters and lithographs by Robert Mapplethorpe and David Bowie will also be auctioned.
"We've always noticed that a large percentage of artists and actors and other unemployed people were listening," said the station's program director, David Newgarden. "We do surveys, and we'd get fantastic drawings on the response sheets, and after a while we started to ask for drawings. When we realized we had to raise so much money, we knew we had a huge art audience and we thought it would be a great idea to ask for donations that would support the legal defense fund and make a great show."
The performances and auctions, at Germans van Eck Gallery at 420 West Broadway, will include performances by the Soldier String Quartet, the accordionist Guy Klucevsek and the singer and instrumentalist David Garland. Morris Katz, who the Guinness Book of World Records says is the most prolific painter alive, will paint. For information, call (201) 266-7911.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The Pop Life column on Wednesday misidentified the label of Lou Reed's recent album "Magic and Loss." It is Sire, not RCA.

HEADLINE: New York, Amid Doubts, Broadens Recycling Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
Faced with a welter of new Federal and state regulations, New York City will soon embark on a recycling program that could quickly become one of the most costly and ambitious in the nation.
But after three years of the city's halting, anemic attempts to begin recycling, even the new program's most committed supporters question whether New York can make it work. 
 On paper the goals seem simple. The plan would rapidly accelerate recycling here from its current rate of less than 6 percent of the city's trash to at least 40 percent by the end of the decade.
By September, all residents of Manhattan will be required to bundle newsprint, plastics, glass, and metal separately from other garbage. Next year, the program will expand to every section of the Bronx and all other boroughs will be added gradually until the fall of 1994, when each New Yorker will have to participate.
In addition, the city will be required to purchase hundreds of expensive new trucks and build major new centers to process the materials they collect. The Sanitation Department will begin a vigorous new effort to target extra refuse for recycling -- like mixed waste paper and food scraps now dumped in with regular garbage.
But both advocates and skeptics wonder if New York can overcome the seemingly intractable financial, political and technical problems that have kept recycling out of a majority of city neighborhoods and have turned it into a confusing mystery in most others. The annual costs alone would more than double within the next three years and rise to at least $100 million by the year 2000.
"It will be a huge, gargantuan task," said Emily Lloyd, the city's new sanitation commissioner, who assumed office this year amid an increasingly bitter debate over the relative merits of burning garbage in major new incinerators and recycling far more than the city ever has. "There are going to be some real difficulties, but I don't think the obstacles are insurmountable."
Here and across the nation, polls repeatedly show that recycling has been embraced with a religious fervor. Its fans insist that a city like New York -- which generates more trash than any place on earth -- has a singular opportunity to mine an unending river of waste for vast and valuable troves of newsprint, plastics, metal, glass and food scraps that can be turned into compost.
 
Nervous Community Leaders
 But increasingly, as city officials debate the first waste management plan in a generation, nervous community leaders and cautious planners wonder how. After watching recycling budgets cut and almost eliminated in the past two years, they see the city falling further behind its modest goals of recycling 10 to 12 percent of its trash each year, and without new labor agreements, a fleet of sophisticated trucks, more efficient collection practices, the kinds of incentives that have worked elsewhere, the ability to sort the trash properly and above all, a budget to finance it, nobody expects recycling to succeed.
"Until now it has failed about as badly as a program can fail," said John Schall, a waste management expert who teaches at Yale University and who, as a consultant for the Tellus Institute in Boston, wrote much of the city's new comprehensive solid waste proposal required by the state. "It began as a horrible half-hearted creation. Every district collects different material on different days. It is impossible to understand. The Sanitation Department wouldn't be able to explain it if they put the instructions on a billboard. And, of course, they don't."
But a series of recent and pending laws has already begun to compel New York City to act more forcefully. The Federal Government has banned the routine practice of dumping the city's sewage at sea. A city law will require 25 percent of the New York's garbage to be recycled by 1994, more than four times the current rate. And by the end of the decade, the state will up the ante to 40 percent. Legislation likely to pass Congress this year will for the first time permit states to ban the import of garbage, which would instantly increase the pressure on New York to find less expensive new ways to dispose of its waste.
Recycling means more than separating garbage and hauling it away. The material must be uncontaminated by other refuse -- difficult at best in apartment houses that rely on chutes to funnel tons of trash each week. New York will need factories to process recycled waste and places to sell the products. Right now, for the most part, the city has neither. Its one tiny processing plant in East Harlem is squeezed onto a site of less than an acre and is continually clogged by the 80 tons of glass, metal and plastics that churn every day through its lumbering conveyers.
Markets will have to emerge for the products, because no major manufacturer is going to spend twice as much on recycled paper as it would on North America's plentiful stocks of virgin timber, or purchase plastics that do not meet its standards.
"New York keeps putting its toe in the water then taking it out," said Arthur Veverka, an engineering consultant who is trying to help bring a paper mill to New York City that would process recycled newsprint. "Business doesn't work that way, neither do people. If you make an investment in recycling, it will pay off. But it won't pay off tomorrow, and it won't pay of next year. We should be able to see further than that."
So far, however, city leaders clearly have not. Despite its enormous size and the obvious difficulties of recycling in a city that is so hard to manage, advocates say that a true political commitment could solve the problem almost overnight. Uniformity in the program would permit concise and specific public education. Markets can only develop after materials have been collected, so if the city waits for demand before it generates a decent supply the program will be doomed.
Most policy experts believe it will take a complex system of incentives, fines and legislation as wells as political commitment to catapult New York into the front ranks of recycling. The costs of garbage disposal has been masked here for 40 years by the unusual economics of the Fresh Kills Landfill. Other cities must pay to bury their garbage. New York owns Fresh Kills so the costs of using it are harder to divine. As a result, city officials have never had the urgent need to find a cheaper alternative.
 
Economic Questions
 But with available space at Fresh Kills vanishing every day, all that will have to change soon. Recycling proponents worry whether doing it on a scale never before attempted in the United States makes economic sense in this densely packed, financially hobbled and ethnically diverse world of towering apartment houses and giant dumpsters. But they worry even more about what will happen if the city is forced to rely solely on the rapidly depleting landfill or the politically detested alternative of incineration.
Budget analysts and environmental leaders often disagree, but not in this case: They all acknowledge that as long as recycling remains solely a nice idea that costs New York far more than burning or burying its garbage, the program and the expansive vision of its most ardent supporters have little chance of success.
Not surprisingly for a program with uneven financing and little consistency, participation has been paltry. New Yorkers recycle less than 6 percent of the 28,000 tons of trash they produce each day -- 13 percent if commercial waste is included. Cities rarely do well, but others do better. By comparison, Philadelphia recycles 14 percent of its residential waste each year, Newark more than 35 percent and last year Seattle, which has the nation's most aggressive residential recycling program surpassed 40 percent.
"The city has had a garbage crisis for 300 years," said John F. Ruston, a senior economist at the Environmental Defense Fund, a research and advocacy group. "But the costs are finally going to make people start to pay attention. When we are paying three times as much to ship our garbage to Pennsylvania -- and we can't afford enough teachers for nurses -- people will start to notice."
Mr. Ruston and his colleagues hope the debate over the waste plan will force the city to devote a far larger percentage of its budget to recycling than to burning or burying waste.
At hearings on the city's solid waste plan in every borough over the past week, community advocates embraced recycling as they never have before. Huge signs, painted boldly on stark fields of smoke stacks, coughing stick figures and symbolic gravestones read simply, "Recycle or Die." Worried residents presented a message that could not have been louder or plainer: Recycle first, burn later -- much later.
"Accept the fact that the Navy Yard incinerator will never be built," said Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn, before a wildly approving audience in Borough Hall. "The people of Brooklyn can, must and will recycle."
Even if several incinerators are constructed in New York City in the coming decades -- a policy option that many consider inevitable but others regard as a political impossibility -- recycling will have to struggle to succeed here. Currently, there is no uniform education, largely because there is no uniform recycling program. This infuriates environmentalists, but they acknowledge that it does no good to teach a child what to recycle in school if he or she can rarely put his education to use.
 
Recycling Zone
 Recycling at some level clearly can succeed in New York. Supporters frequently point to one neighborhood, Park Slope in Brooklyn, where recycling works as well as anywhere in the country. Under the direction of Barry Commoner, director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College, the city has established a recycling zone where bottles, newsprint, mixed waste paper, plastic and glass are recycled. Last year, the 13,000 residents in the neighborhood became the first in the country to begin regular separation of food scraps for compost.
The results have been impressive, with the overall recycling rate reaching 36 percent in less than a year.
"It works like a dream," said Alicia Culver, the gregarious recycling missionary whose job it is to monitor compliance in the neighborhood and help its residents increase participation. "We have found that when you give people some help they really want to do it."
But such help -- spread throughout the city -- will cost money, and though Ms. Lloyd, the sanitation commissioner, regards the Park Slope program as a model, she acknowledges that the neighborhood is more politically active and affluent than many other communities.
"Ideally, I would love to see a volunteer army of Alicias ready to decipher the program and help neighbors," she said. "But can we rely on that alone. I just don't know."

HEADLINE: Our Friend, Japan

BYLINE: By Jonathan Rauch; Jonathan Rauch is author of "The Outnation: A Search for the Soul of Japan."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the conventional wisdom of popular economics, commerce is like warfare. That's a core belief of economic nationalism: if they are winning, then we must be losing.
If you believe this, then you probably believe that foreigners generally, and the Japanese particularly, are attacking and laying waste to America's industrial base. In fact, the truth is just the opposite. Foreign competition and investment, notably Japanese competition and investment, are revitalizing the U.S. industrial base. 
 In steel, American companies are competitive again after decades of disinvestment and obsolescence. In their 1991 study of the industry, Richard Florida, a professor of public policy at Carnegie-Mellon University, and Martin Kenney, a sociologist at the University of California at Davis, found that $7 billion in Japanese investment played a key role in bringing cutting edge technology to the U.S. "Without Japanese investment, technology and manufacturing organization," they wrote, "we would likely find ourselves with a much smaller domestic steel industry, if any at all."
In the automobile industry, relentless competitive pressure has made the Big Three miserable, but it has also taught them to build a better car. In Danville, Ill., Toyota sent a team of engineers to teach lean-manufacturing techniques to Bumper Works Inc., a company that makes bumpers for trucks. With Toyota's help, productivity rose 60 percent while defects fell 80 percent. "I don't think we knew how bad we were," the owner told The Wall Street Journal. In addition, Japanese automakers have invested $9 billion in American plants, and are demonstrating how to get higher productivity from U.S. workers.
What's true for steel and automobiles has also been true for electronics. In St. Louis, an executive of MEMC Electronics Materials told me how processes that his company learned in Japan have made the company's U.S. plants 20 percent more efficient. And Japan's quality revolution has forced companies like Motorola to reduce defects from 6,000 per million to 40 per million.
The pattern holds even for convenience stores. Japanese 7-Eleven stores are half the size yet sell twice as much as their U.S. counterparts. Now Seven-Eleven Japan Company is teaching some of its techniques to American 7-Elevens, whose parent company the Japanese bought in 1991.
International commerce, unlike war, is a positive-sum game: in the long run, everyone wins. We shouldn't be surprised, then, that figures on manufacturing output and productivity counter the idea that the U.S. industrial base being eviscerated by foreigners.
Between 1982 and 1990, U.S. manufacturing output rose 47 percent -- close to Japan's 54 percent and far ahead of output increases of 30 percent in Britain, 22 percent in Germany and 11 percent in France. The U.S. figures are not numbers you would associate with a deindustrializing country.
As for manufacturing productivity, it rose by 37 percent, beaten only by Japan's 38 percent and well ahead of Germany's 26 percent. Lagging productivity in the relatively sheltered service sector, not in manufacturing, is what drags down U.S. living standards.
Japan's economic vitality is a font of industrial innovation and vigor. Only once or twice in a century is the world blessed with such a wellspring, the last example being Henry Ford's America. Unquestionably, Japan has particular trade policies and practices that are harmful and ought to be changed (as does Europe, and America). There are plenty of issues to complain to the Japanese about. But destroying the U.S. industrial base is certainly not one of them.
