HEADLINE: EUROPEANS IMPOSE A PARTIAL EMBARGO ON BELGRADE TRADE

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 27

 BODY:
European Community governments imposed a partial trade embargo on Serbia and Montenegro today and called on the United Nations to go further and ban oil sales in its own economic sanctions in the hope of forcing an end to Serbian intervention in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Their move came just three days after they were publicly admonished by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for moving slowly to tackle what he called the "humanitarian nightmare" gripping the former Yugoslav republic since it declared its independence from Belgrade three months ago. 
 Embarrassed by American criticism of its failure to broker a political settlement in Yugoslavia, the community was evidently eager to act before the United Nations Security Council. The Council is expected to impose a trade embargo on Serbia and Montenegro later this week.
 
Oil Is Not Included
 The community nonetheless decided against including an oil boycott in its trade embargo on the ground that the two members that send oil to Serbia and Montenegro, Greece and Britain, account for only 11 percent of the republics' oil imports.
Community officials argued that only a global oil boycott ordered by the Security Council could cut Serbia and Montenegro off from their main suppliers: Russia and China, which each provide 22 percent of their oil, Romania, which supplies 15 percent, and Iran, which supplies 13 percent. The community decision today to seek such a boycott was backed by Britain, France and Belgium, which are also Council members.
At the United Nations, diplomats said that Council members had until now been leaning toward a two-stage trade embargo, with an oil boycott left for later resolution, in part to satisfy Russia and China. But they said the community's move would strengthen the hand of governments, notably the United States, that favored including an immediate oil ban.
 
Trade Both Ways Banned
 The community decision, reached after a daylong meeting of ambassadors at its Brussels headquarters, has still to be endorsed by foreign ministers, but this is considered a formality. European diplomats said the embargo should go into force on Monday.
The community sanctions cover two-way trade with Serbia and Montenegro, which at present send over half their exports to community countries and import 45 percent of their goods from them. A community study said a trade embargo would have an "important impact" on the two republics, costing them as much as $140 million a month.
Community governments also plan to freeze export credits and to suspend scientific and technological cooperation accords, and they urged the Security Council to freeze financial assets held abroad in the name of the former Yugoslav federation. Officials said the community did not order such a freeze because these assets have reportedly already been removed from Europe.
The community's sanctions against Belgrade did not include cancellation of food, medicines and other humanitarian aid, a ban on sporting contacts or revocation of air landing rights. Germany and Italy, however, have already canceled landing rights for the Yugoslav airline, JAT, and Germany has also banned commercial road and rail traffic with Serbia and Montenegro. The United States and Canada have banned JAT from landing in their countries.
"Together, all these measures are taken in the hope of convincing Serbia and Montenegro to fully participate in the search for a lasting and peaceful solution in the peace conference," the community statement said, referring to the community's suspended mediation effort in Yugoslavia.
Before reaching their consensus today, the community ambassadors reportedly faced resistance to the idea of a trade embargo from Greece and France. Greece will lose sales to Serbia and Montenegro and France argued in favor of awaiting a decision at the United Nations Security Council.
 
France Denies Stalling
 But a French Government spokesman denied today that Paris was stalling. "France has constantly repeated that it is not opposed to sanctions being imposed on Serbia as long as they are part of a policy aimed at achieving a negotiated solution within the framework of ex-Yugoslavia," he said.
The community's efforts to broker a political settlement between the former Yugoslavia republics have been paralyzed by the upsurge of fighting of recent weeks, with the community's chief mediator, Lord Carrington of Britain, arguing that he can do little until there is a permanent cease-fire.
A separate community-backed effort to negotiate a settlement between the warring Serbs, Croats and Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina broke down in Lisbon today after Muslim leaders blamed Serbian militia for a mortar attack on a market in Sarajevo in which scores of people were killed or wounded.
Frustration over the international community's failure to end the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina even brought a flurry of speculation last weekend about the possibility of dispatching a multinational military force to guarantee the delivery of humanitarian aid to the growing army of refugees and displaced people in the region.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is now a member of the United Nations, has also appealed for the protection of such a force, but the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros Ghalil, has said that the 14,000-man peace-keeping force assigned to Serbian-populated areas of Croatia has no mandate to operate in Bosnia.
 
No U.S. Troops Plans
 After a two-day meeting North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting, the American Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, also said today that there were no plans "at present" for American troops to become involved in Yugoslavia. While willing to contribute troops to United Nations peace-keeping forces, key community governments are opposed to the notion of trying to "make peace" in Yugoslavia.
The Yugoslav crisis nonetheless served as a backdrop for the NATO meeting in Brussels because defense ministers endorsed the proposal that the Atlantic alliance offer its troops for possible peace-keeping operations to the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
This offer, which will probably be formalized when NATO foreign ministers meet in Oslo next week, appears intended to strengthen the European Security Conference's ability to tackle just the sort of complicated ethnic, minority and nationality dispute that exists in Yugoslavia.
Asked whether the 16-nation alliance was ready to send peace-keeping forces to Yugoslavia, NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, replied, "I won't speculate on a possible scenario." But he stressed that NATO had no intention of becoming "the defense arm" of the European Security Conference.

HEADLINE: Russia Braces for Storm Of Mass Unemployment

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 27

 BODY:
Four months into Russia's economic reforms, as prices go up and production declines, unemployment, the most dreaded of capitalism's consequences, remains the shoe that has yet to drop.
Compared with Europe and the United States, the level of joblessness here is still negligible: 118,000 people, or less than two-tenths of 1 percent of the nation's 74 million workers, according to Russia's Government. 
 But these statistics are not much use to Anatoly, a 52-year-old Russian diplomat who will be without a job as of June 1. He is leaving the Russian Foreign Ministry on a new wave of staff reductions, and has embarked on a lonely search for work in a land where unemployment offices are ill prepared, and head-hunters unknown.
 
Idleness Is 'the End'
 "I have had offers but I am looking for something reliable, something firm," said the career diplomat, who asked that his last name not be published. "I have to find something because for me, to stay idle is the end."
Being jobless is unthinkable for most Russians, all of whom grew up with the notion of guaranteed employment, one of the few promises that Communism was able to keep. But now, as a market economy makes its debut, some are already getting their first taste of a free labor market.
Small-scale layoffs have begun, mostly among white-collar workers. The Russian Foreign Ministry, for instance, has already cut its staff by at least 40 percent, and has drawn up plans for further reductions. At the Moscow Excursion Bureau, 110 of 250 tour guides were laid off this spring, a trying experience for Yevgeny S. Likhenko, the agency's director.
"It was very difficult," Mr. Likhenko said. "These people are not being laid off because they worked badly, but because we do not have enough work to give them. Some understood that, but for others, it was very painful. They just don't want to look at reality."
 
Millions of Jobless to Come?
 Fyodor Prokopov, chairman of the Committee on Employment, a Government agency, predicts that by year's end 2.5 million to 3.5 million people will be out of work, as Russia's gigantic factories finally show the effects of their own insolvency.
As it is, an estimated 14 percent of factories and enterprises have virtually run out of money for everything but salaries, according to Mr. Prokopov, and with the country in a cash crunch, many salaries are not being paid. What is most surprising, at this stage of the reforms, is that unemployment is not more significant.
"It is in the Russian tradition that firings are very rarely practiced and only as a last step," he said. "Many factory managers are using their last tricks -- long holidays, internal transfers from the central part of the factory to its branch operations, delayed paychecks. But many of these tricks are already used up."
In big industrial centers, women are being encouraged to use up their three-year maternity leaves or to retire on maternity benefits, workers are offered long vacations at half-pay, or shorter work weeks -- all forms of what experts here call "hidden unemployment."
Layoffs are also procedurally difficult, requiring approval from the local labor unions. And as ranking members of the local establishments, factory directors are held responsible for civic order, making them reluctant to put people out on the street.
Hardest hit will be regions where the only jobs belong to a now-dying military-industrial complex. In these places, Mr. Prokopov said, unemployment could soar into the double digits, whereas in big cities like Moscow and St. Petersburg, enough of a private sector has emerged to absorb some of the loss of state jobs.
In one underground passageway under Pushkin Square, a private employment agency named Triza has laid out a table under a sign asking "What is your profession?" It matches professionals with vacancies at clients' institutes and enterprises. So far, in most professions, there are still more jobs chasing qualified people than the other way around, said a Triza representative.
 
Shift to Private Sector
 The decline in the state sector, once a monopoly, began even before the upheavals of the last year when Communism collapsed and President Boris N. Yeltsin undertook his move toward a market economy. Between 1988 and 1990, as joint ventures with foreign investors and cooperative enterprises increased, the number of people working in the state sector dropped by 3 million. In 1991, the decline was 8 percent, or 4.9 million people. By the end of 1991, 17 million people -- 23 percent of the work force -- were already working outside the state sector.
In many cases, people have simply walked out from their dead-end, low-paying Government jobs, long before the final notices were issued. Engineers have become taxi drivers, geologists work as nannies, veterans of the state supply system turn up on the bustling commodity exchanges and computer operators have taken to selling goods on the street.
This new world of business and commerce, still tenuous and sometimes shady, partly explains the relatively painless collapse of the Soviet Government last fall, when giant ministries with vast apparatuses simply disappeared overnight. Another explanation is the growth of the bureaucracy in local governments, which have become havens for displaced Communist apparatchiks and former Soviet bureaucrats.
 
Preparing for Mass Layoffs

But neither the Government nor the private sector are in a position to absorb the shock of mass layoffs, which some expect this fall. The Committee on Employment is now scrambling to put its network in place, but it admits that not all 2,300 local offices are ready. In Pskov, a medium-sized city, the local unemployment office is a room in a college dormitory.
Efforts are now being made to amend Russia's laws on unemployment, and to pass a law on bankruptcy which for the first time will lay out procedures for the actual closing of bankrupt industries.
Under the current law, an employer must pay a laid-off worker a full salary for the first three months of unemployment. The Government then picks up the benefits for a year, starting at 75 percent of the former salary, and ending at 45 percent. Unemployment benefits do not extend beyond a year -- something that proposed legislation would change, along with a flat benefit that would be simpler to distribute and administer.

COUNTRY: RUSSIAN FEDERATION (95%); EUROPE (92%); UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Model-School Plan Gets More Ideas Than Money

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's private-sector effort to inspire innovative models for the nation's schools, the New American Schools Development Corporation, has attracted a flood of proposals but less than a quarter of the $200 million needed to finance them.
Officials at the corporation said today that the nonprofit group would have enough money to finance the first round of 20 to 30 projects in July at $1.5 million apiece. But they also announced the election of Ann D. McLaughlin, a former Secretary of Labor in the Reagan Administration, as president and chief executive officer, with a mandate to improve the fund-raising effort. She will take over July 1. 
 The corporation was created last July at the behest of President Bush to persuade American businesses to donate money to create 535 experimental schools over a five-year period.
Although many business leaders saw the idea as an opportunity to encourage corporate donations to education, they also expressed concern about the venture's prospects given the depressed economy. Others worried that political pressure to contribute to the corporation would cause their existing philanthropic programs to suffer.
The corporation now has less than $45 million in commitments, raising the issue of just how many, if any, innovative projects can be financed. Some observers find it a bad omen that the deadline for financing the projects has been moved from May to July.
Paige Cassidy, a spokeswoman for the corporation, said the delay was to give the board more time to assess proposals.
 
Potentially Embarrassing
 "The Administration has really put a lot of marbles on this," said Gordon Ambach, executive director of the Chief State School Officers, a group of the top school officials from each state. "If this doesn't fly with a lot of powerful grants, I think this is going to be a tremendous embarrassment."
Ms. McLaughlin was named Secretary of Labor in December 1987 and served a little more than a year, during which she established the Workforce Quality Commission, charged with analyzing the global competitiveness of America's work force.
Ms. McLaughlin, a visiting fellow and board member at the Urban Institute, a private, nonprofit policy research organization in Washington, was traveling today and could not be reached for comment.
In a statement released by the corporation, she said: I am deeply concerned that our students are increasingly ill-prepared for the world that awaits them, and the gap between us and our competitor nations is widening every year."
The group has been without a president since February, when W. Frank Blount, a former AT&T executive, resigned as head of the corporation to run the new Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation.
Some business leaders said they thought that an improving economy and Ms. McLaughlin's ties to corporate America would boost donations.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Is Knocked Off Course by Tide for Perot

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., May 27

 BODY:
There comes a time in many campaigns when a candidate seems trapped in a script of someone else's making. So it goes for Bill Clinton, looking stoically into a local television camera and answering, perhaps for the ninth or 10th time of the day, questions about his lagging poll ratings and the growing threat of Ross Perot.
Mr. Clinton told reporters in Cleveland on Tuesday night that he was going "to stop answering foolish questions about polls," but the vow was short-lived. Within hours he was giving a series of live local television interviews, which began with a question about why it took him so long to get a local endorsement and moved quickly on to a new Ohio poll that showed the Arkansas Governor in third place in a three-way race. 
 The Democratic primary season is winding down, but Mr. Clinton seemed to be on anything but a victory tour as he traveled through Arkansas, Ohio and New Jersey this week. What should have been a grace period for the likely Democratic nominee, a time to polish his image and consolidate his support, has instead become a struggle to simply be heard over the roar of Perotism.
The Clinton entourage is acutely aware of its plight; there is a sense of grievance just below the surface, much of it directed toward the press. "I think this process in a lot of ways betrayed him," said one Clinton aide. Clinton allies talk of the unfairness of their candidate's emerging from the primary season so little known -- and known in large part for a series of "character issues" like accusations of infidelity.
But there is also a strange fatalism among some in the Clinton camp, a sense that there is little they can or should do about Mr. Perot at this stage of the campaign. Mr. Clinton himself, perhaps unwittingly, reflected that view this week, when he was asked whether it was a good idea to spend four days in his native Arkansas, given the growing threat from Mr. Perot. The Governor itemized the business that kept him home, including Tuesday's primary there. Then, referring to Mr. Perot, he added edgily: "There's nothing I can do about that now. I'm not out there running against him."
There are strategic reasons for this caution: Mr. Perot is focusing his fire on Mr. Bush, not Mr. Clinton, and in a three-way race, it could make sense for Mr. Clinton to refrain from attacks on Mr. Perot and try to remain an appealing alternative for the billionaire's supporters. But some Democrats argue that Mr. Clinton needs to take some risks with his message and his campaign style simply to get the public's attention again. He sometimes seems frozen, adrift -- an image that his Arkansas-centered schedule earlier this week only underscored.
One Democratic consultant, who like several others spoke only on condition that he not be identified, suggested that Mr. Clinton may not be keeping pace with an outraged electorate hungry for action. Mr. Clinton's candidacy is steeped in the careful centrism of the Democratic Leadership Council, and largely revolves around trying to rebuild the consensus for a new, better-managed, domestic agenda. For example, he calls for expanded college loan programs and training opportunities, welfare policies to encourage work and a new focus on economic competitiveness.
 
Leadership and Policy
 In a three-way race with Mr. Perot, who blithely asserts that the voters are interested in leadership, not detailed policy positions, Mr. Clinton's fine-tuned positioning might not be enough. Others argue that Mr. Clinton, with his calibrated responses, often comes across as too political, in a year when that is not considered a good thing to be.
He talks often about his commitment to fighting for change; he even flatly appropriated former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s slogan Monday night, "Take it Back." But he also slips easily into the language and approach of a man who has spent his career in government, a man who in a competition for outsider status seems unlikely to beat Mr. Perot, at least stylistically.
Moreover, the Clinton campaign still puts him in events that make him look like a traditional, establishment candidate; for example, the picture on Cleveland television Tuesday night showed him surrounded by two dozen Ohio mayors, who were endorsing him that day.
His aides say they are planning some bold moves in the days to come. They say that, just as they did when Mr. Clinton ran into trouble in New Hampshire and New York, they will find ways to go over the heads of the news media and put Mr. Clinton directly before the voters. He taped an interview with David Frost today, and Paul Begala, a Clinton strategist, said the campaign plans similar appearances in the future.
 
May Buy TV Time
 Mr. Begala bristled at the notion that Mr. Clinton was appropriating a page from Mr. Perot's book, asserting, "This is a Clinton strategy." The campaign is also considering such measures as buying 30 minutes of television time for a national appeal before the convention.
Beneath the strategizing, though, remains a sense of bewilderment, not unlike that found in the Bush campaign, which is also struggling to adjust to Mr. Perot. And there is a weariness to Mr. Clinton these days. He wandered back to the reporters' section of his darkened plane on Tuesday night, trying to direct the talk to safe subjects, like "The Prince of Tides" or "One Hundred Years of Solitude," two of his favorite books.
But the talk inevitably turned to Mr. Perot, and a popular Perot scenario: How a Democratic House would vote if the election where thrown to the representatives? Mr. Clinton demurred. "All of this is fascinating to talk about, but it's never going to happen," he said, quiet and guarded, dodging one last Perot question for the day.

HEADLINE: Olympia Files Bankruptcy Plan For Huge London Office Project

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 27

 BODY:
Olympia & York Developments Ltd., in a sign that its desperate efforts to keep its global real estate empire intact are falling apart, tonight sought British court protection from creditors for Canary Wharf, its crown jewel and the largest office-development project in Europe.
The decision by the Canadian company to ask a British court to appoint an administrator to take control of the project in East London came after 11 banks with about 550 million ($990 million) in construction loans to the project could not agree among themselves on a plan to provide additional funds, bankers and company officials said. 
 This failure by Olympia increased the chances that it would no longer be able to hold banks and other creditors at bay in New York, where Olympia is one of the city's largest landlords. If that proves to be the case, Olympia could have to seek bankruptcy protection for its New York properties.
On May 14, Olympia and a group of its Canadian subsidiaries filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada. While the company then took similar action in the United States, the purpose was to support the Canadian filing. Its operations in the United States are not in bankruptcy proceedings. Canary Wharf was an enormous cash drain and played a big part in bringing the Olympia empire to its knees.
 
Olympia Issues Statement
 In a statement, Olympia said it had decided to file for court protection for Canary Wharf to give it more time to try to work out a plan with its 100 or so bankers to reorganize the whole company and to protect Canary Wharf from anyone trying to seize its assets.
Olympia officials said earlier this month that Canary Wharf had about 1.15 billion ($2.07 billion) in debts.
The flagship of what is one of the world's most ambitious urban regeneration programs, Canary Wharf is less than half-finished. It currently includes about 4.6 million square feet of office space -- the vast majority of which is completed or in an advance stage of construction. The completed buildings include an 812-foot tower, Britain's tallest building.
Canary Wharf represents the dream of Olympia's owners, the Reichmann family, to build a third business district in London -- one that would rival the West End and the venerable City. The Reichmanns' decision to go ahead was a coup for Margaret Thatcher, who was then Britain's Prime Minister. She was the champion of the effort to rejuvenate the derelict docks on the Thames, where Canary Wharf is situated, and enticed developers with generous tax breaks and the promise of vast Government expenditures on the area.
But Canary Wharf fell victim to the longest recession to hit Britain since the 1930's, which has caused London's vacancy rate to soar and office rents to plunge. Today, only 60 percent of the development's 4.6 million square feet is occupied or committed.
Olympia has had particular difficulty in persuading British companies to take a chance on the development, which is reflected by the American companies that dominate its list of tenants.
Tenants include Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns, Ogilvy & Mather, the International Wheat Council, the International Sugar Organization, State Street Bank, KPMG Peat Marwick, CNA Reinsurance and Telegraph, the publisher of Britain's largest broadsheet daily newspaper.
Canary Wharf also has commitments from American Express, Texaco, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lehman Brothers International and Credit Suisse First Boston.
 
Possible Unraveling
 There is the possibility that the project will further unravel if some of its major tenants decide to abandon it now that its owner is insolvent. By filing for court protection, Olympia & York will have defaulted on virtually all the major leases of the project, and that will give tenants the right to jump ship. American Express, which has leased about 300,000 square feet at Canary Wharf, has indicated that if the project was put into administration the company would move to another site.
The project has been living hand to mouth for several months. On May 8, the 11 banks agreed to provide it with 21 million ($37.8 million), most of which was needed to complete work so tenants with leases could move in. But without additional funds, construction would have stopped at the end of the month.
The Canary Wharf debts include construction loans, which are backed by Canary Wharf buildings; 100 million ($180 million) from the European Investment Bank, a European Community institution, and 500 million ($900 million) covered by the Canadian bankruptcy filing. The latter, which come from a small group of banks including Canadian Imperial, Royal Bank of Canada and the Bank of Nova Scotia, are backed only by guarantees from Olympia itself.
Olympia missed a 40 million ($72 million) payment to the British Government that was due at the end of March. It was supposed to be the first installment in the 400 million ($720 million) that Olympia had agreed to contribute to the 1.7 billion ($3.06 billion) cost of building a subway line that would go through Canary Wharf.
Olympia officials had said earlier that they were seeking 300 million ($540 million) for Canary Wharf from bankers as part of the long-term plan that they had presented to their 100 or so bankers to bring their empire out of its financial crisis. In return, Olympia had offered the 11 banks up to a 30 percent equity stake in the existing phase of the project, an offer that got a chilly response from several banks.
The Financial Times reported today that Olympia had raised the request to the banks to 500 million ($900 million). It could not be confirmed tonight whether that report was accurate.
Whatever the case, a substantial number of the 11 banks -- six or seven, according to one banker -- said they were against continuing to finance the project. The 11 include Barclays, Lloyds Bank, Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover, several Canadian banks, Credit Suisse, Hongkong and Shanghai Banking and Credit Lyonnais.
In the end, the banks decided unanimously to recommend that the project be put into administration. This is a form of bankruptcy that gives the project much more chance of it emerging from bankruptcy under Olympia's control than receivership, which the banks could have demanded.
One banker who insisted on anonymity stressed that "it's not the end of the line" because the situation would give the banks more time to try to agree on a plan for the project. "It does provide a breathing space to try to find a way forward for the company as a going concern," the banker said.
 
Added Funds Approved
 A spokeswoman for Lloyds Bank P.L.C., said tonight that the banks had agreed to provide the court-appointed administrators with additional funds for Canary Wharf, but did not know the amount. Lloyds and Barclays Bank P.L.C., another large British bank, have been co-heads of the bank committee negotiating with Olympia over Canary Wharf. The administrators will be two partners of Ernst & Young, the accounting firm.
One banker who insisted on anonymity stressed that "it's not the end of the line" because the situation would give the banks more time to try to agree on a plan for the project. "It does provide a breathing space to try to find a way forward for the company as a going concern," the banker said.
Bankers are eagerly waiting to find out if the British Government picks Canary Wharf for office space for several thousand civil servants. The Government is looking for up to 500,000 square feet of office space but has vowed that it would not bail out Canary Wharf and would agree only to competitive rents.
An executive involved in the Canary Wharf negotiations said one factor that precipitated the decision to seek court protection was that the Government refused to assure the banks that it would move several thousand employees into Canary Wharf.
In a statement issued tonight, Olympia officials insisted that they still hoped that the vast majority of the company's real estate operations in North America and Britain, including Canary Wharf, would emerge from bankruptcy intact. They said of today's filing: "The application has been made to provide a mechanism for further consideration to allow for the possibility of the reorganization of the group and to protect the assets of Olympia & York/Canary Wharf Group."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International

HEADLINE: Racetracks Search Out New Group Of Bettors

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 26

 BODY:
The horse players are back on stage in the Broadway revival of "Guys and Dolls," singing of a "horse right here -- the name is Paul Revere," waving their racing forms and touting their picks. But unless current trends are reversed, the scene may mean almost nothing to audiences at future revivals.
That's because the generation of bettors who regularly visit tracks, who follow the progress of horses the way others do batting averages and who would not be caught dead in an Off-Track Betting parlor is aging, and track operators say too few young horse players are showing up to take their places along the rail. 
 Leonard M. Cohen of Scotch Plains, N.J., a 71-year-old retired engineer who has been visiting New York tracks for 45 years, said the number of familiar faces was decreasing. "The old people are dying out, and they aren't attracting enough young people," he said. "The track operators haven't found the right combination."
Increased competition for the gambling dollar and a generation weaned on the instant thrills of video games is proving a tough market for a sport that offers a minute-long race every half hour.
Despite an increase in the number of racing days over the last two decades, attendance and the amount of money placed on bets have been slipping in the metropolitan area and across the nation.
Figures from the New Jersey Racing Commission show that 5.6 million people went to the state tracks for 852 racing dates in 1989, compared to 7.2 million people for 733 racing dates in 1985. Nationally, the average amount of money bet on racing each day fell by 48 percent between 1970 and 1988, said Richard K. Thalheimer, an associate professor at the University of Louisville's School of Business and the president of an economic research company.
 
Luring Young People
 At the American Horse Council's annual convention in Washington last June, Robert E. Mulcahy, president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, said that the industry was being hurt by its failure to compete successfully with the proliferation of other gambling and entertainment opportunities.
"Without a concerted national campaign, in my opinion, horse racing, save for a handful of events of national interest, may cease to exist as an American entertainment form," he said.
Tracks have been sinking more money into purses to attract better horses and knowledgeable horse players, while adding giveaways, free rock concerts and family-day promotions to bring the uninitiated through the turnstiles.
The Meadowlands track here, in an effort to attract what marketing analysts call the "unlaunched generation," young people who are working but who still live with their parents because of an expensive housing market, has added a sports bar and, through a direct-mail campaign that has met with some success, offers free tickets to concerts and sporting events.
"I have this theory that some people have an innate gambling gene, and if we can give them an excuse to come out and see what a wonderful entertainment experience horse racing is, they'll come back," said Allen Gutterman, vice president for marketing of the New York Racing Association.
Jim Settembre of Lake Worth, Fla., said, "The tracks are trying to attract families by putting in such things as playgrounds, but that's like putting a Band-Aid on a heart attack."
He recalls his parents' taking him against his will to Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J., on a rainy Memorial Day more than 20 years ago, an event that began his lifelong love affair with racing. Now, Mr. Settembre says, "I'm 41, and when I go to the track I feel like a kid when I look around at the other patrons."
His analysis of the problem is one shared by Mr. Gutterman and other experts: There is too much competition, including casinos and lotteries, for the amount of money to be wagered.
"You can't throw a rock down here without hitting some gambling establishment," Mr. Settembre said, "and jai alai frontons and dog tracks have recently started taking bets on horse races, which generates some dollars for racing but doesn't bring people to the tracks."
Professor Thalheimer of the University of Louisville studied the impact of intertrack wagering -- betting at a host track on races being staged at another New Jersey track -- and other forms of gambling on horse racing in New Jersey between 1960 and 1988. Professor Thalheimer decided to follow trends in New Jersey because it is the only state that allows gambling at the tracks, in the casinos and on the lottery.
He concluded that when New Jersey became the first state to offer intertrack wagering in 1983, that helped offset some of the adverse impact on racing from casinos and the lottery. In 1988, he found, the "handle," the amount wagered, dropped 29 percent for thoroughbred racing and 35 percent for harness racing. Without intertrack wagering, the Thalheimer report said, the handle for both types of racing would have dropped 51 percent.
Harold G. Handel, executive vice president of the New Jersey sports authority and manager of its racing programs at the Meadowlands and Monmouth Park, said that if people were reluctant to go to the track, then the races and the ability to place a bet will have to be made available to them wherever they are -- through television.
The Meadowlands track now offers televised races from other tracks on large and small screens and will spend $2 million on a new 500-seat television theater that will be able to offer the full card of races at tracks such as Belmont in New York and Laurel in Maryland.
The most dramatic change coming for bettors, according to both Mr. Gutterman and Mr. Handel, will be a system that will allow people to place bets from their living rooms as they watch races on a cable channel, with bets and winnings channeled through an account with an authorized bank.
Philadelphia Park is already using a precursor of the system that Mr. Handel said reportedly generates about $200,000 daily.

HEADLINE: American Airlines Cuts Some Fares in Half

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
American Airlines raised the stakes in the fare wars yesterday by announcing a 50 percent cut in its lowest fares less than 24 hours after Northwest Airlines offered a two-for-one summer fare. Within minutes of American's surprise announcement, most other big carriers, which matched Northwest earlier in the day, said they would also cut fares by 50 percent.
Last night, Northwest also decided to match American. "We started something others seemed to like," said Mark E. Abels, Northwest's vice president for corporate communications. 
 The two-for-one offer requires an adult and a child to fly on the same flight for the price of one ticket. In announcing American's plan, Michael W. Gunn, American's senior vice president for marketing, said anyone could fly for half price to any American or American Eagle destination in the 48 contiguous states. He added, "They are more than welcome to bring the children, but it is not required."
While most industry officials had expected American to match Northwest, its unexpected response amounted to a warning to rival carriers not to tinker with the simplified fare structure American introduced on April 9.
Through June 5, passengers can buy tickets for travel in the 48 states through Sept. 13 at 50 percent off the airlines' lowest advance purchase fare. While the current lowest fare requires a 14-day advance purchase, the new one requires only a seven-day advance. All the advance-purchase fares require a Saturday night stayover and are nonrefundable, though flights can be rescheduled for a $25 fee.
Thus, the lowest advance purchase round trip fare between New York and Los Angeles is now $200, compared with $400 -- on a 14-day advance purchase -- yesterday. Between Miami and Chicago, the lowest round trip fare drops to $145 from $290. Between Boston and San Francisco, it drops to $165 from $330.
While the new fares were not put into reservations computers before last evening, there were already indications the public may respond: After Northwest's two-for-one fare, airline ticket offices and telephone lines were far busier yesterday than at any time in recent weeks.
United Airlines, which matched Northwest's two-for-one fare on Tuesday night, reported that business was strong most of yesterday. At midafternoon, Northwest said it was so busy with telephone calls that despite its having added extra reservations agents, as many as 400 calls were on hold much of the day.
That surge of interest appears to bear out the belief of Northwest officials that something needed to be done to stimulate leisure travel, which has lagged behind industry expectations.
A big reason, apparently, is that leisure travelers considered fares too high in a sluggish economy. Full- coach fares were lowered an average of 38 percent under last month's restructuring, and first-class fares were lowered 20 to 50 percent, but advance-purchase fares were cut less than 10 percent on average and were even raised on some routes.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Edge Upward

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading yesterday, as dealers and investors cautiously began to buy securities following sharp declines in the previous two sessions.
A Government report showing a 1.4 percent increase in new orders for durable goods during April was stronger than anticipated, and traders sold notes and bonds immediately after the report was released. 
 On closer inspection, however, the data showed that excluding big gains in defense and transportation, the gains were quite modest. Moreover, unfilled orders, a leading indicator of business activity, fell for the eighth straight month, to the lowest level since August 1989.
"The level of shipments continues to exceed the level of new orders, so the manufacturing sector continues to run down its order backlog," said Charles Lieberman, a managing director at Chemical Securities Inc.
"As long as that happens, there will not be big gains in production. This report reinforces what has been the case: the manufacturing sector is not primed for a rebound."
Traders said the market was showing a somewhat firmer tone, and noted that an absence of new Treasury note and bond issues should favor higher prices over the next month.
"We are not going to see any new Treasury supply until June 23," one government bond trader said. "The absence of new paper should do the market some good, even though the economy looks like it has improved somewhat."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 5/32 , up 6/32 , to yield 7.89 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Tuesday.
 
Outstanding Note Issues
 Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year securities were offered at 100 18/32 , up 5/32 , to yield 7.41 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes auctioned last week were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 5.25 percent, compared with 5.32 percent late Tuesday.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.69 percent, down four basis points, or four one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by seven basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.81 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.02 percent.
At a Treasury auction of 15-day cash management bills, the securities were sold at an average discount rate of 3.77 percent.
States and municipalities issued new tax-exempt securities at a rapid rate, as more than $1.7 billion worth of new issues were priced.
The largest competitive offering was a $256 million issue from the District of Columbia.
A bid from a group led by J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. won the bonds.
The securities were reoffered to investors with yields on serial bonds from 3.25 percent in 1993 to 6.55 percent in 2010.
A term bond maturing in 2012 was priced to yield 6.60 percent.
The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, and is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
New-issue activity in the corporate bond market was very light.
Late Tuesday Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company acted as the sole underwriter of a $550 million three-part issue of first-mortgage bonds for Old Dominion Electric Cooperative.
The bulk of the issue consisted of $350 million worth of 30-year bonds. These 8.76 percent securities were priced at $100, or par. They are non-callable for 10 years.
The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted securities slipped by about 1/8 point.
Meanwhile, prices of outstanding investment-grade corporate bonds were mostly unchanged, according to market participants.

HEADLINE: In Hudson, 2 Democrats In Spotlight

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION CITY, N.J., May 27

 BODY:
In an area where winning the Democratic primary has been tantamount to winning the general election, next week's primary in the 13th Congressional District has attracted one candidate bidding to become New Jersey's first Hispanic Representative and another bent on dismantling a Hudson County political machine that once had national prominence.
The Democratic incumbent, 67-year-old Frank J. Guarini, is retiring after 14 years in office, and his would-be Democratic successors are Robert Menendez, a lawyer, state Senator and the Mayor of Union City, and Robert Haney of Jersey City, a 35-year-old corporate lawyer with a Manhattan law firm. 
 The Republican candidate, Fred J. Theemling Jr. of Weehawken, is running unopposed. Mr. Theemling, also a lawyer, lost to Mr. Guarini in 1988 and 1990 and is given little chance of succeeding this year.
The emergence of Mr. Menendez and Mr. Haney as leading political contenders says as much about changes in the area as it does about redistricting, which divided the old 14th District Mr. Guarini had represented.
 
Career in Office
 At 38, Mr. Menendez has spent nearly half his life in elective offices. His public career has been nourished by the ascendancy of the Hispanic community in the political and economic life of Hudson County.
At age 20, two years after he finished high school, Mr. Menendez was elected to the Union City school board. He was elected Mayor in 1986, voted into the State Assembly the following year and in 1991 became the New Jersey Senate's only Hispanic member.
"What we are offering is the proven track record," Mr. Menendez said today after taping a debate with Mr. Haney at the studios of Riverview Cable in Union City. The debate is to be broadcast on Saturday night. "Bob Haney would take what is something positive in all our lives, experience, and try to make that a negative."
Mr. Haney has never held elective office and lost to Mr. Guarini in the 1988 Democratic primary. With a background in community service, he has campaigned almost exclusively by attacking the remnants of the Hudson County political machine and trying to link Mr. Menendez with the ham-fisted style it embodied.
 
Fight for Control
 "Mr. Menendez is basically a person who worked his way through the machine and then took it over," said Mr. Haney. "There's an undue awe for the machine. People think it can't be beat."
The patchwork of communities that make up the new 13th District is 43 percent Hispanic, and that has made Mr. Menendez, a son of Cuban immigrants, the favorite.
Behind the Democratic primary race is an even hotter fight over control of local politics.
Mr. Menendez has the backing of scores of the district's most influential politicians, including Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and the state Democratic Party chairman, Senator Raymond J. Lesniak of Elizabeth.
Mr. Haney has emerged as a favorite-son candidate among Jersey City politicians, picking up the backing of the acting Mayor, Marilyn Roman; City Councilman Jaime Vazquez; the city's Democratic chairman, Allen Manzo, and the Essex County Democratic chairman, Raymond Durkin.
The last time this area sent a Republican to Congress was on the coattails of Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952, and after taking office, the new Representative promptly announced that he was switching to the Democratic Party.
The district is still heavily Democratic, though the once-vaunted Hudson County Democratic machine has been wrecked by the criminal convictions of some of its major power brokers, infighting over dwindling political spoils and now new boundaries that divide the political fiefdom.
 
Loss of a District
 The new lines were necessary because of a population shift in which New Jersey lost one of its 14 Congressional Districts.
Mr. Guarini's old 14th District was confined to Hudson County. With Jersey City, the state's second-largest city, as its base, the Hudson County Democratic Party was a juggernaut. It produced such storied politicians as Frank Hague, who during a mayoral tenure that ran from 1917 to 1949 once proclaimed, "I am the law."
The new 13th District includes only part of Jersey City and extends into Newark, in Essex County, and sections of Union and Middlesex counties.

HEADLINE: Stocks Strengthen, With Dow Up by 6.23

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market staged a small upswing yesterday, as traders reappraised the outlook for oil prices. Fear of inflation's being unleashed by higher oil prices caused stocks to tumble on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 6.23 points yesterday, to 3,370.44, after falling 22.56 points on Tuesday. 
 Advancing issues held a narrow edge on declines at the New York Stock Exchange.
Volume on the Big Board came to an estimated 182.2 million shares as of 4 P.M., against 197.7 million at the same point Tuesday.
The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks rose 1.70, to 577.35. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down o.04 at 391.85.
Analysts said investors seemed to be taking a less emphatic view yesterday of the oil situation. A report that Saudi Arabia, a pivotal force in world energy markets, had shifted its oil strategy to encourage higher prices, which, in turn, could impede the nascent economic recovery, led to Tuesday's market slide.
 
Retreat in Energy Stocks
 Energy stocks, however, surged on Tuesday, only to give up some of those gains yesterday. Among the international oils, Exxon fell 2 1/4, to 61 3/4; Amoco 1 5/8, to 49 7/8; Chevron 1 5/8, to 71; Texaco 2 1/8, to 64 5/8, and Mobil 1 5/8, to 65 3/8.
In the oilfield service and drilling group, Schlumberger slipped 1 1/4, to 67 1/4; Baker Hughes 1/4, to 23 1/2, and Halliburton 7/8, to 29.
As components of the Dow Jones industrial average, Chevron, Exxon and Texaco limited the average's gain yesterday after having significantly reduced the size of its loss the day before.
In the economic news, the Commerce Department reported that new factory orders for durable goods took a bigger-than-expected 1.4 percent jump in April.
Interest rates rode out that sign of economic strength to post moderate declines. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds stood late in the day at about 7.90 percent.
Syntex led the active list, down 3 1/2 at 37 5/8 on turnover of more than 5.7 million shares. Late Tuesday the company posted flat operating earnings for its latest fiscal quarter.
Philip Morris gained 1, to 75 3/8. The company announced a new $3 billion round of stock repurchases.
Control Data rose 1 5/8, to 13 3/8. The company said it planned to divide itself into two separate entities embracing its computer products business and the remainder of its operations, which will come under the name Ceridian Corporation.

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Rise 1.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
New orders for long-lasting factory goods rose 1.4 percent in April, the fourth straight monthly advance, the Commerce Department reported today.
The continued climb helped allay lingering fears that the sluggish economic recovery will abort. But analysts found little to encourage a belief that the pace of the recovery will be picking up substantially. Indeed, the backlog of unfilled orders for durable goods -- a component of the department's forecasting index -- declined for the eighth straight month. 
 "I don't think they are as good as they look on the surface," Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said of today's figures. "They look much weaker," he added, citing in particular the decline, albeit a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, in the level of unfilled orders to its lowest point since August 1989.
Another widely watched item, orders for capital goods, fell 6.8 percent with military equipment excluded and 2.6 percent with military equipment and commercial aircraft excluded.
The quarterly survey of members by the National Association of Business Economists, meanwhile, showed somewhat more optimism about the economy in late April and early May than the previous survey taken in late January and early February. The 44-member panel predicted that national output would rise at an annual rate of 2.6 percent in the second quarter, up from 2.1 percent projected in the late-winter poll.
And while the probability of another recession setting in by the end of the year was put at less than 1 in 5, the association said the recovery's pace would "remain subdued."
The report on durable goods, items ranging from air-conditioners to jetliners and designed to last at least three years, registered a $1.9 billion increase for transportation equipment alone. This was slightly more than the $1.8 billion increase in overall orders for durable goods, to $125.4 billion.
"The prognosis must remain guarded for the time being, due to the weakness in the nondefense capital goods sector," said Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. "This suggests that business is waiting for more decisive signs of recovery before undertaking significant new increases in equipment investment."
Orders for transportation equipment rose 6.1 percent, to $34.1 billion, while orders in primary metals rose 2.8 percent, to $10.7 billion, the report showed. But these were largely offset by declines of 2 percent, to $40.3 billion, for capital goods; 1.9 percent, to $21 billion, for industrial machinery and equipment, and three-tenths of 1 percent, to $17.3 billion, for electronic and other electrical equipment.
The military component of capital goods jumped 21.6 percent, to $8.5 billion, a level 11.3 percent more that of April 1991.
The overall 1.4 percent rise in durable goods followed increases of 2.3 percent in March, two-tenths of 1 percent in February and 2.4 percent in January. The March gain was initially reported as 1.6 percent.
Michael P. Daly, economist for the Cigna Corporation, noted that durable-goods figures tend to swing widely from month to month and said today's report did not alter his expectation for sustained but lackluster recovery.
"A pickup in capital spending is still lacking," he said.
Among unfilled orders, or backlogs, a small increase for transportation was more than offset by declines for all other major groups, the biggest being a 1 percent decline for industrial machinery and equipment. Primary metals group, the Commerce Department noted, has now fallen for seven of the last eight months.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Plans Payout In Deposit Insurance Crisis

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
It has been a long time in coming, but with yesterday's sale of $306 million of bonds by Rhode Island, nearly 40,000 victims of the state's banking debacle should soon recover most, but not all, of their deposits.
The deposits were frozen on New Year's Day 1991 after the collapse of the private insurance company covering deposits at 45 credit unions and bank-like loan companies in the state. 
 The collapse of the Rhode Island insurer, which touched off a deposit run and the collapse a week later of the Bank of New England in neighboring Massachusetts, affected about 250,000 accounts with $1.7 billion.
In a state of two million people, the freeze was a serious blow to the economy and a major challenge to state officials, who felt a need to protect depositors but were required by law to keep the budget in balance.
Although the state did not own or back the failed deposit insurance company -- the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation -- "it was decided that the state had a moral obligation to protect depositors," said Barbara Cottom, a spokeswoman for Gov. Bruce Sundlun.
She noted that the name of the insurance company and the advertising of local institutions created an appearance of state backing.
Unlike the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which generally pays insured deposits within days of closing a failed bank, Rhode Island's financial limitations have required it to move more slowly in paying depositors.
Treatment of Rhode Island depositors has varied widely, with some regaining full access to their funds within a few weeks or months because their credit union or loan company was solvent and was eligible for Federal deposit insurance. Others have had to wait for a merger, or are still waiting.
The delay in payments was needed for the state to create a special corporation called the Rhode Island Depositors Economic Protection Corporation, or Depco, which could raise money for depositors by selling bonds. To provide Depco with money to repay the bonds, the state raised the sales tax to 7 percent from 6 percent, with six-tenths of 1 percent, or $31.8 million in 1992, earmarked for Depco.
A year ago, depositors with less than $4,000 were repaid in full with money from a $150 million bond sale. But even after those payments and the shift of solvent institutions to credit unions, there are 38,600 customers at seven institutions who still do not have access to their funds and have not been earning interest since their institutions were closed. Although the state has allowed some deposit withdrawals in hardship cases, there is still $535 million frozen and unavailable.
 
Payments on June 30
 According to the state's plan, 90 percent of every deposit over $4,000 will be paid with checks to be issued on June 30. The money will come from a $306 million bond sale arranged by Depco yesterday, and a smaller sale of different bonds totaling about $150 million to be arranged next month. The remaining 10 percent will be paid in 15 annual installments beginning in 1998.
Michael V. Frazier, deputy director of Depco, said yesterday that while they were waiting for their remaining 10 percent, depositors would earn 5 percent annual interest, a better rate than is available on short-term bank certificates of deposit or money market accounts.
 
Money From Other Sources
 The money for the last 10 percent of depositors' funds will come from assets of failed institutions that Depco is selling, money collected from insurance companies or lawsuits, and Depco's share of sales tax receipts that exceed what it needs to pay interest and principal on bonds it issued.
Yesterday's bonds were offered through securities firms led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. The bonds have yields as high as 6.75 percent for triple-A rated bonds due in 2019 and insured by Financial Surety Assurance, and 6.95 percent for uninsured bonds rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Although Depco's bonds are not guaranteed by the state, they are backed by the Legislature's promise to appropriate to Depco each year its share of the sales tax revenues.
 
Unusual Sale Ahead
 The next bond sale by Depco promises to be more unusual than yesterday's.
Under one scenario, the corporation could take advantage of an amendment to last year's Federal banking bill that would allow for the sale of up to $180 million of bonds whose interest would be taxable, but which would be guaranteed by the Treasury.
The amendment, which was sponsored by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, would require Depco to pledge various assets, and any surplus from its share of the sales tax, and pay a fee of up to one-half percent of the loan.
Alternatively, Depco could sell bonds backed by assets it holds from failed credit unions and others.
Depco has hired Kidder, Peabody & Company to devise the best structure for the coming bond sale. It is paying Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, $1.8 million to evaluate the 6,000 individual loans or pieces of real estate that were valued on the books of the failed institutions at $500 million, but are worth much less.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Control Data to Separate Into Two Companies

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 27

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation, which has not turned a profit since 1988, said today that it would split into two independent companies and take charges of some $400 million in the second quarter as a result of the split and other restructuring costs.
After the split, Control Data's computer business will be called Control Data Systems Inc., while the company's various information service businesses will be known as the Ceridian Corporation. The information services include the Arbitron Company audience-measurement business, payroll management services, computer network services and computer systems management for government clients worldwide. 
 In a related move, Silicon Graphics Inc. said it intended to make a 10 percent investment in Control Data, which primarily resells work stations and servers manufactured by Silicon Graphics. The NEC Corporation, which sells its supercomputers in the United States through Control Data, said it was considering taking a 5 percent stake in Control Data Systems.
Control Data shares closed today at $13.375, up $1.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Company executives said they hoped the split would make it easier for securities analysts to understand each independent company, and in turn help the companies raise capital.
 
A Slow Decline
 The split comes after Control Data's sale or closing of nearly 20 businesses in recent years, including supercomputers, disk drives and lottery management. The move marks Control Data's latest effort to restructure the company. For 1991, it reported a loss of $9.8 million on revenues of $1.52 billion.
Founded in 1957 by William C. Norris, Control Data helped make Minneapolis a center of high technology, and led to the spinoff or creation of more than 100 other companies, including Cray Research Inc., the Zytec Corporation and Northern Telecom. The company was also a leader in its support of innovative social programs, like leasing automobiles to ex-convicts. But Control Data foundered in the mid-1980's because of uncompetitive products and unfocused management.
 
Growth Opportunity Is Seen
 Unlike previous sales and restructurings, which were aimed at merely surviving, the split offers Control Data an opportunity to grow for the first time in 10 years, said Lawrence Perlman, who has been Control Data's president and chief executive since 1990. Mr. Perlman will hold those same positions for Ceridian, which he said comprised operations that had 1991 revenues of $900 million and would have been profitable as a stand-alone company.
"Everything else we've done has been to raise cash or get rid of losing operations," Mr. Perlman said in a telephone interview.
"Here, we're able to do something which will strengthen the entity," he said. "We expect the separation to provide each company with increased flexibility and the ability to pursue cooperative ventures, business combinations and other actions to grow and improve their competitive positions."
Spinning off the computer business returns Control Data to its roots, said James E. Ousley, who has headed that business for three years and will be president and chief executive of Control Data Systems.
He noted that Control Data would be the last of the so-called BUNCH companies -- Burroughs, Univac, National Cash Register, Control Data and Honeywell -- to remain an independent computer manufacturer.
Before the split, "there wasn't enough energy or financial wherewithal to really focus on the computer business," Mr. Ousley said in a telephone interview. "We are spinning out as a healthy company, with a very clean balance sheet," including $95 million in capital from Control Data, and no debt, he said.
The computer business had 1991 revenues of about $570 million, or 35 percent of the corporate total, he said, but did not have operating profits last year.
 
Attracting Investors
 Mr. Ousley said that the investments from Silicon Graphics and NEC validated the decision to split the company. As part of a conglomerate, Control Data's computer business was unable to attract such investments, he said.
Silicon Graphics has served as a supplier to Control Data since 1986, providing the company with work stations and file servers for resale. Control Data has had a similar arrangement with MIPS since 1989; Silicon Graphics is in the process of acquiring MIPS.
"Control Data and Silicon Graphics have had a very strong relationship for five or six years now," said John Kohler, vice president and general manager of Silicon Graphics' business systems division.
"Unlike a traditional buy-sell arrangement, this is an opportunity for us to get involved and help them out," he said, noting that Control Data was an investor in Silicon Graphics in its fledgling days.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Gains; Gold Slips in U.S. Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose broadly in active trading on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices settled marginally lower after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338 a troy ounce, off 20 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 30 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $337.55. 
 The dollar firmed in technical trading overseas and continued to advance when activity shifted to domestic markets. A Government report showing a larger-than-expected increase in new orders for durable goods propelled the dollar higher.
The Commerce Department said orders for "big ticket" manufactured goods rose 1.4 percent in April, far larger than the two-tenths of 1 percent increase many economists had been expecting.
"The psychology has changed now," said Randolph Donney, research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "People are thinking that the Fed won't ease, that maybe the economy really does have the legs to get going."
The dollar had been forced lower by expectations that the Federal Reserve would trim interest rates to stimulate the economic recovery. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, thereby decreasing demand for dollars.
Trading was active throughout the session. In Europe, many traders were squaring up their positions ahead of today's Ascension Day holiday. Analysts said they expected many dealers to be absent tomorrow as well.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.78 Japanese yen, from 129.15 yen on Tuesday. Later in London, it rose to 129.90 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 130.20 yen, up from 129.45 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8010, from $1.8280 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.7950 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.8250.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Down in the Latest Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down in the latest week.
In the period ended Monday, yields on tax-exempt money funds were down for the third time in a month. Analysts at Donoghue's said the reasons for the decline were still tied to supply. As the yield spread between taxable and tax-exempt funds continues to narrow, the tax-free funds become relatively more attractive and demand increases, driving prices higher and yields lower. 
 "In fact," said Walter E. Frank, chief economist for Donoghue's, "all short-term yields have been coming down since the Fed easing in April. But I suspect money fund yields are bottoming, with yields moving in a narrow range through the summer at least."
The seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund fell 5 basis points, to 3.03 percent, while the simple yield dropped 4 basis points, to 2.99 percent -- less than 3 percent for the second time this year. In the same period, the lagging 30-day compounded average yield and simple yield both dropped by a basis point, to 3.13 percent and 3.08 percent, respectively. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts at Donoghue's said the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios remained unchanged at 52.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 4.20 percent, while the equivalent for those in the 31 percent tax bracket is 4.39 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said the Fidelity Spartan Municipal Money Fund offered the best return, 3.86 percent, for the second consecutive week, though it was down 11 basis points. The fund's distributor is the Fidelity Distributors Corporation.
 
Taxable Funds
 In tracking the taxable funds for the week, Donoghue's reported assets declined $625 million, to $492.8 billion. Institutional assets grew $170 million, to $166 billion, while retail assets declined $795 million, to $326.8 billion.
The average seven-day taxable compounded and simple yields both fell 4 basis points, to 3.53 percent and 3.47 percent, respectively. For the 30-day compounded average, the yield was 3.58 percent, down 3 basis points, with the simple yield down 2 basis points, to 3.52 percent.
The Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series maintained its hold as the best performer with a return of 4.31 percent, 10 basis points off its pace a week ago. The fund is distributed by the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of the money funds, is at 3.42 percent.

HEADLINE: Electronics Job Losses

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., May 27

 BODY:
The United States electronics industry, which has been shrinking for nearly three years, lost 40,000 jobs in the first quarter, the American Electronics Association said today.
Total employment in the industry fell to 2.35 million in the period, compared with 2.39 million in the fourth quarter of 1991, the trade group said. 
 Employment in electronics peaked at 2.6 million in August 1989; the industry lost 90,000 jobs in 1991.
Job losses were proportionally highest in the semiconductor segment, which lost 4.1 percent of its positions in the quarter, shrinking to 219,400 from 224,600. Employment in the computer industry fell 1.3 percent, to 403,100, while the software sector was flat at 133,400.
