HEADLINE: With Films Scarce, New York Still Feels Impact of Boycott

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
The idea was a winner: a romantic New York comedy, starring Michael J. Fox, that would recall gems like "Breakfast at Tiffany's," "The Apartment" and "Barefoot in the Park." In the eyes of Universal Pictures, there could be only one location to make such a latter-day New York comedy. Toronto.
"In my first meeting with Universal, I was told it's impossible to shoot in New York," said Barry Sonnenfeld, director of the film, which is as yet untitled. "I said, 'I've worked on lots of films in New York.' They said, 'Well, you haven't been there in a few years. It's changed.' " 
 For film makers, the message is clear: if you want New York, you're going to have to fight for it.
A year and a half after a boycott by the Hollywood studios shut down major filming in New York, the city is struggling to recover its luster as a location for feature films, even as it experiences a continuing decline as a production center for television series and commercials.
Mr. Sonnenfeld won his battle. His comedy is now being made on the streets of Manhattan, but only because the director, fresh from the hugely successful "Addams Family," threatened to pull out of the project and the film's budget was pared to a near-Toronto level.
 
Search for a New Director
 In this uncertain climate, the search for a new director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, a post left vacant last month when Jaynne C. Keyes left to take a job at the William Morris agency, has taken on special urgency. The city's battered film industry, valued in the billions, is looking at the appointment as a test of the city government's commitment to New York as an entertainment capital.
Anxiety is high. "This is starting to matter," said Alan S. Gordon, eastern executive secretary of the Directors Guild of America. "We're seeing rank-and-file members not being able to make a living."
As of mid-May, the Mayor's film office had issued shooting permits for 23 feature films, three of them with big budgets, compared with 48 features for the same period last year. (A more telling figure is the actual number of shooting days, since many films shoot exteriors in New York for a few days and move elsewhere to complete the film, but the film office does not compile those totals until the end of the year.) This year's figures, which do not include several big-budget films that began in late 1991 and carried over into the early months of 1992, may improve. Nina Streich, the acting director of the film office, said there were "rumblings of significant activity later this summer."
But others are not so sure. "The real state of the industry is that we've lost more than half of it, if not more, to other cities," said Martin Bregman, the producer of "Serpico" and "Sea of Love." "And once they go to other cities, they don't come back."
 
Just One TV Series Left
 The signs of malaise extend well beyond feature films. The city has experienced a long-term decline as a production center for television series. With "The Cosby Show" now off the air, NBC's "Law and Order" is the sole remaining network television series filmed in New York.
The city's hopes for a substantial new television project were dashed last month when Universal Pictures and the city's unions failed to reach agreement on a contract that would bring a potential new series, "Crime and Punishment," to New York.
Opinion in the industry is divided on whether the negotiations should be interpreted as a test case of the climate for television filming in New York, but there is no question that they were closely watched by Hollywood.
"I think it's a setback for New York, a terrible thing," said Jeffrey Hayes, a co-producer of "Law and Order." "I hire 150 people 10 months of the year for 'Law and Order.' That's a lot of work, and it's year after year."
The unions and Universal are close to a final agreement on a new, less expensive contract for "Law and Order," but the series could still leave the city. "The show has been picked up for 22 weeks," said Mr. Hayes. "The fear is that if it's renewed for 44 weeks, they'll do it anywhere."
The least glamorous segment of the business, television commercials, once provided steady work for the union rank and file in New York. But the business and the directors have drifted west to California over the last five years. In 1989, for the first time more than 50 percent of all commercials were filmed in Califonia. Last year the figure was 65 percent.
 
Sales, Not Production
 "New York has become a sales base rather than a production base," said Morton Dubin, the president of Iris Films, which produces television commercials. "There are lots of companies, but they're sales offices. I have done one shoot in New York in six months. I would love to shoot here, but I have not got a single director living in New York."
The decline in filming has begun to take a toll on the dozens of ancillary businesses that depend on filming for all or part of their livelihood. TVC Precision, one of the city's three largest film-processing laboratories, recently ceased operations, and Camera Mart, an equipment rental business, sold off part of its operations to keep afloat.
"We probably work on more major motion pictures than any other rental facility in New York, and we're off the mark by 30 to 40 percent," said Mary LeStrange, vice president for sales and marketing of General Camera. "The commercial business is painfully slow. Anyone who says their business isn't hurting is lying."
The city's film producers, union leaders and industry groups are are therefore watching developments at the film office closely. A search subcommittee drawn from the Mayor's Advisory Committee on Film and Television, a volunteer group, is now reviewing applications for the job, although it can only advise. It is looking at about 16 candidates, said Ms. Keyes, a member of the subcommittee, and will pare that number to four this week. A press spokesman for Mr. Sullivan's office said a final decision on the appointment would be made in about a month.
 
Politicking Feared
 Many film-industry representatives say they worry that the job will be treated as a political plum for what Mr. Gordon called "an administrative or public relations type." Although Mr. Gordon declined to name specific people, several others in the industry have mentioned Jeanne P. Nathan, director of public affairs for the city's Housing Authority, whose name has come up often as a potential candidate for the film office.
There is strong sentiment in the industry for both Nancy Littlefield, who served as director of the film office from 1979 to 1983, and Grace Blake, a producer and the president of New York Women in Film, who has said she does not want the job.
Ms. Streich, the acting director, has her resume on the table, and Ms. Keyes, who as a former director of the film office has powerful allies in the city government, has put forward the names of Caitlin Buchman, the head of Film Strategies, a Los Angeles consulting company, and Belinda Breese, the vice president of East Coast publicity Universal.
What the film industry appears to want is a double or even triple threat. The ideal candidate should have enough experience to wheel and deal with the studios: "Not just somebody who can beat a tomtom, but somebody who can make a deal," said Frank Stiefel, president of the East Coast chapter of the Association of Independent Commercial Producers. The art of the deal might mean delivering a block of Manhattan hotel rooms at cut rates, or sitting down with the head of Columbia Pictures to steer "Lost in Yonkers" to Yonkers. At present, the film is scheduled to be made in Cincinnati and Los Angeles.
At the same time, the ideal candidate must be wise in the ways of city politics, able not only to work the city's agencies for maximum cooperation with the film industry, but also to head off political crises of the kind that threatened to shut down production of "Bonfire of the Vanities," when the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, took exception to the way his borough was being portrayed.
 
Combating a Perception
 The new head of the film office also needs to start countering the widespread perception of New York as a hellishly difficult place to make a film.
That perception, many in the local film industry say, is unfair. The city's unions may have been a major obstacle in the past, but they now have delivered concessions on salaries and overtime that make New York more competitive with other cities. The East Coast Council, created by the unions during the boycott, now negotiates bargain-rate contracts for low-budget feature films. So far, 20 films have been made in New York under this arrangement, one for as little as $350,000.
But that's not how New York is viewed from the outside "and the city is the only entity big enough to change it," said Mr. Gordon, who has mounted a campaign to persuade the city to see the local film industry, and the film office, as an economic development opportunity. "No one thinks it's foolish to go to a bank that wants to move and offer incentives," he said. "Well, the city has a lot more to offer the movie business than it does, say, the shoe business."
The city film office has a marketing budget of about $30,000, compared with $140,000 for the California Film Commission, and $100,000 for the film office of Orlando, Fla.
"To bring the business back, you have to start from scratch and woo California," said Ms. Littlefield. "A lot of cities and states are offering a great deal. The city has to recognize this and offer something."
"The Los Angeles office knows it's a business," Mr. Gordon said. "They spend what they have to, but New York doesn't have the money to tell people that it doesn't cost 20 percent more to film here."
 
Quick Response to Rioting
 As evidence of Los Angeles's sharp reflexes, a number of film industry representatives noted that after the recent riots, Mayor Tom Bradley immediately sent out a letter to 1,100 film, television and advertising executives seeking to assure them that the city remained open for business.
In the long term, New York could rebound strongly because of its natural advantages of location, talent and culture, said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Institute at New York University.
"I see hope in the globalization of the advertising business," Mr. Moss said. "New York is still a good, symbolic site for world media, and it's a center where we produce and groom talent. New York is still a mecca for learning how to act and make films." The boom in television programs that treat news as entertainment should also favor New York, he said.
Mr. Moss also pointed out that New York's film-training programs are turning out young directors and producers, like Spike Lee, who are committed to New York, and who generate images of the city that are enormously persuasive to foreign audiences.
Persuading Hollywood is the immediate problem, however, and ingrained attitudes die hard. "The studios view New York as if it's Tokyo, a foreign city," said Mr. Sonnenfeld. "They're afraid of it, of losing control of their projects."
"I think we will bring this film in on time and on budget," he said, referring to the Michael J. Fox film, "but it will make no difference to Universal."
Mr. Sonnenfeld laughed and shook his head as he recalled the comments of one disgruntled Hollywood producer, who vowed never to return to New York: "He said his feet ached all the time because the sidewalks in New York are harder than the ones in Los Angeles."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Where Have New York's Fans Gone?

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
FOUND my longies and went to the ball park the other day. No traffic backing onto the highway. No lines at the parking lot. The attendants all asked, "How are you today, sir?" They seemed lonely. Inside Shea Stadium, a cold, damp wind reminded me of how Richard Todd's passes often fluttered on dank December afternoons. The Jet fans, such as they were, huddled together for warmth.
It is all well and good to lay blame for the bad weather on Saddam Hussein for setting the oil wells on fire in Kuwait, on the Brazilians for burning their forests, on modern technology for producing acid rain. But is weather the main culprit for the Mets' attendance being down from last year by an average of 8,921 and the Yankees' attendance being down by 1,142? 
 Around the country, major league attendance is up by 0.7 percent, mainly because of the new stadium in Baltimore and the enthusiasm in Atlanta -- "the tyranny of statistics," said Commissioner Fay Vincent, noting that attendance for 15 of 26 teams is down, and that tickets unsold in April and May can never be recovered.
The fans will cite the poor national economy, and many will say they are turned off by high salaries and rising ticket prices, but I'm not sure they are making any overt statement by their absence. In the meantime, is something unattractive happening with New York baseball?
"I think it's a whole group of things," said Al Harazin, the general manager of the Mets, observing the turnstile average drop from 30,652 a year ago to 21,731 going into last night.
"First, it's the general economy of the New York area," Harazin said. "Normally, when you bring in superstars like Bobby Bonilla, Bret Saberhagen and Eddie Murray, you think ticket sales will jump. But despite all that, our season sales were off a little."
Harazin said that longtime customers were "consolidating" their plans from eight tickets to four, or dropping out because of financial problems. Don't cry for the Mets just yet. Harazin said the average tickets sold in the glory years was 3.3-3.5 million, and he fully expects to sell 3 million this year.
National League policy is to announce only the fans in attendance. From a Mets record of 3,047,724 in 1988, attendance dropped to 2,284,484 last year. Since the Mets make approximately $3 per person on concessions, they do prefer the paying fans to actually attend the games.
Why haven't the fans been coming out this year? Harazin said: "This has been the lousiest spring I remember. We haven't had one warm night yet, although we had a few warm days. Plus, our games are on television, and the Knicks and Rangers advanced and it was easy for the fans to say: 'Hey, it's a crummy night. Let's stay home and watch the Knicks.' "
Harazin is convinced the fans are not staging any kind of protest over prices, which now reach $15 for a box seat and $12 for most decent seats. Some other force is at work in Flushing, and it may be as simple as a generation-long period of mourning. "It may be that in the mid-80's we had a unique set of personalities," Harazin said. "We had somebody like Keith Hernandez. We had a young Doc Gooden. We had Strawberry, Carter, Mookie Wilson, Lenny Dykstra. As good as we might be, we may not be entitled to that kind of team again."
The same may be true in the Bronx, where the monuments behind the outfield fence and the retired numbers in the scorecard produce a maudlin sense of nostalgia. The Yankees' attendance dropped to 1,863,731 last year, the lowest since 1984, and their dip is more moderate than the Mets' because American League policy is to announce actual tickets sold, and because the Yankees had less far to fall.
Some people believe fans shy away from the south Bronx, but Vincent said that "is more of a perception problem than a reality problem."
"Yankee Stadium," he added, "is still a magical atmosphere, and the Yankees do a pretty good job there."
My own guess is that the fans have not been drawn back by the discreet charms of Andy Stankiewicz, Melido Perez and Buck Showalter.
Attendance is one thing, but the real economic crunch is going to come after next season when the networks start lopping off zeros from the current $1.46 billion, four-year contract with CBS and ESPN, and the owners realize how foolish they were with long-term player contracts. As somebody lucky enough to have a good job, I would not minimize the economic problems in the nation, but there is money kicking around for witless third-sequel $7 movies, expensive sneakers, designer haircuts, nail salons. My own guess is that if the Mets and Yankees were fashionable, the fans might be wearing long johns or they might be wearing short shorts, but they would be surging to the ball parks.

HEADLINE: The House Ducks on Energy

 BODY:
A sound energy strategy would have two key components: stiff energy taxes, to discourage unnecessary use, and large buffer stocks to protect the economy against catastrophic supply interruptions. Congress hasn't even thought about the former and, after yesterday's vote in the House to approve an energy bill, won't pay for the latter. So much for a sound policy.
Succumbing to pressure from oil companies and potential voter backlash, the House rejected by a vote of 263 to 135 an original provision of the bill to bring the Strategic Petroleum Reserve -- 600 million barrels of oil stored in caverns along the Gulf Coast in Louisiana and Texas -- up to its targeted capacity of one billion barrels. 
 The provision would have required oil importers and refiners to turn over about 1 percent of their sales, or the cash equivalent, to the reserve.
The need for a larger reserve was demonstrated after the 1990 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Oil prices doubled, pushing the economy into recession. Yet the Administration refused to squelch the price hike by releasing oil from the reserve. It said the reserve was too small. And the law permitted use of the oil only to offset shortages, not price increases. So after spending tens of billions to create the reserve, the oil lay unused as the economy shriveled.
The solution is straightforward. First, Congress needs to amend the law so that the reserve could be tapped to offset severe price increases due to supply interruptions. Second, Congress needs to come up with money to make the reserve bigger.
Proponents of the reserve devised a plan more clever and complex than it had to be. Under one option, producers could have turned over oil directly. The companies would surely have passed along the cost to consumers -- a tax hike in all but name. And this camouflage would have invited layers of wasteful regulation and bureaucrats; there are numerous grades of oil, each of which would have to be separately regulated.
Given the onerous nature of the likely regulations, most companies would probably have elected the second option -- a straight cash payment to the Government instead. The Government would then use the cash to buy oil for the reserve. But this, too, would be little more than a disguised gasoline tax -- a fine idea, but deceptively packaged and needlessly expensive.
The honest and cheaper solution would be to fill the reserve with a visible tax hike. But the defeated provision was a next-best solution. By defeating it, the House decided to protect its electoral hide by leaving America prey to the next Saddam Hussein.

LENGTH: 510 words

HEADLINE: 'Hello, 911? This Is Bosnia'

 BODY:
When there's an emergency and you call 911, says Haris Silajdzic, Foreign Minister of helpless little Bosnia, "someone must respond. Otherwise there can be no new world order." Every day brings ever grimmer evidence of the need for forceful help. Just yesterday, Serbian troops lobbed mortar shells into a bread line in Sarajevo, killing at least 16 civilians and wounding more than 100.
Thankfully, Secretary of State Baker appears ready at long last to answer Bosnia's call for help. Moved by its "humanitarian nightmare" and the test that poses for global security after the cold war, he urges the United Nations to impose mandatory economic sanctions on Slobodan Milosevic's outlaw Serbian regime. And commendably, Mr. Baker does not rule out more forceful steps if sanctions fail to stop the Serbian aggression and atrocities. 
 That begins to get at the causes of this nightmare. Mr. Baker also needs to deal urgently with its effects -- the 700,000 people already displaced by the Serbian carnage. The first way to do that is to encourage an armed U.N. escort for international relief efforts to ease their suffering.
Mr. Milosevic, a Communist parading as a Serbian nationalist, brazenly flouts U.N. calls to cease his aggression in Bosnia. Belgrade's behavior is so bloodthirsty, so criminal that it surely warrants mandatory step-by-step sanctions under Chapter 7 of the U.N. charter.
Chapter 7 is especially well chosen because it permits U.N. members to use force, as they did against Saddam Hussein, if the economic screw does not squeeze the Milosevic gang hard enough.
The U.S., after a period of odd dissembling, now has recalled its Ambassador and suspended all flights by the Yugoslav national airline. Washington needs to go beyond symbolic gestures. A U.N. arms embargo is already in effect; the U.S. could help tighten it by putting pressure on neighboring states that now wink at gun-running.
The European Community has imposed partial sanctions; but no real leverage is possible without an international cutoff of oil. That would require Greece, Romania and all of Serbia's neighbors to go along. The U.S. and others could offer to buy the oil bound for Serbia, and threaten sanctions against those who violate the embargo.
Meanwhile, an urgent short-term responsibility falls on the U.N., one it has so far failed to shoulder: to deal with the plight of desperate people driven from their homes by Serbia's appalling "ethnic cleansing" in Bosnia.
What did the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees do last week after a dozen U.N. trucks loaded with food and medicine were hijacked at gunpoint? Did he send in armed guards? No. He suspended the aid convoys, despite the Bosnians' urgent needs. The Red Cross also suspended operations after one of its relief workers was killed.
The U.S. can respond to the emergency by urging that these relief convoys be resumed under armed escort. Forceful U.N. action is needed to show that now, when small countries frantically call the police, the world will answer.

HEADLINE: Get Behind Child Health Summit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The promises, presages and imprudences of the political candidates are well presented by the media. In comparison, relatively little is available on the candidates' willingness to support the health of our children in the United States and worldwide. All support the health of children; one cannot do otherwise emotionally or politically. But what constitutes "support"?
The World Summit for Children resulted last year in the promises of President Bush and 70 other world leaders to enact programs to reduce disease and malnutrition among children worldwide. Congress responded by approving an increase in funds for child survival and immunization programs as contained in the World Summit for Children Implementations Act. The act received the support of more than 165 representatives and 36 senators, including the majority of our New York Congressional delegation. But the final form was severely crippled, with $101 million in aid amputated. 
 Forty thousand children die daily from causes that are preventable. Effective vaccines against six childhood infections allow an estimated four million children to survive each year. Measles, whooping cough and tetanus still result in 1.7 million children dying yearly. Yet vaccines against these and three other childhood diseases are available at a cost of about $10 per child.
This is not only a problem of other countries. Despite our greater resources and technology, the United States falls behind other countries in rates of immunization of young children. In many urban areas, the majority of preschoolers are poorly or incompletely immunized.
This year the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control have recommended a new and important initiative for universal immunization of infants against hepatitis B virus infection. Despite the availability of a safe and effective vaccine for 10 years, the incidence of hepatitis B has increased, causing an astounding burden in health care and human costs
An estimated 300,000 acute hepatitis B infections occur each year in this country, and more than a million individuals are chronically infected. Although many of these infections are mild and unrecognized, their sequelae result in chronic liver disease, cancer and more than 5,000 deaths every year. This annual toll is as great or greater than that caused in pre-vaccine years by diseases for which we currently vaccinate.
The devastation of this disease can be eliminated by universal immunization of our children. For this we have the vaccine and ability, but currently not the will or funds. Although the additional cost of this vaccine for infants seems like an economic burden to parents, physicians and law makers, the benefit in future dollars and health far outweighs the current cost. But promises are easily obscured by current constraints. The financing proposed for 1993 childhood immunizations does not include an increase adequate to cover the cost of this new immunization program.
Each of us should write our Congressional representatives and candidates to ask for their full support of the World Summit for Children Implementation Act for 1993 and domestic financing for immunizations.
 
CAROLINE BREESE HALL, M.D.
Prof. of Pediatrics, U. of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry
Rochester, May 12, 1992

HEADLINE: Give Homeowners A Tax Break

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The recession we are emerging from has had many causes, but one key reason it lingers can be found by looking carefully at what has happened to home values since the Comprehensive Tax Reform Act of 1986.
The reform ended many of the tax code's wildest abuses. The ability to write off against taxes $3 or $4 for every $1 invested in certain kinds of real estate partnerships made syndications boom, bidding up prices for every kind of real estate.
Unfortunately, in this climate most of us bought our homes. When tax reform let the air out of the market for abusers, it let the air out for average homeowners, too. 
 Because a primary residence is the largest single asset most people have, any big rise or fall in property values has a dramatic effect on consumer confidence. Nationwide, there has been a net drop in the average value of most people's primary asset of something like 25 percent. It's very little wonder consumers feel poorer and hesitant to spend us out of the recession. Moreover, no drop in interest rates will fix this problem.
Rather than just provide breaks to business, Congress should help average Americans regain the value of their most important asset: their homes. This could be accomplished by enacting the following programs:
* Restore the favorable capital gains treatment for primary home transactions.
* Provide an investment tax credit for first-time home purchasers.
* Grant limited tax credits for capital losses incurred in the sale of a primary residence.
* Create investment tax credits for primary home capital improvements.
It came as no surprise to me, as one who has participated in the residential real estate market for more than 20 years, that the stock market crashed and consumer confidence went south less than a year after home values were legislated away. It's time Congress helped homeowners rather than penalize them for the sins of others.
 
CLARK P. HALSTEAD
New York, May 15, 1992

HEADLINE: U.N. Official Rebukes U.S. on Haitians

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva sharply criticized the Bush Administration today for returning Haitian refugees to Haiti without giving them the chance to appeal for protection and asylum.
United Nations officials said they believe that the United States is in violation of international agreements prohibiting the forced return of refugees rescued on the high seas. 
 The High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata of Japan, said in a letter to Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger that she was "deeply disturbed" by President Bush's executive order Sunday ending the process by which Haitians rescued at sea were taken to the detention center set up at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, for questioning by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Mrs. Ogata said the order "denies those Haitians genuinely in need of international protection the opportunity to present their claims, thus exposing them to risk upon their return to Haiti."
President Bush, asked today on a campaign trip in Georgia to explain his policy, acknowledged that he worried about the "appearance" of the new measures. But he reiterated his Administration's beliefs that Haitians were not persecuted when returned forcibly, and that "the vast majority of refugees are economic."
Mr. Bush, visiting the Mount Paran Christian School in Marietta, Ga., had been challenged by a man in the audience who asked whether this new policy didn't seem "to stand counter to what America has stood for over the last couple of hundred years."
 
'Still Open Our Arms'
 The President responded: "I would not want on my conscience that that person having fled oppression would be -- anyone that was fleeing oppression -- would be victimized upon return."
"Yes, the Statue of Liberty still stands, and we still open our arms under our law to people that are politically oppressed," Mr. Bush said. But he added: "I will not, because I've sworn to uphold the Constitution, open the doors to economic refugees all over the world. We can't do that."
The crowd applauded.
At the State Department today, Richard Boucher, the deputy spokesman, said that the Administration was preparing to put into effect an Organization of American States resolution of May 17 banning from American ports all ships that do business with Haiti.
The United States has barred American ships from commercial trading with Haiti since an embargo went into effect last fall. The Administration, which has not been able to persuade European nations to join the embargo, will now have to decide whether to track and challenge European ships, which have been bringing petroleum products and a wide range of other essential supplies to Port-au-Prince.
At the same time the Administration is tightening rules on ships trading with Haiti, it is apparently continuing to relax controls on goods going to Port-au-Prince from the United States.
This week, said an aide to Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, the State Department and National Security Council approved a change allowing seeds, fertilizers and pesticides to be imported from the United States. Senator Wallop has been critical of the embargo, saying it hurts people more than governments.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 29, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about United States policy toward Haiti misidentified Lawrence S. Eagleburger in some editions. He is Deputy Secretary of State, not Under Secretary.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Industry Views Environment

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
As next week's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro nears, the advertising industry is concentrating on a variety of environmental issues.
Still, interest in the environment among consumers, as expressed in surveys conducted by the Leo Burnett Company, has dropped to its lowest level since the agency began the nationwide studies in September 1989. 
 The Chicago-based shop said that only 40 percent of respondents in the most recent of its seven surveys, conducted in February, called the environment their leading concern, compared with the more than 70 percent who cited unemployment.
Other findings that support a declining interest in the environment included a response that 46 percent strongly agree there should be mandatory recycling laws, compared with 57 percent 18 months ago, and a tapering-off of participation in environmental activities like recycling aluminum.
Separately, an international code on the self-regulation of environmental marketing claims was endorsed yesterday by the board of the Association of National Advertisers in New York. The code, created by the World Federation of Advertisers and the International Chamber of Commerce, is intended to eliminate the need for Federal or state legislation.
The code is composed of 10 rules, including one mandating that only "serious scientific work" should support ads using technical demonstrations.

HEADLINE: To Gauge the Film Industry, Start With a Magic Number

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Filming in New York is often called a $3 billion-a-year industry, but that figure is more guesswork than fact.
 The magic number comes from the the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting and represents an estimate of the value of all location filming in 1990, New York's best year, in the 10 categories for which the office issues shooting permits. 
The number has a history. The formula that generated it was arrived at in 1982, when the office carried out a study of the economic impact of film and television production in New York. Working with M. Claire Roussy, an economist for the state's Office of Financial Analysis, the film office looked at a sample of filming budgets and arrived at an average daily expenditure on salaries, goods and services for different types of filming and still photography.
 The current dollar figure, which has not been adjusted for inflation since 1982, ranges downward from feature films -- an estimated average of $100,000 per day, or about what a $3.5 million film shooting for 35 days would spend -- to music videos ($15,000) to student films ($2,500). Multiplying the total number of shooting days in a year by average daily expenditures yields a "primary impact" figure, which is multiplied by 2.3 to obtain a "total economic impact" figure.
 
Allowing for Ripple Effect
 The 2.3 multiplier, which was calculated using models developed by the Regional Science Research Institute of Teace Dale, R.I., expresses the ripple effect that occurs when persons and companies that have received film dollars then turn around and make purchases.
 The film office says that its 2.3 multiplier is one of the lowest in use among the country's more than 200 film offices, which tend to prefer high multipliers, perhaps as a way of accentuating the importance of the film industry, and their offices.
 In 1990, the New York office issued 2,612 daily permits for feature films, making a primary impact total of $261.2 million in that category. Permits were issued for 31,746 shooting days in all categories that year, which translates into a primary impact of $1.26 billion. When multiplied by 2.3, that amount produces a total economic impact of about $3 billion.
 The figure is at best a rough estimate. First, the multiplier is by definition an educated guess. Second, because the film office keeps data only on location filming, the $3 billion does not include such New York products as network news programs, "Late Night With David Letterman," "Donahue" or the hundreds of television commercials that are shot in studios. In fact, there are only two rock-solid statistics that serve as an index to filming in New York: the daily permits issued by the film office, and the number of days worked by union members, which some unions make available and some do not, for reasons of policy or difficulty.
 Two economic portraits of the city's film industry are in the works, however. The Directors Guild of America has just announced that it will prepare an economic policy analysis of the industry, and at the Urban Research Center of New York University, Mitchell Moss, the center's director, is overseeing a study on the economic impact of the entertainment industry in New York that is scheduled to be finished by the end of the summer.

HEADLINE: U.S. SEEKS U.N. BAN ON YUGOSLAV TRADE OVER BOSNIA STRIFE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 28

 BODY:
The United States pressed the United Nations Security Council today to impose an immediate and virtually total economic embargo, including a ban on all oil sales, on the rump Yugoslav Government in Belgrade to force it to end Serbian intervention in neighboring Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Britain, France and Belgium, the Council's three European Community members, accepted the American position in consultations at the Security Council today after favoring a weaker plan for imposing sanctions in stages. But Russia and China, two permanent Council members with veto power, which are also Serbia's principal oil suppliers, have appeared reluctant about sanctions. It was not certain that they would accept the embargo plan being pushed by Washington.
 
Medicine and Food Are Exempt
 The sanctions the United States now wants are as comprehensive as those imposed on Iraq before the Persian Gulf war. They include a ban on trade, with the exception of medicine and approved supplies of food. An embargo on arms deliveries is already in effect. 
 The sanctions would require the severing of all air links with Serbia, the freezing of its external bank accounts and other financial assets, an end to cultural, scientific and sporting contacts and "significant" cuts in the size of its diplomatic missions abroad.
The United States, with the support of Britain and Belgium, also wants the Council to rule that the Belgrade Government cannot automatically take over the old Yugoslav seat in the United Nations, but instead must apply for membership. This would give the United States veto power over Belgrade's eventual readmission. However, France has not yet agreed to this.
 
Islamic Nations Add Pressure
 Islamic nations, which have been angered by Serbian attacks on Bosnia and Herzegovina's Muslim population, were reported today to be urging Russia and China to support the sanctions. The United States is expected to have a majority of the 15-nation Council in support of the sanctions, so passage only awaits a decision by Moscow and Beijing to go along with the resolution, abstain or cast a veto that would block it. The two nations went along with a series of tough Council resolutions on Iraq in the past two years.
The American move followed a mortar attack on Wednesday that killed 16 civilians in Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina,. The Bush Administration had earlier seemed ready to support the European plan for a two-stage sanctions package with an oil embargo delayed until the second stage. In Brussels on Wednesday, the 12-nation European Community imposed a limited economic embargo on the Belgrade Government, but left a decision on a ban on oil sales to the Security Council.
The new American pressure came just a week after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d seized the lead in organizing resistance to the violence in Bosnia and Herzegovina from the European Community, accusing it of moving too slowly, calling for punitive measures against Belgrade and warning that military intervention might prove necessary.
Appearing on the NBC News program "Today" this morning, the United States Ambassador to Belgrade, Warren Zimmermann, accused Slobodan Milosevic, who as President of Serbia is the dominant figure in the new Yugoslavia, of "waging a war of aggression" against Bosnia and Herzegovina. Recently withdrawn from Belgrade as a sign of protest, Mr. Zimmermann said the Serbs, who constitute one third of the population in Bosnia and Herzegovina, were now "trying to take over two-thirds of the country" by driving other ethnic groups from their homes.
He said the mortar bombs that struck a civilian bread line in Sarajevo probably came from Serbian attackers in the hills outside the city. And he warned that if conditions worsened further, the international community would have to consider "some kind of multilateral use of force.
 
Disgust Over Attack
 American officials said the Administration was toughening its stance partly out of disgust with the Sarajevo attack, whose aftermath was shown on television around the world.
They accused the Belgrade Government of double-crossing the world by seeking to carve a Greater Serbia out of the wreckage of the defunct Yugoslav federation by force, while outwardly professing to want peace. The old federation has been broken up into independent states: Croatia, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the rump Yugoslavia, which includes Serbia and Montenegro. Another former member of the federation, Macedonia, has also declared independence but has not yet received worldwide recognition.
Many foreign diplomats here speculated that political factors entered into the the Bush Administration's sudden decision to take the lead against Belgrade.
These include a desire for President Bush to appear decisive, with six primary elections scheduled for next Tuesday. In addition, the Bush Administration, unhappy over the decision of France and Germany to create the nucleus of their own joint force outside of NATO, may also be seeking to take the lead among the Western powers, in effect showing the Europeans that only Washington has the will to be decisive. The sanctions favored by the United States are intended to force the Belgrade Government to carry out the peace proposals for Bosnia and Herzegovina that the Security Council adopted this month.
The draft sanctions resolution begins by condemning Serbia and the Yugoslav National Army for failing to cease their interference in Bosnia and Herzegovina and demands that all elements of the Croatian Army also withdraw from that republic.
Acting under Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, the resolution would then impose a list of sanctions until the Security Council decided that Serbia had fully complied with the earlier peace terms.
The resolution would require Belgrade to promote an immediate cease-fire in Bosnia and Herzegovina, disband and disarm former elements of the Yugoslav Army there, end the forced displacement of ethnic groups, disarm all irregular forces and grant free access for United Nations and other humanitarian agencies.
Finally, the Security Council has demanded that all communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina take part in talks on a new constitution for the independent republic that the European Community mediators want to organize.
The 21-paragraph resolution also forbids all trade and financial dealings with Serbia except for sales of medicine and approved supplies of humanitarian foodstuffs. It freezes Belgrade's outside financial assets, but allows Greece and other countries that transship goods through Serbia to continue to do so.
Besides banning all air traffic other than approved humanitarian flights, the resolution also forbids the servicing of Serbian aircraft as well as provision of spare parts and the insurance of planes. It also calls for a security zone around Sarajevo and its airport that would allow it to be reopened for flying in humanitarian supplies.
In a new report to the Security Council today, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali stressed the growing humanitarian crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina as a result of the fighting and the campaign for "ethnic purification."
He reported that more than 520,000 people had been been driven from their homes and that the displacement of the civilian population "is proceeding on a scale not seen in Europe since the Second World War."

HEADLINE: Newspaper Drivers Ratify Pacts With The Times and a Distributor

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Newspaper delivery drivers approved far-reaching labor contracts last night that ended a bitter three-week labor dispute with The New York Times and a newspaper distributor and carried the prospect of labor peace in the industry to at least the year 2000.
The new contracts promise to change the way the industry operates, giving management sweeping new powers to decide how papers will be delivered, in what size trucks, by how many drivers and along what routes. And the contracts set the stage for similar reordering, as well as other long-range agreements, with other unions.
 
A Bad Bargain to Many
 In the case of The Times, the ratification appears to clear the way for the long-delayed opening of its $450 million color printing plant in Edison, N.J.
Last night's vote resulted from the dissolution of existing contracts when distribution companies changed hands. After rejecting an earlier version of substitute contracts, union drivers at two distributors were replaced, setting off scattered violence and delivery disruptions. 
 Yesterday, after the proposed contracts were amended, 1,428 of the union's 2,900 drivers voted by substantial margins to accept what many said they still believed was a bad but unavoidable bargain.
Nevertheless, cheers greeted the results, announced at 10:30 P.M. outside the Long Island City, Queens, headquarters of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity.
"Let's go back to work!" shouted the union president, Douglas LaChance, who steered the four contracts to ratification over often vociferous opposition.
The Times contract, which passed by the narrowest margain, was approved 754 to 655.
The votes on two other contracts with wholesale distributors to be acquired by The Times was 782 to 600 for the contract with the Metropolitan News Company and 834 to 543 for the contract with the Newark Newsdealers Supply Company.
A contract between the union and two wholesale distributors owned by Arthur E. Imperatore of Imperial Delivery Service was approved 932 to 457. The two Imperial wholesalers are Westfair Newspaper Distributors in New Rochelle, N.Y., and Newspaper Distributors Company in East Farmingdale, L.I.
The results drew praise from the publisher of The Times, Arthur Sulzberger Jr. "I couldn't be more pleased by the ratification of the contracts," he said last night. "This has been a long and painful process for everyone." He credited the efforts of Mr. LaChance and three union-appointed intermediaries who helped bring the parties together two weeks ago.
In his own statement, Mr. Imperatore, a New Jersey trucking entrepreneur, said he was pleased that the union "voted to join our family of operating companies."
But some of the drivers were clearly dismayed. Inside the Metropolitan News Company in Long Island City, which along with the Newark distributor delivers more than half the Times's daily 900,000 copies, Patrick Rizzotti, 36 years old, said it was only economic hardship after three weeks of joblessness that "put it over the top."
 
Holding Nose and Voting
 Throughout the day, drivers streamed into union headquarters a block off traffic-choked Queens Plaza under the Queensboro Bridge. Many of them left saying that they had voted yes holding their noses.
"It's designed to destroy the union," said Gary Konigsberg, 52 years old, a driver for 23 years who has been shut out of work at Mr. Imperatore's East Farmingdale distribution center.
"After they finish with us," he said, his mouth quivering, "they're going to move on other unions."
The exuberant Mr. LaChance, who has campaigned for passage of the contracts, back-slapped his way to the head of a line of drivers waiting to vote at 3 P.M.
 
'Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes.'
 "Watch me vote!" he cried, handing his union card to a member of the Honest Ballot Association, which was overseeing the voting. Then, lunging into one of the two voting machines, he shut the curtain and announced: "I'm in favor of all of them." He snapped down four levers, shouting, "Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes."
What was most difficult for his members to swallow, Mr. LaChance said, was the realization that the takeover of one company by another can abrogate the hardest-won labor contracts. By law, new contracts can be negotiated after so-called asset sales, the sale of parts of a company rather than its entire stock -- a matter of right or fairness, perhaps, to a buyer but anathema to workers suddenly forced to renegotiate or be replaced.
This fear of the unknown, more than any single provision, Mr. LaChance said, fueled a burning resentment throughout the membership. But at the same time, Mr. LaChance campaigned for ratification because, as he said he asked the union board on Tuesday, "Somebody want to tell me what the alternative is?"
The same blunt message was carried to the membership at the meeting on Wednesday by three union-picked intermediaries who got the parties together after the union's earlier rejection of a previous version of the contracts on May 6.
 
Brother Against Brother
 The three -- Barry Feinstein, president of Joint Council 16 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters; John P. Kennedy, president of the New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2, and Michael E. Connery, a lawyer with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom who represents unions in the The Daily News sale talks -- told the members that they could not expect a better offer and warned that the alternative was a war pitting union brother against brother, perhaps killing off two other precarious newspapers, The Daily News and The New York Post, in the process.
But many members said that the principles at stake overrode even the self-interest of retaining their jobs in a grim economy.
The contracts will reduce the number of union members through the use of attrition and severance bonuses, as well as cut overtime and strengthen management's hand in delivery operations ranging from staffing to route structure. At the same time, they will guarantee the jobs and advancement of regular full-time drivers, and provide for company contributions to union benefit funds and modest wage increases.
The elimination of most of the drivers' overtime would cut in half the $80,000 in annual wages many drivers make. But the contracts provide increases of $124 a week over three years, with further increases possible after that.
 
A No-Strike Provision
 Galling to many drivers is a no-strike provision that they say would force them to cross picket lines of brother union members during strikes elsewhere in the industry.
The vote followed a tangled sequence of events that go back to November 1990 when The Times and the union began talks about staffing at the Edison plant. After the union rejected two Times offers, the company won a favorable arbitration ruling, spurring the union to agree to yet another proposed settlement.
As an inducement to work-rule changes and a reduced labor force, the Times had offered severance bonuses, job guarantees and a longer-than-usual contract extending to the year 2000. This was rejected several times but became the core of the contracts ratified last night.
In February, The Times announced that to gain a firmer grip on the distribution of its papers, it planned to acquire two wholesalers, Metropolitan News and Newark Newsdealers. The wholesalers deliver the paper to stores, newsstands and home-delivery services. With the purchase of the wholesalers' assets, the existing contracts would lapse and the proposed new contract would be substituted.
Mr. Imperatore's Imperial Delivery made a similar bid for the Westfair and Newspaper Distributors operations. And that set the stage for negotiation of new contracts.
At the Newark distribution center, sighs of relief greeted news of the contracts' passage. "Hey babe, we got a job," Kim Connell, a 36-year-old driver from Lake Hiawatha, N.J., told his wife on the phone. "Yes, I'm serious. It's like winning the Super Bowl. Maybe now we'll all go to Disneyland."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas La Chance, head of the newspaper drivers union, and members cheering after contract vote. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: What About Oil?;
The Gulf War Put the Focus on Supplies, But a New Energy Bill Skips That Issue

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Sixteen months after the nation went to war over oil in the Persian Gulf, an energy bill is taking final shape in Washington, yet the focus is everywhere but on oil.
Two similar versions, one passed by the House Wednesday and the other by the Senate in February, do, however, include a variety of significant measures, most importantly affecting electric utilities. Those changes would increase efficiency in lights, appliances and motors, improve the natural gas supply for utilities and other customers, and, possibly, remove one of many stumbling blocks to building nuclear plants. 
 "I would call it a positive first step on the way to something we don't ever seem to achieve, which is a comprehensive national energy policy," said Wilfrid L. Kohl, director of the international energy program at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. That, he said, would require a stiff gasoline tax.
Such a tax was not seriously discussed in Washington, but with the United States now importing about half its crude oil and destined to import more in the future, and with the economy resonating with every big oil-price movement, there was no shortage of proposals to cut the nation's consumption or increase its supply.
Congress seriously considered drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, requiring more fuel efficiency in cars and rapidly filling the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. But in the end, the House or Senate rejected all three.
This was probably essential to the energy bill's survival, because opponents of either Arctic drilling or stricter gas-mileage requirements could probably have sunk the package; certainly they could have done so together.
 
A Lack of Will
 "The most potentially valuable provisions were the most controversial, and there wasn't the will to tackle them," said Eli Bergman, director of Americans for Energy Independence, a Washington-based interest group.
"Senators and Congressmen will whisper that the thing that would do the most would be a $1 hike in the gasoline tax," he said. "They'll whisper it, but they won't do anything about it." In fact, last fall Congress choked on adding a nickel.
The result is an energy bill pushed into the public eye by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, but which, paradoxically, is hardly relevant to the oil-related aspects of the war. The notable exception -- extending for 10 years some bans on offshore drilling -- is a negative for the industry.
"At least," mused Lawrence J. Goldstein, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, "they were smart enough to realize they've done nothing to deal with U.S. security."
 
A Two-Year History
 The bill, now the National Energy Strategy, began life two years ago as the National Energy Security Act, intended to reduce the impact of oil shocks, Mr. Goldstein pointed out. But reaching political consensus on oil in a nation so divided between the interests of producers and consumers will evidently require a bigger oil crisis or a bloodier war.
The bill's most important provision is, for the public, obscure and barely comprehensible: revising a 50-year-old law on electric company monopolies. The change might cut electricity bills in the future, but the case is far from clear-cut. It will probably create a bigger cast of characters in the business of building generating stations, but much will depend on the outcome of the House-Senate conference on the bill, because the two houses set different terms for those generators to have access to utility-owned transmission lines.
The House bill's second-most important provision will aid in raising the efficiency of electric lights, motors and appliances. But in this role the Federal Government is merely helping along what the states and utilities are doing already.
The bill may not really deserve the title "strategy," but there are a wide variety of provisions. One would provide $927 million between now and 1996 for conservation and development of renewable energy sources.
But more than half of that "expenditure" is a Federal agreement not to jeopardize existing state conservation programs. At the urging of the states, utilities are making cash grants to electricity consumers to buy more efficient equipment, and Washington has been threatening to tax those grants, in effect putting a brake on the states' conservation programs. The House bill makes utility grants to residential customers tax-free, along with two-thirds of the grants to industries and businesses.
 
Billions for Renewables
 The rest of the money would be used to encourage production of electricity from the sun, the wind, crop wastes and the heat of the earth's core. In contrast, more than $800 million was given to independent oil producers, in the form of tax exemptions from the Alternative Minimum Tax provisions of the Federal tax code.
The bill authorizes billions of dollars for research and development, into coal, nuclear power and renewable fuels. The slice for renewables is larger than approved in recent years, but environmentalists say they are waiting to see how much is appropriated.
"It's O.K. as far as it goes," Mr. Bergman said. "It's almost incredible that we even get an energy bill this year, when the price of gasoline is at historic lows and the country has a hell of a lot of other problems."
Mr. Bergman's group was perhaps the only one to favor both drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and an increase in automobile fuel efficiency, alternatives that were initially put forward as tacitly balanced, with at least a third of the Congress vehemently opposed to one or the other.
At the Sierra Club, which feels good about the outcome in the Arctic and bereft over the failure to require higher-mileage cars, Daniel F. Becker, a lobbyist, said, "We're calling it half a good energy package."
"It's marginally better than nothing," said Mr. Goldstein of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat on the Energy and Commerce Committee, said that while oil companies should have been forced to pay for the expansion of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, he supported the bill for its many other provisions.
"Any way you slice it, this bill helps our nation reduce its dependence on foreign oil," he said, pointing specifically to the sections on conservation and electric utilities.
But the United States is not without an energy policy. The leading Federal component, according to oil experts and environmentalists, is disguised as the Clean Air Act of 1990, which encourages the use of methanol, natural gas and electricity to run cars.
 
Influence of California
 Perhaps more significant is the California Air Resources Board, whose regulations on cars appear likely to be adopted in several large Northeastern states, perhaps almost all of them. Those regulations appear to require huge numbers of electric vehicles, along with others running on methanol and natural gas.
There are other components of the energy bill that appear likely to have a long-term impact, although not on oil. Almost no one is happy with the present system for deciding whether natural gas pipelines should be built, and the energy bill would make it easier to win approval. The electric efficiency provisions will also probably increase the average efficiency of refrigerators, lights and similar devices in years to come.
There is also a wild card: a change in the rules for licensing nuclear power plants. The change has no immediate importance, but reduces one of the many obstacles to a revival of that industry.

HEADLINE: Bush Ordered Iraqis Plied With Aid

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
A secret policy directive on the Persian Gulf region signed by President Bush in October 1989 said the United States should offer economic and political incentives to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as a way of moderating his behavior and increasing American influence in his country.
The directive, part of which was made available to The New York Times today, also stated that Iraq should be told that the United States would impose economic and political sanctions and urge its allies to do so if Baghdad resumed its use of chemical weapons, used biological weapons or tried to develop a nuclear weapon in violation of international accords. 
 The Presidential order stipulated that Washington remained committed to defend its vital interests in the region, with military force if necessary, if they were threatened by the Soviet Union or another regional power.
The directive served as the operative guide for American policy until Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990. It has become the focus of a strenuous debate over whether the United States ignored increasing signs in the late 1980's after the Iran-Iraq war that Iraq was preparing to use its military might to intimidate its neighbors.
 
Policy Clear, Order Secret
 A part of the directive was recently declassified by the White House after a request by Representative Sam Gejdenson, the Connecticut Democrat, who said today he would present it to a Congressional hearing on United States policy toward Iraq on Friday. In light of Mr. Gejdenson's plan, a Government official today made the declassified section available to The New York Times.
The section on Iran and other countries in the Persian Gulf remains classified, and it is not known whether additional material on Iraq also remains classified.
The general direction of American policy before the invasion of Kuwait has been clear for some time, but the directive has remained secret.
According to the excerpts of the document, known as National Security Decision Directive 26, Mr. Bush also stated that the United States should consider selling forms of assistance like training courses and medical exchanges on a case-by-case basis as a "means of developing access to and influence with" the Iraqi military.
 
Iraq as Regional Threat
 "Normal relations between the U.S. and Iraq would serve our longer-term interests and promote stability in both the gulf and the Middle East," said the document. "The U.S. Government should propose economic and political incentives for Iraq to moderate its behavior and to increase our influence with Iraq."
At the time, Iraq had emerged from the Iran-Iraq war as the clear victor with the most formidable military power in the Persian Gulf, while Iran was devastated and seemed intent on reconstructing its economy. Although some analysts inside and outside of Government were warning at the time that the new Administration should craft a more balanced policy that recognized Iraq, not Iran, as the primary regional threat, the directive seemed to assume that Mr. Hussein would respond favorably to rewards by Washington.
Administration officials have said that the policy was also based on the assumption that Iran and Iraq were so exhausted by their eight-year war that neither would seek outside adventures in the short term.
That assessment was also articulated in an estimate by the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister intelligence agencies in October 1989 that stated that Iraq was not expected to turn aggressive toward its neighbors for two to three years, according to recent Congressional testimony by Robert M. Gates, Director of Central Intelligence.
 
Wider Economic Ties
 The document, at least in its unclassified version, does not describe Iraq's nuclear-weapons program or its use of chemical weapons against Iran and against Kurdish civilians in Iraq.
But the directive said that Iraq would be punished if it used chemical or biological weapons or sought to develop a nucler weapon. The Reagan and Bush Administrations had strongly opposed every initiative in the Congress to impose economic sanctions against Iraq for its use of chemical weapons against its Kurdish population in August 1988.
The policy, as articulated in the directive, was also based on an expansion of economic ties between the two counties. It also said that "normal relations between the U.S. and Iraq would serve our longer term interests and promote stability in both the gulf and the Middle East."
The directive also stated the long-held policy that "access to Persian Gulf oil and the security of key friendly states in the area are vital to us national security."
It continued, "The U.S. remains committed to defend its vital interests in the region, if necessary, and appropriate, through the use of us military force, against the Soviet Union or any other regional power with interests inimical to our own."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

METRO DIGEST
 
NEWSPAPER DRIVERS PASS CONTRACTS
Newspaper delivery drivers approved a series of far-reaching labor contracts that ended a bitter two-week stalemate with The New York Times and a newspaper distributor and carried the prospect of labor peace in the industry to at least the year 2000. A1.
 
PAINTING BY THE CENSUS NUMBERS
In the nation's self-portrait by numbers, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York can be found largely where they are on any map: at the edge. By many economic measurements in the 1990 census, all three states rank near one end of the spectrum or the other compared with the remaining 47 and the District of Columbia. A15.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
A VOTE TO GIVE POLICE MORE POWERFUL GUNS
After a debate that included the spectacle of two New York City lawmakers waving semiautomatic weapons, the State Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill that would require the city to arm its 26,000 police officers with the more powerful guns they say they need to counter the deadly weapons used by criminals. The Assembly now gets the measure, which is opposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins and Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown. A1.
 
IT TOOK 17 MINUTES TO GET HELP
An 81-year-old Bronx resident who lived half a block from a fire station died of a heart attack earlier this month after an Emergency Medical Services ambulance took more than 17 minutes to answer his son's call for help. B4.
 
A CRASH COURSE IN SCHOOL FINANCE
Some of New York City's best and brightest at the Bronx High School of Science tackled a pair of problems not found in any textbook: how to fight both student apathy and the proposed cuts in public education. Classes were replaced with a daylong teach-in where education policy experts gave a crash course in school finance. B3.
 
New Board of Education AIDS policy is criticized. B3.
 
School janitors charged in gun sales. B3.
 
REGION
 
HEALTH NOMINEE ACCEPTS PAY CUT
Nine months after he was nominated as commissioner of the New York State Health Department, Dr. Mark R. Chassin has agreed to accept $70,000 less in salary than he was first offered. State lawmakers, who had never challenged Dr. Chassin's qualifications, just his proposed pay, said they were prepared to move forward with his confirmation. B5.
 
THE NEW JERSEY OAKLANDS?
The wildfires that stormed through 15,000 acres of the New Jersey pine barrens earlier this month rekindled a debate over development and wilderness in the million-acre preserve. Without fire, everyone agrees, the Pinelands will eventually become the New Jersey Oaklands. B4.
 
AN AWARD FOR RAISING TAXES
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was honored by the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation as an exemplar of modern political courage in America for imposing a tax on the wages of Connecticut residents. The Governor accepted the prize with characteristically blunt words, saying that anyone who took action "in the midst of the whiniest moment in our history" deserves praise. B5.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Move Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates dipped again yesterday, as traders chose to focus on news suggesting economic weakness and to largely ignore a report that may herald an improvement in labor markets.
Developments traders seemed to find important included a sizable drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of spot commodity prices, and declines in weekly money supply figures that were bigger than expected. 
 Mostly overlooked was a report from the Labor Department showing that the number of Americans filing for initial unemployment benefits fell by 4,000 in the week ended May 16, to 403,000, the lowest level in more than seven months.
Analysts had been expecting a small increase.
Market participants registered only mild disappointment after the report was released early yesterday, as prices showed only a modest and temporary decline.
Demand for securities quickly reappeared, particularly for issues with maturities of up to five years.
"The claims numbers weren't extraordinary, but they were on the strong side," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "Right now the market's mentality is to buy on price dips."
The drop in the C.R.B. index seemed to reassure those market participants who earlier in the week were worried about reports that oil prices might be moving higher.
 
Declines in Monetary Aggregates
 And the reported declines in the monetary aggregates may have rekindled hopes that the Federal Reserve Board may yet decide to lower short-term interest rates, even though many analysts said yesterday the money numbers would not be the ultimate determinant of Fed policy.
The Fed reported that all three of the money supply measures it tracks most closely fell during the week ended May 18.
M-2, the aggregate most closely monitored by the Fed, declined by $7.4 billion. The drop pushed M-2 growth back below the bottom of the 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent range the Fed has chosen for M-2 this year.
The Fed cited weak money growth as the primary reason it last eased policy in April. But analysts said that reports of the substance of recent Fed policy meetings made it unlikely weak money growth alone would cause another Fed move.
"M-2 will continue to crisscross the bottom of its target range through June," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said in their daily market commentary. "But until the economy shows definite signs of declining again, M-2 data will not draw the Fed off the sidelines."
 
Yield Down on Long Bond
 By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 5/8, up 15/32 , to yield 7.85 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 1/32 , up 15/32 , to yield 7.35 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 13/32 , up 9/32 , to yield 6.65 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 27/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 5.20 percent.
Demand was said to be fairly strong at an auction of one-year Treasury bills.
The bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.07 percent, down from 4.20 percent at the last one-year bill sale on April 30.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.66 percent, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged on the day at a late offered rate of 3.81 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Police Charge 2 Janitors With Gun Sales in School

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Two school janitors were charged yesterday with running a gun-selling operation for at least a year out of two Brooklyn public schools, one across the street from a police station house, the police said.
The janitors and two other people operated the ring mostly at night from Prospect Heights High School in Prospect Heights and Intermediate School 61 in Crown Heights but were not believed to have sold any guns to students, the police said. Instead, the four used the schools as a base, with the sales, mainly to drug dealers, occurring elsewhere, said Lieut. Kenneth McCann, the commanding officer of the Police Department's joint task force with the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. 
 "We have nothing to substantiate that they sold these guns to students," said Lieutenant McCann, who added that the task force had worked closely with the Board of Education to evaluate whether children were involved. They "were using the schools as a location to sell the guns or meet prospective customers."
 
An Anonymous Tip
 The police received an anonymous tip about the operation last June, the lieutenant said. Several undercover officers then worked to infiltrate the network, ultimately buying 15 semiautomatic weapons from the ring in 10 separate purchases between March 10 and yesterday, Lieutenant McCann said.
The four, who were arrested by the police yesterday afternoon, were Joseph Stiff, 35 years old, a custodial assistant at Prospect Heights High School; Travis Walker, 24, a part-time custodial assistant at I.S. 61; Sophie Sealy, 24, who was described as Mr. Walker's girlfriend, and Orlando Pourchiau, 29, who was described as an unemployed friend of the other three.
All four were charged with criminal sales of firearms and criminal possession of a firearm, said a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Edelle James. Mr. Stiff and Mr. Walker were mainly involved in arranging the purchases, while Mr. Pourchiau was primarily a supplier, the police said.
Ms. Sealy's role was believed limited to a sale that she and Mr. Walker made yesterday, with their 6-month-old baby in tow, to an undercover officer outside a White Castle restaurant in Brooklyn, Lieutenant McCann said.
Although it had not been determined yesterday how long the ring had been in operation, Lieutenant McCann said, it existed undetected for a time because Mr. Stiff and Mr. Walker worked at night, when the schools are deserted. The lieutenant also said the police could not estimate how many guns the ring had sold.
Ed Stancik, the special commissioner of investigation for the public schools, attributed the existence of the gun ring in part to the custodial system, which he said is largely out of the control of the Board of Education. For years, the Board has been campaigning to change the system. Currently the head custodians work for the board, but they hire their cleaners, boiler-room workers and repair personnel without any assessment by board officials.
Mr. Stancik said there was no evidence that the head custodians at the schools were aware that their assistants were selling guns.
Several students playing basketball last night outside the high school said they were surprised to hear that one of their janitors had been arrested. "Janitors are the quiet ones," said Tyrone Johnson, 15. "You never hear anything funny about them."
 
Difficult to Trace
 The 15 guns that the police bought, at a total cost of $7,800, had their serial numbers removed, making them difficult to trace, Lieutenant McCann said.
Of the 10 purchases made by the undercover officers, one took place inside a first-floor office of the high school, at 883 Classon Avenue, another was in front of the intermediate school and the rest were at the corner of East 92d Street and Rutland Road in Brownsville, which the lieutenant described as busy with drug dealers.
The intermediate school, at the corner of East New York Avenue and Empire Boulevard, is across the street from the 71st Precinct house.
"I was surprised they would sell guns so close to a police station," Lieutenant McCann said.
