HEADLINE: Empire in Trouble;
3 Named to Administer Olympia London Project

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 28

 BODY:
A British bankruptcy court today appointed three administrators to take charge of the vast Canary Wharf office development here, marking the first time that the financially crippled Olympia & York Developments Ltd. has lost control of part of its global real estate empire.
On Wednesday night, Olympia sought bankruptcy protection from Canary Wharf's creditors, after 11 banks with about 550 million, or $992.2 million, in loans to the project, refused to provide new funds to keep construction going beyond the end of this month. 
 At a news conference today, Michael Dennis, an Olympia executive who was until today Canary Wharf's chief executive, and Robert S. Miller Jr., a financial adviser to Olympia, conceded that the bankruptcy was a grim development for Olympia as a whole, as well as for Canary Wharf, which is less than half finished.
The bankruptcy greatly reduces Olympia's chances of being able to persuade its 100 or so banks to accept its plan for emerging from its financial crisis with most of its core real estate operations in North America and Canada, they said. "This is a serious setback for the overall debt restructuring negotiations," Mr. Miller said.
Olympia asked banks to provide easier payment terms for about $12 billion of its debts and new funds in return for nonvoting equity stakes of up to 20 percent in the parent company and 30 percent in Canary Wharf.
But the 11 banks rejected the idea of taking a stake in Canary Wharf, so Mr. Miller and Mr. Dennis said Olympia was now trying to find investors to inject equity capital into the development. They said they had held preliminary talks with some potential investors whom they did not identify, but indicated there were not yet any bites.
They said they hoped that rather than being deterred by the severely depressed state of the London real estate market, investors would see it as an opportunity to buy a stake in Canary Wharf at a bargain price.
Some bankers today were dubious about Olympia's prospects for finding such investors. "If you had 500 million to spend, where would you spend it?" one said sardonically.
Mr. Dennis and Mr. Miller conceded that the fate of Canary Wharf, Europe's largest office-development project, was now in the hands of the administrators -- Stephen Adamson, Nigel Hamilton and Alan Bloom, who are partners in Ernst & Young, the accounting firm.
"We will work with them to see if the company can be reorganized and brought back to life," said Mr. Dennis, whose drawn face showed the strain of what for him had to be a personal defeat. He repeatedly said he still believed Canary Wharf could become London's third major business district, after the West End and the City.
But he added, "We don't know ultimately who the owners will be."
Under British law, administrators run a bankrupt company and submit to the court the plan that decides the company's ultimate fate. Creditors typically wield much more influence with the administrators than the company's directors and executives.
In contrast, the directors and executives of an American company that has sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code typically remain in control and draw up a reorganization proposal.
 
Reviewing the Options
 The administrators, who were appointed only at 9:30 A.M., were predictably noncommittal about what might happen to Canary Wharf or Olympia's other holdings in London. "Our job at the moment is to review all the options," Mr. Adamson said. The administrators said these included selling some or all of the properties or, if investors could be found, bringing the development out of bankruptcy intact.
The administrators have three months to propose a plan to creditors. But they will have to decide soon whether to ask the banks to provide more funds so construction can continue beyond this month so that the buildings can be finished and tenants can move in. Construction slowed to a crawl today, Mr. Dennis said.
Canary Wharf now consists of about 4.6 million square feet of commercial space -- the vast majority of which is completed or in an advanced stage. Tenants occupy or have signed leases for about 57 percent of the completed space, the administrators said.
Olympia also owns or holds leases for an estimated 500,000 to a million square feet of London office space, which it took over from companies to entice them to relocate to Canary Wharf. If the administrators tried to dump this space quickly, it could put pressure on London's already badly depressed real estate market, analysts said.
Bankers said Wednesday night and today that the 11 banks had unanimously agreed to recommend that the company file for bankruptcy administration because it would give it a better chance to survive as a going concern.
One banker who insisted on anonymity stressed that "it's not the end of the line" for Canary Wharf.
Banks have every reason to try to avoid a liquidation. With London property prices severely depressed and Canary Wharf unfinished, they would undoubtedly suffer large losses on their loans if the 71-acre development were liquidated piecemeal. The administrators said the development, if liquidated, could also lose valuable tax benefits.
Mr. Hamilton said that "high on the agenda" was a talk with British Government officials about the possibility of their choosing Canary Wharf as offices for more than 2,000 civil servants. The Government is looking for up to 500,000 square feet of office space.
Canary Wharf was the flagship in an ambitious initiative to rejuvenate the derelict docks in East London that was championed by Margaret Thatcher, when she was Prime Minister.
But the current Conservative Government led by Mrs. Thatcher's handpicked successor, John Major, repeated today that it would not bail out Canary Wharf by agreeing to above-market rates or by bearing the entire 1.7 billion ($3.07 billion) cost of a planned subway line through Canary Wharf. Olympia had pledged to contribute 400 million, or $721.6 million. "There's no change at all in the Government position," a spokesman for Mr. Major said today.
Canary Wharf also faces the grim possibility that companies that have signed contracts but have not yet moved in will now change their minds. These include American Express, Texaco, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lehman Brothers International and Credit Suisse First Boston.
Apparently, many have clauses in their contracts that could give them ways out. The American Express Company, which is scheduled to move into 300,000 square feet at Canary Wharf between July and September, had reportedly threatened to move to another site if the project went into administration. Interviewed today, Jeanne Segal, an American Express spokeswoman, would say only: "The bankruptcy filing has created uncertainty. The implications are unclear. We are continuing to monitor the situation closely."
New details emerged today about the events that led the banks to force Canary Wharf into bankruptcy. Olympia had told the 11 banks the project would need 300 million ($540 million) to see it through the next five years or so.
But the banks brought in their own adviser, who told them that under the worst-case scenario, the project would need much more -- Mr. Miller said 500 million, or $902 million, but a banker said it was closer to 600 million, or $1.08 billion.
Two British banks, Barclays and Lloyds, and four Canadian banks, Canadian Imperial, the Bank of Commerce, the Royal Bank of Canada and the Bank of Nova Scotia, voted against providing more money. Others, including Citibank, Credit Suisse of Switzerland and Credit Lyonnais of France, wanted to provide more. At an impasse, the banks unanimously agreed to recommend that Canary Wharf be put into bankruptcy administration.

GRAPHIC: Chronology: "Months of Misfortune"
 
Feb. 13 -- Toronto-based Dominion Bond Rating Agency downgrades several Olympia debt issues, rattling the commercial paper market and making it difficult for Olympia to refinance its short-term debts.
 
 March 12 -- Morgan Stanley Group Inc. wins a 100 million ($180 million) judgment against Olympia.
 
March 22 -- Olympia says for the first time that it faces a "liquidity crisis".
 
March 24 -- Thomas S. Johnson, former president of the Manufacturers Hanover Bank and Trust Company, is named president of Olympia, replacing Paul Reichmann, one of the brothers who own the company, as chief strategist.

Gerald Greenwald is named president as Mr. Johnson leaves. Olympia asks its lenders for 100 million ($180 million) for Canary Wharf and the equivalent of $84 million for its Canadian operations.

 May 8 -- Lenders grant 21 million ($37.8 million) in emergency loans to keep Canary Wharf under construction and out of bankruptcy through the end of the month.
 
 May 11 -- Reports that the British Government may rent up to 500,000 square feet at Canary Wharf lift hopes for the project's solvency.

In Canada, Olympia's parent company and some Canadian subsidiaries file for bankruptcy protection; some of these Canadian companies also file for Chapter 11 protection in the United States.

 May 21 -- In bankruptcy court, Olympia accepts severe restrictions on its ability to shift revenues from Canadian properties to other projects, including Canary Wharf.
 
May 27 -- Olympia puts the huge Canary Wharf project, with more than 1 billion ($2 billion) in debt, under the protection of a British bankruptcy court.

HEADLINE: Tax Quixote Shakes Town Hall

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
It was with an unmistakable air of satisfaction that George Hammer Jr., the son of a Manhattan real-estate appraiser and grandson of a Bronx developer, plunked a cardboard box with 97 property-tax complaints on the counter in the town assessor's office and demanded to be heard.
For three years, until an appellate court ruling last month, Mr. Hammer, a realtor and owner of a Montauk hotel, had been something of a nonperson in East Hampton, ignored by officials as he battled for justice for overtaxed homeowners -- and a 50 percent contingency fee. 
 A blustery gray-haired 60-year-old who favors a green blazer over a business suit, Mr. Hammer had gone into business as a tax-reduction consultant, a member of a new recession-driven profession that is riding a wave of populist rebellion against rising local property-tax bills.
To the consternation of local assessors, mayors, supervisors and council members, an increasing number of tax consultants like Mr. Hammer have filed tens of thousands of property-tax grievances, winning tax cuts and exposing flaws in an often inequitable tax system.
 
Words Ignored, Appeals Denied
 But when Mr. Hammer appeared before the town on behalf of his clients, his words were ignored and his appeals denied. When he challenged the rulings in Small Claims Court and won -- an average of a $1,000 tax refund per house, he says -- the town refused to pay.
"Maybe the town was a litle too zealous in defending itself," said Tony Bullock, the East Hampton Town Supervisor, after a town lawsuit challenging Mr. Hammer's right to appear at hearings was thrown out by the State Appellate Division last month.
"But the town board didn't go after George Hammer; George Hammer went after us." Mr. Bullock said. "Mr. Hammer did not make our job any easier by coming in and dropping this huge load of tax appeals on us."
Now, after East Hampton spent more than $30,000 fighting against Mr. Hammer's right to do business, the town has given up and joined other governments in recognizing the right of consultants -- disparaged in Town Hall as "mass filers" -- to represent clients, even though the consultants are not lawyers.
Soaring property taxes have ignited a powerful anti-tax movement on Long Island and across New York State. Property taxes are going up at the rate of $1 billion a year, and now exceed $20 billion annually, according to the State Division of Equalization and Assessment.
 
Taxes Increasingly Unfair
 At the same time, the property-tax system -- taxes, in theory, are based on the value of property -- has grown increasingly unfair in many places, as identical houses with identical market values have vastly different tax burdens.
While other states, like Connecticut, mandate a reassessment every 10 years, New York State does not, and some towns like East Hampton have not reassessed older properties for a generation.
So newer properties, especially those built during the real-estate boom in the 1980's, have higher taxes than older ones. And older properties that were sold and then reassessed (a practice known as "Welcome, stranger," barred by the United States Supreme Court in 1989) have higher taxes than unsold ones.
Enter the tax-reduction consultants, usually appraisers like Mr. Hammer or computer experts, like Paul Henry of Greenport on the north fork of Long Island, who for a percentage of the first year's tax savings help homeowners work their way through complicated tax appeals. Mr. Hammer requires a $100 initial payment, Mr. Henry $45.
The emergence of tax consultants who are not lawyers and who solicit business from regular homeowners is new. It follows a change made by the Legislature in 1983 to simplify tax appeals by homeowners, through informal hearings in Small Claims Court for a $25 filing fee. At first nearly all these complaints were filed by individual homeowners.
But beginning in the late 1980's, a few consultants began helping homeowners out. Now there are dozens scattered across the metropolitan area, and even seminars intended to teach people how to set up their own consulting businesses.
 
Huge Backlog of Appeals
 Suddenly these consultants began to make up an increasing share of all tax appeals, contributing to a huge backlog of appeals filed through Small Claims Court, especially when the court system ran out of money ($75 per case) to pay hearing officers.
In Nassau County more than 35,000 tax protests were filed this year, an increase from 28,000 the year before, and 20,000 in 1990, according to Abe Seldin, the chairman of the County Board of Assessors.
"I would say that the majority of these came from these filers," he said. "There are quite a number of them and many new ones and a great deal of solicitation. A number of them are using fear tactics on the public."
For Mr. Hammer, the tax-appeal business was more than something to do during the slow season at his 70-room hotel, the Shepherd's Neck Inn in Montauk. It was in his blood.
His grandfather developed apartments and private homes in and around Pelham Parkway in the Bronx in the 1920's and 1930's. His father, George Hammer Sr., was an appraiser of commercial real estate in Manhattan, and eventually specialized in tax reduction cases.
"My first exposure to tax reduction was when I was 12 years old, working on files in my father's office," Mr. Hammer said. "He eventually appraised all the most notable buildings in Manhattan."
After Mr. Hammer's father died in 1955, he moved out to Montauk to run the family-owned hotel, and continued to dabble in real estate and appraisal work. After working briefly as a Small Claims Court hearing officer in 1988, he got the idea of going into business for himself, and righting some wrongs in the process.
"The tax system is unfair, and they have made an effort to be unfair, to maintain the unfairness and the inequity," he said.
In a typical tax appeal, Mr. Hammer compiles data on recent sales showing that the house was assessed at a higher value than other homes of comparable size and location.
But East Hampton did not make it easy. It went to court, and accused him of practicing law without a license. Several similar suits were filed against other consultants by the City of White Plains.
Not only did the East Hampton suit challenge his right to appear in Small Claims Court, it challeged the validity of all the court decisions awarding refunds on behalf of his clients.
When he appeared in Small Claims Court, the town sent its real-estate lawyer, Roger Ramme, at a cost of about $150 an hour to sit in on each case. And when he appeared before the town's tax review board, the Board of Assessment Review, it informed him that it would simply ignore what he had to say.
"He was told he could talk all he wanted; the board didn't look at his oral argument as being credible," said Jeanne Nielsen, chief assessor.
Town officials saw him as someone abusing the system for personal gain, a system that had provoked few complaints over the years and produced revenue to keep the town in business.
"We are a small town," said Mr. Bullock, the Supervisor. "People can come down here and talk to the assessors that they elected, and the assessors have been very responsive, accessible and fair."
But Mr. Hammer wryly observed that he had appeared on behalf of a dozen property owners who happened to be lawyers, including one who was an appellate judge, and that none had objected to his lay status. In April the court threw out the lawsuits in both East Hampton and White Plains. Dozens of clients who won appeals are now due refunds, with 12 percent interest, according to Mr. Hammer.
 
Pressure on Local Officials
 Mr. Hammer and Mr. Henry, who got into the tax consulting business after he filed an appeal on his own home, say their efforts will eventually lead to a fairer tax system.
By providing relief to more and more individual taxpayers, they put pressure on local governments to undertake the politically perilous path of updating assessment rolls.
In East Hampton, where even Ms. Nielsen, a neighbor and family friend of Mr. Hammer, acknowledged that fully a third of all taxpayers were paying significantly too much taxes, the town board has consistently sidestepped the reassessment question.
"The history books tell us that when reassessment occurs, elected officials lose their jobs," Mr. Henry said.
So last week, Mr. Hammer nervously made his first appearance before the Assessment Review Board at a tiny meeting room in the town office complex. A hand-lettered sign on the door warned homeowners: "Plan to spend the day."
"It has been a costly and unneeded battle you have waged against your own citizenry," Mr. Hammer said in a written statement he submitted to the board, before agreeing to adjourn most of the cases for later hearings. "And I am glad, for the taxpayers, that it is finally over and that we can get on with business."
Jerry Katz, a developer, was glad, too. He had come to the hearing to complain that a house in East Hampton he had been unable to sell at a loss for $190,000 was assessed as if it were worth more than $370,000. He hired Mr. Hammer on the spot. The taxes are $5,600, he said.
"This is not a real-estate recession; it is a depression," he said. When a buyer who had offered $190,000 backed out, he cited the high taxes on the property, Mr. Katz said.
Jeannette Molloy and Ed Butler came to appeal the $4,500 in taxes in the house they built a few years back for $109,000 in Springs. It was assessed as if it were worth about $300,000.
It took them a while to realize they were overassessed, they said. "If we had come from Oklahoma we would have thought that $4,000 in taxes was ridiculous," said Ms. Molloy. "But we came from Huntington and taxes there were high too."
What if the board denies their appeal, they were asked. "Maybe we will go with Hammer," Ms. Molloy said.

HEADLINE: Applications For Jobless Claims Fall

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing initial claims for unemployment benefits fell to a seven-month low in mid-May, the Government said today in a report that suggests the labor market is regaining vigor.
First-time claims fell to 403,000 in the week ended May 16 from 407,000 the previous week, the Labor Department said. 
 The four-week average for initial claims, considered a more accurate barometer of job trends, also continued its gradual decline of recent weeks. It fell to 412,500 from 412,750 in the previous four weeks.
The figures were better than had been expected by Wall Street economists, who had predicted a rise to 408,000 claims. It was the lowest level since the week of Oct. 5, when claims reached 401,000.
"The worst of the job layoffs is behind us, and we should have some pickup in hiring in the second half of the year," said Lynn Reaser, senior vice president at the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
The steady improvement in claims data bodes well for the May employment report, due on June 5, said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at the Shawmut National Corporation. Mr. Perna predicted that about 126,000 new jobs were added to the economy this month, the same as in April. The April unemployment rate was 7.2 percent, down from 7.3 percent in March.
The drop in new claims for unemployment insurance benefits was widespread, with 36 jurisdictions reporting declines and only 17 reporting increases, the Labor Department said.
California saw the strongest improvement, with a 4,992 decline in new claims from the previous week, partly because of a pickup in agricultural hiring. After California came Ohio, with 4,563 fewer claims, and New York, with 3,010 fewer claims.
The states reporting the largest gains were Missouri, 1,505; North Carolina, 1,364, and Virginia, 1,256.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 27.99 to Hit 3,398.43 Peak

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A late rally in the stock market lifted the Dow Jones industrial average to a new closing high yesterday as investors focused their attention on falling interest rates.
The Dow rose 27.99 points to close at 3,398.43, just managing to surpass the previous 3,397.99 record set on May 19. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones, 999 to 683, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the composite rose 2.09, to 229.24.
Volume on the Big Board totaled 195.3 million shares, versus 182.2 million on Wednesday.
 
Broader Market Up
 Broader gauges were also higher. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.57, to 416.74, while the American Stock Exchange's composite index gained 0.45 point, to 392.30. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index finished 3.14 higher at 580.49.
Interest rates declined in the credit markets yesterday, extending their drop. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds fell to 7.85 percent from 7.89 percent late yesterday.
Analysts said investors were still recovering from an inflation scare touched off earlier in the week by a report that Saudi Arabia was seeking to encourage a rise in oil prices.
Meanwhile, the economic news offered some new encouragement for recovery hopes on Wall Street.
The Labor Department reported that initial claims for state unemployment insurance dropped by 4,000 in the week that ended on May 16, in contrast to analysts' estimates of a small increase.
 
Little Enthusiasm Seen
 But with all the positives, traders said the Dow's new high yesterday failed to produce some important signs of broad enthusiasm among investors. For example, just 51 of the 2,000 or so issues listed on the Big Board set individual new highs for at least the last 52 weeks.
In addition, yesterday was a rocky day for investors in telephone and airline stocks.
Centel tumbled 10 1/2, to 32, and Sprint fell 1 3/8, to 23 1/8, as the Big Board's two most active issues. On Wednesday, Sprint agreed to acquire Centel in a stock exchange that values Centel shares at well below their recent market price.
Centel's volume totaled 6.4 million shares, while 5.2 million Sprint shares changed hands.
The Centel-Sprint news depressed the stocks of other cellular-telephone issues, including McCaw Cellular, down 1 1/2 at 27 1/2, and Vanguard Cellular, down 2 3/4 at 25 1/4, both of which were among the volume leaders in over-the-counter trading.
 
AMR Falls $2
 AMR, which was also heavily traded, dropped 2, to 61 5/8, following a fare cut on Wednesday by the company's American Airlines subsidiary that appeared to intensify a price war among passenger carriers.
Other airline issues fell yesterday, as recent worries of rising fuel prices have put pressure on the sector. UAL, which owns United Airlines, dropped 4, to 113 3/4; Delta Air Lines was off 3/4, to 57 7/8; USAir Group fell 3/4, to 12 1/8, and British Air's American depository receipts were down 1/2, to 52 7/8. Southwest Airlines, which matched American's fare cut, lost 3/4, to 43 1/2.
 
Philip Morris Up to $77
 Philip Morris climbed 1 5/8, to 77, after the company said it would buy back about $3 billion in shares.
Teradyne, a maker of electronic test equipment based in Boston, dropped 3 1/2, to 11 1/8. At its annual meeting, the company projected lower second-quarter earnings.
Sbarro, the Italian restaurant chain that is traded on the American Stock Exchange, climbed 2 1/2, to 25 1/2. The company is to meet today with managers and Wall Street analysts to discuss a recent quarterly earnings report that sent its stock price tumbling.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar and Gold Decline In a Day of Listless Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against most currencies yesterday in trading thinned by a holiday in Europe.
Gold prices also fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $337 a troy ounce, off $1.20 from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold had slipped 65 cents an ounce, to $336.90. 
 The dollar traded in narrow ranges.
Markets in much of Europe were closed for Ascension Day, and analysts said they expect many dealers to be absent today as well. Interest in the dollar was slight, traders said.
In addition, there was not much news to move the market, said Kevin Logan, chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation. New unemployment figures indicating a small drop in first-time claims were taken as a positive but not significant sign, he said.
The Labor Department said initial jobless claims had declined by 4,000, to 403,000, during the week that ended on May 16. "The data didn't lead anyone to change their views on what's going on in the economy," Mr. Logan said.
But the weekly United States money supply figures, released after the New York close yesterday, may move markets in Asia, said Kevin Lawrie, the Bank of Boston's director of foreign exchange.
The data showed that M-2 growth had contracted by $7.4 billion in the week that ended on May 18 -- higher than the $4.5 billion economists expected. The data could push the Federal Reserve to make more money available and ease interest rates, traders said. Speculation about the Fed's monetary policy has driven the dollar lower in recent weeks.
In Tokyo the dollar rose to 129.92 Japanese yen, from 129.78 yen late Wednesday. Later, in London, it fell to 129.60 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 129.50 yen, down from 130.20 late Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8060, from $1.8010 late Wednesday. In New York the pound finished at $1.8050, up from $1.7950 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
An Anti-Plonker Bids a Farewell

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
STEPHEN POTTER, creator of "Gamesmanship," the art of being one-up on competitors, called economics "the plonking science." And what is plonking? Mr. Potter instructed those who would learn to plonk in this way: "If you have nothing to say, or, rather something stupid and obvious, say it, but in a 'plonking' tone of voice -- i.e., roundly, but hollowly and dogmatically."
As an economic journalist, I have sought to rid economics of its plonking tone, and, more important, to demonstrate that behind the tone, economics has nonstupid and nonobvious things to say. 
 For instance, there is Slutsky's Proposition, maintaining that the moving average of a random series of numbers oscillates through time; or Keynes's Paradox of Thrift, postulating that an individual can save more by spending less but an entire society may wind up saving less if it cuts spending; or Pareto-optimality, the concept of an ideal economic state at which nobody can be made better off without making somebody else worse off.
These concepts and doctrines are relevant to such issues as how to get the economy to expand more vigorously and how to solve America's social ills. But none is an eternal verity; each is a tool, useful if applied appropriately to an economy in a particular state and to serve a particular objective, and destructive if misapplied.
A government or central bank can be led into a policy of do-nothing if Slutsky's Proposition is interpreted to mean that randomness is all and any deliberate effort to stabilize the economy will destabilize it further. Keynes's paradox of thrift may be useful for helping to cure unemployment but not inflation or stagflation; it offers short-term stimulus but may worsen debt, reduce savings and investment, and curb long-term growth. Pareto-optimality may be employed to support a right-wing social policy by implying that an effort to help the poor will worsen the state of society, if it makes the rich worse off, even temporarily.
The relative simplicities of economics are essential as a means of making sense of an incredibly complex world. The danger comes when economists fall in love with particular abstractions and confer upon them a kind of Platonic truth, as though they were more real than reality itself. From that conceit, it is a short jump to the kind of dogmatism and plonking against which Stephen Potter inveighed. One serious problem is that the dogmatic plonkers do not agree on their dogmas, and the profession of economics becomes a mud-slinging match against rivals.
The real world that we inhabit and try to understand and, if possible, improve is one of people, smart and dumb, ambitious and lazy, good and bad and in between, and institutions, rigid and flexible, free and enslaving, decadent and progressive, as well as the natural environment. Economics cannot restrict itself to studying a very limited domain, to which it assertedly holds a magic key.
As an economic journalist, I felt that what I had to explain was not eternity but particular events, developments, stories or, to be fancier, history. This meant trying to understand Presidents, Treasury secretaries, Federal Reserve chairmen, and other decision makers or evaders.
And it meant dealing with the question of whether those "heroes," to use Thomas Carlyle's term, mattered all that much or whether institutions -- the White House, the political party and its ideology, the Fed and its traditions, including an addiction to secrecy, the Pentagon and its own obsession with secrecy (an instrument everywhere of power and autonomy), the corporation, the media, the courts, the laws of the land, property rights, civil rights, etc. -- were the real shapers of history, including economic history.
Soviet Communism was brought down by its institutions, and the inefficiency and corruption and inhumanity they bred into the system -- and into its leaders, secret police and bureaucrats. And the most difficult job of the transition to a market economy is building new institutions.
I see economics as a branch of philosophy -- moral philosophy, as it was called in the days of Adam Smith. Its mission was and still is to improve the lot of humanity, especially for the poor.
It has been a privilege to pursue this career on the staff of a great newspaper dedicated to truth in all its complexity. It is never easy to be sure one has gotten the whole truth, and there are many sides to an important question. Nevertheless, my conviction is that there always is such a thing as the truth and one must pursue it with all one's heart and mind -- and with the deepest respect for the facts. And, if possible, with humility and a sense of humor.
I have been fortunate to have had, these many years, the sensitive help of the artist Nicolae Asciu, who always knew what I was trying to say, and said it shorter. I have also had the benefit of voluminous letters from people who liked what I had written and people who hated it. To friends and foes alike, I bid an appreciative farewell.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

New Home for 'Guernica'
The board of directors of the Prado in Madrid voted last week to allow Pablo Picasso's "Guernica," now displayed within a huge bulletproof case in an annex of the museum, to move several blocks away to the Reina Sofia Art Center, Spain's national museum of contemporary art. The Reina Sofia is also getting other works from the Prado, including Picasso's drawings for "Guernica," several Cubist works by both Picasso and Juan Gris (the bequest of the collector Douglas Cooper) and two Joan Miro paintings from the artist's family.
"It's a reorganization of the collection," said Maria de Corral, the director of the Reina Sofia. "As the national museum of contemporary art, we are getting 20th-century works from the Prado, and in exchange the Prado will be getting some 19th-century art from us." 
 The "Guernica" announcement did not come as a surprise in Spanish art circles, since the plan has been under discussion for more than four years. Still, the final move caused somewhat of an uproar among critics who contend that the 1937 work, about the bombing of the ancient Basque town of Guernica by German planes, should remain in the Prado. Moving it, they say, betrays Picasso's wishes that it be displayed there permanently. Picasso specified that the painting, which had been on loan for decades to the Museum of Modern Art in New York, should go to Spain once Generalissimo Francisco Franco left power and democracy was established in the country.
When "Guernica" arrived at the Prado in 1981, in time for the centennial celebration of Picasso's birth, it was placed behind bulletproof glass because the Spanish Government feared that the painting, a symbol of anti-fascism and a rallying cry for Spanish republicans, might be vandalized. In 1974, while displayed at the Museum of Modern Art, the painting was splashed with red paint as a political protest by an Iranian artist, Tony Shafrazi, who is now an art dealer in New York City. The work was subsequently restored. There have been no further attacks.
"It's a key work," said Mrs. de Corral. "And it belongs in the Reina Sofia. The painting is owned by the Spanish Government and was bought by the Republic."
When it arrives at the Reina Sofia next month, it will be displayed in a room by itself, again behind a wall of bulletproof glass. "But in a simpler way than it was at the Prado," said Mrs. de Corral. "It will be less isolated than it has been." Plans to reorganize the Reina Sofia's collection include displaying works chronologically and by movements. "Guernica," while in a room by itself, will be shown along with its preparatory sketches and drawings, as it was in the Prado, but it will not be as isolated.
Although no exact date has been set, Mrs. Corral said the work should be on display in about six weeks.
 
Sotheby's Cellar
 The one-stop shopping-center mentality that the chairman of Sotheby's, Alfred Taubman, introduced in New York 10 years ago is being copied in the company's London headquarters. Sotheby's 72d Street galleries offer customers pricey artworks upstairs and lower-end items in what they call the Arcade, or basement. This week Sotheby's, London has opened an Arcade of its own. With the art market even shakier in London than it is in New York, Sotheby's move is an attempt to broaden its client base by offering a greater variety of art and objects under one roof.
In New York, Arcade items range in price from about $500 to $2,000. London's Arcade, which is in a new gallery on the main floor of its sprawling Bond Street building, has priced its offerings from $700 to about $2,100. The first sale, Oriental Works of Art from the Neolithic Period Onward, took place Wednesday and yesterday.
The sale did far worse than Sotheby's expected. The total for the two days was $524,000, well under its low estimate of $919,000. "It didn't dishearten us at all," said Roger Faxon, managing director of Sotheby's, Europe. "We had only modest expectations for the sale. In the future we plan to do more aggressive marketing."
"Certainly it's true that a healthy part of our business has been with goods under 1,500 pounds," said Mr. Faxon. (In dollars, the figure is about $2,550.) Previously, Sotheby's held auctions of cheaper items in two country house sales rooms, one in Sussex and another in Chester. Eighteen months ago it closed its Chester branch. Sussex will stay open, however, offering general sales of items like the contents of country houses as well as garden statuary, sporting guns, and oak and country furniture.
"The Arcade sales in London will be scheduled in close proximity to the major sales in the same area," said Mr. Faxon. "We conducted a survey of what kind of service our clients wanted, and this is what came out of it."
 
Arts Magazine at the Brink
 Like most other publications, art magazines are having trouble getting advertising these days, but if help doesn't come fast, it looks as though Arts Magazine will be another victim of the recession. A little more than a year ago, Contemporanea failed. Artscribe, the British magazine, closed this year. Now, Arts Magazine, a 66-year-old New York publication that covers the contemporary art scene and has a circulation of 16,000, has not been able to afford to print its May issue. (It had problems getting out in April, too. It made it to the newsstands, but subscribers are only receiving copies this week.)
"Our pockets aren't as deep as the other guys'," said Paul Shanley, the magazine's publisher. "But we intend to keep the magazine going. We are in the middle of negotiations with a potential buyer." Mr. Shanley declined to discuss who the buyer was or how realistic the offer seems. He did say he was hoping to have news of a deal next week.

HEADLINE: Cultural Groups Plead With City For More Funds

 BODY:
In an effort to have the $19.7 million recently cut from New York city's culture budget restored, representatives of the 31 cultural institutions that occupy city-owned buildings presented a slide show to members of the City Council yesterday.
The presentation included a "Recovery Plan" that showed how the money would be used by cultural groups if the city's financial support were restored to the 1991 level. 
 For example, library hours and programs for children and teen-age mothers would be resumed at the Brooklyn Children's Museum; the fire and safety system at the Studio Museum in Harlem would be repaired and brought into compliance with city codes, and the American Museum of Natural History would rehire 25 "vitally needed" guards and maintenance people.
"With this support, we can insure that New York's cultural institutions will continue to stimulate the city's economic revival and to educate and enlighten its citizens," said Harvey Lichtenstein, chairman of the Cultural Institutions Group and president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
The City Council is scheduled to vote on the 1993 budget next month.

HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
Folk Tunes That Address Real Folks

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
"I really feel that working people are at a disadvantage when it comes to surviving in this world," the folk singer and songwriter Hazel Dickens declared recently. "The big corporations have just taken over, and there's not much room now for the little person. The last two Administrations have really been tough on the working class."
Ms. Dickens, who was speaking by telephone from her home in Washington, has been writing and singing songs about the lives of working people for more than 40 years. Tonight she is appearing at Weill Recital Hall in the second concert of the second annual Carnegie Hall Folk Festival, which continues through June 12. Joining her in an evening titled "Workin' in a Coal Mine" will be the Rabbit Ridge Pea Pickers and Nomonde Ngubo, all of them, like Ms. Dickens, with bitter experience of the hardships of the coal-mining life. 
 Ms. Dickens, who was born in Mercer County in West Virginia, is one of the 11 children of a Baptist preacher who hauled timber for the mines. A song she expects to perform is "The Mannington Mine Disaster," which tells the true story of a mine explosion that left 78 miners sealed in the earth. Another, "Black Lung," she wrote for her oldest brother, who contracted the ailment from breathing coal dust. She has lost three brothers to the disease.
The Rabbit Ridge Pea Pickers -- a quintet composed of three brothers, Billy Rhea (on fiddle), Burl Rhea (on banjo) and Denver Rhea (on mandolin), a nephew, Gary Bailey (on guitar), and a friend, Lonnie Hobson (on bass) -- are all coal miners from Russell County in Virginia. They have been performing together since 1970. Four years ago, they changed their name from the Buffalo Mountain Boys after entertaining their fellow workers on a picket line for the United Mine Workers in Rabbit Ridge, Va.
 
Teaching With Song
 And Ms. Ngubo, the third act on the bill, is a union organizer from South Africa who was associated with the Federation of Black Trade Unions and the National Union of Mine Workers in her homeland. In 1983, she moved to the United States and spent two years studying industrial relations. Six years ago, she worked with the United Mine Workers during a boycott of the Shell Oil Company. In 1991 she joined the Institute of Policy Studies, a research group in Washington. She lectures at leadership training programs in high schools, colleges and churches, using songs to teach people.
Ms. Dickens, who is the host of this evening's show, left West Virginia at 16 to follow her older sister to Baltimore, where she took jobs in factories and worked as a waitress and sales clerk, all the while remaining connected with union work. Through one of her brothers, she met the folk singer Mike Seeger, who introduced her to Alice Gerard, a college-educated singer with a passion for bluegrass music. The two became a vocal duo and developed a repertory by studying sheet music in the Library of Congress and by attending folk festivals and taping the performances of old-time musicians.
In 1965, they recorded the first of four albums together and gained a feminist following performing such original Dickens songs as "Working Girl Blues." The duo recorded three albums for Rounder Records, after which Ms. Dickens went solo. Rounder has put out five solo albums by Ms. Dickens, whose hard Appalachian twang is driven by a fierce sense of commitment to friends and causes.
The turning point in her career, Ms. Dickens said, was Barbara Koppel's acclaimed 1974 documentary of the coal-mining struggle, "Harlan County U.S.A," on whose soundtrack she sang four songs. One number from the film, "They'll Never Keep Us Down," was later used by the United Mine Workers as the title song for a video on organizing. In 1987, she appeared as well as sang in John Sayles's film "Matewan."
 
The Music Won
 It wasn't until 1979 that Ms. Dickens decided to make music a full-time career.
"I decided if I was going to starve, I was going to starve doing something I liked," she said. "I had been promoted to being the manager of a small retail store, but it seemed like I never had a day off to myself. I decided I had to do one or the other, and the music won out. It was the best decision I ever made, because although I don't make much money, I can at least go visit people when I want to."
"I still write whenever the urge hits me," she continued. "I'm a homemade-type personality who doesn't do anything on schedule. Right now I'm trying to write a song about the way the economy is and unemployment running so high among workers. What bothers me is the way that people who have spent their entire lives working in factories, mills and mines are getting laid off without any benefits."
This evening's show is at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $20 and are on sale at the Carnegie Hall box office or through Carnegie Charge, (212) 247-7800.

HEADLINE: Portrait of America;
3 States That Set a Pace For the 'Average' America

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In the nation's self-portrait by numbers, New Jersey, Connecticut and in particular New York State can be found largely where they are on any map: at the edge.
The statistical average American would be a stranger in New York, though the person generally would find its neighboring states more like home. But by many economic measurements in the 1990 census, all three states rank near one end of the spectrum or the other compared with the remaining 47 and the District of Columbia. 
 Connecticut can claim the nation's highest household median income, the highest percentage of people who make more than $150,000 a year and the second-lowest poverty rate.
New York often defies its national stereotype when measured as a state, rather than being defined just by its largest city. But it is distinguished by smaller percentages of homes or apartments that are owned by their occupants, of households that include married couples, of people who drive to work alone, and by more than four times the national average of people who commute to work on public transportation. New Yorkers also take longer to get to work.
 
Biggest Not Always First
 But even New York City itself ranks behind other major cities in several categories that signal economic and social distress. New York is fifth in the percentage of its children living in poverty (with 29.9 percent, behind Detroit, Chicago, San Antonio and Philadelphia); fourth in the percentage of its elderly who are poor (with 16.5 percent, behind Detroit, San Antonio and Houston), and eighth, with 9.6 percent, in the percentage of high school dropouts who are unemployed or not in the labor force.
States were artificial creatures of political map-makers, so statistical comparisons among them can obscure vast disparities within them. New York, for example, contains among the wealthiest (Nassau) and the poorest (the Bronx) counties in the nation. Also, for the most part the statistics do not reflect the impact of the recession, which hit the Northeast most severely since the census was taken two years ago. Nor do the figures include hundreds of thousands of people -- many of them poor, black or Hispanic -- who local officials say went uncounted.
Yet the statewide figures suggest a number of trends, when measured against one another, and against comparable figures from 1980.
"In most characteristics, Connecticut comes up high in education, income and housing valuation, New Jersey is somewhat behind and New York brings up the rear," said Connie O. Hughes, an assistant director for occupational and demographic research in the New Jersey Department of Labor.
 
Positives and Negatives
 New York in particular, said Regina Armstrong, an economic consultant for the Regional Plan Association, "has always been ahead of the rest of the country, either in the positive or the negative."
In all three states, the population is slightly older, more urban and better educated than the national average -- ranking roughly in the middle third in the percentage of high school graduates, but higher among those who received a bachelor's degree.
All three rank near the top in median household income -- Connecticut is first, with $41,721. New Jersey is third, with $40,927 and New York is 11th with $32,965. Per capita income in all three states is about two to three times the national average of $7,290.
New York fared better in another measure of wealth, the percentage of its people who make $150,000 or more. Again, Connecticut is first, with 3.53 percent; New Jersey is third, with 2.95 percent; and New York is fifth, with 2.48 percent.
 
Memorie of a Boom
 Reflecting the booming 1980's, real income in all three states rose by 18 percent or more between 1980 and 1990, as it did in only five other states, all in New England or in the mid-Atlantic region.
New York State was distinguished by greater poverty in the region, but with rates well below nearly half the states.
From 1980 to 1990, poverty rates declined slightly in all three states. New Jersey registered the sixth-largest decrease nationwide, but that was only 1.9 percent. The decline in Connecticut and in New York was even smaller.
Connecticut and New Jersey had the second- and third-lowest poverty rates in 1990 -- 6.8 percent and 7.6 percent, respectively. The rate in New York was about twice that, 13 percent, making it 31st. That was marginally higher than Florida, California and Ohio, but substantially less than the rate in many Southern states.
When the states were ranked by the percentage of families headed by women with small children and living in poverty, New York fared worst in the region, 20th, with 57.2 percent. Connecticut was 11th, with 51.5 percent, and New Jersey was eighth, with 45.9 percent. All three were below the national average, though not by much.
 
Differences Abound
 New York ranked second highest, behind only North Carolina, in the percentage of high school dropouts 16 to 19 years old who are either unemployed or who are otherwise not in the labor force. New Jersey was 11th, with 7.85 percent; Connecticut was 51st, with 2.81 percent.
"This region is different," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It is different in its industries. It is different in its people. We have a greater concentration in complex and demanding jobs and more of a problem in taking measure to bring new deomgraphic groups into the mainstream.
"Connecticut is very different from New York and New Jersey," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "And New York, when it comes down to cases, is very different from every place."
Nowhere is the region's changing complexion more visible than in New York State.
"There's no question that New York City and Los Angeles are the two major poles for immigrants to the United States, and no other metropolitan area comes close," said John Mollenkopf, a political science professor at the City University of New York Graduate Center. "That is changing all of our old stereotypes and shibboleths about what race and ethnicity mean."
 
People on the Move
 New York was third highest in the percentage of residents who had been born in the state, 8 in 10, compared to 6 in 10 in both New Jersey and Connecticut. But more than 1 in 20 New Yorkers immigrated from outside the United States during the 1980's. That was about half the number as in California, but enough to place New York second in the percentage of immigrants. New Jersey was fifth, with 1 in 20. Connecticut was 14th with about 1 in 40.
All three states were among the top 10 in the percentage of residents who speak a language other than English at home.
"In New York, there are pockets of extremes and places that mirror national averages," said Robert Scardamalia, chief demographer for the State Department of Economic Development. "In factors heavily weighted by immigrant populations, New York will stand out from national averages."
Both New York and New Jersey have a higher proportion of black residents than the national average, but the disparities among the three states were greatest in the percentage of non-Hispanic whites.
Nationally, they constitute about 80 percent of the population. Non-Hipsanic whites account for 69 percent of the population in New York and 74 percent in New Jersey. In Connecticut, they represent 87 percent.
People who classified themselves as Hispanic accounted for 6.5 percent of Connecticut's population, again, below the national average of 9 percent. In New York, they made up 12.3 percent; in New Jersey, 9.6 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
A Stung Clinton Attacks Bush and Pokes at Perot

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 28

 BODY:
Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas, whose efforts to stage a triumphant final march to the Democratic nomination have been all but drowned out by the attention given to Ross Perot, struck back today with a veiled attack at Mr. Perot and a direct assault on President Bush.
Mr. Clinton, who had planned to travel the country raising money and campaigning in New Jersey and Ohio during the next several days, scrapped that agenda late Wednesday. By this morning the Governor and his strategists, stung by polls showing the campaign continuing to lose ground to Mr. Perot, had decided to use an appearance here in Silicon Valley as a first step toward regaining the spotlight. 
 And a poll published today in the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette showed Mr. Clinton and his Democratic rival, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., in a virtual tie going into Tuesday's primary. The poll of 374 likely Democratic voters, which was conducted Friday through Tuesday by Mason-Dixon Political-Media Research Inc., showed Mr. Clinton with 45 percent to 44 percent for Mr. Brown. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
Mr. Clinton told supporters that the President governs "by a nutty theory of abandonment of responsibility." The latest example, he said, was the speech Mr. Bush delivered in Atlanta on Wednesday in which he cited a new report that showed more American children watch television than read.
The President, Mr. Clinton said, was attempting to shift responsibility "as they always do in Washington."
"I believe people should read more to their kids and watch less television and let them watch less television," he said. "If we had a President who put his money and his actions and his heart and his work where his mouth is, more people would follow his example."
He also accused the White House of cutting money for literacy programs and failing to fully pay for Head Start.
 
Veiled Perot Reference
 Although he did not mention Mr. Perot by name, the intent of his dig was unmistakable. "But there's something else we don't need four more years of either," Mr. Clinton said. "Talk that sounds good with no plan or action to back it up. Anybody can talk about change, but there's one person in this race that's worked 10 years to improve education and to generate jobs in a tough global economy, and to bring people together, one person who's offered a plan instead of just saying things that sound good."
Mr. Clinton's advisers have wavered about how best to handle Mr. Perot and have been frustrated that reporters have spent more time asking about the Texas billionaire than about the President, whom they consider vulnerable.
As Mr. Clinton headed into a string of satellite interviews, appearances on radio talk shows and a taped interview with David Frost on PBS that is scheduled to air Friday night, he clearly hoped that today's remarks would turn attention back to his own top priority: portraying himself as as the best alternative to Mr. Bush. He has also agreed to appear on live television call-in program on CBS Tuesday night. Mr. Perot and the President were also invited, but declined, the network said.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that he would have to alter his approach to be heard in California. "I have done everything I knew to do in this campaign, and I obviously have to do a better job of piercing through," he said. "Maybe one way of doing that is to be more aggressive."
Mr. Clinton and his campaign officials said he canceled plans for further campaigning in Ohio and New Jersey to avoid more all-night coast-to-coast flights within the next few days.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate;
Perot in Wide-Ranging TV Interview

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 28

 BODY:
In a television interview, Ross Perot, the likely Presidential candidate, said that he opposed raising taxes to trim the Federal budget deficit, that it would not be "realistic" for homosexuals to be in the armed forces and that he would not appoint homosexuals to top Cabinet-level jobs.
"No, I don't want anybody there that will be a point of controversy with the American people," the Dallas billionaire said during a segment of the ABC-News program, "20/20," which is scheduled to be broadcast Friday night. "It will distract from the work to be done. See, as far as I'm concerned, what people do in their private lives is their business." 
 During much of the interview, conducted by Barbara Walters, Mr. Perot repeated homilies familiar to those who have seen him on programs like the Larry King and Phil Donohue shows. In recent weeks, as the drive to place Mr. Perot's name on the ballot has gathered momentum and public opinion polls have shown him leading or in a dead-heat with President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic nominee, Mr. Perot has been under increased pressure to make his opinions known on critical issues.
A transcript of the interview, which was taped on Monday, was provided by the show.
 
Straightforward Answers
 Although he rarely gave detailed explanations of his views, Mr. Perot provided several straightforward answers to questions without the rancor he often has displayed when pressed on a particular subject.
For example, when he was asked if there should be parental approval for an abortion, he replied: "We're saying a 15-year-old girl? Sure. I think her parents should have a vote in that."
In commenting on last year's Senate Judiciary Committee hearings into allegations that Clarence Thomas had sexually harassed Anita Hill, a law school professor, when the two of them worked at the Department of Education and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Mr. Perot castigated both the Senate and the nominee.
"I thought it was reprehensible, the way the Senators treated Dr. Hill," he said. "They were willing to destroy her for partisan reasons. And I thought it was a sad day for our country and really damaged the credibility of the Senate with the American people."
Ms. Walters asked Mr. Perot if he were a member of the Senate, would he have voted to confirm Justice Thomas.
"I would vote for a Supreme Court Justice without regard to color," Mr. Perot said of Justice Thomas, who is black. "I'd vote, vote solely based on ability. I have serious questions about his ability."
Would he have voted against him?
"Well, it, I'd say in, in that case, I would have urged the President to come forward with a more capable person," Mr. Perot said.
Asked about his ideas for reducing the Federal deficit, Mr. Perot said he favored a Congressional act to limit Federal spending and promised he would soon deliver proposals to cut waste in the Federal budget.
 
'Getting Rid of Waste'
 "The second thing you've got to do is then just turn the world upside down aggressively, getting rid of the waste," he said after declaring support for legislation to limit spending. "And there is a lot of waste. And in a few weeks I will be able to go down my detailed list of where the waste is so that we can get in very, very specifics."
Mr. Perot added that he wanted to "replace our current tax system with a new tax system," which he said he would develop in consultation with leading members of Congress.
When asked about increasing taxes, however, Mr. Perot said, "I'm absolutely against raising taxes."
In foreign affairs, Mr. Perot repeated his assertion that he would provide financial aid to the former Soviet republics to help them become economically viable. "I think the most cost-effective thing we can do is to help Russia get through the transition successfully," he said.
Mr. Perot, who has had contentious dealings with the State Department when he tried to deliver mail, food and medicine to American prisoners in North Vietnam in 1969 and 1970 and when two of his employees were jailed in the Iranian Revolution in 1979, said he would restructure the department.
 
State Department Shakeup
 "Well, first off, the embassies are relics of days of sailing ships," he said. "At one time, when you had no world communications, your ambassador spoke for you in that country. But now, with instantaneous communication around the world, the ambassador is primarily in a social role."
Seated by Mr. Perot's side during the interview was his wife, Margot, who is rarely seen at public events and has granted few interviews. She told Ms. Walters that as First Lady, she saw herself having a "supporting role."
"I -- really -- I say that because my first priority is the family, and creating a happy home life for Ross," she said.
Mrs. Perot described herself as an "independent" woman who "reads" and has her own opinions. But she said she does not provide any counsel for her husband. "He doesn't need my advice," she said.
Mrs. Perot said the biggest misconception about her husband was that he is "thin-skinned," and, without naming them, she criticized reporters for projecting that image.
"I think they're trying to, to build a persona that I wouldn't recognize at all," she said. "I think he's very warm."
Then she added: "Well, he may be impatient with some of the questions that they ask him. But I find that that's not the man he is, certainly not at home."

HEADLINE: Panel Votes to Release File on Kennedy Death

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
A House subcommittee today unanimously approved legislation to release Government records on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
The panel, the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Economic and Commercial Law, gave the legislation its first favorable vote after defeating two Republican amendments that would have increased the executive branch's control over the documents. Today's action moves the measure to the full Judiciary panel. 
 The bill would set up a judicially appointed citizens' review board to examine all the secret files on the assassination and recommend which should be released. The President could withhold documents on the ground of privacy or national security, however.
The secret material contains everything from autopsy photographs and top secret intelligence reports to newspaper clippings and tax returns.
The Warren Commission concluded in 1964 that Lee Harvey Oswald, acting alone, killed Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963. Conspiracy theories have abounded ever since.

LENGTH: 459 words

HEADLINE: On China: Beyond All or Nothing

 BODY:
Very soon, President Bush is expected to renew China's favorable trade status for one more year despite Beijing's horrendous abuses of human rights. Before he does, he should consider a clever new proposal for using selective trade sanctions to advance human rights.
This fine-tuned approach was proposed by Holly Burkhalter of Human Rights Watch in a Times Op-Ed article this week. It would smartly sidestep the all-or-nothing trap that doomed past Congressional efforts to pressure China by putting conditions on all trade. If adopted by the President and Congress, it could rebuild consensus on China policy and restore Washington's squandered bargaining power with Beijing. 
 Despite Americans' horror over Beijing's 1989 massacre of democracy demonstrators, its continuing political persecutions and fierce repression of minorities, Congressional efforts to attach human rights conditions to China's trading status have repeatedly fallen short. A key reason was legislative overreach. Human rights advocates have tried to restrict trade severely unless unrealistic conditions were met, like the release of all political prisoners.
Sobered by successive setbacks, some rights advocates now favor a more narrowly calibrated approach. And the Bush Administration, at least in reacting to commercial abuses, has shown itself willing to threaten selective penalties. Put selective sanctions and human rights together, and America can constructively assert its influence on behalf of liberty.
Ms. Burkhalter proposes threatening China with tariff increases against selected products unless it agrees to release a significant number of political prisoners, respect basic religious freedoms and open its prisons and labor camps to international inspection. The longer Beijing resists, the higher tariff penalties could go.
There's reason to hope threats alone might produce results. When Washington threatened selective tariff reprisals for patent and copyright violations last year, Beijing responded with reforms. China has also made limited human rights gestures to influence the trade debate.
If it did become necessary to apply penalties, Ms. Burkhalter notes, these could be aimed at exports like silk, cashmere or petroleum-related products that are mainly produced by state companies, thus preserving steps toward entrepreneurial reform in China.
The selective sanctions approach would restore honor to American policy by supporting human rights in China. It follows tactics the Bush Administration has already used on the patent and copyright issue. And it offers considerable likelihood of success while maintaining strong ties with China. The White House and Congress would do well to embrace and refine Ms. Burkhalter's proposal.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Israeli Inheritance

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
In Israel, governments change, and may again, soon. But the life of the nation has certain constants. They last from one election to another. And they are the only certain inheritance of the winner.
The permanent realities of Israel are these: 
 Its size, the geography of the neighborhood, the animosity of the neighbors, its susceptibility to day-to-day attack from just beyond its borders or terrorism within them -- and its history as the only nation in the world whose existence has been the target of political, economic, military and hate-propaganda attack every hour of its life.
No other nation has quite this collection. And whatever their differences, the two men contesting for the prime ministership are both entirely clear-eyed about every item in it.
The national realities have a lot to do with how Israelis think of themselves. The choice seems to be as passengers in a circle of covered wagons, pioneers of the frontier or, mostly, just people who would give anything for a little peace and quiet, for God's sake.
The realities make them think about questions that never have to cross the minds of Americans. Will the country really last and what do we have to do to make sure it does, always?
Or, for leaders, this question: I have the right to entrust my own life to neighbors who frighten my people but do I have the right to entrust my country? Or this, for all Israelis: whom do I despise more, the terrorists who stabbed a Jewish girl to death or the mob that shouts "Kill the Arabs"?
The tensions built into national life make some Israelis pack guns when they go to work. Others just lean on the car horn as if it were Arafat.
But every time I visit I am seized all over again by the understanding so hard to remember from the outside: Israel is a country, not some kind of lament.
Its people insist on working, studying, making music, making money, making love, dancing -- just as if they were entitled to be as happy and creative as people who do not have to do army duty every year. Music comes out of schoolroom windows.
This time, a busy Christopher Columbus, I made another discovery. That image we have about the elections -- two leaders locked in battle about almost everything vital to Israel. It is not really so.
Talks with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and with Yitzhak Rabin, the front-runner at the moment, showed that although they may wish each other oblivion, they both know they may need each other again. Because of Israel's cockamamie election system, neither party may get a majority. That means whoever comes out on top may have to find partners, and Mr. Shamir and Mr. Rabin may wind up staring at each other.
On the "peace process," Mr. Rabin believes enough settlements have already been put up on the West Bank. This endears him to Washington and may get him the loan guarantees should he win.
Mr. Rabin says he will speed the day of Palestinian autonomy. Mr. Shamir's particular personality manages to obscure his own commitment toward autonomy for Palestinians.
Mr. Rabin hints that he will move Israeli troops out of highly populated areas -- without giving the Palestinians sovereignty. First of all, that would not happen until five years from now. And, like Mr. Shamir, he sees Palestinian statehood as an unacceptable military danger to Israel. Since Palestinians insist that statehood is the only acceptable goal, they may find a Rabin prime ministership as distasteful as Mr. Shamir's.
But where both men come together most importantly is in how they see the world in which Israel lives -- the world of election-to-election realities. Both said in conversations with me that the collapse of the Soviet Union and the defeat of Saddam Hussein had eased the threat to Israel for the short term.
But Mr. Rabin and Moshe Arens, Mr. Shamir's Defense Minister, underline precisely the same long-range dangers for Israel. Specifically: Iranian and Libyan nuclear weapon plans, Iraq's waiting army of skilled nuclear scientists and the rapid military buildup of Syria with Saudi cash.
Israel votes on June 23. If the election is close it may be a little time before things sort themselves out. Then Israel will find out who gets the prime ministership and the inescapable inheritance that goes with it.

HEADLINE: The State of the States of the Union

 BODY:
What a decade. Those with jobs took 42 seconds longer to get to work in 1990 than they did in 1980. Workers were less likely to car pool or use public transportation. Americans were more likely to have graduated from high school, but their children were also more likely to be growing up in poverty.
The Census Bureau asked a lot of questions in 1990, and yesterday it released many of the answers. The announcement included a comprehensive state-by-state look at a host of statistics -- on income, housing, migration into the country and among the states, and fluency in English.
