HEADLINE: U.N. Is Said to Be Ready On Yugoslav Sanctions

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 29

 BODY:
At least 13 of the 15 members of the United Nations Security Council, including Russia, appear ready to support tough economic sanctions against the Government of Yugoslavia when the issue comes to a vote on Saturday, diplomats said tonight.
They said that after a day of consultations, it appeared that four of the five Security Council members with veto power would support the sanctions resolution drafted by the United States, and that the fifth, China, would abstain. 
 A number of small changes will be made in the resolution as a result of today's consultations, the diplomats said. Food and medicine would be totally exempted from the embargo, and the United States abandoned its attempt to force Belgrade to relinquish Yugoslavia's United Nations seat and apply for membership again. Some Security Council representatives discussed the possibility of military action if Belgrade still refused to help end the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
Backfire Is Feared
 Those diplomats said they feared that the trade embargo might only make the Serbian-controlled Belgrade Government more intransigent, encouraging it to press on with efforts to carve a Greater Serbia out of the ruins of the old Yugoslav federation.
If that happens, some Council members see themselves being pushed into threatening military action along lines already familiar from their experience with Iraq. When he urged Europe to join him in imposing trade restrictions on Yugoslavia 10 days ago, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was careful not to rule out military intervention.
So far, no one is going as far as President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, who called today for United Nations or NATO military action to stop the killings in Bosnia and Herzegovina and said Turkey, a Muslim country angered by Serbian pressure on Muslims in Bosnia, is ready to send troops.
Some members say the Security Council might authorize a naval blockade of the Adriatic ports of the former Yugoslav federation, which now includes only Serbia and Montenegro. Such a blockade, they believe, could serve to enforce a trade embargo and to frighten the Belgrade authorities into a change of policy by hinting at more serious military action to come.
The Iraqi crisis provides a clear precedent for such a blockade. In August 1990, the Security Council authorized countries with naval forces in the Persian Gulf to "use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary" to enforce its trade sanctions.
 
U.N. Allows Show of Force
 Article 42 of the United Nations Charter permits "demonstrations" of military power to warn an aggressor nation that the Security Council is contemplating military action.
A second idea discussed informally by some Council members is for the United States and European countries to close the airspace over Bosnia and Herzegovina and threaten to shoot down Yugoslav warplanes and helicopters that might try to assist local Serbian militants fighting there. Once again Iraq provides the precedent, with the United States and its allies still flying regular patrols over a zone in the far north of that country that they have declared off-limits to Iraqi warplanes.
The Council has already asked the Secretary General to examine the feasibility of using United Nations peacekeeping forces to reopen Sarajevo airport for emergency relief flights and to guard humanitarian convoys.

HEADLINE: Florio Battles G.O.P. Again With 2 Vetoes

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 29

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio said today that he would use his second and third vetoes in two weeks to try to force the Legislature's Republican majority to amend two bills that backers say will help New Jersey keep jobs and business.
He was reluctant to veto the bills, Mr. Florio said, because "they reflect the need to do everything possible to help our state's business deal with the devastating effects of this national recession." 
 But he said that one measure, to extend the time that construction permits are valid, did not provide adequate protection for wetlands. Supporters of the bill, which extended construction permits granted since Jan. 1, 1989, until Dec. 31, 1994, said Federal law safeguarded environmentally sensitive areas.
 
Deciding What Is Taxable
 The Governor also vetoed a bill intended to address a 1990 tax court ruling that made items such as business machines subject to local property taxes, just as buildings are.
Mr. Florio said he wanted to protect municipalities and homeowners by amending the bill to address such traditionally taxable property as pipes, wires and storage tanks.
The New Jersey Builders Association said Mr. Florio's veto of the bill to extend permits "demonstrates a calloused insensitivity" to hundreds of thousands of the unemployed. The group's vice president, Patrick J. O'Keefe, said the measure would generate 40,000 jobs.
Environmental groups, including the Sierra Club and the New Jersey Environmental Federation, praised Mr. Florio's decision.
"Fortunately, the Governor took a look at this bill and found out what the Legislature didn't want to hear when they allowed the builders to bulldoze the bill through the process," said Robert A. Stuart, program director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.
In his first face-off with the Republicans, on May 18, the Democratic Governor vetoed a bill to roll back the sales tax to 6 percent, from 7 percent, effective July 1. The Republicans overrode the veto three days later, the first time in a decade that a veto had been overridden.

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviets Road to Capitalism Hits a U.S. Bump

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
A half- dozen newly independent republics in the old Soviet Union, still fumbling their way toward free markets and fast food, received a bracing lesson in American capitalism today. The Commerce Department said they were selling uranium at unfairly low prices and proposed a punitive import tariff that would more than double the price.
The preliminary ruling, which will be followed by a final determination in early fall, was issued in response to complaints from American uranium producers. The decision puts the Bush Administration in the embarrassing position of moving to cripple exports from some of the most impoverished republics while the United States is rallying international aid for them and criticizing Western Europe for excluding goods from Eastern Europe. 
 Struggling to set up governments and find officials trained in Western economic practices, the republics made little effort to defend themselves in a case concerning one of their most important exports.
"These guys are pretty naive over there, and they have sort of a blind faith in the American system," said James C. Cornell of the Stamford, Conn., office of Nukem Inc., a German nuclear fuels trading firm. "They're just not equipped to go in there and understand what Commerce is doing. It's hard for Americans to understand."
The collapse of the ruble and poor living conditions mean that the republics' mining and ore processing costs are the lowest in the world, so that their export prices probably do cover their costs with money left over for profits, Mr. Cornell said.
Today's decision, which proposes a 116 percent tariff and requires importers to start posting bonds for this amount immediately, drew a blistering response from the republics' American lawyer in the case. "It appears that the left hand of our Government does not know or care about what the right hand is doing, and the net result is to the detriment of the taxpayers and electricity consumers of the United States and the people of the six new struggling nations," said Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., who was the chairman of the Republican National Committee through most of the Reagan Administration.
Current and former Bush Administration officials defended the decision as the unavoidable outcome of a highly litigious and technical process over which they have little control. A long succession of laws has progressively limited the discretion of successive administrations to influence the results of trade cases for diplomatic and national security reasons.
"Our dumping procedure is a quasi-judicial process," a Commerce Department official said. "There is no political influence."
If today's decision becomes final, as appears likely, then uranium prices on the spot market may nearly double from their current levels at $7.80 a pound. But much of the world's uranium is sold under long-term contracts between mines and electric utilities, especially in Asian and European markets. Uranium is used in nuclear power plants, but at the current price it accounts for a negligible portion of their costs.
In practice, the law still gives Administration officials a little flexibility over cases in which goods may have been dumped on the American market at low prices. Many decisions must be made on which costs to include in calculating production costs. But even with political influence, it is difficult to affect the final decision by more than a few percentage points, officials familiar with the process say.
The republics botched some Commerce Department forms and failed to file others, making a detailed cost evaluation impossible, forcing the department to follow the American producers' suggestion of assuming that the republics' costs were comparable to those in Britain, Canada and Namibia.
The republics have filed separate legal cases contending that they should be excused from the petition because the case began before the breakup of the Soviet Union.
One republic that may be hurt most by the decision is Kazakhstan, which only last weekend met American requests that it eventually destroy its nuclear weapons or transfer them to Russia.
Today's decision appears to hold virtually no political benefit for the Administration to offset the international embarrassment. After more than a decade of decline, the American uranium industry now employs about 4,000 people, most of them in rural Western states like Wyoming that are already solidly Republican.
Congress has taken virtually no interest in the case, in contrast to other trade cases that have drawn numerous letters to the Commerce Department from legislators backing larger industries in their home districts.
By law, American nuclear weapons use uranium mined in the United States. The big increase in United States imports of Soviet uranium for civilian use came with a reduction of bilateral tensions in the late 1980's.
 
Imports Soared Last Year
 Imports soared to $110.4 million last year from just $2 million in 1986.
The United States has enjoyed a rapidly widening trade surplus with the former Soviet republics, exporting $3.58 billion worth of goods to them last year and importing goods worth only $812.8 million. The uranium imports have kept the bilateral trade surplus from growing even faster.
The American uranium industry's trade association welcomed today's ruling. "The industry hopes that the department's action will restore some stability to the market, which has been devastated by this massive unfair trade," said Michael McMurphy, the president of Uranium Producers of America.
Uranium prices fell last year from $12 a pound to a low of $6.75 a pound in November as the foundering Soviet Union exported much of its production and stockpiles in a desperate bid for foreign exchange.
The Commerce Department found that Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia, Tajikistan, Ukraine and Uzbekistan were exporting at unfairly low prices, while the other six former Soviet republics did not produce or stockpile uranium. Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan are the two biggest exporters, followed by Russia, Mr. Cornell said.
Uzbekistan, already one of the poorest republics, faces particular trouble now because it has little else to export, said Barnett R. Rubin, the director of the Center for Central Asian Studies at Columbia University. Kazakhstan, on the other hand, should be exporting large quantities of oil within several years as a result of last week's contract with the Chevron Corporation to develop the giant Tengiz oilfield there, he added.

HEADLINE: Corporate Profits Post Rise of 8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Benefiting from severe cost-cutting and moderately higher sales, American companies increased after-tax profits by 8 percent in the first quarter, as the economy at large grew somewhat faster than initially estimated, the Government reported today.
The profit figure, the best performance in four years, was the highlight of the Commerce Department report, which put growth at a 2.4 percent annual pace during the first three months of the year instead of the 2 percent pace estimated a month ago. 
 Three other gauges of profitability also posted strong gains, including a 9.9 percent jump from fourth-quarter 1991 levels for earnings derived from current production, as opposed to profits from asset sales or other nonrecurring transactions.
 
Stock Market Is Cited
 "There's been an enormous improvement in the profitability of firms," commented Gary Ciminero, chief economist for the Fleet Financial Group based in Providence, R.I. This, he and others said, is reflected in new peaks in the stock market, where investors like both the profits themselves and their implications for lower interest rates as companies are better able to finance expansion without having to borrow.
The profit and growth figures in the report today gave the stock market further encouragement, and the Dow Jones industrial average held well above the 3,400 milestone level for most of the day. But late selling pushed the average down to a close of 3,396.88, off 1.55 points. [Page 36.]
In a separate report today that also gave signs of a strengthening economy, the Federal Reserve found in its quarterly survey of loan officers that demand for business and consumer loans "generally strengthened" over the latest three months. [Page 34.]
The Commerce Department's upward revision in gross domestic product was considered satisfactory even though most analysts had expected an even larger advance. The data did, however, prompt some analysts to trim estimates for the current quarter since inventories were not reduced during the winter as much as had been thought.
The President's top economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, called today's report "good news -- further demonstrating a return to a pattern of solid economic growth." He dismissed the fact that the revised G.D.P. fell short of what had been anticipated, pointing rather to recent improvement in the automotive sector that he said bodes well for employment and production in coming months.
 
Outlook to Be Revised
 Mr. Boskin confirmed the Administration's intention to make a "significant upward" revision of its estimate for 1992 G.D.P., now 2.2 percent on a fourth quarter to fourth quarter basis, to a figure thought to approach 3 percent.
The main factors in adding four-tenths of a point to the first-quarter G.D.P. rate were smaller reductions of inventories and an advance rather than a decline for business investment.
Inventories shrank at an annual rate of $26 billion rather than $33.7 billion, thereby swelling G.D.P. by $7.7 billion. For the current quarter, and later in the year, however, the effect will be negative, because the fuller shelves will need less restocking. Nonresidential fixed investment grew at a $2.1 billion pace instead of shrinking $1.9 billion, adding $4 billion to output.
On the other hand, exports were considerably less robust than first estimated, with the result that foreign trade represented a $1-billion-a-year drag on the economy instead of a $3.5 billion spur.
 
Inflation Rate Is Raised
 Other data showed that inflation as measured by the fixed-weighted index of prices paid by American residents ran at rate of 3.1 percent instead of the 2.7 percent reported last month.
The savings rate was 4.9 percent instead of 4.7 percent, despite the fact that personal consumption rose at an even faster pace, 5.4 percent, than first reported. Some analysts questioned the personal spending data in light of a sharp downward revision in retail sales for March, reported in mid-May.
The 8 percent rise in after-tax corporate profits, to a rate of $204.9 billion, was the biggest since an 11.1 percent gain in the first quarter of 1988, the department said. The 9.9 percent jump in profits from current production was the biggest since the second quarter of 1987, when the advance was 11.7 percent.
Other gauges showed profits before taxes rising 7.5 percent and current-production cash flow -- the internal funds available to companies for investment -- rising 4.8 percent.
Last year, corporate profits fell 4.6 percent, their third straight annual decline.
At the first-quarter pace, G.D.P. was $4,896,900,000,000 in 1987 dollars and $5,817,500,000,000 in current dollars, the report showed.
Despite the upbeat nature of many recent indicators, most analysts continued to predict that the recovery would remain subdued. "I don't see anything to suggest a dramatic acceleration," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.

HEADLINE: Demand for Loans Is Up, Fed Survey Finds

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
In a sign that the economy may be rallying, the Federal Reserve Board reported today that demand for business and consumer loans strengthened during the last three months.
 In contrast to the review in January, which found that business loans had declined, "the May survey revealed that, on balance, loan demand had generally strengthened over the prior three months," the Fed said after surveying loan officers. 
 Loan applications from small and medium-sized businesses seeking money for new investment or to finance inventory had increased, the Fed said.
 At the same time, consumers sought more credit, and banks were more willing to lend, the central bank said.
 "Loan demand is one of the signals of an improving economy," said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. "The pickup in loan demand is mirroring a pickup in the overall economy."
While demand for credit grew, banks generally left credit standards unchanged.
 
Criticism and Response

 For more than a year, critics of the banking industry blamed banks for a "credit crunch," which they said was prolonging the recession, but banks rejected the criticism and said customers simply were not seeking loans.
 Demand for home mortgages picked up during the last three months, as did applications for home- equity and consumer installment credit, the Fed said.
 The central bank surveys loan officers at three-month intervals to measure loan demand and the requirements that banks set for approving them. The latest survey covered 57 banks controlling $965 billion of assets.
 A number of banks reported easing some of their credit standards for small businesses; none of the banks surveyed reported tightening credit standards for such companies.
 Only commercial real estate companies experienced a tightening of lending standards, and that by a handful of banks, the Fed said. Residential lending standards were basically unchanged.
 While demand for loans by large corporations changed little over the last three months, demand by medium and small businesses "strengthened noticeably," the Fed said.
 The loan officers said businesses, no matter what their size, most often wanted loans to build their inventories or to make new investments.
 Of those banks reporting weaker corporate demand, several said potential borrowers apparently were using other sources of credit like the capital markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls As Japanese Support Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled sharply lower on world currency markets yesterday after early waves of aggressive dollar selling by the Bank of Japan to support the yen.
Analysts said the Bank of Japan entered the market overnight during Asian trading hours and sold dollars for Japanese yen. The move was followed by statements that the Japanese authorities might seek an even stronger yen in an effort to address their country's growing trade surplus. 
 "The Japanese are coming under a lot of political pressure" to reduce the growing trade imbalance, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA. A stronger yen would make Japanese goods more expensive abroad while making foreign goods cheaper for Japanese consumers.
The dollar continued to fall when the market opened in New York, dropping nearly 2 yen from its Thursday close.
 
Data Are Disappointing
 Traders expressed disappointment with a Government report that showed the United States economy grew at a revised seasonally adjusted annual rate of just 2.4 percent during the first quarter. Even though the Commerce Department figure was up from an initial estimate of 2 percent and marked the fastest rate of growth in three years, expectations were for an even more bullish annual growth rate of around 4 percent.
"The Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve seemed to be indicating that the figure would be a dramatic increase, and the market was disappointed," Mr. Chandler said.
Trading was choppy, as many dealers were apparently reluctant to take on new dollar positions on the final trading day of the month.
In New York, the dollar settled at 127.60 yen, down from 129.50 yen on Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 128.33 Japanese yen from 129.92 yen at Thursday's close. And in London, it fell to 127.75 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8295, from $1.8060 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.8282 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.8050.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6080 German marks, down from 1.6270; 1.4560 Swiss francs, down from 1.4770; 5.3990 French francs, down from 5.4630; 1,210.00 Italian lire, down from 1,225.00, and 1.2037 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2035.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6055 German marks, down from 1.6275; 1.4540 Swiss francs, down from 1.4780; 5.3920 French francs, down from 5.4640; 1.8080 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8325; 1,209.75 Italian lire, down from 1,225.50, and 1.2049 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2042.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $336.40 a troy ounce, off 60 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid 65 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $336.25.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $337.25 a troy ounce, from $336.45 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Up on Modest Growth Outlook

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell for the third straight session yesterday, as traders seemed to become increasingly comfortable with the view that the nascent economic recovery will be neither explosive nor inflationary.
Data released yesterday appeared to support that sense. 
 Despite a great deal of trumpeting last week from the White House, revised first-quarter growth figures showed the economy performed only modestly better in the first three months than the 2 percent rise originally estimated by the Commerce Department.
Last week Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted the revised numbers would be "substantially" higher than the initial estimate.
 
'Isn't That Hot'
 "When he said substantially, I thought it would be a really big number, like 3.5 percent," one government-securities trader said. "But 2.4 percent isn't that hot, and it's not such a great harbinger for growth in the second quarter."
Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., said the Commerce Department's revisions meant more inventories were left on shelves than previously thought.
As a result, Mrs. Ramirez said: "There should be less of an inventory buildup in the second quarter, assuming a modest pace of consumer spending. The bottom line is that second quarter growth could be weaker than expected."
In addition to the revised gross domestic product numbers, traders were also encouraged by survey results of purchasing managers in the Chicago region.
The overall survey showed that conditions in the manufacturing sector improved modestly in May. But the employment component of the index fell from April levels.
"Those two reports provided the excuse to hold on" to securities, the trader said.
 
New Economic Data
 Next week market participants will receive a raft of fresh economic data, including May employment statistics, which are scheduled for release on June 5.
Without predicting what those figures will show, analysts said they were encouraged by the market's positive reaction to reports this week that could have pushed prices lower.
"We have confronted a lot of challenges this week, from the report on Saudi Arabia's desire to push up oil prices to a healthy rebound in consumer confidence and stronger auto sales," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Despite those reports, "fixed income investors seem to be very comfortable with the notion that the recovery will be sustainable, but will not pose a threat to the bond market," Mr. Sullivan added.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10130/32 , up 9/32 , to yield 7.83 percent, compared with 7.85 percent late Thursday and 7.86 percent on May 22.
Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 10110/32 , up 6/32 , to yield 6.95 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9929/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 5.17 percent. A week ago, those securities were trading at a price to yield 5.24 percent.
 
Short-Term Results
 Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.68 percent late yesterday, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.82 percent.
In the corporate bond market, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette acted as lead manager for an offering of $122.5 million worth of high-yield securities issued by Reeves Industries.
The 11 percent 10-year senior notes are noncallable for five years. They were priced at $99.276 to yield 11 1/8.
The securities are rated Ba-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Alan Bond Gets Jail in Australia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, May 29

 BODY:
Alan Bond, who built a $7.6 billion fortune from scratch and financed Australia's 1983 America's Cup victory over the United States, was sentenced today to two and a half years in prison for fraud.
The entrepreneur, who is now bankrupt, "is a very, very debased citizen today," his lawyer, Ian Callinan, said in closing arguments to a jury in Perth District Court. "Those dizzy heights are gone." 
 Mr. Bond, 54 years old, was charged in connection with efforts to save the Rothwells merchant bank, which was hit by a run on its funds after the stock market crash in October 1987.
Mr. Bond was the central figure in putting together a $280 million rescue package. He negotiated a $12 million fee for the role of his company, the Bond Corporation, in organizing the bailout.
 
Didn't Disclose Fee
 Mr. Bond was convicted on Thursday of failing to disclose the fee to one of the rescuers he enlisted -- a longtime friend who invested $6 million. Rothwells collapsed in November 1988 with losses of about $200 million.
Mr. Bond received half the maximum sentence for the offense.
Last month, just after his divorce was made final from his wife of 37 years, he was declared bankrupt. He filed a financial statement listing personal assets of about $1 million, including a partly constructed 50-foot yacht.
Born in London in 1938, Mr. Bond emigrated to Australia with his family when he was 11. He made his first property deal at 22 using borrowed funds and quickly used the same strategy to make his first million at age 25.
At its peak, Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. had interests in brewing, media, resources and property. It had a gold mine in Chile; the Heileman brewing group and mining interests in the United States, and the Channel 9 national TV network in Australia.
 
Owned a Van Gogh
 Mr. Bond's personal tastes were expensive. He bought Van Gogh's "Irises" for a then-record $53.9 million as the centerpiece of an extensive art collection. He also owned a pair of $10 million penthouses in New York and a corporate jet.
Mr. Bond rode out the stock market crash on a strong cash flow from his beer assets but continued to overextend. The Bond Corporation eventually ran up debts estimated at more than $6 billion.
He blamed the world economic slump, high interest rates and the fall in the price of nickel arising from the Persian Gulf war for his financial woes.

HEADLINE: Joseph Trerotola, Unionist, 82; Led Teamsters Unit for 26 Years

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Joseph Trerotola, who started as a milk deliverer and rose to power in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died on Tuesday at St. Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived in Yonkers.
He died of a heart attack, his family said. 
 Mr. Trerotola served for many years as first vice president of the international union. For the last 26 years he was also president of the Teamsters' Joint Council 16, with 150,000 members in the New York City region, and chairman of the union's eastern conference, with 500,000 members from Maine to the Carolinas.
He retired under pressure last fall to satisfy Justice Department officials who had accused him of failing to investigate other union officers for ties to organized crime. Mr. Trerotola denied having mob associations and vowed, "I'm not investigating anybody." He said the Government wanted him "to be a stool pigeon."
 
Knew the Union Ropes
 Mr. Trerotola had thrived in internal union power struggles. He served temporarily as president of Joint Council 16 in 1956 during a bitter court fight between two contestants for the office who were supported by rival factions headed by the international president, David Beck, and by James R. Hoffa.
Mr. Trerotola was responsible for one of the teamsters' most vivid images when he was the host of a lavish 1986 party with tables laden with fancy food and drinks for thousands of union delegates at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.
The high point came as he and Jackie Presser, the teamsters president, were borne into the room reclining on an imperial chariot wheeled by men wearing the costumes of Roman soldiers while martial music played and the loudspeaker proclaimed "Hail, Caesar!"
Known as a calming influence, Mr. Trerotola helped New York locals settle various strikes, including walkouts by milk deliverers, fuel oil deliverers, United Parcel drivers and commercial trash collectors.
 
Social Concerns
 He also spoke out on political and social issues. In 1967 he reported that the city had lost manufacturing jobs and that welfare rolls had doubled in a decade. In a prophetic warning, he said those trends, coupled with expanded government spending, were a recipe for fiscal catastrophe. The city's financial crisis came to a head in 1975.
In 1977 he estimated that out-of-wedlock births in the city had doubled to 30 percent in a decade, a trend with social and fiscal implications. Another teamsters report that year showed that New York had the nation's highest state and local tax burden, sharply undercutting workers' take-home pay.
Mr. Trerotola is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Anita Ranalli; a son, Vincent, of Greenburgh, N.Y.; six grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: To Help Itself, Utility Aids Riot Area

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 29

 BODY:
For the Southern California Edison Company, the response to last month's riots did not end when it finally got the power back on.
The utility, whose profits from selling electricity are directly dependent on the economic health of the Los Angeles area, saw that the unrest would be another blow to the long-term prospects of the region. The area was already being hurt by a severe recession and by a flight of companies and jobs to other states. 
 The riots also made clear to corporate leaders the severity of the city's social problems, giving Edison a troubling glimpse of what the future holds if nothing is done to give inner-city residents more economic hope.
So within two weeks of the rioting, the utility put together what is so far the biggest corporate financial commitment to improving conditions in some of the area's most blighted neighborhoods. The plan is to contribute $35 million worth of cash, buildings, labor and services over the next five years to create job training centers, support educational and charitable programs, and help businesses devastated by looting and arson.
"We as a company will be successful only if the region is vibrant, and the region will be vibrant and healthy only if companies like ours assume some responsibility for leadership," said John E. Bryson, the chairman of Edison and its parent company, SCEcorp.
Southern California Edison's response is an example of what government officials and economic development experts call enlightened corporate self-interest. If they are to succeed in building a stronger economic foundation for the poor neighborhoods of Los Angeles and other cities, those officials said, they will need to persuade many more companies to adopt that kind of attitude -- and then do more.
Government officials have long looked to corporations to play a greater role in shoring up schools, providing jobs and job training and financing charities and community development efforts. But perhaps never before have corporations been so directly challenged by government officials and community leaders to make a lasting difference as they have in the wake of the Los Angeles riots.
And although they express their thanks for programs like Edison's, government and community leaders ultimately want the business community to do more than make charitable contributions. They want companies to open factories, distribution centers and other operations in poor neighborhoods as a means of creating jobs for local residents and a strong framework for further economic growth.
 
Opportunity for Profit
 In return, they acknowledge that government must work harder to give companies greater opportunity to make a profit from their investments in the inner city. No matter how civic-minded, they said, no company will stay long in any area if it is losing money.
"Corporate America has to come together on a sustained, long-term basis to create opportunities that are money-making for them and that create jobs as well as real ownership possibilities for disadvantaged people," said Mark Fabiani, a Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles. "Anything short of that means failure."
Mr. Fabiani said a number of large companies had already offered to open new factories or other operations in the area to create jobs. But none have made public announcements, and Mr. Fabiani declined to identify them. He said that the companies, local governments and the privately financed Rebuild L.A. effort headed by Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, first wanted to study issues such as community support, tax breaks and low-interest loans that would give the companies a better chance of being successful in the long run.
"Our goal has to be to convince corporations that these investments are in their best interests, that they are essential to their interests," Mr. Fabiani said. "They have to know that the investments will be profitable and ultimately advantageous to their shareholders."
But Mr. Fabiani and others said it was unclear how many companies would be willing to make substantial investments in new operations in South-Central Los Angeles and other poor communities, especially once the publicity surrounding the unrest faded away along with the urgency of dealing with the underlying problems.
 
'Project for Marathoners'
 For every company that can identify a reason to make large-scale investments in improving the inner city, there clearly are many more that see little direct benefit to themselves in taking on the problems of security, insurance and an inexperienced work force by establishing some kind of permanent presence in a blighted area like South-Central Los Angeles.
"This is a long-haul game, a project for marathoners," said Jon P. Goodman, the director of the Entrepreneur Program at the University of Southern California, who has worked extensively in aiding businesses in the inner city. "What I am really waiting to see is whether, after the crisis, after the pressure of the recent events abates, they are still there, still rolling these projects out."
There are limits, in fact, to what even socially active companies like Edison are willing and able to take on, especially when it comes to actually creating new jobs in the areas that most need them.
Mr. Bryson said Edison would try to step up hiring efforts to some extent in poor communities. Yet Edison, which like many large corporations has been reducing its work force, decided it could not prudently make a commitment to hiring any substantial number of people in coming years from the neighborhoods affected by the rioting, he said.
Edison is instead concentrating much of its effort on job training programs. As part of its $35 million plan, it is allocating $6.5 million to developing such programs in Compton and Long Beach, two of the communities hardest hit by the rioting. In Compton, the company is donating an unused building it owns and will pay for it to be renovated and then finance the center's operations. The company expects the center to provide job training for hundreds of people each year.
 
Forgiving Utility Bills
 The company plans to contribute $7.5 million in cash, equipment and technical expertise to various charities, economic development efforts and community organizations, and increase by $500,000 the $2.25 million it had previously planned to spend on a program to help "at risk" students in local schools. To help owners of homes and businesses destroyed in the rioting, the company will forgive bills owed to it by those owners and will provide low-interest loans toward the purchase of energy-efficient equipment as they rebuild.
Edison will also make a multimillion-dollar donation to Rebuild L.A. And the company said it was still seeking suggestions from community leaders on how to spend an as-yet unallocated portion of the $35 million.
"As an electric utility, we have a network of wires, but also a network of people in all of the affected communities," said Robert H. Bridenbecker, Edison's vice president for customer service. "We're talking to leaders in each community to see what's needed."
For the most part, he said, the answers have centered on help in creating jobs and in improving education. But the company has also tried to address narrower and more immediate needs by soliciting employee suggestions.
Ed Robinson, an energy services representative in Compton, suggested after talking to many customers that Edison provide some employees to help small-business owners fill out the complex forms needed to apply for assistance from the Small Business Administration. He is also pushing for the company to help involve gang members, unwed mothers and other disenfranchised residents in deciding how to address the community's problems.
 
Key Is Involvement
 Economic development specialists say the key to any company's sustained efforts at community improvement is the involvement of employees. Edison executives concede that some employees oppose the spending of $35 million to address inner-city problems, especially at a time when the company is cutting employment. But over all, they said, employee support and involvement have been strong.
"I was around after the Watts riots in '65, and I saw a lot of Band-Aid solutions," said Bill Thomas, an area manager in Compton. "I see some of the things we are doing now as having positive long-term effects."

The company plans to commit $35 million to create job training centers, support educational programs and help devastated businesses recover. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Correction: The 1990 Census

 BODY:
An article yesterday about the 1990 Census incorrectly reported two statistics on disability in some copies. The fraction of people age 16 to 64 limited in mobility or ability to care for themselves was 10 percent, not 1 percent. The proportion of those 65 or older in this category was one third, not two thirds.
Charts about the Census also contained several errors in some copies. 
 Income growth from the 1980 Census to the 1990 Census for the metropolitan region was misstated. It was 18.2 percent for New York, 23.3 percent for New Jersey and 24.0 percent for Connecticut. The percentage point increase in the high school graduation rate in each state was also misstated. It was 8.5 points for New York, 9.3 points for New Jersey and 8.9 points for Connecticut.
On a front-page chart, the percentage of New Jersey residents who had moved into the state from another country in the previous decade was misstated in some copies. It was 5.0.
Maps accompanying various census statistics erroneously showed Arizona instead of New Mexico, and a map accompanying statistics about female-headed families with young children in poverty failed to show Nevada as one of the bottom five states.
In addition, a list of five states with largest percentage of dwellings lacking telephones included Arizona in some copies; it should have listed Arkansas. Because of a production error, the figures in that list were eliminated in some copies. The top five states were: Mississippi, 12.6 percent; New Mexico, 12.4; Arkansas, 10.9; West Virginia, 10.3, and Kentucky, 10.2. The bottom five were: Connecticut, 2.6; Hawaii, 2.6; Pennsylvania, 2.6; Minnesota, 2.4, and Massachusetts, 2.1.
A map shaded to show the range of English-speaking abilities was improperly labeled. It should have been labeled people who speak a language other than English at home, not people who speak no English.
Finally, a map intended to show the percentage of people born in the state in which they now live was shaded incorrectly in some copies. A corrected map appears above.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Father Aristide's Hebrew
The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the exiled President of Haiti, took more than a few Jewish organizational leaders by surprise yesterday when he addressed them in flawless Hebrew. 
 At a breakfast meeting in Manhattan sponsored by the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, Father Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, recalled that from 1979 to 1982 he lived in Israel and studied the Bible in Jerusalem. He added in Hebrew, "I may not remember everything I learned there but in my heart I always remember 'Love thy neighbor as thyself' " (Leviticus 19:18).
Referring to the Old Testament by its Hebrew acronym, the Haitian leader added: "In the Tanach we learn how we are one family with one Father. My friends, we all believe in God, and God for us is love and peace.
"The Jews can understand what is happening in Haiti. It is not hard for you. There is no shalom in Haiti. And you understand how important shalom is."
When President Aristide, who first spoke in English, finished his Hebrew remarks, Kenneth J. Bialkin, the president of the community relations council said, "Mr. President, you give us more credit than we deserve" in assuming that all the assembled knew Hebrew.
"But we all understand the words shalom and chaverim," Mr. Bialkin said, using the Hebrew words for peace and friends. The meeting, a breakfast attended by representatives of the 63 community and religious organizations that make up the council, was held at Mr. Bialkin's law office at 919 Third Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets.
In his remarks, Mr. Bialkin said that the recent decision by the Bush Administration to turn back Haitian refugees to Haiti without giving them the chance to appeal for protection "produces very painful memories" for Jews. He recalled the boatloads of Jews fleeing Nazi persecution in the 1930's and 1940's that went "from port to port and were turned away."
Father Aristide would not be drawn into criticizing the new policy of the Bush Administration, which has supported his return to power.
As for the military coup that overthrew him last year after only seven months in power, he said he favored economic rather than armed action. "Let us continue to show how the power of love is stronger than the power of hate," he said.
 
Blue-Penciling the Archaic
 They are among the best known words in Christian prayer: "Our Father, who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name." But under a proposal by a Catholic commission that recommends liturgical changes, words like "who art" and "thy" would be edited out of the prayer as archaic.
Some Protestant denominations have already adopted the changes, as have conferences of Catholic bishops in other English-speaking countries, like New Zealand. The bishops of the United States are not expected to vote on the proposal until 1994. If approved, Catholics would say, "Our Father in heaven, hallowed be Your name."
The changes are being proposed by the International Commission on English in the Liturgy, which makes recommendations for English-speaking nations. Changes are also being proposed for another central statement of Christian faith, the Nicene Creed. Instead of saying that Christ came down from heaven "for us men," the proposed translation would say "for us."
Translators say that the new wording is faithful to the authoritative Greek and Latin texts.
Msgr. Alan F. Detscher, associate director of the liturgy commission of the United States bishops, declined to predict whether the bishops would go along with the changes.
 
Lowering Its Sights
 The Universal Fellowship of Metropolitan Community Churches, a mostly homosexual denomination, has temporarily abandoned its quest to be a full member of the National Council of Churches and is instead applying for observer status. The council is an ecumenical organization of more than 30 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations.
The Universal Fellowship, which has 27,000 members in 265 churches around the world, first applied for membership to the council in 1981.
When a series of talks about the membership issue were canceled early this month by the national council, the denomination decided to make observer status its goal.
In the last year, Orthodox groups have threatened to withdraw from the council, saying they were unhappy with what they called its "liberal leanings." But the Rev. Kittredge Cherry, ecumenical director of the Universal Fellowship, said she believed the delays had resulted from "homophobia" within the member churches rather than the objections of the Orthodox.
The Rev. J. Martin Bailey, director of communications for the national council, said that "a complex number of factors" had led to a breakdown and acknowledged that one factor may have been a fear of homosexuals among some people. But he added, "I don't know anybody who is working harder than we are in the churches to eliminate homophobia."
Mr. Bailey said he could not immediately assess whether the denomination qualified for observer status, which would allow the group to attend meetings without the right to vote.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primary;
Enthusiasm Is Lacking On Ohio Ballot Choices

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, May 28

 BODY:
Ohio is so representative of America that some political analysts half-seriously say that Ohioans should nominate Presidential candidates in a single primary and be done with the long, noisy national campaigns.
But instead of having a leadership role, this bellwether state is holding a primary next Tuesday that is expected to draw fewer than a third of the state's voters and do little more than help shutter up the long primary season. 
 "How boring," Jerry Austin, a political analyst in Columbus, said of the primary and its wasted potential.
 
A Mirror of National Patterns
 Mr. Austin, who managed the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign in 1988, is one of those who wonders if it would not be easier to just let Ohio alone pick the nominees. After all, he said, the state has shown it is a microcosm of the nation by backing the winning Presidential candidate in every general election since 1964, and it has done so with voting patterns that were always within 2 percentage points of the national winning margin.
Presidential primaries are also being held Tuesday in Alabama, New Jersey, California, Montana and New Mexico.
Many Ohioans are showing more interest in Ross Perot's undeclared candidacy than in the uncompetitive primaries. Mr. Perot is the topic of so many political conversations here that some people seem to think he is on Tuesday's ballot. Although Mr. Perot is not on the ballot, voters in both parties' primaries will be able to cast write-in votes for him.
"Perot's going to do well, but I think he's too radical for this country," said Stephen R. Giesel, 41 years old, when asked about the Ohio primary.
 
A Choice of Primaries
 Mr. Giesel, a laid-off electronics engineer who is temporarily driving a taxi, said today that he would probably vote for President Bush on Tuesday, when voters will have a choice of voting in either the Democratic or Republican primary. He said he would not vote for Bill Clinton, who appears certain to be the Democratic nominee, because the Arkansas Governor reminds him too much of former President Jimmy Carter and long lines at gasoline stations.
Expressing the dissatisfaction that many Ohioans feel with the choices available on the ballot, Gregory S. White, a 37-year-old antique dealer, said, "I'm probably going to vote for Hillary Clinton's husband."
Ohio, with its slowly diversifying industrial economy, is the nation's seventh largest state, and has an ethnically diverse population of 10.8 million people and a per capita income that tracks the national average.
As in most other states, economic worries top the list of voter concerns here, even though Ohio has weathered this recession better than many other places. In April, Ohio had an unemployment rate of 6.9 percent, as against a national rate of 7.2 percent.
"There is a lot of worry here in the state that is the nation's No. 2 auto maker," said Herb Asher, a professor of political science at Ohio State University in Columbus. "Akron's already lost the tire industry; Youngstown's lost the steel industry, and General Motors is talking about closing plants."
This week the Clinton campaign began buying some advertising on radio and television here in the Cleveland area, where 42 percent of the state's Democrats live, said Greg Has, state coordinator of the Ohio campaign. Supporters of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., Mr. Clinton's last remaining Democratic opponent, say they plan to broadcast one radio commercial in Cleveland.
The state's news organizations have concentrated on the Perot phenomenon and have given short shrift to the primary campaigns, said Jesse F. Marquette, director of the Survey Research Center at Akron University.
"Clinton made good policy speeches here last week that got almost no media play," he said. "Bush was in Ohio and didn't get much coverage. Perot hasn't been around or said anything, but he is getting all the media play."
Mr. Marquette helped put Mr. Perot's name in the news last week when he conducted a statewide voter survey. It found Mr. Perot and Mr. Bush in virtually a dead heat, 25 percent to 23 percent, with Mr. Perot holding the statistically insignificant lead. Mr. Clinton trailed far behind with 14 percent, and 36 percent of those surveyed were undecided.
To a certain extent, the Presidential primaries here have also been overshadowed by Congressional races. There are 19 districts now, down from the 21 that existed before the reapportionment this year.
Dozens of candidates are fighting for three seats opened by retiring members and there is a heated Democratic campaign in which an eight-term incumbent, Representative Mary Rose Oakar, who has been caught up in the House bank scandal, is being challenged by Timothy F. Hagan, a Cuyahoga County Commissioner.
Redistricting also created a race between two incumbent Representatives, Bob McEwen, 42, a six-term member, and Clarence E. Miller, 74, a 13-term member. Both are Republicans.
Senator John Glenn has no Democratic primary opposition and most polls show him well ahead of his likely Republican opponent in the fall, Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Expressing the dissatisfaction that many people feel with the choices available on the ballot, one voter in Ohio said, "I'm probably going to vote for Hillary Clinton's husband." Gov. Bill Clinton campaigned yesterday in Sacramento, Calif., where he addressed a town hall meeting of women. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)
