HEADLINE: THEATER;
On Broadway, the Lights Get Brighter

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
On the night Los Angeles was burning down, I went to the theater in New York.
Earlier on that Friday, May 1, such a plan might have seemed quixotic. Wild rumors and sheer panic seized New York once television images of the South-Central rioting traveled east, and Times Square emptied out at midday. Outside the Marquis Theater, home of the supposedly indomitable "Man of La Mancha," a hastily assembled wall of plywood materialized, turning one of Broadway's most conspicuous houses into a bunker suitable for downtown Beirut. 
 But the burning of New York was not to be -- not this day, anyway -- and when I returned to the neighborhood at curtain time, the theater district was reawakening. The marquees on 45th Street were all aglow, and at "Guys and Dolls," my happy destination, a line of hopeful theatergoers waiting for cancellations stretched halfway down the block. To be sure, "Guys and Dolls" is not a panacea for what ails Broadway, let alone for the ills of urban America. But on that tense night, it seemed to loom particularly bright, both as a symbol of a troubled town's resilience and as the glittery centerpiece of what nearly everyone agrees is the city's most exciting theater season artistically in years. A nationwide audience will see what some of the excitement is about as that season -- or, more accurately, the Broadway half of the season -- is celebrated tonight on the Tony Awards show on CBS at 9 P.M.
Why has "Guys and Dolls" become what politicians would call the season's defining event, proving so popular that audiences will stop at almost nothing to see it? It's not just that Jerry Zaks's production of Frank Loesser's 1950 masterpiece is fresh and fun. "Guys and Dolls" has touched a nerve because its very subject is a fantasy Broadway, both honky-tonk and cultivated, that perhaps never actually existed (except in the imagination of Damon Runyon) but that everyone keeps hoping will somehow be reborn. To believe in "Guys and Dolls" is to believe that such a rebirth is actually in the wings. And to believe that Broadway is coming back is to fantasize that New York is coming back from recession and decay, to believe that this city can solve its many problems without the riots that consumed the rival metropolis on the other coast.
These are romantic dreams, of course, and may well be shattered at any moment. Though a good Broadway season no doubt helps Manhattan's tourist trade -- no small part of the city's economy -- New York City cannot be saved by good theater alone. And the survival of good theater no longer depends in any case on Broadway, which generally imports its best plays from Off Broadway and institutional theaters throughout the country rather than create them from scratch. Yet one can watch the Tonys with a reasonably full heart tonight. Broadway's economic comeback, though not nearly as solid as the street's publicists would have us believe, is for the time being something more than an illusion. The theater district is, after all, full of booked theaters, some of them occupied by serious plays, when only months ago the landscape was defined by dark marquees, long-running English musicals and the eternally previewing and ultimately doomed "Nick and Nora." What's more, the artistic quality of the season was, if anything, even higher than tonight's undoubtedly hyperbolic Tony rites will reveal.
The Tonys will undersell the achievements of the season because this is the first year in ages when there were actually more worthy nominees in most categories than there were slots to be filled on the ballots. The four best- play contenders -- Brian Friel's "Dancing at Lughnasa," August Wilson's "Two Trains Running," John Guare's "Four Baboons Adoring the Sun" and Richard Nelson's "Two Shakespearean Actors" -- are all at the very least honorable choices, and so would have been such non-nominees as Herb Gardner's "Conversations With My Father," Alan Ayckbourn's "Small Family Business" and, had the Broadway production not emasculated its anger, Ariel Dorfman's "Death and the Maiden." A larger, even more impressive list of potential best plays could be drawn from Off Broadway productions, all ineligible for Tonys: Terrence McNally's "Lips Together, Teeth Apart," Scott McPherson's "Marvin's Room," Donald Margulies's "Sight Unseen," Jon Robin Baitz's "End of the Day" and Caryl Churchill's "Mad Forest."
The actors nominated for Tonys tonight are sensational. I will not soon forget, among other performances, best-actor nominee Brian Bedford's pickled old 19th-century ham in "Two Shakespearean Actors" and best-featured-actress nominee Brid Brennan's dreamy release from domestic drudgery into nameless ecstasy while dancing to radio music in "Lughnasa." But such was the quality of acting this season, both on and off Broadway, that one could field a gala awards ceremony with slates of performers ignored by the Tonys. Indelible theatergoing memories are made of Christine Baranski talking compulsively to ward off the hidden anguish in a Fire Island beach house in "Lips Together," of Laura Esterman extending her spirit in unselfish love even as her body fails her in "Marvin's Room," of Spiro Malas rising from bitterness and defeat to grab what he really wants in the Depression-era Napa Valley of "The Most Happy Fella."
These and the season's many other outstanding performances are thrilling in part because the roles often are. As has been true for several seasons now, the American theater is being reinvigorated by a new generation of artists, especially writers and directors. Many of the season's most interesting playwrights are in their 30's -- witness Mr. McPherson, Mr. Baitz, Mr. Margulies and George C. Wolfe (the author of "Jelly's Last Jam") -- and the producers who are making things happen, particularly in the nonprofit theaters that originated most of the best Broadway and Off Broadway plays, are often no more than a decade older. The vitality of American playwriting right now is such that by far the most adventurous and talked-about new play in London, an epic, revisionist view of recent American political, social and sexual history titled "Angels in America," is the work of a 35-year-old New Yorker, Tony Kushner. Currently in repertory at the Royal National Theater, no less, "Angels in America" is nearly certain to be a focal point of the next New York season.
As Tony show watchers will see tonight, the explosion of youthful talent now extends to the American musical, a form that has been reeling for much of the last decade and without which an economically healthy Broadway cannot exist. In 1991-92, even the one British import nominated for best musical, Cameron Mackintosh's production of "Five Guys Named Moe," is a tribute (however sanitized) to an American jazz artist, Louis Jordan, conceived and performed by Americans. It is also the only negligible show in its category, and it may mark the end of New York audiences' infatuation with the West End esthetic that places Euro Disneyland gimmicks above content. (The environmental stunt of "Five Guys," comparable to the kittyland of "Cats," is an adjoining restaurant called Moe's into whose cash bar the audience is hustled at intermission.)
The other best musical nominees of the season, to be seen in excerpt on the Tonys tonight, are, if one chooses to look on the dark side, a repackaging of old goods. "Crazy for You" is fashioned from Gershwin standards, "Jelly's Last Jam" from vintage Jelly Roll Morton jazz, "Falsettos" from two one-act musicals that were seen Off Broadway in recent seasons. And certainly the past is on view in "Guys and Dolls" and "The Most Happy Fella," the twin testaments to the genius of Frank Loesser, which have been nominated for best revival.
But in my view all these musicals give one enormous hope for a regeneration of this indigenously American theatrical form. "Crazy for You" has, in Susan Stroman, the most imaginative new choreographer to reach Broadway since Tommy Tune (who a mere season ago was the only game in town in his field); she makes us hear and see some of the most familiar and beloved songs in the American repertory as if they were written just yesterday. Hope Clarke, the principal choreographer of "Jelly's," and Christopher Chadman, of "Guys and Dolls," are also likely to have big futures following their Broadway debuts as dance makers.
Mr. Zaks and Gerald Gutierrez, the directors of the Loesser shows, are both young men who bring their rich experience with contemporary American playwrights (from John Guare to Wendy Wasserstein) to bear on works that are usually not explored for their emotional reality. Their productions are not Broadway revivals in the way that dirty term has come to mean, but rethinkings of American classics by artists too young to have seen them the first time around. Instead of relying on the old tricks and familiar stars, these directors start from scratch and create new stars, most notably Faith Prince, the Adelaide of "Guys and Dolls."
What makes "Jelly's Last Jam" and "Falsettos" remarkable is that they bring the contemporary passions that inform many of the best new American plays to the musical theater. As conceived by Mr. Wolfe, "Jelly's" is the first black Broadway musical that can truly be described as African-American, in that it views its characters' identity (and their battles with racism) from within, rather than as merely an external matter of black-versus-white melodramatics. Mr. Wolfe's depth of vision, sophistication and honesty about his subject, reflected in both his book and his direction, also lead him to reinvent the musical's form. He doesn't merely pile on jazz and blues numbers and the tap dancing of the incomparable Gregory Hines for showbiz effect but seeks to uncover the ethnic and political meaning of the music, as well as the pain and sheer rage expressed in the dancing. That this show, thorny and (its last number excepted) uncompromising, is becoming a hit with an integrated public may prove an epochal event in Broadway's cultural history.
"Falsettos" is a much different piece in style and texture but a related breakthrough for the commercial theater in content. While homosexual characters are hardly new on Broadway, even in musicals, "Falsettos" presents its gay men and women from an intimate, adult perspective on their own individual terms, much as "Jelly's" does with its black men and women, rather than turning them into generic figures engaged in predictably symbolic battles with bigots. The characters' idiosyncratic specificity gives William Finn's songs for "Falsettos" a distinctive quirkiness, both musically and lyrically, that is as far removed from "I Am What I Am" in "La Cage aux Folles" as Susan Birkenhead's tough, ribald lyrics for "Jelly's Last Jam" are antithetical to those of Broadway's civil-rights-era musicals like "Raisin" and "Purlie."
The fate of "Falsettos" as a Broadway venture is unclear. It's a small-scale musical on a street full of blockbusters, and it deals in part with AIDS. That this moving, original show should have to fight for an audience is just one example of why Broadway, despite its current boom, remains a precarious venue for any attraction that does not have one of two commercial attributes -- big stars or a large dose of spectacle.
Of all the fine plays produced on Broadway this season, the only two now playing to anything like full houses are two of the most poorly received of the lot, both of which were largely (and justifiably) slighted in most Tony categories: Mike Nichols's candied version of Ariel Dorfman's "Death and the Maiden" and Gregory Mosher's musty revival of "A Streetcar Named Desire." They have big audiences because they have Hollywood stars -- including the Tony-nominated Glenn Close (for "Maiden") and Alec Baldwin (for "Streetcar") -- and all power to them. But even these two hits, like every other straight play on Broadway, were selling tickets at the half-price ticket booth by last weekend, and they will close the moment that their stars depart in August. Many of the other, starless plays on Broadway, no matter how many Tonys they win or how good their reviews have been, will have to fight to last that long. By Labor Day, give or take a couple of weeks, the two dozen current Broadway productions may have dropped to half that number, with most of the survivors being musicals. We'll be back where we came in, and the "Is Broadway Dead?" chorus will be sounded yet again.
Why do plays without stars have such a hard time of it on Broadway, even when they receive critical acclaim and prizes? In a word, money. Audiences who are paying Broadway ticket prices, now reaching $50 for plays and $65 for musicals, want a sure bang for their buck, and that means a known title, a known name above the title, a known quantity of dancers, singers, scenery and glitter. A "Falsettos" or "Conversations With My Father" or "Two Trains Running" does not fit this bill, and the younger or more adventurous audience that might take a flyer on such shows is often priced out of Broadway entirely.
That audience has not gone away, however. When prices are lowered from the Broadway norm, whether at the half-price ticket booth or through subscription series run by companies both competent (the Tony-nominated Lincoln Center Theater and Roundabout Theater Company) and not (the new and Tony-snubbed National Actors Theater), theatergoers will turn up -- for the classic and the offbeat. It's an audience that materializes nightly Off Broadway, which is why a "Marvin's Room" or "Lips Together" will run far longer than a comparable play produced on 45th Street. It's an audience that might yet be lured back to Broadway for daring, impossible dreams more visionary than "Man of La Mancha" if the theater industry could find its Lee Iacoccas or Ross Perots -- which is to say, reformist business minds as imaginative and revolutionary as its most inventive playwrights and directors.
This year's Tony Awards should be uncommonly festive, as befits the artistic health of the 1991-92 season. But there's still a long, hot summer ahead, both in the theater and in the city around it. If you want to know more about what divisions New York is facing at this moment, the play to see is not "Guys and Dolls" but Anna Deavere Smith's brilliant evocation of the people and forces swept up in last summer's Crown Heights riots, "Fires in the Mirror," at the Joseph Papp Public Theater. If you want to know the real economic state of the commercial theater right now, you must look beyond the lines at "Guys and Dolls" to consider that hit's struggling neighbors. No matter who wins the Tony Awards tonight, this has been an uncommonly winning season for American theatrical talent. But as a business Broadway remains, more unhealthily and nervously than ever, the oldest established permanent floating crap game in New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Along West 45th Street, booked theaters, hit shows and enthusiastic audiences reflect a season of plenty. Last year, by contrast, many marquees were dark. (Lee Romero/The New York Times)(pg. 1); Photos of playbills. (pg. 6)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2700 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Just Whose 'Malcolm' Is It, Anyway?

 BODY:
"Malcolm X" is a film that didn't have to be made to be controversial. The project has been embroiled in controversy since it was launched in 1968. At that time, a screenplay by James Baldwin and Arnold Perl was commissioned by Marvin Worth, a producer who had acquired rights to Alex Haley's as-told-to "Autobiography of Malcolm X." Over the years, the focus of the controversy has changed. Initially it involved Hollywood's readiness to deal with Malcolm X. Later it concerned which phase of his ideological development to emphasize. Then it focused on whether a white director could capture Malcolm's complexity.
When Spike Lee actually began filming "Malcolm X" for Warner Brothers last year, everybody, it seemed, had an opinion about what was in store. Within the black community, ideologues and intellectuals of every stripe -- cultural nationalists and integrationists, buppies and revolutionaries, Five Percenters and Baptist ministers alike -- wondered aloud about Mr. Lee's right to portray the complex life of Malcolm X for the big screen. 
 In addition to battling critics like the poet Amiri Baraka, and amid reports of a conflict over Mr. Lee's insistence on a three-hour running time for the film, the director became engaged in a budget dispute with Warner Brothers. He also ran into financial difficulties. When Mr. Lee exceeded the film's $28 million budget, the Completion Bond Company, which insures investors against films going over budget, seized financial control and refused to approve further expenditures. In mid-May, Mr. Lee announced that prominent African-Americans -- among them Bill Cosby, Michael Jordan and Oprah Winfrey -- had responded to his appeal to donate money to save the film, which is now being edited.
But much of the hue and cry has been over who "owns" the image of Malcolm X, an image that evolved considerably. Here was a man who went from pimp, hustler and thief to defiant prisoner, black nationalist, and leading minister and propagandist for Elijah Muhammad's Nation of Islam. Then -- after a visit to Mecca -- in the year before his assassination in 1965 at the age of 39, Malcolm X became a profound humanist. So forceful and incisive in life, Malcolm has, paradoxically, become a cultural and political Rorschach blot for the generations who honor his memory. The result has been considerable discussion and soul searching about the black artist's "burden of representation," as James Baldwin put it, as well as about the film itself, which is scheduled for release in November.
One afternoon recently, at Mr. Lee's 40 Acres and a Mule Studio in Brooklyn, the film maker talked with Henry Louis Gates Jr., W. .E. B. Du Bois Professor of the Humanities at Harvard University and editor of Transition Magazine, about the making of "Malcolm X," and various other subjects -- among them, fact and fiction in films, his vision of Malcolm, his thoughts about black youth and the recent disturbances in Los Angeles. Here are excerpts from their conversation.
 HENRY LOUIS GATES JR.: The "Malcolm X" project has been in development hell for two decades. James Baldwin and Arnold Perl, David Bradley, Calder Willingham, Charles Fuller and David Mamet were attached to the project as writers at various points. What's the real reason this movie was never made -- until now?
SPIKE LEE: I just think the studios were scared of the film. And the rising popularity of Malcolm, coupled with the box-office appeal of Denzel Washington and myself, is what made it economically feasible for them to invest in the project.
GATES: David Bradley says the writers weren't fired because the scripts were wrong; they were fired because the story was wrong.
LEE: I would agree with that. Malcolm X was basically disputing the American dream. And if there's one thing Hollywood is about, it is selling the American dream. So Malcolm X is at odds with the images that Hollywood has always been about.
GATES: On the other hand, he is the American dream: the self-made man. His story is very much like Benjamin Franklin's autobiography or Booker T. Washington's.
LEE: Yes, but the story Hollywood chooses to tell is always John Doe's, Horatio Alger's. It's never been about people of color.
GATES: What do you think about the relation between the film and the facts? Any form of narrative history involves falsification or distortion to fit a narrative framework. But in the case of Malcolm X, there's an especially heavy political freight to carry. There was a taste of this in the controversy over the historical veracity of Oliver Stone's "J.F.K." While the "Autobiography" stands as a fundamentally truthful document, individual episodes are disputed or controversial. As a film maker, do you think that matters?
LEE: It does matter. That's something every film maker or writer has to deal with when dealing with someone who has lived. I think Oliver Stone's "J.F.K." is a great movie. And the most important question you have to ask is: What is the intent? Our intention is not to tear down Malcolm; for us, this is an act of love.
In those cases where we had to change names, change events or make three or four characters into one, well, I don't think that's distorting the Malcolm X story. You have to realize we're not making a documentary; we're making a drama. You can't include everything; some things you switch or turn around. But you always have to ask artists what their intent is. I know there are people who will say this film is false because Malcolm didn't do such and such, and Denzel is too light-complected; and even though he dyed his hair red, that's not the color Malcolm X's hair was. Those little things do not detract from the overall work. Let's look at the body of the film, the overall sense of it.
GATES: Is this a "Malcolm" for our time?
LEE: Viewers will have to make up their own minds. One of the reasons we've gotten static is that Malcolm was so many people. Everybody has their own Malcolm who is dear to them, and their Malcolm fits their own personal and political agenda. So everybody claims him in whatever period of life he was in at that particular time. All I can say is: I was the director, I rewrote the script by James Baldwin and Arnold Perl, and I will take full responsibility. I will say that this is the Malcolm I see.
GATES: Is Spike Lee's Malcolm the Malcolm before or after he went to Mecca?
LEE: We show them all. That's why this film is an epic. That's why it's three hours. We want to show the total evolution of what made him. We want to show the three or four different people he was along the line. People tend to have one view of Malcolm, but he had many different views over his life; he turned completely around several times in this life. We leave it up to the audience to pick and choose which one they agree with, but we want to show all the Malcolms.
GATES: Do you have a favorite?
LEE: I like them all -- even when he was a hustler. I can see what steered him that way, having seen the state commit your mother, the family broken up, your father killed. I try to keep him together as one person, and all these things, you might say, are spokes in the wheel that made him. I know for sure Warner Brothers is trying to stress the Malcolm after Mecca, when he stopped calling white folk blue-eyed mutant devils.
GATES: Does this post-Mecca Malcolm, this more embracing figure, appeal to you, given your own sensibilities?
LEE: Yes. I think Malcolm came to a point where he saw that we're all brothers.
GATES: You mentioned that Warners prefers a certain Malcolm. How did that manifest itself, and how did you deal with it?
LEE: They just make suggestions; I have final cut. I know what they're trying to get at. At the same time, they have a point. Because Malcolm post-Mecca is the Malcolm who evolved the most. That is not to negate what Malcolm did when he was in the Nation, aside from those theories that white people were grafted by the evil scientist Yakub, and that there's this wheel spinning above us that's going to destroy the world. Even in those days, he was speaking important truths about oppression and resistance, and at a time when no one else had the courage to say the things Malcolm was saying.
GATES: One way people attack you is to say that, in the end, you don't really have final cut.
LEE: I have final cut on all my films. That means I decide what goes in, what stays out of the movie. That's it.
GATES: What's your relation to the Nation of Islam? During one of the many controversies about this film, you were quoted as saying that a nonblack director like Norman Jewison wouldn't be able to do justice to the subject. By that logic, what about a non-Muslim director?
LEE: I think it's got to do more with race than religion. There was so much research that had to be done, and the people you had to speak to for the most part were black. I don't think they would have opened up to anybody white.
GATES: Why is the life of Malcolm, Spike Lee's Malcolm, needed right now?
LEE: It's needed for the same reason that Malcolm was needed when he was alive, and even more so today. One of the things that Malcolm stressed was education. Well, we're just not doing it. It's such a sad situation now, where male black kids will fail so they can be "down" with everyone else, and if you get A's and speak correct English, you're regarded as being "white." Peer pressure has turned around our whole value system.
GATES: I saw the results of a survey conducted in black Washington schools in which students listedthings they consider "acting white." One thing on the list was going to the Smithsonian Institution. I couldn't believe it -- when I was a kid, going to the Smithsonian was like going to Disneyland, or better. Then you realize that a certain amount of romantic black neo-nationalism is tied into this attitude we've been discussing. Is your movie going to counteract that?
LEE: You see Malcolm educate himself, you see him going through the dictionary, copying every single word and definition, A to Z. You see him striving to better himself, to educate himself, to talk correctly, to stop swearing and stop other people from swearing.
GATES: But there's a generation for whom Malcolm is purely a symbol, rather than somebody with substance.
LEE: That's something we hope to address in this film. You have to realize there's a lot of re-education that has to go on. I guess the first step is their wearing a cap or a T-shirt with a Malcolm X quotation. But hopefully that's only a first step. Then you hope that it starts to be more, and deeper.
GATES: Why do you think there has been such a resurgence of interest in Malcolm X, especially among black youth? You see "Malcolmania" in rap music, posters, baseball caps, a flood of new books and, of course, your movie.
LEE: Chuck D., with Public Enemy, and K.R.S.-One, with Boogie Down Productions, have to be credited with really giving black youth Malcolm through their lyrics. It began there, and it just started to build. Even more, though, the issues he talked about haven't gone away. Conditions have even gotten worse. That's why he's more popular now than ever.
GATES: What about the need for heroes? I think one reason Malcolm is so visible on the streets is the lack of heroes. Does your Malcolm emerge as a hero?
LEE: Very heroic. I think Ossie Davis put it best in his eulogy. He said Malcolm is our shining black prince.
GATES: Why are we seeing "Malcolmania" and not "Martinmania"? Why isn't Martin Luther King Jr. comparably appealing?
LEE: Well, Martin was more mainstream. The whole nonviolent, turn-the-other-cheek business just isn't getting anywhere in black America.
GATES: What was your reaction to the verdict in the Rodney King case and the ensuing riots?
LEE: This is definitely a wake-up call to the nation. And what has been sad for me is the insidious way that the media have been portraying this. This wasn't a case of random violence or a riot; a better word for me was a revolt or uprising. The media have tried to say this was the work of black thugs and gang bangers. But the fact is that everybody was looting.
The media want to give equal weight to the image of four black men pulling one white man out of his truck and beating him up, as they did to the image of Rodney King being beaten by the Los Angeles police. Ironically, the same videotape that allowed the four white cops to walk free is going to send four black men to prison. People are fed up. It only takes one spark to ignite a revolt. In L.A., the disparity between the haves and have-nots is astronomical. That's the difference between New York and L.A.
GATES: What should the government do?
LEE: Stop blaming this on welfare. They don't want to do anything really. They just want to keep us confined to the inner city, killing each other off with drugs and violence.
GATES: What audience is "Malcolm X" primarily directed toward. Are you trying to educate black America or white America? Given the complexity of the subject, can one film do both?
LEE: Yes, I think all my films have done both. I've always found it interesting to view my films as having two different audiences, one black and one white.
GATES: That's a hard balancing act to pull off.
LEE: It can be done. This film's about America, and all Americans can learn from it. Like Malcolm, we're taking a global view of this film: it's not just about the United States; we're thinking about the world. And there will be people who'll want to see this around the world.
GATES: Baldwin said that when white people attacked him, it got his blood up; but when black people attacked him, it made him want to cry. Could you talk about what it's like being trashed by black people?
LEE: I don't think that just because you're black, you can take the attitude that you're beyond criticism. For the most part, black people have been too lenient on black artists. If a black artist goes around doing stuff that we feel is an affront to the people of the race, we should stop buying their records or seeing their movies, or whatever. But we never realize our economic clout the way we should.
GATES: Still, is black criticism more painful than white?
LEE: I think Public Enemy said it best when they sang, "Every brother ain't a brother." You can't assume that because you're black and they're black, they're going to love your work. In the end you have to please yourself.
GATES: Film history is littered with flashes in the pan: the black message films of the 40's, Harry Belafonte in the 50's, the blaxploitation era of the late 60's and early 70's. What have you done to render yourself flashproof?
LEE: Flashproof means having a body of work. With "Malcolm X," that makes six films over the last seven years. We need to grow and to get better, because there's so much to learn in film making.
GATES: How do we keep the renaissance in black film making from being just a trend?
LEE: By trying to be the best film makers we can be, by learning the craft, by having a love of cinema. Not being in it just for the money, for the glory or the sexual conquests you can make when you're casting your films. It was a love of music that enabled Duke to do what he did. You've got to have that love of whatever it is you're doing. And you have to go and spend time in the woodshed. John Coltrane, Wynton Marsalis, they practice five, six hours a day. A lot of these guys making films today, they don't have any craft, and they're proud to say: "I didn't go to film school, I never made a film before." Most of the time it ends up looking exactly like that.
There are so many stories to tell. Hollywood -- for the most part -- is dried up. And our stories have not really been told. Think of all the novels that have still to make it to screen: "Song of Solomon," "The Bluest Eye," "Their Eyes Were Watching God." It's like virgin territory.
GATES: Critics talk about a Ford film, a Hitchcock film and so on. What will a Lee film be remembered for?
LEE: I want to be remembered for honest, true portrayals of Afro-Americans and for bringing our great richness to the screen.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Air-Conditioner Charges
 
Question: In August I signed a new two-year, rent-stabilized lease. It included a separate charge for "new equipment" and a rider requiring me to pay a $5-a-month charge for each window-mounted air-conditioner if I put them in. Is the air-conditioner charge legal? . . . Kenneth Lee, Manhattan
 
Answer: It probably is. According the Joseph D'Agosta, acting deputy commissioner for the Office of Rent Administration in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, in certain circumstances landlords of rent-regulated units are allowed to add an extra charges to the rent for the use of tenant-owned air-conditioners.
If a rent-stabilized tenant pays for his own electricity and installs his own air-conditioner, the landlord is entitled to a $5-a-month fee for each air-conditioner that protrudes beyond the window line. This fee would apply to the use of most portable air-conditioners.
Tenants whose rent includes electricity and who use their own air-conditioners may also incur extra charges. The air-conditioner charge, which is set each Oct. 1, is based on the index of the operating costs for rent-stabilized housing in New York City. The current allowable charge is $18.57 a month.
 
Damage From Renovation
 
Question: I am the owner of a co-op apartment. With the permission of the co-op board, a neighbor has been doing a lot of construction and renovation recently. The constant hammering and pounding has caused some walls in my apartment to crack. There is even a hole in one wall now. Who is responsible for repairing the damage caused by the work, the neighbor or the co-op? . . . Isabel Kivy, Manhattan
 
Answer: Responsibility could fall on both the neighbor doing renovations and the co-op.
According to Ronald Sher, an attorney who specializes in real estate matters, the shareholder doing the renovation should pay for the cost of repairing damage done inside your apartment, like cracked plaster. But if the work has resulted in damage to any of the building's structural elements, like interior-wall supports, the co-op would be responsible for the repair work.
"Part of the specified area of responsibility for co-op boards," said Mr. Sher. "is to insure the structural soundness of their buildings, So if the renovation work caused structural damage, ultimate responsibility for repair work would be the board's.
"But I would also expect the board to seek compensation from the shareholder doing the work for any expense for these repairs."
Some boards require shareholders making renovations to sign indemnification agreements, before the work begins, to protect the co-op against the costs of repairing damages.
 
Late Fee in Co-op
 
Question: I live in a small, seven-unit, town-house co-op. We have recently had two unexpected assessments in two months, which came to $5,000. I paid my share 10 days to two weeks late. I was charged a late-payment penalty, which usually is charged only for late maintenance bills.
My late payment did not cause the co-op to incur any extra charges. Is it legal for the co-op to charge for late payments if they do not result in costs to the co-op? . . . Eleanor Kairalia, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. The board has the legal right to impose fees on shareholders for the late payments of assessments as well as for late-payment on maintenance fees. The financial impact of the tardy payment to the co-op would not be a factor in the board's ability to enforce late payment rules. The right to impose late fees has withstood court challenges.
Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said that some co-ops are willing to be flexible on late charges in certain circumstances.
"Most boards recognize that unexpected assessments, particularly ones that are close together, can be hardships for shareholders," she said. "If the board was notified in advance of the financial problem of the shareholder, it might have made an exception on the late payment charge, if the shareholder was able to pay part of the assessment on time."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Port Chester

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
LIFE was sweet in the village of Port Chester when the Life Savers plant was operating there. In its heyday, it pumped out four million packs a day of the "candy with the hole in the middle."
Mayor Peter Iasillo said that while growing up he could always tell what flavor was being made. "The smell would permeate the entire town," he said. 
 When the plant closed in 1984, it threw the village into a commercial decline that it is still struggling to overcome.
"I remember when this was a bustling village," said Goldie Solomon, vice president of the Port Chester Historical Society and a 44-year resident of the Westchester community. "After industry left, they tried to replace it with urban renewal, but that didn't work out too well."
Today, the village has a somewhat mixed character. On the one hand, it has some of the most beautiful housing in the county. Stately Tudor, colonial and Victorian homes, all built before World War II, sit on spacious lawns on tranquil suburban streets. On the other hand, parts of the downtown are run down. And the Life Savers plant was just the last in a long series of industries to leave.
For years, officials have been predicting a revival, bolstered by a series of development projects. But most have been stalled by the real estate malaise.
The only successful one was the refurbishing of North Main Street in 1987. The street was widened and lined with 80 saplings. Overhead wiring and utility poles were removed, and replaced with 49 Victorian-era lamps, each with four globes, creating one of the most dramatic night-time scenes in the county.
South Main Street, with its tangle of overhead wires and rundown storefronts, is still waiting for its makeover. The Robert Martin Company, Westchester's largest commercial landlord, is planning a $250 million project for Main Street, Westchester Avenue and the waterfront by the Byram River, including a 315,000 square-foot shopping center, 660 apartments, a 20-screen movie theater and a waterfront park with a promenade.
This project got its first approvals back in 1986, but was held up until the right commercial tenants could be found. According to Robert Weinberg, chairman of Robert Martin, "Significant leases are now in the process of being drawn."
One of the leases, he said, involved the movie theater, the project's linchpin. "The theater will bring in people from all over," Mr. Weinberg said. "And then all kinds of different stores will come in to take advantage of that market."
Another ambitious project, proposed by Trammel Crow Developers, involves the building of 400 waterfront rental apartments on Long Island Sound. "We'd like to create a New England town appearance with small clapboard buildings that blend into the topography there," said Thomas Ferrell, director of development. The plan is still preliminary and has yet to be approved by the village board.
"Five years from now, you won't know Port Chester," predicted John Boyle, president of the Port Chester/Rye Brook Chamber of Commerce. "Lately, I've been hearing more good things than ever before. I'm cautiously optimistic."
That optimism has not carried over to home sales. Real estate agents say selling activity in almost all areas has been slow. "The only really active category right now is in houses in the low $200,000's," said Susan McDonnell, sales associate with Coldwell Banker in nearby Rye. House prices in the village top out at around $400,000.
"WE moved here because there were homes we could afford," said Teri Koenig, who came from Harrison, with her husband, Edward, nine years ago. They now feel they may have outgrown the village.
"It's a great place to get started," Mrs. Koenig said. "But if we're going to go up in price, I'd rather go elsewhere."
Port Chester is surrounded by some of the most affluent communities in the nation, among them Rye and Greenwich, Conn. Parts of the village are indistinguishable from those areas, except for the price of housing. "I have a listing now for a $429,000 house in Port Chester," Ms. McDonnell said, "that would be $690,000 in Rye. And it's the same house."
There are also many condominiums and cooperative apartments available at good prices, since they are not selling well at the moment. Most condos have amenities, such as a pool and tennis courts. And prices range from the mid- to upper-$200,000's for two- to three-bedrooms.
The old Life Savers factory is now a 198-unit condominium complex known as the Landmark. Because of the factory's peculiar design the apartments vary widely in size and design. Prices run from $150,000 for a one-bedroom unit to $180,000 for a two-bedroom.
Co-ops, mostly in converted mid-rise brick apartment buildings, are priced from $90,000 for a one-bedroom to $150,000 for the most deluxe two-bedroom.
Port Chester was originally known as Sawpits, because of a prevalence of saw mills in the area. In the 1830's, residents changed the name to Port Chester after Chester in England, the birthplace of many early settlers.
Two of the original settlement houses still stand. One, the Samuel Brown Homestead, built in 1740, is now a private residence. And Lyon Park, the home of Justus Bush, a New York City merchant, built in 1750, houses the Port Chester Historical Society. It is on the National Register of Historic Places.
The stock of historic houses and such landmarks as the Summerfield Methodist Church on King Street, built in 1828, is what attracted Lynn Mara, an artist, and her husband, Frank, promotions director for the New York Giants, to Port Chester. Two years ago, they bought a seven-bedroom white clapboard colonial, built in 1855.
"Being an artist, I'm endlessly fascinated by all the house's little details," Mrs. Mara said. She and her husband moved from Rye Brook, a more affluent community to the north.
Like many residents, they often shop at the Stamford Town Center, a 15-minute drive into Connecticut. The village itself, with about a million square feet of retail space, also has many shopping and dining options. Among the more popular restaurants are the Willett House for steaks and Bel Paeze for Italian food.
Unlike some Westchester communities, Port Chester has a racially diverse population. And Anthony Napoli, the schools superintendent, says racial balance in the elementary schools is his goal.
At present, the King Street and Park Avenue schools are predominantly white and upper middle class, while the Edison School has a largely Hispanic attendance, and the John F. Kennedy mostly black.
LAST fall, the district turned Kennedy into a magnet school, specializing in math and science. "We hoped to attract more white students, and it's worked to a degree," Mr. Napoli said. "It is now about 20 percent white. That's an improvement, but we still have work to do."
Mrs. Koenig, who is white and lives in the Park Avenue district, sends her 7-year-old son to Kennedy, where he is completing the first grade. "It's been great," she said. "He takes Spanish and art once a week, and he's reading above his grade level."
Next fall, all the elementary schools will be k-4. The fifth grade will move to the Port Chester Middle School to relieve overcrowding in the lower grades.
Rounding out the district schools is Port Chester High School, which has four science labs, a photography lab, a cable-TV studio, three computer centers and a 16,000-volume library. In addition. there are three Roman Catholic elementary schools, Corpus Christi, Our Lady of Mercy and Holy Rosary.
There are five village parks, with basketball and tennis courts, baseball fields, and children's playgrounds. The 22-acre Lyon Park is a popular picnic spot and has open-air concerts Friday nights in July and August.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Economy and Environment;
Critical Issues At a Seminar

 BODY:
How can the New York metropolitan region compete successfully in national and global economies? How can it create open space, conserve water and cope with solid waste? How can it use existing transportation to stimulate economic growth? And how can Manhattan be maintained as the economic and cultural hub?
At an assembly to be held Tuesday at the Sheraton New York Hotel, the Regional Plan Association will take up these and other questions. 
 David Halberstam, author of the "The Next Century" and "The Reckoning," is to be the keynote speaker. In the morning, James R. Jones, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, will preside at a session titled "Maintaining the Region as a World Center." Christopher J. Daggett, managing director of William E. Simon & Sons, will head a group on "Creating a More Sustainable Region." And J. Max Bond Jr., a partner in the architectural firm of Davis, Brody & Associates, will be the chairman of a session called "Integrating Land Use, Transportation and Design."
After lunch, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan will lead a forum on the future of that borough as the regional hub, with Daniel A. Biederman, president of the Grand Central Partnership; William H. Luers, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
The assembly runs from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Sheraton, Seventh Avenue and 53d Street. Those wishing to register tomorrow may call (212) 398-1140, extension 227. The cost is $115 for association members, $165 for nonmembers (a price that includes one-year membership).

HEADLINE: Talking: Relocation;
Companies Cutting Benefits

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IN the heady days of the 70's and 80's, corporate employees could rely on their companies to pick up virtually all the expenses of a transfer to a different community.
Today, transferees will find a somewhat frayed welcome mat at their relocation department door as recession and business cost-cutting pare traditional expectations. Increasingly, employees are being asked to bear some relocation costs themselves -- a change that will force many to take a more active role in the move. 
 "We are seeing caps being put on all types of relocation benefits," said Chris Collie, executive vice president of the Employee Relocation Council, a trade group based in Washington.
Corporate officials defend the change by insisting that the cost of transferring an employee at a time of declining real estate values is proving steeper than anticipated. It now costs an average of $45,000 to move a home-owning employee, up from $31,000 10 years ago, according to the Employee Relocation Council.
Take, for example, the loss-on-sale benefit given to a transferee whose home has dipped in value since it was bought. This benefit alone costs about $15,000 an employee, reports Terry Portale, senior relocation specialist at Colgate-Palmolive Company. He saidthe figure can rise to $40,000 or more in the Northeast.
The biggest loss facing transferees will probably come from the refusal of their companies to buy their homes if they do not sell on the open market before the scheduled moving date -- a benefit known as a "buyout."
Ann Moore, vice president of William Pitt Relocation Corporate Services of Stamford, Conn., estimates that only 60 percent of the transferees she handles are being given buy-outs today, compared to virtually everyone years ago.
Starting in July 1990, USAir, which moves about 500 home-owning employees a year, began dividing them into two categories: Senior executives and those with special technical skills, who could still count on a buy out, and lower rank employees, who would have to make do with a "settling allowance" equal to two weeks' salary.
Other companies are making their buy-outs contingent on the transferee's doing more to sell the home before the scheduled move, said Karen Alpi, manager of the New York regional office of Home Buyers' Assistance Corporation, a national relocation counseling service.
To qualify for a buyout, said Ms. Alpi, the transferee may be required to establish a listing price that conforms to company policy, such as taking the average of three brokers' opinions rather than putting the house on the market at the highest possible price.
They also may be limited to a selling agent on the company's recommended list. And they may have to make cosmetic improvements along guidelines provided by the brokers and counselors. But these should not prove onerous, said Mrs. Alpi, being most often limited to removing clutter, getting rid of pet odors, cleaning or removing soiled or worn carpeting and painting a shabby room.
If they work for a company that prefers to use the carrot rather than the stick, they could actually end up with more, not less, money. Typical of this approach is A.T.&T., which is motivating its transferees to sell their own homes by offering a bonus equal to 3 percent of the sale price if they are successful. The bonus provides cash benefits of about $4,500 a family, said John Bemont, the company's relocation director.
SOME companies are also providing a "marketing allowance" of around $1,500 to pay for improvements such as painting or repairs or to subsidize a buyer's closing costs, said Susan Bankes, director of marketing at PHH Homequity of Wilton, Conn., which buys transferees' homes on behalf of their employers.
This option can be particularly valuable now because selling a home independently should bring a better price than a buy-out -- a result, say these experts, of a new method of buyout appraisals that factors in a possible further decline in market values during the period the home might have to remain in corporate inventory.
Another setback facing transferees is the retreat of employers from paying all the auxiliary costs of a move, such as house-hunting trips and temporary accommodations. In lieu of total reimbursement, the transferee is increasingly likely to be offered a lump sum.
Runzheimer International, a corporate relocation policy research company headquartered in Rochester, Wis., said that 36 percent of companies regularly involved in relocations have gone over to lump-sum allowances compared to 20 percent in 1989. It reports that the sum ranges from a low of $2,200 to a high of $15,000.
For transferees, this may mean cutting corners. But it might also mean cash to spare if a resourceful way can be found to pare costs.
Consider the experience of Kenneth McNeely, a lawyer with A.T.&T. who moved from Charlotte, N.C., to Atlanta last October. Given a $9,000 lump sum, he managed to end up with a $1,000 surplus by moving quickly into an apartment on a short term rental instead of spending weeks in a hotel.
He also saved on travel between the old and new locations by selling his Charlotte home in five days using the more aggressive marketing strategies recommended by the company.
Others may not always be so fortunate. The decline of automatic buyouts means that an increasing number of families are having to split up temporarily, with the spouse and children staying behind until their home is sold.
Still others are taking modest rented quarters in the new location while waiting for a sale. Should this happen, the family might consider the approach of an Atlanta couple with two school-aged children who came to Fairfield County, Conn., last year facing just such a predicament.
According to Ms. Moore, whose agency handled the move, the family felt it would be best to rent in the neighborhood where they eventually intended to buy so they could enroll their children in school right from the start. They did so, she said, and although it was a difficult period it proved to be the least disruptive way of handling the problem.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Semi-Custom Houses;
A Bid for Staten Island's Move-Up Buyers

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
TO find a location in New York City where a builder is producing semi-custom, single-family houses in a sizable subdivision it is necessary to venture to Staten Island.
There, on 7.3 acres where the Franzreb family ran a riding stable for 42 years, Tom Costa is developing 56 lots under the name Park Place North. Eighteen of them are reserved for brick colonial models that are priced from $350,000 to $500,000, or more when customers are inclined to greater luxury. 
 The rest, a more standard single-family house on a smaller lot, are on the market for $275,000 to $280,000. A model is nearly complete.
The land is off Clove Road near Bard Avenue in one of the prime residential neighborhoods of Staten Island's North Shore, close to Clove Lakes Park, the Staten Island Zoo and the city-owned golf course at Silver Lake Park. On the slope overlooking the golf course, Mr. Costa is offering sites for high-end homes.
It has not been easy. "I should have sold at least 10 customs by now," he said. Instead, only one is finished and occupied and two others are sold and in construction. Nevertheless, interest is stronger this year than last.
The Park Place North development illustrates the attempt by builders to reach for the move-up market during what may be a transitional period in home sales. Time has purged the new-home sales market of the product that was least salable when the recession struck, the small two-bedroom starter home, and builders have largely abandoned it.
But the key to builders' success will be the pace of resales this year. Most people have to be able to sell their current houses before they can buy a move-up house.
In 1986 and 1987, the market for starter houses was strong, said Philip Farinacci, who is building semi-detached houses under the name Palmers Run off Jewett Avenue near Forest Avenue on the North Shore. But when the recession struck, starter houses were the hardest of all to sell, he said.
"The trend is to stop developing town houses," said Thomas Maira, a broker with Daniel Master Real Estate, a large packager of land for builders. "Duplexes are more popular now. Builders are hounding me for duplex sites -- but not for 22 houses anymore. More like five or six."
Mr. Costa's presence at the site of the former Clove Lakes Stables is the result of another builder's problems. He is coming back to build on land he sold to a New Jersey group six years ago. The price was about $120,000 a lot, which is about the value of land for the lower-end houses today, he said.
BECAUSE of the market's decline, prices for house and land are down roughly 20 percent from three or four years ago, said Mr. Costa, who is the 38-year-old son of the late Joseph Costa, the builder of about 1,000 houses on Staten Island.
The stables property was originally sold by the Franzreb family in 1985 to another builder, Sal Surace. He subdivided the land into 66 lots.
Then he sold the property with the approved plans to Mr. Costa, who installed sewer and sanitary lines and resold it to the New Jersey partnership.
They started sales and construction, but ran into trouble. The Buildings Department stopped the job on the ground that the houses failed to conform to a new zoning law adopted for one- and two-family districts in northern Staten Island. The change came after a model was up and commitments accepted based on approved plans under the old zoning, Mr. Costa said.
Caught by this and other financial problems, the builders sold to still another investor, Michael Rottenberg. He drew Mr. Costa in as a co-venture partner.
At the time, Mr. Costa was building custom homes in the Annadale section of Staten Island under the name Park Place. These were imposing houses on lots of 100 feet by 100 feet. A five-foot brick wall along the street gave the development the look of "estate housing," Mr. Costa said.
A similar wall encloses the 650 feet of frontage of Park Place North along Clove Road. The backyards of the new lower-priced housing will abut this wall, illustrating one of the less desirable characteristics of several of the newer Staten Island residential projects along major thoroughfares: insensitivity to the vista from the street.
To build to the maximum permissible density, developers have sacrificed the opportunity to provide a better street-side shield for their developments. One effective way is to raise the land along the avenue side and provide heavy landscaping. That creates privacy and noise insulation for buyers, and a better streetscape for the public.
Instead, along such thoroughfares as Richmond Avenue, Ocean Terrace, Victory Boulevard and Hylan Boulevard, the backyards of new houses frequently run up to plain unattractive barrier walls at the sidewalk.
At Park Place North, the key change brought about by Mr. Costa and his architect, Jerome L. Grushkin Associates of Bulls Head, on Staten Island, was a reduction in house lots. With 56 lots instead of 66, the builder has provided for the 18 higher-end houses.
One of the buyers is Anthony Fiore, a 37-year-old officer at Canadian Imperial Bank in Manhattan. He bought a co-op in a high-rise called The Fountains across the street from Park Place North five years ago. Now he is trying to sell it for $60,000 while buying a new house for $430,000.
"This is one of the nicest areas on Staten Island -- suburban but convenient," he said. He commutes to midtown Manhattan on a city express bus that stops at his doorstep. The fare is $4 each way.
The other buyers are a couple, Philip and Donna Collins, with two young sons. They spent two years trying to sell through brokers a raised-ranch house in Annadale on the South Shore. They bought it new for $350,000 in 1987 and spent about $150,000 to improve it, Mrs. Collins said.
UNABLE to sell it through brokers, they took matters in their own hands, slashed the price and sold so quickly that they found themselves forced to move out before their new house was ready. So they have moved temporarily into Mr. Costa's model house as renters. Their garage is the sales office.
"We loved our old home," Mrs. Collins said, "but the problem was we always wanted a center hall." Mr. Collins is a financial broker.
After he refiled plans, Mr. Costa was permitted by the Buildings Department to complete 12 unfinished houses on the site. They were sold for $280,000 to $310,000 and are now occupied.
He also is building the remaining lower-priced houses under the new zoning. The effect of this zoning is to drive the builder to lower the garages within the house, which are approached from an inclining driveway.
Lowering them allows the garage space to be classified as a "cellar" rather than a "basement." Under the new area basements count as floor area but cellars do not. By taking advantage of the topography of the property to create living space in "basements" but garage space in cellars on the same level, the builder is able to provide a house with no loss of living space.
The houses, 28 feet wide by 40 feet deep, have 2,200 square feet of living space on two levels, plus the basement level and garage. They also have two entry doors, one at the front and one at the side. A buyer could alter space entered through the side into a private apartment, although this would be illegal under zoning law.
Nevertheless, "mother-daughter" houses are popular. Buyers often have a single parent or relative living in the downstairs space.
Financing for Park Place North has come from the Richmond County Savings Bank.

HEADLINE: Pressure Mounting to Restrict Boaters' Sewage

BYLINE: By States News Service

 BODY:
IF Federal regulators reject a plan by Huntington to restrict boat waste in the town waterways, town officials may have to choose between the baymen and the weekend boaters who flock to the bays and harbors each summer.
Huntington is one of six Long Island towns that face the closing of shellfish beds to baymen because of the pollution from sailboats and motorboats. The town is the first to propose a compromise that may keep summer boaters and the shellfish industry afloat side by side. 
 Town officials are proposing to the State Environmental Conservation Department that that the Federal Government declare Lloyd Harbor and the East Neck Coast Guard Basin zones where boat discharges are prohibited. Under rules of the Environmental Protection Agency, boats would be forbidden to dump any waste, even sewage treated with chemicals.
Huntington and the state hope to stave off requirements by the Federal Food and Drug Administration to make a choice between the summer boaters, many of whom contribute to the tourism industry, and the shellfishers, whose families have pulled their incomes from the bays and harbors for centuries.
There is no evidence linking the waste from sailboats and yachts that anchor overnight in bays and harbors to shellfish-related diseases, experts on both sides of the issue say.
But just the possibility of clams, oysters and other mollusks' ingesting raw sewage is too much of a risk, said David Dressell, chief of shellfish sanitation in the F.D.A. For that reason, he said, boating and shellfishing are incompatible.
For the towns, the problem is as much rooted in economics as in tradition. Long Island shellfishers received more than $27 million for their harvests at the docks in 1990, according to the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
Recreational boating brought in $42 million in 1990 in fuel, repairs and other activities, according to the Long Island Sound Taskforce, which commissioned the University of Connecticut to conduct a study.
The E.P.A. will decide whether to designate Lloyd Harbor and the Coast Guard basin as no-discharge zones, but the F.D.A. will have the final say on whether the zones can be enforced. F.D.A. officials say they are skeptical.
One researcher said the cost of such zones could be prohibitive.
 
Two Towns Step Forward
 Although Huntington is taking the first step toward a no-discharge area, other towns may follow. The state has targeted five other North Shore and East End towns for possible closures.
Southold and East Hampton volunteered last summer to eliminate overnight boat anchoring in shellfish beds. Parts of the West Harbor in Southold are closed to boaters, and East Hampton officials moved their anchorage area in an attempt to accommodate the baymen and the boats.
The Environmental Conservation Department is studying boating this summer in Brookhaven, Oyster Bay and Shelter Island. At stake are popular anchoring and shellfishing spots in Port Jefferson Harbor, West Neck Bay, West Harbor and Oyster Bay Harbor.
Boaters who enjoy the Sand Hole at Caumsett State Park will continue to anchor overnight there. The state refused to exclude the boaters, so the shellfish beds likely will be closed, according to the D.E.C.
 
Planning by the State
 "There are more demands that people put on our harbors and bays than they can accommodate," the state director of marine resources, Gordon Colvin, said. "Jet skiing, water skiing, sailing, swimming, fishing, harvesting shellfish. It becomes increasingly difficult to navigate all those activities without limit."
If the no-discharge zones are not approved by the E.P.A. or are rejected by the F.D.A., the beds at the Coast Guard Basin will close to baymen on Memorial Day and reopen in October. The Lloyd Harbor beds would close next summer, state officials say.
Baymen, boaters and marina owners are angry.
The president of the North Shore Baymen's Association, Charles Murphy, has raked clams out of Lloyd Harbor and other waterways for 30 years. The threat of losing the harbor and other prime areas to recreational boating infuriates him.
"There's more than 100 of us trying to make a living on the water," Mr. Murphy said. "Those months they are talking about are our prime months. We earn 65 to 70 percent of our income then. How would they like to be told that for those five months they won't get a salary?"
The North Shore baymen have contacted lawyers in Washington, who say they will go to Long Island to discuss suing the state if the shellfish beds are closed.
The commodore of the Greater Huntington Council of Yacht and Boating Clubs, William Saltzman, said he understood the baymen's fears, but believed that the boaters were being blamed for pollution that much more often comes from sewage overflows and agricultural and street runoffs.
"We as pleasure boaters are very annoyed over the fact we have become easy targets, especially when we contribute less than 1 percent of the waste problem," Mr. Saltzman said. "I don't know what the solution is. I really don't. Clammers have a bona fide interest. They are scratching out a living. But these boaters are not wealthy people by any means."
Marina owners are upset, too. The co-owner of the Coecles Harbor Marina on the eastern side of Shelter Island, Peter Needham, said the threat of closing the harbors to overnight anchoring could drive away an already diminishing business.
"The boaters I've talked to say they will just avoid the areas" that are closed, Mr. Needham said. Out-of-town boaters might not travel to Long Island, and local boaters may sell their boats, he said, adding, "If they close these areas, boaters don't see any reason to own a boat anymore.
"I don't doubt there is discharging by boats," Mr. Needham said. "But nobody has ever come up with a clear idea of what the potential is or if it even exists."
 
Harm to Boat-Related Businesses
 A lobbyist for the Empire State Marine Trades Association in Albany, Richard True, said he doubted that the proposed rules would drive away recreational boating, even if the no-discharge proposal fails.
"I don't think any of the towns intend to directly ban" overnight anchoring, Mr. True said. But he agrees that the perception that boaters were not wanted on the Island would hurt marinas and other boat-related businesses.
The association had its members sign an agreement to ban boat discharges in their marinas, and it is pushing for a state ban on discharges. The bill would require all marinas serving at least five boats to provide facilities to pump out sewage waste at the site or within two miles, Mr. True said.
He added that the no-discharge zone was the only acceptable option for the boaters and baymen. The E.P.A. has established such zones in Texas and California. Local authorities police the boats by locking the valves that would discharge any waste and by dropping dye tablets into their toilets.
A marine specialist working with the New York Sea Grant Extension Program, Jay Tanskey, questions whether the state or local governments have the resources to enforce no-discharge zones. "Right now the state doesn't have the manpower to manage the sewage-treatment plants," he said. "Are they going to have the manpower to go out and check all the boats? It's not going to be easy, and it's going to be expensive."
 
25,000 Boats in Huntington
 Town officials are sympathetic to the boaters but still want to preserve the baymen's way of life.
The Huntington Harbor Master, Harry Acker, said that 350 to 400 baymen earned their livings from the town waters and that 25,000 boats were registered in Huntington. If the the E.P.A. or the F.D.A. rejects the no-discharge request, the town will have a tough time deciding what to do, he said.
If Oyster Bay has to choose between the two, the town would most likely pick the baymen, said Town Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli, adding, "It would be a tragedy if there were no oysters in Oyster Bay Harbor."
East Hampton Town Supervisor Tony Bullock said his town reached a good compromise by moving the boat moorings and prohibiting overnight anchoring in the shellfish beds. Yet he criticized the choice officials had to make.
"That's a very good goal, protecting the shellfish from contaminants," Mr. Bullock said. "But if some people just drop anchor for the night, that doesn't mean all the shellfish are suddenly contaminated.
"We're doing all the things we should do. We shouldn't have to decide if we should have a boat or a clam. It's too simplistic. It's not workable in the real world."

HEADLINE: Trying to Change the Way People Mow the Lawn

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

 BODY:
AS the familiar sounds of lawn mowers usher in a new summer season in Westchester, county and local officials are asking homeowners to radically change the way they mow their lawns in order to save both money and the environment.
A new recycling program, called "grasscycling," encourages people to leave grass clippings on their lawn after mowing. By mowing more frequently, program advocates say, homeowners can keep their lawns looking good and at the same time provide fertilization through natural methods. Most important, thousands of tons of grass clippings will be kept out of the county's overburdened waste stream. 
 The term grasscycling was originated by the Professional Lawn Care Association. The county received permission from that group to use the name.
"Westchester epitomizes the suburban ideal of green lawns with a manicured look," said James J. Hogan, recycling director of Westchester County. "But somehow we have to stop putting material like grass clippings at curb-side."
In 1990, 27,300 tons of grass was generated in the county, according to an October 1991 study prepared for the county by S.C.S. Engineering of West Nyack, N.Y. In total, the county study says, yard waste, which includes leaves and brush as well as grass, accounted for 109,200 tons of waste in the county.
 
Waste Taken to Peekskill
 Mr. Hogan estimates that much of that waste was being taken to the Charles Point Resource Recovery Plant in Peekskill for incineration. The plant there is limited by state law to burning 675,000 tons of waste yearly. By contrast, Westchester generates 900,000 tons of waste a year.
In addition to the environmental benefits, proponents of grass recycling point to the economic saving to taxpayers because less yard waste will have to be picked up and hauled away by municipal sanitation departments. While saying that it is difficult to gauge the exact saving under this program, Mr. Hogan said it has the potential to reduce county waste by 30 percent in the summer.
The county's program is modeled on similar efforts in Texas and Ohio. The Long Island towns of North Hempstead and Islip also recycle grass clippings.
Under the program, the county recycling office, with the help of a $350,000 three-year grant from the State Department of Environmental Conservation, printed 50,000 brochures to explain grass recycling. The brochure was prepared with technical assistance from the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Westchester County.
The idea of leaving freshly mowed grass on a lawn is not new but was often rejected by homeowners as unsightly and bad for the lawn.
"Everybody is interested in the esthetics of having a beautiful lawn," said Nancy Cook, senior horticultural consultant with the Cornell Cooperative Extension. "But they can also be taught that recycling will eliminate labor and costs. You may have to mow more often, but the labor savings come in not having to bag the clippings. The money saving comes in what you will save on fertilizer."
 
Savings on Fertilizer Costs
 Because every garbage bag of clippings is estimated to contain up to a quarter pound of usable nitrogen, residents can save about 25 percent of their annual fertilizing cost by letting the lawn recycle its own nutrients. Experts claim that recycling will also cut by 25 to 30 percent the amount of time spent mowing a lawn since there is no need for raking or emptying bags.
To recycle grass properly, homeowners should mow when grass is dry and three to four inches tall, never cutting it shorter than one-and-a-half to two-and-a-half inches. This builds up the lawn's root system and protects it against weeds and drought.
Westchester lawns are composed of "cool spring grasses." They grow most rapidly in the spring. Ms. Cook recommends mowing every five days during the spring and maybe once a week in the summer.
Alfred Krautter, owner of the Sprainbrook Nursery in Scarsdale, said golf courses have practiced this type of recycling for years, but many homeowners mistakenly feared that grass clippings caused the formation of thatch, a layer of decomposing organic matter on the lawn.
"Among those of us in the turf industry, there has to be an educational approach to tell people that recycling can be done and will work," Mr. Krautter said. "We have to change our way of taking care of our lawns. We have to do it in a more environmentally safe manner."
 
Aggressive Action in Cortlandt
 The town of Cortlandt is taking an even more aggressive approach by becoming the first municipality in the county to ban the curb-side collection of grass clippings. The decision was reached by the Town Board late last year and is now in effect.
"It was a twofold decision," said Richard McIntyre, Superintendent of Sanitation for the town. "First, it was environmentally sound, and second, it is economical. Taxes are foremost on everybody's mind. In order to set up these recycling programs with the same personnel, we had to streamline what we collected. We had to bite the bullet on this."
Mr. McIntyre said that his town, along with all other Westchester towns and municipalities, must step up recycling efforts in order to reach the state-mandated goal of recycling 40 percent of the waste stream along with reducing waste by 10 percent by 1997.
Public reaction so far has supported the ban. "Two out of three people who have called about it understand our need to recycle," Mr. McIntyre said.
Mr. Hogan of the County Recycling Office praised Cortlandt officials for their "progressive effort" and said the town is "moving in a direction that everyone will take eventually."
Murray Bodin, a resident of Hartsdale, said he has been recycling the grass clippings on his lawn for 30 years.
"I didn't realize the value of doing it when I started," said Mr. Bodin, a member of the county's Recycling Advisory Board. "It just seemed logical to me. It didn't make sense to take the grass off the lawn. But now grasscycling is a win-win situation. It is healthier for the lawn; it saves you money and at the same time does something to improve the quality of life on the planet."
