HEADLINE: Did Insurers Abandon the Inner City?

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
As the rioting ebbed here, Kibok Yoo stared into the cave-like ruin that once had been her liquor store. Melted electrical cables hung like tendrils from a blackened ceiling. A lifetime's savings lay in heaps of ash and shattered glass. The rioters had destroyed the business that provided Ms. Yoo with $6,000 a month in income and the promise of delivering her 3-year-old son into a comfortable life in middle-class America.
But the greatest trauma to Ms. Yoo came in the news from her insurance agent: Her $280,000 insurance policy, it turned out, was written by a tiny, unlicensed company in the Caribbean. Like hundreds of other inner-city merchants, she had unknowingly bought from a gray market of policies sold widely in poor areas. She was shocked to hear that she might have to wait months or years to get money on her claim, if she gets it at all. 
 Several miles away in a battered neighborhood of South-Central Los Angeles, 65-year-old Robert Cunningham and his son stood guard with shotguns during the riots to protect the liquor store they have owned for 23 years. Like many small-business owners here, Mr. Cunningham said he cannot afford more than minimal insurance, and an hour's looting would have left his family penniless.
"I wouldn't have risked my life like that if I'd had insurance protection," said Mr. Cunningham, who is black. "Insurance is a giant weight on my back, and all of us in this area are climbing uphill."
Nearly a quarter-century after President Lyndon B. Johnson's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders declared insurance "redlining" a crippling barrier to economic development in the inner city, many of the same problems persist. In more than a week of interviews, dozens of black, Korean and Hispanic business people throughout South-Central Los Angeles spoke with rage about what they charge is blatant discrimination and abandonment of poorer areas by the nation's large insurance companies. Their experiences in finding insurance vary greatly -- depending on the company, the type of insurance and the luck of the individual involved. Large businesses and chain stores seem to find insurance easily. Homes are easier to insure than businesses or cars.
 
The Lost Neighborhoods
 But the lack of insurance, the high price of insurance and the poor quality of insurance sold in the impoverished neighborhoods of Los Angeles, merchants and politicians say, have choked small business and with it the chance for economic life. And the riots could worsen the situation by raising prices or making insurance even harder to find.
The insurance industry strongly denies such charges. But in the aftermath of the riots, California's Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, has called for a change in insurers' treatment of the poor and for investment by the industry in poor neighborhoods, just as the banking industry was required to do by the Federal Community Reinvestment Act of 1977.
"I am convinced redlining exists," Mr. Garamendi said on a recent driving tour of blighted areas. "The bottom line is either you can't get or can't afford it. For the long-term growth of these communities, insurance is absolutely critical."
Insurance is crucial to small businesses in myriad ways. It allows them to obtain credit, lease equipment or order merchandise on consignment. An auto repair shop cannot get most referrals without fire and liability insurance. A liquor store, whose wholesale costs are determined by ability to buy in large quantity, may be limited if it cannot insure merchandise.
Spokesmen for the state's largest property and casualty insurers bitterly deny that the industry is "redlining," the practice of refusing to write insurance in certain neighborhoods. They say critics confuse the painfully high price of insurance in poor areas with discrimination by insurers. Prices are high because the risks are high, said Patricia Lombard, the executive director of the Western Insurance Information Service, a trade group representing a dozen major insurers. The high prices, she said, may lead consumers to buy cheaper policies from so-called non-admitted or unregulated companies or to go without it.
The industry, she said, cannot be held responsible for solving the problems of poverty. "We can't go in and make neighborhoods safe," Ms. Lombard said. "We can't make people feel good about their lives."
One piece of evidence that the industry is making insurance available in the inner city, she said, is a recent industry estimate that insurers will pay $775 million for damages during the riots. The claims, she said, were from large and small businesses. Neither the state, the city, nor the industry has data, however, on losses of uninsured or underinsured businesses.
Another indication that insurance is increasingly available from private insurers, the industry says, is that policies written by California's FAIR plan, a state-sponsored program that provides limited insurance to property owners who cannot find coverage elsewhere, has dropped 15 percent since 1987. And at least two regulated companies, the Crusader Insurance Company of Woodland Hills, Calif., and the Farmers Group of Los Angeles, have made aggressive marketing efforts in poor neighborhoods.
"Insurance is available and it is affordable," said Richard G. Donegan, the regional underwriting manager for the Allstate Insurance Company in Los Angeles. "We are committed to those communities."
 
Charge of Unfair Pricing
 Critics of the industry, including lawyers for Consumers Union in San Francisco, say one way insurers deter inner-city buyers is pricing. Instead of considering the risks of neighboring poor and affluent areas together, they say, companies consider poor areas alone, assuring high prices. They say it would be more fair to look at risks over larger areas.
One 28-year veteran of Allstate, who heads its sales office in downtown Los Angeles, said the company developed rules and a price structure designed to turn away inner-city businesses and automobile drivers. "Their actions speak louder than words," Brian Storey said of Allstate. "You will find it in every major city. It is not just Los Angeles."
Black and Asian insurance agents in the area, some of whom testified in state hearings last year, say many residents in South-Central Los Angeles and other poor areas do not have access to insurance from major companies because there are few agents there. One indication of the lack of access, the California Insurance Department says, is the high number of uninsured inner-city drivers.
That is one reason why, according to Insurance Department figures, more than 40 percent of drivers in poor, inner-city zip codes in Los Angeles County drive without insurance.
At least in the property-casualty area, the minority agents say, agents are scarce in the inner city because it is extremely difficult to get appointments -- or the right to sell insurance -- from major companies.
 
'A Gool-Ol'-Boy System'
 "They are not giving these appointments because they don't want to insure these people," said Barbara Glenn Miller, a black insurance agent who is vice president of the Alliance of Inner City Brokers and Agents, a trade group here. "I've been in this industry long enough to know it is a good-ol'-boy system."
Juno Eun, one of the few Korean agents who has appointments from several major carriers, says insurance companies often make it impossible for small businesses in poor areas to buy coverage by using ploys such as taking months to estimate the price of a policy. Rather than wait, they may buy unregulated policies.
Mr. Eun, a member of the board of directors of the local Korean Insurance Agents and Brokers Association, says the best indication of the unavailability of insurance is the present precarious situation of hundreds of Korean merchants. In his survey of 900 of the more than 2,000 Korean businesses damaged or destroyed by the Los Angeles riots, Mr. Eun found about 20 percent had no insurance and more than 40 percent had insurance from companies unregulated in the state, mostly off-shore companies.
The unregulated policies, while not illegal to sell in California and some other states, have been the source of widespread consumer abuse in recent years, the Insurance Department says. The policies are sold under a regulation designed to help consumers get rare or hard-to-obtain types of insurance. But in recent years, the department says, scam artists have entered the field, selling what seem like cheap policies in poor and immigrant communities. The Commissioner has recently taken legal action against several brokers selling such policies, and has proposed tougher regulation of unregulated carriers.
The industry says most of the non-admitted companies are honest and offer good services. But the Insurance Department says that off-shore companies have frequently turned out to have few assets and have disappeared suddenly without paying outstanding claims. In such cases, policyholders receive no protection from state guarantee funds.
Ms. Yoo, a 37-year-old Korean immigrant, was paying $1,600 a year to insure the liquor store on Centinela Avenue in Inglewood. Only recently did she discover, through her agent, that her policy was sold by a company with a post office box on Grand Turk Island in the British West Indies; no phone number was listed on the policy itself. After her store was destroyed by rioters, she said her agent told her that because of the riots, Pacific Fire and Marine might take as long as a year to pay. Her agent, she said, told her to accept whatever money Pacific offered.
"This was all my savings and income and now I need money to pay for my mortgage and food," she said. "My boy needs food."
Repeated calls to Pacific's office in Scottsdale, Ariz., reached an answering machine; the company did not call back. The Insurance Department said Friday it was about to order agents and brokers to stop selling Pacific policies after finding it had inadequate assets and reserves.
The agency that sold Ms. Yoo her policy said it had explained that it was from an unregulated carrier. A number of Korean-American agents said they sold policies from off-shore companies because they were locked out of the licensed market by the major carriers.
Spokesmen for major insurers, including Allstate, State Farm, and TransAmerica, said they do have agents in the inner city. They pointed to their losses in the riots -- tens of millions of dollars each -- as proof.
Mr. Donegan of Allstate, for one, said customers can simply look up the phone number of a company's nearest agent and call. He offered numbers of four Allstate offices near riot-affected areas, including that of Mr. Storey in downtown Los Angeles.
On a walk along Crenshaw Avenue, near the center of the disturbances, merchants still open among the blackened storefronts tell of their adventures trying to find good insurance and the price they pay for its absence.
Sherman Draper, the owner of Sherman's Bar-B-Que, said that in the last 10 years he has gone to agents as far as 30 miles from his store to find insurance. Mr. Draper now has a policy from an unregulated company.
"Most of the agents in the neighborhood just don't have insurance for businesses," Mr. Draper said. "If you ask the big companies for business insurance they tell you one thing or another until you get the idea."
A few blocks south, Gerald Hutchinson, the owner of the Crenshaw Body Shop, which his father founded in 1968, said that without extensive fire and liability coverage 90 percent of the cars he repairs would not be referred to his shop. Recently, he said, Crusader Insurance canceled his policy because he surpassed their limit on the number of cars he could keep on his property. Mr. Hutchinson said he called more than 20 companies before he was able to buy insurance from a Farmers agent miles away in more-affluent Santa Monica. He now pays $4,500 a year, he said, and can no longer keep up with the rising cost of liability insurance. He has had to give up six tow-trucks, and with them, nine employees.
At All Star Liquor, Mr. Cunningham says the high price of insurance in the area plays a critical role in his profit margins. His business, he says, is under severe pressure from Korean competitors who buy stock jointly to get lower prices. To compete, Mr. Cunningham says, he buys in lots that are as large as possible, but is limited because he cannot afford to insure the stock -- already he stores more merchandise than he can afford to lose. If he had cheaper insurance, he said, his prices would be lower and his business far healthier.
Although he believes the lack of insurance is often the result of redlining, Mr. Garamendi says he does not have enough evidence to prosecute. Many insurers, who say the state's first elected Commissioner is taking a tough stance because he is looking to run for higher office, accuse him of making charges without proof.
 
Incentives for Insurers
 Steven L. Miller, deputy commissioner, said the department was developing a plan to provide incentives for insurers that increase the number of policies they write in the inner city, under a formula that would allow for greater profit margins. Such a plan, the department says, may increase insurance prices outside poor areas. The Commissioner also said he will pressure the property casualty industry, with its hundreds of billions in assets, to provide capital for investment in inner-city areas.
The banking industry in the state has made billions of dollars available to homeowners and small businesses in underserved areas. Security Pacific, now a part of Bank of America, for example, has committed $2.4 billion over the last 10 years, said Selwyn Whitehead, president of the Economic Empowerment Foundation in Oakland, Calif., a group that pressures corporation to invest in poor areas. By contrast, she said, the insurance industry has made no such large commitment of capital to the state's poor urban areas.
Ms. Lombard of the Western Insurance Information Service, said insurance companies, unlike banks, do not make loans and are precluded by state regulations from investing most of their portfolios in stocks or high-risk business ventures. Insurers do help cities by buying municipal bonds, she said. And many companies provide charitable grants to people and businesses in poor areas.
"The business of banks is making loans," Ms. Lombard said. "Our business is selling insurance. And we do that."
 
 
 
GOVERNMENT OFFERS HELP, BUT ONLY SO MUCH
 As a result of the riots of the 1960's and the subsequent disappearance of insurers from many poor urban areas, Congress passed legislation in 1968 that helped 28 states create property insurance plans for people unable to get coverage in the private market.
The program in California, known as Fair Access to Insurance Requirements, or FAIR, has more than 113,000 policies in force for homes and businesses in the state.
The program, which is operated jointly by insurers doing business in the state, has significantly helped businesses and homeowners in inner-city areas get at least minimal coverage and access to bank loans. FAIR expects to pay out more than $40 million for 535 claims as a result of the riots.
But Steven L. Miller, the California deputy insurance commissioner, points to FAIR's limitations. FAIR policies are just as expensive as private policies for the same coverage in poor areas. Although FAIR provides property insurance, it does not provide liability insurance or business-interruption insurance. It also insures only the market value of a building, not the cost of replacing it. Because of the riots, Mr. Miller said, the department and the industry are discussing ways to improve coverage.
And the 15 percent annual drop in the number of FAIR commercial policies since 1987, while perhaps an indication of the wider availability of insurance in inner-city areas, may instead reflect the unknown number of people who have dropped insurance because they cannot afford it, department officials say.
It could also reflect purchases from the growing number of unregulated, off-shore companies.
 
 
 
WHERE OTHERS SEE RISK . . .
 Even some bitter critics of the insurance industry from poor areas of Los Angeles praise the Crusader Insurance Company. Since the tiny company in Woodland Hills, Calif., started selling policies in 1985, it has tried to carve out a niche by insuring small businesses, including those in the poorest neighborhoods.
While many large insurers believe that the worst risks are mom-and-pop operations in poor areas, Crusader made money with such customers. Cary Cheldin, the executive vice president, said its assets grew to $23 million in 1991, from less than $2 million in 1985, and that its underwriting each year remained profitable. Crusader, which is owned by the Unico American Corporation, a publicly traded holding company, has 7,000 customers, mostly minority-owned businesses in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Mr. Cheldin and his father, Erwin, who founded the company, are white. "My parents were poor immigrants," said Erwin Cheldin. "Discrimination was everywhere and I hated it."
But the riots have transformed the Crusader story. The company suffered $20 million in losses and although reinsurance and tax write-offs will reduce losses to $10 million, it must now consider withdrawing from business or raising rates in poor areas.
The company's reinsurers say their actuaries expect one such riot every 15 years in Los Angeles. The result for Crusader, Mr. Cheldin said, could be price rises of as much as 30 to 35 percent.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 495 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Profits Are Growing, But Is That Enough?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Will profits catch up with the stock market?
That was the hope raised last week when the Government reported that after-tax corporate profits leaped 8 percent in the first quarter. The number was better than the seers expected and may reflect the benefits of all the corporate restructurings of the last couple ofyears. 
 The long recession in corporate profits started just as George Bush was preparing to be sworn in as president, well before most analysts figured out that an economic recession was coming. And while overall earnings seem to have turned up in the summer of 1991, it was not until Friday's report was released that things really seemed to be moving ahead.
For a while, it looked as if that increase in profits would spur the Dow Jones industrial average to a close above 3,400. But perhaps it was appropriate that share prices fell back late Friday. After all, if stocks could zoom while profits were stagnating, should they not slip when profits are soaring?
But another reason may have been the fact that corporate cash flow -- the money that companies have available for such uses as paying dividends, building plants and paying down debt -- is not rising quite as rapidly as the profit numbers would indicate. In the 1980's, particularly after the Reagan tax cut of 1981, cash flow rose much more rapidly than profits, and the stock market eventually responded. During Mr. Reagan's eight years in office, corporate cash flow rose by 78 percent, while profits climbed by just 46 percent.
As profits fell early in Mr. Bush's term, cash flow also fell, but at a slower rate. Unfortunately, when the rebound came, cash flow rebounded less rapidly, gaining just 5.7 percent in the first quarter.
As everyone knows, the lousy profit performance of the past few years has not dragged down stock prices. That may illustrate the market's confidence that earnings will improve, or perhaps it reflects such other factors as the relatively low rates of inflation and rapidly falling short-term interest rates. In some previous eras, notably the 1970's, high inflation and high interest rates depressed share prices despite rising cash flows.
In the end, however, the reason to own stocks is to share in corporate profits. And last week's fiasco in Centel, whose shares plunged 23 percent on the news the company would be acquired -- at a price far below what investors had hoped -- provides a reminder of how optimistic some market prices have become.
In the short run, higher share prices appear likely. There is a lot of cash sitting in mutual funds and short-sellers have stepped up their activity to levels that sometimes precede sharp market rallies.
But in the long run, a big gain in share prices is likely only if Friday's report of rising corporate profits is followed by reports showing even bigger gains. That could happen -- profits leaped 33 percent in the first nine months of 1983 -- but it is far from being a sure thing.

But Share Prices Leaped," tracks precent change in S.&P. 500 over first 13 quarters of each presidential term, 1973-1992.

HEADLINE: Aircraft-Leasing Giant Strives To Insure Its Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Tony Ryan, the founder and chairman of the GPA Group P.L.C., the aircraft-leasing giant, seemed unusually subdued the other day for a man whose company, after a year's delay, was about to go public, thereby confirming him as one of Ireland's richest men.
If the public offering in the United States, Europe and Japan goes as planned, investors will pay $10 to $12.50 each for 80 million new and existing GPA shares. 
 Some analysts, though, warn that the worldwide travel slump could hurt GPA's ability to raise the hoped-for $658 million in the sale. And that could jeopardize its ability to pay for one of the world's largest orders for new jetliners and turboprop planes -- one that could more than double the 420-plane fleet it now owns or manages, and would consolidate its position as the one of the world's leading plane lessors.
If GPA is not a household name, this Irish company is well-known to the more than 100 airlines to which it leases planes. Smaller airlines or carriers in developing regions dominate GPA's customer list, but it also includes big carriers like American Airlines, Delta, Swissair, Air France and Iberia. With airlines unable to pay for the huge number of planes they believe they will need over the next 20 years, they are expected to turn increasingly to companies like GPA.
Carriers have already found that leasing enables them to obtain planes they otherwise might not be able to afford. It also increases their flexibility to adjust their fleets to the changing demands of their markets. With its large purchases, GPA can wring 20 to 25 percent discounts from manufacturers and it passes part of the savings on to airlines.
By aggressively seeking out airline customers and by employing innovative financing techniques, GPA has become the world's biggest operating lessor of planes built after 1985. It already holds an estimated one-third of the market. Its only significant rival in operating leases, those in which the lessor retains ownership of the plane, is the Los Angeles-based International Lease Finance Corporation, with 162 planes. GPA accounts for 48 percent of the orders and options placed by operating lessors, twice the share of International Lease.
As of March 31, GPA and its joint ventures with aerospace companies had placed firm orders with manufacturers for 308 planes to be delivered through the year 2000. This is a whopping $11.9 billion worth and represents about 10 percent of manufacturers' backlog of firm orders. GPA has options to buy 220 more planes for $9.1 billion.
The stock offering is essential if GPA is to raise the more than $7 billion it needs to pay for planes scheduled for delivery in the next three years. GPA has $2.5 billion in unused credit lines from banks. Its debt already totals $4.16 billion, or 3.4 times shareholders' equity, and GPA cannot allow its debt to rise by more than $1.07 billion on a sustained basis without breaching debt covenants.
Reflecting the pressing need for the stock sale, Moody's Investors Service has placed $1.8 billion of GPA debt securities under review for a possible rating downgrade. "The outcome of the share offering will influence our decision, but we also wanted to take another look at the long-term fundamentals of the air travel industry," said Charles P. Mancuso, an analyst at Moody's.
Another reason for GPA's offering is that two of its biggest private shareholders -- Aer Lingus and Air Canada -- need money to modernize their own fleets. The shareholders planning to sell part of their stakes -- the two airlines and some financial institutions -- stand to make up to $285 million.
Mr. Ryan is not selling any of his 18.7 million GPA shares, which could be worth as much as $234 million. So why isn't he jubilant? "I have a heavy cold," Mr. Ryan, 56 years old, said during a recent lunch with reporters at GPA's headquarters near Shannon Airport in Ireland.
There are other reasons that Thomas Anthony Ryan, who lives on a 300-acre estate in Tipperary, Ireland, and has an impressive collection of 19th and 20th century paintings, might be less than thrilled. Even if the shares fetch $10 to $12.50, this would be about a third below the level hit in mid-1990 in the private secondary market. Some analysts think even $10 is too high.
The offering is being made asthe airline industry climbs out of its worst slump ever. Economic problems plaguing several big countries, including the United States, and fears of terrorism during the Gulf War kept many would-be travelers on the ground last year and prompted GPA to postpone the offering. Air travel fell for the first time ever, by an estimated 2 to 4 percent.
Weakened by the slump, many airlines have postponed or canceled deliveries of ordered planes, analysts note. While air travel is now recovering, a surplus of planes continues. In its prospectus, even GPA notes that "it is not possible to predict how long this period of aircraft oversupply will last."
That, in turn, will affect the prices GPA can get for leases and the planes it sells to investors. All these factors will affect its ability to raise new capital.
Since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, prices for older jets like DC-10's and Boeing 727's have plunged by 30 to 50 percent, according to Avmark Inc., the American aviation appraisal, consulting and publishing company. Prices of jetliners built within the last five years, which had been rising, have been flat since then.
Reflecting the tough times, GPA's profit margins in leasing shrank to 13 percent in the year that ended March 31, down from 21 percent the year before; the planes GPA and its joint ventures sold fell to 36, from 67. GPA makes most of its money by selling investors planes that airlines have leased.
Even so, GPA's profits rose by 32.9 percent, to $202 million, in the latest fiscal year by United States accounting rules. (Under Irish rules, they rose only 2.9 percent.) Its return on equity has consistently remained above 20 percent.
Mr. Ryan hopes investors will be impressed. "Having been through the worst year in aviation history, the company has performed very well," he told European reporters.
GPA concedes that the tough times are not over. It still has 14 or so planes for which it cannot find customers. In its latest fiscal year, GPA decided not to exercise or reschedule 44 options on planes, canceled 11 firm orders and rescheduled delivery of five other planes for 1995 or 1996. In a testimony to GPA's clout, manufacturers have not made GPA pay cancellation penalties.
GPA leaders also are hoping that the industry glut will disappear by early 1994. They are also counting on global air travel growing by an average of 5 to 6 percent a year over the long term, an outlook shared by many airlines and plane manufacturers.
But John Vosper, managing director of Avmark's British subsidiary, points out that the outlook for leasing prices and the prevailing bullish view about the need for new planes assumes there will not be another slump in global air travel. He said this cannot be ruled out. "The problem is if there is another recession or a Gulf War somewhere else," he said.
Not surprisingly, GPA and manufacturers prefer not to think about such things. Their view is that there has not been a dramatic change in airlines' need for vast numbers of new planes to replace aging, fuel-guzzling aircraft; to meet tougher noise standards, and to meet anticipated passenger demand. The need will just take a little longer to materialize than thought two years ago, they say.
The industry consensus is that airlines over the next decade will need 6,200 to 6,400 new planes that will cost $400 billion to $450 billion. Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways P.L.C., recently said the main factor in determining whether those forecasts would come true was the availability of bank financing for purchases.
Tony Ryan loves that kind of talk. GPA and other experts assume that airlines' cash flow and ability to sell new stock will cover only 40 to 50 percent of the cost of the planes they will need through 2000. With banks around the world retrenching, that spells a big opportunity for leasing companies like GPA.
Mr. Ryan, who founded the company as Guinness Peat Aviation with $5,000 in savings in 1975 after he left a middle management job at Aer Lingus, has spotted and exploited such market trends before. GPA's revenues have tripled in the last five years, and its net income has nearly done the same.
It is no accident, GPA leaders say, that only 10 percent of its leasing profits last year came from North America. They say they foresaw the consolidation of America's airline industry and concluded that the surviving giants would be able to obtain discounts from manufacturers as large as GPA's and, therefore, would not have much need for it. Thus, GPA has not been badly hurt by the airline bankruptcies in America, although it did suffer a $52 million loss from the Braniff bankruptcy in 1989.
Mr. Ryan argues that GPA's diversified customer list of 106 carriers in 49 countries will protect it from a big hit. After all, if one regional market runs into trouble and does not need a plane, it can always be flown to another that does, he says. That is true, providing a lot of markets don't sink together, creating a glut of planes like the one that exists today.
 
 
 
RAISING CAPITAL TO BUY PLANES
 GPA has earned a reputation as an innovator in developing new sources of capital to finance aircraft purchases.
It has been adept at attracting Japanese, European and American financial institutions as well as airlines. GPA's larger shareholders include Mitsubishi Trust and Banking, Air Canada, Aer Lingus, Prudential Insurance Company of America, ong Term Credit Bank of Japan, Irish Life Assurance and Citicorp.
Last year, GPA tapped the public debt markets, selling $500 million worth of seven-year notes on the New York Stock Exchange. GPA plans to issue another $1 billion in the next 18 months.
Another important new source of capital that GPA has developed in recent years is the sale of leased planes to institutional or individual investors. In GPA lingo, this is "securitizing" planes or "turning metal into paper." The attractions for investors include the leasing income, the residual value of the planes and tax benefits -- components that GPA in the past year or two has been selling separately.
"When it comes to developing new investor markets from the point of view of securitization of aircraft, they're very much at the forefront," said Clive Anderson, an analyst at Smith New Court Securities Ltd.
GPA now plans to break new ground by issuing a variety of debt and equity securities with varying risks and yields that are backed by portfolios of planes.
GPA and some financial institutions, including Citicorp, are putting the final touches on a $500 million-plus fund that will package 14 planes leased to 14 different airlines in 12 countries. This diversification, GPA hopes, will enable the fund's publicly listed senior debt to get a top credit rating. GPA hopes to put together two other funds of similar size by the end of the year.
Analysts say the first fund will be a critical test of how great an appetite investors have for aircraft-backed securities. "GPA has a lot of new aircraft on order," Mr. Anderson said. "To pay for them, it will be necessary to constantly expand the investor market."

HEADLINE: Who Paid the Most Taxes in the 80's? The Superrich

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
If your Federal income tax bill shrank in the last decade, you probably owe William H. Gates, Steven J. Ross or some other latter-day Rockefeller a thank-you note.
The richest of the rich -- the top 1 percent of American families -- reaped 70 percent of the growth in average family incomes in the late 1970's and the 1980's, Congressional Budget Office data show. But according to a Federal Reserve Board governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, the top 1 percent of families also shouldered a bigger share of the American tax burden, lightening the load for everyone else. 
 Allowing for inflation, all American families together paid $45.2 billion more in Federal income taxes in 1988 than they did in 1981, Mr. Lindsey said. In that same period, however, the income taxes of the top 1 percent, families with incomes averaging $310,000, rose by even more -- $50.2 billion.
In short, the top 1 percent paid the entire increase in tax payments -- and then some. The not-so-rich, it turns out, got a $5 billion tax cut.
"The bottom 99 percent paid less in real terms," said Mr. Lindsey, author of a lively defense of the 1980's supply-side tax cuts, "The Growth Experiment."
"People say Reagan cut taxes on the rich," he added. "Here's a refutation of it."
Not quite. "The predominant reason that the share of taxes paid by the top 1 percent has risen is that the share of taxable income received by the top 1 percent has risen," said Joel Slemrod, a tax expert at the University of Michigan. According to the Congressional Budget Office, very rich families ended up with 13 percent of all pretax income in 1989, up from 8.7 percent in 1977.
The rich did enjoy huge tax rate cuts during the Reagan years. In 1981, the top rate was sliced from 70 percent to 50 percent. At the same time, said Alan J. Auerbach, deputy chief of staff of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation, high-income individuals got several new tax breaks, such as accelerated depreciation allowances for equipment and real estate.
In the 1986 tax reform, the top rate was slashed again to 28 percent, although that reduction was balanced by a rise in the capital gains tax rate and the closing of various tax loopholes. Now the top rate is 31 percent.
Thanks to the lower rates, families in the top 1 percent kept more of their income. They paid an average of just 27 percent of their incomes to the Internal Revenue Service in 1989. In 1977, the earliest year for which Congressional Budget office data are available for the top 1 percent, they paid a much heftier 36 percent.
So how did the rich end up paying a bigger share of America's tax bill? Their incomes surged and that more than offset the lower rates.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, the pretax income of the top 1 percent shot up 77 percent after inflation between 1977 and 1989. The average for all families rose just 9 percent.
The facts contradict received wisdom on both sides of the political aisle. Republicans have long argued that the Reagan tax cuts were manna for the middle class. Democrats have always countered that the rich made out like bandits. In some sense, thanks to the explosion of pretax income at the top, both turned out to be true.

"IT'S correct that the top income group is paying more taxes," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, "but their incomes have risen faster than their taxes." The after-tax income of the top 1 percent grew even faster than pretax income, by 102.2 percent between 1977 and 1989, adjusted for inflation.
"Virtually any set of data that one looks at shows that the decade of the 1980's was a very good decade for those at the top end of the income distribution," Mr. Reischauer said in a recent television interview broadcast on "The Wall Street Journal Report." "The same is true, incidentally, for the second half of the 1970's. This is not a partisan issue."
The critical question for economists, if not for politicians, is, as Mr. Slemrod put it, "to what extent the tax cuts caused the greater concentration of income."
Mr. Lindsey, for one, argues that the income of the top 1 percent went up mostly because their tax rates went down, encouraging them to work harder, report more taxable income (salaries as opposed to fringe benefits) and shift their portfolios toward taxable assets (stocks, say, instead of houses).
In his book, which was published in 1990, Mr. Lindsey reported that the 1980's favored the creation of new fortunes over coupon-clipping and old
 A General Accounting Office report says that the Federal policy of not taxing fringe benefits results in an unfair system. Page 23.
money: "What I found is that in 1963 when the top rate was 91 percent, the typical high income tax return was that of a rentier collecting interest and dividends. In 1983, when the top rate was 50 percent, the typical high income tax return was either someone with capital gains or a wage earner."
Mr. Lindsey's thesis that the tax cuts caused the income spurt at the top is not, however, widely accepted. "The consensus view," Mr. Auerbach said, "is that it's hard to see any significant change in the income distribution in response to the tax cuts."
Mr. Lindsey is now planning to update the analysis of supply-side tax cuts that appeared in his book. And Mr. Slemrod is currently at work on a study of how the rich have responded to changes in tax rates between 1962 and 1989.

A RECENT Council of Economic Advisers staff memorandum supports Mr. Lindsey's contention that the very well heeled contributed a bigger share of Federal tax revenues. The top 1 percent paid 15.4 percent of all Federal income taxes in 1989, according to council economists, up from 13.6 percent in 1977.
By contrast, the bottom 40 percent of American families -- whose income actually declined in the period -- paid just 7.9 percent of the taxes in 1989. That's a smaller share than the 9.2 percent they handed over in 1977. The share of total pretax income of the bottom 40 percent is about the same as that of the top 1 percent -- 13 percent.
The Council of Economic Advisers also used Congressional Budget Office data in its analysis.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 24-29

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Bankruptcy Swallows Canary Wharf 

Olympia & York, North America's largest developer, sought protection last week from its creditors in the British courts for its Canary Wharf project outside of London. It is the largest development in Europe. Olympia went to the courts when 11 banks, with about $990 million in construction loans, declined to provide more money. The filing gives control of the project, which is about $2.07 billion in debt, to a court-appointed administrator. Though a few blue-chip tenants have rented office space and there's enough room for 70,000 people, many potential tenants have shied away from Canary Wharf. It takes hours to get there from London. Olympia was supposed to put up about $720 million in additional funds, which would be matched by the British Government, so a subway line could be extended to the project. Last week Prime Minister John Major ruled out building the rail line without Olympia's help.

Into the Pill Trade
 
Last week industry analysts said Procter & Gamble Inc. was in talks with Marion Merrell Dow Inc., a pharmaceutical manufacturer, to distribute an over-the-counter version of Marion's hugely successful antihistamine, Seldane. Non-prescription medicines are one of the fastest-growing segments of the consumer market.

Perot as Quintessential Insider
 
Although he portrays himself as a political outsider, when it comes to getting government to do what he wants the billionaire Ross Perot knows which buttons to press. In the last five years, Mr. Perot managed to get Federal, state and city governments to invest nearly $200 million in cash and tax incentives to expand Alliance Airport outside of Fort Worth. Alliance is situated in the middle of 17,000 acres of land Mr. Perot is developing. In 1987, Mr. Perot asked the Federal Aviation Administration for $25 million so the airport could accommodate Boeing 747's. When the F.A.A. refused, Mr. Perot went to the House Speaker, Jim Wright of Texas. Congress authorized the money.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
The Saudis Switch Strategies
 
OPEC sets oil prices by consensus: Whatever Saudi Arabia wants is the consensus. Last week oil prices moved up by more than $1 a barrel to $22 after Saudi Arabia let it be known that it was no longer averse to letting prices rise. That was a shift from Saudi Arabia's traditional strategy of keeping prices low to foster long-term demand for oil. The impetus for the change was the European Community's plan to tax oil, beginning at $3 a barrel this year and rising to $10 a barrel by the end of the decade. The new tax was unveiled in preparation for this week's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. But with Saudi Arabia now determined to make its money in the short term, economists worry about a new round of global inflation.

The War on Saddam's Money
 
Operation Desert Storm may have routed Iraq's army from Kuwait, but it failed to dislodge Saddam Hussein from Baghdad. Last week details of a secret destabilization plan leaked out. The plan, which involves several Western governments including the United States, aims to spur inflation. Fake dinar notes are being trucked into Iraq while airplanes pelt the countryside with "dollars." But the plan must have been cooked up by the economists, not the generals: History records few examples of inflation-induced coups. And even if there is unrest, Hussein and his Government are protected by a guard of 45,000 troops.

Science's Bargain Basement
 
The Russians may not be capitalists yet, but they are learning. Last week a physics institute in Moscow made a deal with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to put 100 Russian scientists on A.T.& T's research payroll. But the new employees in Moscow evidently haven't learned how to negotiate. While American researchers hire out for about $70,000 a year, Russia's mental muscle will go for just $40 a month.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
So Vile, Everyone's for It
 
The House energy bill, which was overwhelmingly passed last week, must be a compromise of a very high order. No one likes it. Conservationists got a ban on new offshore drilling, angering the White House. They also got higher mileage standards for cars, angering Detroit, and an increase in the use of alternative fuels, angering oil producers. The nuclear power industry got its regulations streamlined, which upset environmentalists. Competition between electricity suppliers was intensified, which pleased consumers while distressing producers. Gas producers liked a provision speeding up pipeline licensing, but disliked rules taking away their right to limit production to keep prices high. "This is half a good energy bill," said Daniel Becker, a lawyer for the Sierra Club.

Consumers Are Cheerier
 
If the Conference Board's Index of Consumer Confidence is any indication, consumers are beginning to emerge from their funk. The board's index rose to a cheerful 71.6 in May, from 65.1 in April. The index was 100 in 1985. Since two thirds of all economic activity is driven by consumers' spending, a rosier attitude forecasts growth.

A Smart Bet for Recovery
 
While the nation's academic economists have yet to declare the recession over, the National Association of Business Economists revised upward its growth forecast for the year, to 2 percent from 1.5 percent. "The odds against another downturn are 5-to-1 " said Joseph Duncan, vice president of the association.

At Last, Detroit Gets a Break
 
For Detroit, mid-May could be the light at the end of the tunnel. Sales of North American-built vehicles rose 9.3 percent in that period, the auto makers reported last week. The figures were especially welcome by the Big Three, since they showed Detroit had won back a smidgeon of market share from Japan. Detroit's share of total sales -- cars, trucks, vans and buses -- rose to 89 percent from 88.4 percent last year. "If the rate were to stay like this for a few periods, we could definitely say it was a turning point," said Harvey Heinback, an automobile analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York.
 
Good News on Joblessness
 
New jobless claims fell by 4,000 last week to 403,000, the best showing in more than seven months, the Labor Department said last week. The drop came despite 1,400 new unemployment claims in California growing out of the Los Angeles riots.
 
Growth, Yes, but It's Wimpy
 
Most recessions are followed by at least a year's worth of spunky growth in gross domestic product. Five to 6 percent is normal. By those standards, this recovery is plagued by the wimp factor. In the first quarter, the Commerce Department said last week, the nation's GDP increased by 2.4 percent, up from an earlier estimate of 2 percent. "This recovery is like an aircraft that takes off but fails to gain much altitude," said Norman Robertson, an economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "Though it's sub par, it's nothing to sneer at. It's the best growth performance we've had since 1989."

HEADLINE: At Work;
Should Fringe Benefits Be Taxed?

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
If Government reports were zeppelins, the skies over Washington would perpetually look like a turn-of-the century airshow. Last month, the General Accounting Office quietly floated its own lighter-than-air craft, a baggage-crammed survey of the pros and cons of taxing employee benefits as income, and let it drift quietly onto the desks of various interested parties, most of whom cast a nervous glance toward the electorate and madly disavowed any knowledge of the report's provenance.
Little of "Tax Policy: Effects of Changing the Tax Treatment of Fringe Benefits," the G.A.O.'s report to the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation, is original. But it brings together data that had previously been reported by several agencies in different publications, and in doing that it provides a centralized document for Washington's tax policy experts to pore over. "It put some of the details behind what we knew intuitively," said David Certner, a pension specialist at the American Association of Retired Persons. "We knew benefits are expensive." 
 As the report points out, the Treasury Department forgoes an estimated $91 billion in revenue annually because benefits like pensions, health care and life insurance are not counted as taxable income.
Pensions and health benefits are two of the top three forms of "tax expenditure," or reductions in income tax because the Government chooses not to collect it. Mortgage deductions are the third. Giving fringe benefits tax expenditure status is "an important incentive to provide socially desirable benefits like medical care," said William Custer, research director of the Employee Benefits Research Institute in Washington.
The G.A.O. says the report was done, not at the request of Congress, as is common at the agency, but of its own volition, to clarify a complicated and controversial topic. "We are not out there trying to advocate a position; it's meant to be a thought piece for Congress," said Thomas J. McCool, assistant director for tax policy and administrative issues at the G.A.O. and an author of the report. "We wanted to see if income tax systems treat people with similar incomes in the same way."
The report concludes that tax systems do not treat similarly situated people similarly. It said, "Current tax treatment of fringe benefits works against tax equity because some workers receive employer-provided, tax-preferred fringe benefits while others do not." In the words of the A.A.R.P.'s Mr. Certner, "The deficiency in the current system is that not everyone gets the benefits even though everyone pays for them."
Millions of Americans receive untaxed compensation in the form of pensions, health benefits, life insurance and flexible plans, which taken together have become increasingly important. Since 1950, benefits as a percentage of total compensation have more than tripled, to 16.2 percent.
But the proportion of the civilian work force covered by employer-provided pension plans -- to take the single largest type of tax expenditure, at $51 billion -- has declined to less than half and is expected to keep dropping for the next few years. And even workers who have pension plans today are more likely to have them in a form considerably more limited in value and certainty than the traditional pension, in which an employer pledged a defined amount that an employee could count on for life.
So should taxpayers who are already footing more of the bill for their retirement have to subsidize the pension system? The intuitive answer is no. But as the report and several people in the benefits "community" pointed out, a pension system has functions other than subsidizing the sunblock of a few lucky retirees in Florida.
"To the extent that employers contribute and it's tax-free, people have an incentive to save" through contributory benefit programs like 401(k) plans, said Andrew Katz, who tracks tax-related compensation issues at the Research Institute of America, a publisher in New York. Pension funds in their present form provide assets of more than $2.7 trillion to the national economy, and they make unnecessary an even costlier system backed by the Federal Government.
Given the number of groups with a potential interest in any change in the system, on the one hand, and the sheer amount of untapped revenue, on the other, it is impossible to predict where the inevitable push-me, pull-you of lobbying will go, but few people expect any discussion of taxing benefits to rise above a whisper before the election. "In the short run, the danger of any policy change is quite minute," said Jim Jaffe, a spokesman for Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is vice chairman of the Joint Committee on Taxation.
 
 
UNSPEAKABLE IDEAS ON HEALTH CARE
 "Tax hike" is a phrase that nobody dares to speak aloud in Washington in an election year. So it is an indication of how seriously the crisis in the health-care system is taken in Washington that some, even some on the Hill, are pondering the possibilities in untaxed health-care benefits.
Yet despite what many call the inequity between high-salary employees with rich health-care plans and the millions of employees with medium salaries and no health care, any attempt to impose taxes will almost certainly encounter ferocious opposition. "It has been suggested that the tax treatment of health care is one of the causes of health-care cost inflation," said William Custer of the Employee Benefits Research Institute.
Jim Jaffe, a spokesman for Dan Rostenkowski, treads carefully around the possibility of change. "In the context of health-care reform legislation, there is a growing awareness of how large a subsidy exists," he said. Still, the only proposal on the horizon is to put a cap on the deductability of health care benefits and that is given only a slim chance of ever seeing the light of the Capitol's dome.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Ford Caps Its Line of Crown Victorias

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
EXCEPT for New Orleans, where the cabs are as flamboyant as the food, you are not likely to see a spiffy taxi in most cities, much less in New York. So I was surprised when I got into one last week that had both a fresh wax job and a newly polished interior.
Another surprise was that the car was a Ford, a rarity on potholed streets that are the special province of the Chevy Caprice. My comment on the oddities produced a conversation with the driver, who was genuinely pleased to hear that Ford has resumed its sale of rear-wheel-drive fleet vehicles after a 14-month hiatus. 
 "I've been waiting and waiting," he said. "This is my own car. It's an '89 and I've been nursing it along. I wouldn't have one of those Chevies. On these streets, they're always out of alignment."
Half of his brain thought for a moment while the other half dealt with a fire engine that was bearing down on us. And then he said: "This one's always out of alignment, too. But I take it to Sears."
The four-door sedan that Ford has finally brought to market as a commercial and police vehicle is its Crown Victoria, introduced in March 1991 as a '92 model. Incredibly, the new car represented the first major redesign of the company's full-size sedan since 1979, and Ford decided to hold off on fleet sales until the retail market had been satisfied.
Until this spring, the car could be had only in standard and LX models, but now there is a civilian version of the heavy-duty chassis and it takes over the line's top spot as a Touring Sedan.
As such, it sports a 210-horsepower V8, antilock brakes, a stiffer suspension with front and rear stabilizer bars, cast-aluminum wheels with performance tires, tinted glass, air-conditioning, an air bag for the driver and an optional bag for the front passenger.
According to Ross Roberts, Ford Division's general manager, the new Crown Vic is meant to bridge generations, and it just might do that.
The long if not the short of it is that this is a b-i-g old-fashioned American sedan, and some of us love that. It offers size, comfort, security and status. It has a column shift for the standard automatic transmission. It has terrific headroom and you can actually see out of it.
It has chrome trim and bench seats, front and rear, with pockets on the backs of the front seats. The rear compartment is, as they say, commodious, and the back windows go all the way down, just like they did in the old days.
The Touring Sedan even has a power antenna that you have to raise and lower by pushing a button, unlike most cars today with automatic antennas that work when you turn the radio on and off.
O.K., so that's not a genuine plus. And neither is the front bench seat, particularly. Despite the power adjustments, it is simply too flat. It is uncomfortable on a trip, and the tester's gray leather upholstery offered no grip for the seat of the pants.
There is no place to put a coffee cup and there is pretty much no place to rest your left foot when you are driving. But those are the only complaints, I promise, and there are plenty of really neat things to compensate.
Like its sister ship, the Mercury Grand Marquis, the Vic is very quiet, very supple on the road. Gearing is meant to preserve fuel economy and the high ratios take their toll on acceleration, but the car's performance certainly is satisfactory.
It also handles nicely for the sort of car that it is, and it is . . . well, just plain pretty. There is a roundness that evokes the early 50's with a touch of Jaguar thrown in, all with a modern overlay.
The doors merge into the roof, limousine-style. Glass is nearly flush, and the steeply sloping nose does its bit for aerodynamics. The test car's black paint was complemented by gray vinyl cladding on the lower panels, and the bumpers are integrated and body-colored.
The Touring Sedan's doors also feature Ford's better idea, combination locks, and they are teamed with the rolling-lock feature that seals all doors when the car is in motion.
Things are equally amenable inside, with a clean dash whose black instrument panel includes a 120-m.p.h. speedometer and gauges for volts, fuel, temperature and oil.
The seat belts have up-down adjustments, a nice touch usually reserved for cars with luxury price tags, and the controls are excellent, even including a sensible single knob to control the parking lights and headlamps.
Perforated leather is wrapped around the four-spoke steering wheel, and the cruise-control buttons live between the spokes next to the air bag. Also, even with a passenger bag in the right side of the dash, the designers have managed to find room for a useful glovebox.
All that said, the new Crown Victoria is no match for the original, at least to my eye.
For a start, and comely as it is, the Touring Sedan is far less sporty than the 1955 model that made sense of the "crown" in its name. And, like its rival, the Chevy Caprice, the new car cries out for treatment as a coupe, maybe a full-size ragtop.
When the Crown Victoria appellation was born 37 years ago, "hardtop convertibles" were just beginning to be the rage. The original Fairlane Crown Vic was one of those, a pillarless two-door hardtop with what came to be called basket-handle roof trim.
An even jazzier version, the Skyliner, had the front half of the roof made of transparent green plexiglass. Ford produced only 1,999 Skyliners, so those cars were fairly rare. But the standard Crown was a big hit, and the company rolled 33,165 of them out of the showrooms.
Along with Ford's bread-and-butter models, the sporty two-door helped to make 1955 the second best year in the company's history, behind 1923 when Model T's dominated America's roads.
Oh, and one other thing: 1992's Crown Victorias carry stickers ranging from $20,108 for the base sedan to $24,377 for the new top of the line. In 1955, the most you could pay was $2,372.
I knew there was something I liked about those old cars.

LENGTH: 318 words

HEADLINE: Groundwater

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stephen Hess, president of the developers' Association for a Better Long Island, is correct in saying in his letter on May 3 that groundwater can be protected by cluster development with covenants guaranteeing perpetual open space in the remainder of the properties. However, the location, type and overall development density of the properties are much more important. 
 For example, within Long Island's nine designated watersheds (called Special Groundwater Protection Areas), which supply all of the Island's aquifers, the fast-disappearing open spaces are so vital to the quality of the groundwater that the Long Island Regional Planning Board has recommended five-acre residential zoning for the remaining large undeveloped tracts. These areas, which comprise about 25 percent of the Island, are the major precipitation recharge areas to the aquifers.
Five-acre zoning is already in place in several Nassau villages (Brookville, Matinicock, Mill Neck, Muttontown and Upper Brookville), and in four Suffolk towns (Brookhaven, Easthampton, Southampton and part of Southold). Five-acre zoning has also been upheld by the New York State Court of Appeals.
Open spaces in the Special Groundwater Protection Area watersheds are as important to the groundwater and ecnomy of Long Island as the Catskill and Croton watersheds are to New York City's reservoirs and economy. Clustering should be employed whenever a large tract is developed within a Special Groundwater Protection Area in order to preserve Long Island's water supply; with the number of units per cluster limited to the number based on five-acre zoning of the overall property. If developers and environmentalists can agree on this, cooperation can replace obstructionism, and the Island's economic recovery can begin.
 
JULIAN KANE
Hempstead, L.I.
 
The writer is a geology professor at Hofstra University

HEADLINE: OUT THERE: PRAGUE;
Still Another Spring

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
Call it a marriage of high-tech Western razzmatazz and the fin-de-siecle elegance of a salon in Mitteleuropa. A grand piano stands in the middle of the office, but the only music is Bruce Springsteen's "Human Touch" on the sound system. Moldings of violins adorn the cornices, but the only instruments in use are cellular telephones and computers. "I hope," says Jean-Claude Van Gansen, "that this mix makes my clients confident."
Whatever the appeal of Mr. Van Gansen's headquarters in the music room of a 19th-century mansion, its eclectic style is appropriate. For this former jeans retailer from Belgium is trying to make a fortune by wedding the financial savvy of the West with the myriad opportunities in an East Europe emerging from years of Communist inertia. 
 Like hordes of other entrepreneurs drawn to this new capitalist frontier, he wants a piece of the action in what amounts to a gold rush. His company, East-West Finance, might as aptly be called Wild-West Finance.
Mr. Van Gansen, who is 40 years old, arrived here from Brussels five days after Czechoslovakia's Communist regime fell in December 1989. He had sold his Jeans Fizz chain of stores in Belgium and reckoned there was money to be made in the East European lurch to capitalism. "I did not come with a single purpose but with an open mind," he said with a smile, "and I soon found the problem is not looking for opportunities but limiting yourself."
Imagine the scene: no advertisements, no marketing, no stock market or fast food, no financial regulations, virtually no private enterprises and just a scant notion of profit and loss. In such circumstances, chutzpah, slickness, style and persistence count for more than the lessons of Wharton or Harvard.
Mr. Van Gansen -- who manages to look both cherubic and fairly ruthless -- moved fast. He started the country's first billboard business and now has 35 percent of that burgeoning market. Then he and a partner bought the rights to produce the Czechoslovak Yellow Pages, and later sold them to New York Telephone for what he calls "a big profit." A move into real estate followed, and a Prague office block is under construction.
Throughout this splurge, he was dismayed by the relative absence of American businessmen. Indeed, German companies had plowed about $2.5 billion into Czechoslovakia before United States businesses recently began to move more aggressively. One possible reason: sometimes, Mr. Van Gansen concedes, you have to give a little baksheesh to get things moving, and that is not part of American corporate style.
The opportunities, even now, remain vast. You only need to sample your second plate of greasy pork and stodgy cabbage smeared with sour cream to realize that in restaurants alone, fortunes await. Drugstores appear stocked with the leftovers from a day of Los Angeles rioting. McDonald's, that worldwide barometer of emergent capitalism, has just opened its first restaurant.
Indeed, all that has been done up to now amounts to little more than an hors d'oeuvre. A blowout sale of 1,446 state-owned companies valued by the Government at $9.3 billion began this month, and Mr. Van Gansen is among those who intend to profit.
There is plenty of dross among the firms being sold but there are also some jewels, among them the renowned Pilsener brewery, another brewery named Budweiser (the original, it claims), several glass factories and some excellent ceramics companies. The nifty thing about the sale is that nobody really knows the value of these companies. In the absence of a market, any valuation is difficult, so there should be bargains. About 8.6 million citizens have paid $37 each for a booklet of vouchers enabling them to buy shares in the companies being auctioned.
Mr. Van Gansen is shopping, too. Using aggressive TV advertising last year, when a 30-second spot cost as little as $1,000, he guaranteed a fifteenfold return in a year to people who ceded him their booklets. He has set up a mutual fund and secured vouchers with a book value of about $20 million.
Mr. Van Gansen is more commercial than industrial. He wants to wheel and deal rather than hold onto the shares he buys. Image is therefore important, to induce trust in his clients. "Take the piano and rock music in this office," he said. "Nobody would have dreamed you could combine such things with business, but it helps put people at ease."
Another thrusting young entrepeneur, Viktor Kozeny, a Czech who attended Harvard and has started a company in Prague called Harvard Capital and Consulting, started earlier and secured vouchers with a book value of close to $700 million by promising a tenfold return within a year to investors.
"I've got $700 million to spend in the next few months," the 28-year-old Mr. Kozeny said. "It should be nice shopping."
The catch is that Mr. Kozeny's $700 million and Mr. Van Gansen's $20 million are purely theoretical, based on the Government's valuation of the companies on sale. Until a true market emerges nobody knows what the shares the two entrepreneurs will acquire with the vouchers are really worth.
"Everyone's playing Monopoly right now," concedes the apparently unrufflable Mr. Van Gansen. "My fund might be worth $100 million in a few years and I started it with virtually nothing. Of course, it might not be worth that much. But to even try this sort of thing in the West you'd need a bank."
It is precisely the absence of strong capital backing for the likes of Mr. Kozeny's or Mr Van Gansen's funds that worries some people. Suppose, a year from now, everyone wants to cash out and take the promised tenfold and fifteenfold returns. The entrepreneurs could be forced to dump their shares and a mass sell-off in a nascent stock market could lead to panic.
"Sure, there's some risk," Mr. Van Gansen said. "But the upside here is so great that it's a mistake to hesitate in seizing a share of the market. The Czechoslovaks are very nice people and good technicians, but they do not understand the power of marketing and commercialism yet."
In other words, style takes you a long way right now on Prague's fast-and-loose frontier.

HEADLINE: Dismissing Inflation Too Easily

 BODY:
To the Editor:
This letter is triggered by Alfred E. Kahn's comments on air fares (Forum, "A Dogfight Over Deregulation," May 17) but does not apply only to him. Is there no end to our being told that the cost of something has gone down or only up X percent, after allowing for inflation? The implication is that we really have nothing to complain about. Tell that to those on fixed incomes. Yet, nowhere is it mentioned that one of the causes of the inflation for which we are adjusting is that same something whose price has gone up. 
 By the way, Mr. Kahn, whom do I charge for my time after having wasted countless hours flying involuntarily into Atlanta, Charlotte, Pittsburgh, Newark and so on?
 
HOWARD KAPLAN
Chevy Chase, Md., May 17

HEADLINE: Conversations/Cajuste Carelus;
A Haitian Refugee Wonders When He'll Return

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Cajuste Carelus, who is in the 12th year of exile from his native Haiti, can speak freely. He has no plans to return home anytime soon.
President of the Haitian Community Association in Huntington, N.Y., and chairman of its Multi-Cultural Center, Mr. Carelus has pledged not to return to Port-au-Prince until democracy does. "I work for change from here," he said. His association tracks Haiti's faltering attempts at democracy, helping scores of the casualties: refugees who land here without money, housing or friends. Mr. Carelus and a friend feed and shelter the newcomers, and provide a lawyer. 
 The friend sits by, listening closely as Mr. Carelus speaks, but says little. He clings to his anonymity because he intends to go home sometime soon.
Through their work, the two men have encountered the fear and desperation of Haitians who have fled the military takeover of their country. They are incensed by President Bush's decision to turn back the rattletrap boats bearing Haitians bound for America, and believe Washington would only have to place one tersely worded phone call to Port-au-Prince to restore to power Haiti's democratically elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
"I don't believe in military intervention from America," said Mr. Carelus, "but if Bush wanted it, Aristide would be sleeping in Haiti tonight." Mr. Aristide left Haiti after a military coup Sept. 30. Since then, thousands of Haitians have escaped the country, and filled the holding camps at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, in their quest to reach Miami.
Citing overcrowding at Guantanamo Bay, the Bush Administration announced last week that to discourage more Haitians from striking out for America, the Coast Guard would escort back to Haiti any boats not in imminent danger of sinking.
Those seeking political asylum would have to do so at the American embassy in Port-au-Prince, Washington said. At the same time, the United States is applying economic pressure against the military regime run by Gen. Raoul Cedras through an embargo.
Mr. Carelus's friend, who had refrained from speaking, now addressed him in Creole. The two agreed that the American-backed embargo of Haiti amounted to little more than an attempt to hedge political bets.
 
Casual Racism
 "There's a big hole in the economic embargo," Mr. Carelus said, switching to English. "We do have the Dominican Republic next to us. Anything can go through there. The embargo would be good if any ship or plane couldn't travel to Haiti, and if the people of the O.A.S. [Organization of American States] enforced it."
He maintains that most of the refugees bobbing over the Caribbean are escaping military repression rather than poverty. "They are political refugees, because before Aristide, a lot refused to come by sea because it was so dangerous," Mr. Carelus said. "But we see this real flow after Aristide lost power, when the military took over."
At 42 years of age, Mr. Carelus, a high school science teacher when he left Haiti, now works in Syosset as a school maintenance man. His 62-year-old friend founded an elementary school in Haiti in the 1950's. The Tontons Macoute blew it up a few years later. Defying a presidential order to remain in Haiti, the principal fled. Now he paints boats for a living in Port Washington, N.Y.
Their Haitian Community Association has also tried to improve the quality of education that the Huntington schools provide for immigrant children. An investigation by the New York State Department of Education found that the schools offered minimal instruction in English as a second language, and placed a disproportionate number of foreign and minority children into special-education classes.
"I had a meeting with the superintendent right here in this room," said Mr. Carelus. "We offered to talk to the children a few times a week, to translate, to work with the school district. I said, 'We have teachers in the district from Haiti.' They smile when we talk, but they definitely don't want us."
The superintendent, Richard B. Stock, did not return a reporter's phone call seeking comment.
Their lives on Long Island are not marked by the harshness faced by Haitians in New York City. Perhaps because the minority population is smaller than in New York, the racism is more overt here, said Mr. Carelus. "You live with it. You see it. You touch it."
The battles Mr. Carelus fought in Haiti were more dangerous than casual racism in Long Island. There he had spoken to his students against the regime of Jean-Claude Duvalier. One April night, the Tontons Macoute took Mr. Carelus to a cafeteria-style restaurant turned torture chamber. "I was there just because I was caught talking to a few people. Some of them were big officers in the regime.
"From 5 P.M. to the next morning, all night, they made me watch. I saw two men beating another man with sticks and then poking him in the ribs with sticks. A woman was so shocked and frightened, she fell on the floor and had her period right there from the emotion. I saw them beat a man so hard until there was blood, just because he sold somebody's painting for $25 and kept a few dollars for himself." Mr. Carelus shook his head as if to empty out the memory. "He was a student of mine."
He was on his feet, acting out the horrors, and glanced over at his friend: "I see all of that. I saw things must change, and the only way to change was to leave the country," he said.
 
'Time to Go Back'
 The men have differing ideas about how to bring change to their homeland. "This is a good time to go back to Haiti," his friend replied. He believes that if he waits for democracy, he may never get back.
Mr. Carelus is troubled that Haitians are being denied hearings to determine whether they are in danger of political persecution. He believes that the United States has not been complying with the United Nations' 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, which guarantees political asylum to victims of persecution.
He mentioned the Russian Jews who have been taken in by the United States without severe scrutiny. The policy towards Haitians is different. "They're going by our skin."
The abrupt shift in United States policy toward the Haitian boat refugees could spread to people escaping persecution in other countries as well, he cautioned. "Today it's the Haitians, tomorrow it's somebody else."
Neither of the men believed that Mr. Bush's policy, requiring Haitians to apply for political asylum at the embassy in Port-au-Prince, would succeed. Mr. Carelus's friend could not contain his feelings. "If one or two go," he said, "it's no big deal. But if it's 400 or 500, the military won't let them go.
"Those military like to see blood. They like to see bodies on the floor. They don't even think about the consequences," he said.
The educator looked down at his hands as he spoke. A week before, his nephew disappeared. His family in Haiti searched for two days, only to find him dead, an electrical cord around his neck.
Nonetheless, he plans to return home this summer. He speaks of building a school, a clinic, a canteen, a tool bank for farmers. It is because he wants to go back so urgently that he restrained himself during the conversation. For when he has spoken publicly about the plight of Haitians, chilling phone calls followed: "You're going to die tonight," unnamed voices warn. Until now, they have never been able to silence him.
