HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
It's Harder Now to Figure Out Compelling National Interests

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Behind the Bush Administration's groping for an appropriate response to the crises in Yugoslavia and Haiti is a much deeper problem bedeviling American foreign policy: figuring out what is an "American national security interest" now that the cold war is over. Which conflicts, if any, really are worth American intervention to settle, and which ones can be safely ignored?
In some ways, the existence of the Soviet Union made life easy. The Kremlin was the North Star of America's foreign policy. All the policymakers had to do was take out their compasses, point them at any regional conflict in the world, see which side Moscow was on and immediately deduce which side America should take. Virtually every conflict from Namibia to Afghanistan to Nicaragua engaged American interests, and prompted some level of American military involvement, because the Soviets were backing one side or the other. 
 But with the collapse of the Soviet empire, the old American compass no longer works. As a result, both the "realist" school of American foreign policy and the "idealist" school seem to have lost their way. After all, what does it mean to be a realist when there is no Soviet threat to override human rights considerations? And what does it mean to be an idealist when what is required to preserve human rights in places such as Yugoslavia and Haiti is military intervention?
This confusion was not immediately apparent in the first post-cold war crisis -- the gulf war -- because oil and an Iraqi nuclear program were involved, and the Soviets were still lurking in the background in Baghdad. Clearly, American national security was at stake.
But then came the coup in Haiti. The island's first democratically elected government, that of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was ousted Sept. 30 by military plotters. Immediately afterward Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in an echo of the Bush Administration's firmness against the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, stated "this coup must not and will not succeed."
That was eight months ago, and the Administration has still shown no inclination to go beyond a policy of sanctions to restore Mr. Aristide the way it restored Sheik Jabar al-Ahmed al-Sabah of Kuwait -- despite the fact that Mr. Aristide was democratically elected and Sheik Jabar never was.
In Yugoslavia, the Bush Administration sat on its hands for months as the Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic ripped apart that country and engaged in "ethnic cleansing" of Serbian occupied areas inside Bosnia. At a recent briefing Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokesman, was asked by a reporter whether the Bosnians "deserve some kind of protection from somebody, given that there is a new world order which has been declared by the President of the United States?" She candidly replied: "The only honest answer I have is one that happens to be a fact: Where is it written that the United States government is the military policeman of the world?"
As tragic as the situation in Yugolsavia was, she explained, the United States had no "national security interests" at stake there.
Although Secretary Baker changed course a few days later and intensified Bush Administration sanctions on Serbia, Miss Tutwiler's statement nevertheless seemed to reflect the Administration's real thinking: that the defense of human rights alone is not in the national interest, especially if it involves getting into quagmires like Haiti or Yugoslavia.
There are good, serious arguments for such prudence, but neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Baker has made them. To the contrary, Mr. Baker said in a major speech last month: "We face a summons to leadership. This time it is not about winning a war, hot or cold, but about winning a democratic peace. The choice for America is this: We can either try to win this peace through a deliberate policy of working with others to shape our times, or we can stand aside and drift while the times shape us. We plan to build a democratic peace."
In other words, the Bush team members talk like idealists but in the crunch act like realists -- without acknowledging the tension between those two principles. At least during the cold war, there was an open debate between idealists and realists. The realists argued that the United States had to stifle its support for human rights in some countries, such as Iran under the Shah, because they were allies against the Soviets; the idealists countered that this was morally too high a price to pay, and such policies in the long run would backfire.
Making the realist argument today is much more difficult with no Soviet threat to justify indifference to human rights in any particular country, and Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker know it. Privately senior Administration officials acknowledge that the realist argument in Yugoslavia is embarrassing because it is so cynical. As one official summed it up: "Do you really think the American people want to spill their blood for Bosnia?"
In fairness, though, the idealists also have not been leveling with the American people. Their case, too, is much more complicated without a Soviet empire around.
During the cold war the principle of nonintervention in the internal affairs of another country was a given, particularly since intervening could set off a nuclear war. And behind the Iron Curtain, civil wars in places like Yugoslavia or Nagorno-Karabakh were prevented by the existence of totalitarian regimes. Therefore, the focus of the idealist argument was on advocating human rights -- demanding free emigration and an end to torture or arbitrary imprisonment in places like the Soviet Union, Rumania or Yugoslavia. The idealists' agenda was to make existing regimes less brutal. They never dreamed they could replace them.
But when the cold war ended, the lid came off various ethnic and nationalist disputes behind the Iron Curtain and the collapse of the Soviet empire removed the biggest impediment to foreign intervention. To protect human rights in Bosnia or Haiti today requires, and invites, a much more ambitious effort.
Human rights activists who have criticized the Bush Administration for refusing to pick up Haitian boat people say the decision will not solve the problem, because the problem, fundamentally, is that life in Haiti is unbearable, and as long as it is people will pour out.
What they won't publicly acknowledge, though, is that the only real solution is intervention -- with peacemakers and peacekeepers on the one hand and political advisers on the other to help develop stable democratic institutions in Haiti that can preserve freedom and promote economic development. That is a tall order.
And what the idealists also don't want to admit is that there is a great discrepancy between what idealism in a place like Haiti or Bosnia requires for fulfillment today -- some form of intervention -- and the amount of real interests the United States has at stake in such places.
 
Cynicism and Constraints
 Realists and idealists both need to reexamine their positions, argues Michael J. Sandel, a Harvard University political theorist. Realism can be a principled position provided it is grounded in a compelling conception of the national interest, he said. Before, the compelling factor was provided by the necessity to confront the Soviet threat. Now, unless national interest can be redefined, the realist argument risks lapsing into cynicism.
"What idealists need to do is move beyond advocating human rights alone to fostering political structures within countries that will allow for genuine pluralism and the self-determination of peoples," Mr. Sandel added. "But this agenda has to be constrained by the sober fact that the American people have neither the ability nor the political will to solve every ancient feud on the map."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
As American as Apple Pie, Dim Sum or Burritos

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Henry Luce called it the American Century, but social observers in a future time may smile as they recall the grandiose sobriquet. They will know how the word American was redefined by two surges of immigration, one ushering in the 20th century and another that is ushering it out. Even national nicknames have lost their resonance. What is a Yank? Can one be found in San Antonio's barrios? Was Kilroy here? Or was it Nguyen?
These future observers will have the advantage of us. Three or four censuses from now, they are likely to know what researchers are just beginning to explore: How the Mexicans, Koreans, Cubans, Filipinos, Hmong, Haitians, Jamaicans, Cambodians and Russian Jews fared after crossing to America. 
 In 1990, the researchers will note, the United States Census marked two watersheds: It found 19.7 million foreign-born residents, the most in the country's history. And it found that in the expanded population of first-generation immigrants the Asian-born now outnumber the European-born. Those from Latin America -- predominantly Mexicans -- outnumber both.
"As recently as the 1950's, two-thirds of legal immigrants to the country were from Europe and Canada, with the bulk from Europe," said Jeffrey Passel, a researcher with the Urban Institute, a Washington research firm. "That ceased being true in the 1960's and it's not even close now. European and Canadian immigration is less than 15 percent of total immigration."
The immigrant meccas also changed: as many immigrants entered California during the 1980's as entered New York State from 1901 to 1910.
Mr. Passel and his colleague Barry Edmonston calculate that 66 percent of Asian Americans and 41 percent of Hispanic Americans in 1990 were immigrants. Another 21 percent of Asians and 26 percent of Hispanic residents were children of immigrants.
If the current levels of immigration continue, the two researchers believe, Hispanic residents will number 39 million in two decades, surpassing blacks as the largest minority group. The number of Asians, which doubled in the last decade to 7.3 million, will double again in 20 years' time, and will triple, to 21.5 million, by 2020, according to the Urban Institute's projections. Black immigrants, from Africa and the Caribbean, who now number 1.1 million, will triple their numbers by 2010.
Who will these immigrants be? Nurses, entrepreneurs, scientists, day laborers or part of the welfare rolls? The work of another researcher, William P. O'Hare of the Urban Research Institute at the University of Louisville, offers clues about Asian and Hispanic populations, though he said he has not been able to study black immigrants.
In the case of Asians, the new arrivals either stimulated the group's overall economic performance, or, at the least, failed to hold it back. Mr. O'Hare calculates that in 1979 the median income of Asian-American households was at least 12 percent higher than that of white, non-Hispanic households. By 1990, the household income of Asian-Americans, whose education levels are well above the general population's, was 18 percent higher than that of non-Hispanic whites.
But the news was not all good. Though median income rates were high for Asians as a whole, poverty rates were also above average. In 1990, the poverty rate for the Asian and Pacific Island population was 12.2, compared to 8.8 percent for non-Hispanic whites.
Mr. O'Hare believes that the overall economic success of Asians will be furthered by the next wave of immigrants. "I think a disproportionate share of the new professional immigration slots will go to Asians," he said. "Asians have come here since 1965 on the basis of their skills," agreed Dave Simcox, director of the Center for Immigration Studies.
Mr. Simcox's characterization of the Asian groups as having "an impressive core of well-trained people," certainly seemed true a decade ago. Then the average Japanese-American household had a median income of $40,537 (in constant 1990 dollars); median income among Filipino households was $39,473 and it was $37,082 among Asian Indians, all in excess of median household income for whites.
Hispanics immigrants, from Latin America and the Caribbean, make up more than a third of the foreign-born population. But this tide of immigration, Mr. Simcox says, cannot be controlled by such legal checks as quotas or by the immigration law's current bias toward skilled immigrants.
While the poverty rate in the country climbed for the population as a whole, it climbed more steeply for Hispanic people in the years between 1979 and 1990. At the beginning of the decade, 23.5 percent of them were living on incomes below the Federally defined poverty level; in 1990 the figure was 28.1 percent.
That gloomy portrait is balanced, Mr. Passel said, by new indications that "the recent immigrants at the end of the 1980's seem to be doing better than recent immigrants did 10 years ago." "We tend to focus on the lower end of the income spectrum of immigrants, and that gives a misleading picture," he said. "They are coming in throughout the economic spectrum."

HEADLINE: WORLDS APART;
Rio: A Start on Managing What's Left of This Place

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
Most of the delegates converging on Rio de Janeiro for the start of the Earth Summit on Wednesday, it seems safe to say, believe that humanity must do something about the harm that human expansion is doing to the rest of the biosphere. But it also seems that many of the world's governments tend to pin primary responsibility on someone else and to duck strong measures that could hurt them economically or politically.
That is why the Rio meeting -- as has already been made abundantly clear in pre-summit talks on the key issues of climate and extinction of species -- is likely to disappoint any who are expecting a dramatic environmental leap forward. 
 This is not to say that nothing important is happening. For the first time, the nations of the world are seriously coming to grips with the fundamental and seemingly intractable question of how to pursue economic growth and combat poverty while at the same time protecting the interacting web of atmosphere, water, soil and biological organisms on which human life depends. But the task is proving difficult and frustrating, made so by the fact that rich and poor countries approach it with divergent perceptions and agendas.
"They come to the bargaining table, literally and figuratively, from two different worlds," said Richard Mott, the treaties officer of the World Wildlife Fund.
 
Blame the Rich
 While most of the industrialized countries can afford the luxury of contemplating environmental problems, most of the poor ones are preoccupied with economic survival. Spanning this North-South gulf, as diplomats refer to it, has been the main difficulty but hardly the only one.
Generally speaking, the poor countries of the South blame most environmental damage on the rich countries of the North, who engage in what they see as wasteful overconsumption. The poor countries say they have no choice but to make economic development their first priority. If the South is to play the game of environmental protection, they insist, the North must pay.
Their attitude, says one American diplomat, is: "You've had your turn; you're fat, happy and breathing dirty air and you have no trees. We want our turn, and when we're rich we can start worrying about the environment." Besides, the diplomat added, no leader in a developing country gets elected on environmental issues.
The North, while acknowledging its own responsibility, asserts that the South's frightening population explosion and advancing industrialization threaten to ultimately eclipse any damage done by the North. If the poor countries develop as the industrialized nations have, the North argues, the result will be environmental disaster.
All of this is the political leitmotif of the summit, but it has endlessly complicated variations, exceptions and sub-themes.
 
Talks on Warming
 In talks on a treaty to limit emissions of heat-trapping gases that scientists fear will cause the earth's climate to warm, the North-South split resulted in an agreement three weeks ago that put most of the responsibility on the industrialized countries. They now emit most of the gases, but that is expected to change in the decades ahead as the developing countries grow. Also in the agreement, the rich countries agreed to give poorer ones money and technical help for cleaner cars and smokestacks.
But many political cross-currents affected the path to that rapprochement. The industrialized countries, for instance, were split over insistence by the European Community that emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas, first be stabilized at 1990 levels by the year 2000. The Europeans, with their forceful "green" parties, committed themselves to an economic future in which fossil fuels loom smaller.
The Bush Administration, given the United States' dependence on huge amounts of coal, oil and natural gas, was unsure the country could meet the Europeans' modest targets without hurting the economy. Given a recession and an election year, anti-environmentalist hardliners in the Administration pressed for no concessions at all. But more moderate forces prevailed, the United States agreed to some vague first-step targets, and a compromise was struck in which the Europeans seemed to yield more.
Nor were the developing countries monolithic. India led a hard-line faction that refused to sign any treaty that did not require the Northern countries to take strong first steps. It is still unclear whether India will sign the agreement that emerged. Other developing countries, recognizing that global warming would hurt them as much as anyone, were more conciliatory, though still insistent that the North bear the cost. Few were fully satisfied with the treaty that emerged on May 9, which is to be presented for signing in Rio. But it is widely considered a step forward in that it establishes a process and general commitments aimed at stabilizing greenhouse-gas levels. Even this lowest-common-denominator agreement was nearly derailed at the last moment when Saudi Arabia, whose economy is based on a fossil fuel, tried unsuccessfully to introduce small amendments that could have filibustered the treaty to death.
 
Biological Diversity
 In the talks that produced a treaty on protecting biological diversity two weeks later in Rio, the United States again became a naysayer. But this time it was actually united with other industrialized nations in pressing for strong action on the main point of the treaty -- creating national strategies for protecting ecosystems and integrating protection and economic development.
The bargain struck in Nairobi says that the South will do nothing without Northern money and states flatly that economic development must be its first priority. The concessions to the South, including some less-than-ironclad commitment language, make the treaty less than satisfying to some ardent conservationists. But again, it sets up an international process for long-term management of the problem of species extinction. And for the first time, it institutionalizes the idea of integrating development and conservation by recognizing that preserving jungles and grasslands can bring in money -- through tourism, for instance, or through royalties from companies that develop new drugs from protected plants or gene material from protected animals or microbes.
The United States has refused to sign the treaty, however, and the balkiness stems again from self-interest. American officials say it does too little to protect the patents of companies that share biotechnology with developing countries and that it tries to regulate genetically engineered materials, in which the United States is a leader.
With Rio nearly here, the likelihood is that the international arguing will reach a new pitch as delegates negotiate a declaration of goals and a more detailed blueprint to guide nations in pursuing environmentally friendly economics, as well as a statement of principles on protection of forests. Developing countries, led by Malaysia, which derives much of its national income from logging, have already drastically weakened the statement in preliminary talks.
The overall outcome in Rio will be at least one big measure of how well the world can unite against a danger that all recognize.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "On the Agenda at Rio"
 
The Rio Declaration
 
In its original form, a brief and dramatic "Earth Charter" for protecting the planet. But that was rejected after developing countries wanted language that didn't implicitly recognize their need to build industriesv and put less emphasis on population control and that put more on the responsibilities of rich nations to help poor ones pay for for the cleanups. A longer compromise draft will be considered.
 
Agenda 21
 
A 900-page blueprint for what governments, development agencies and the United Nations should do to protect the environment while letting third world industries grow in the 21st century. It is not legally binding.
 
Treaties
 
A treaty to slow down global warming requires that the 143 signatory countries submit plans for reducing their emissions. The rich countries are asked to aim at returnig to 1990 levels, though they are not required to. They have to report periodically on their progress.
 
A biodiversity treaty was adopted on May 22 by 98 nations who agree to protect ecosystems. It says that rich nations should pay for protection efforts, and that companies that use the plants, animals or microbes of other countries should share the profits and technology with them. The United States, worried about patent protection, will not sign.
 
Negotiations for a legally binding treaty on forestry collapsed when developing countries complained that the talks focused on preventing them from destroying tropical forests but did nothing to control logging in the temperate forests of the United States, Europe and Canada. A "statement of principles ' may be issued. (pg. 6)

LENGTH: 1166 words

HEADLINE: Primaries;
Here Comes The Finale; No Need To Applaud

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
One myth of American political culture envisions the Presidential campaign as a kind of Arthurian quest.
A group of men (it is usually men) sets out in pursuit of the great prize, endures many tests and trials (at the hands of the press, the voters and one another) and is gradually winnowed down to the worthiest of their number. Democracy is served, the voters are served, and the candidate who finally emerges is better for what he has endured. 
 So much for the myth. The 1992 primary campaign limping to a close this Tuesday can be described in many ways, but "redemptive" and "ennobling" are not among them. The man about to win the Democratic nomination, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, is struggling to repair the damage he sustained in the getting of it. President Bush dispatched Patrick J. Buchanan early on, but rather than gaining strength from the challenge remains stuck in the polls and still searching for a message.
The hottest candidate on the scene at the moment, Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, is the one who completely bypassed the primaries -- and seems to be prospering in part because of it. Some political professionals worry that a process that used to enlarge a candidate, make him seem more like a leader, has instead become a diminishing experience. "Gennifer Flowers" and "but I didn't inhale" have entered the popular culture, woven in night after night in a succession of comedy monologues. Mr. Clinton has a wary, hurt look to his eyes that he did not have six months ago.
The voters seem heartily dissatisfied, about as gloomy at the end of this season as they were at the start, judging from the polls. The news media, which entered this campaign cycle vowing to provide better, more substantive coverage, are widely accused of reverting to their old habits, an obsession with the horse race and "character issues."
Bruce Buchanan, a professor of government at the University of Texas who headed a major study of Presidential politics for the Markle Foundation after the widely bemoaned 1988 campaign, describes this primary season as plainly "unsatisfying." Perhaps the surest sign of the unhappiness with the process and what it has produced, Professor Buchanan and others say, is the boom for Mr. Perot.
A primary campaign is shaped by many forces -- the candidates, the press, by recessions and riots and other things that have a life of their own. On the Democratic side, much of this campaign was determined a year ago, when Mr. Bush was soaring in the public opinion polls after the war in the Persian Gulf and the Democrats considered most likely to run decided not to. The field that formed was politically young and largely untested in national politics; they collapsed under the rush of the early primaries when most people barely knew their names.
The season had an over-before-it-started feel, in part because of the Democrats' frenetic primary calendar. Party leaders set out to produce an early nominee by encouraging a schedule that was jam-packed with primaries and caucuses in the first month. It worked: Mr. Clinton was in a two-man race with former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. only a month after the New Hampshire primary. But voters in huge states like California, Ohio and New Jersey, which vote Tuesday, and New York and Pennsylvania, which voted last month, faced very limited choices. The exit polls often reflected voters' anger at the options before them; so did the astonishing rise of Mr. Perot.
Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said, "I wish that important general-election states like California had played a more significant role; it's one of the reasons I urged California to move up." But he still defends the calendar, arguing, "There are inherent advantages in having an early nominee."
Still, many political professionals agree with former Governor Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, who ran for the Democratic nomination in 1988.
"The problem is too much democracy in too few states," Mr. Babbitt said. "The winnowing process is over much too quickly." Mr. Babbitt, like many other Democrats, argues for a more rational, representative schedule of primaries, perhaps determined by lottery. Geography, after all, is often destiny in Presidential politics; Mr. Clinton's lock on his native South, which voted just about en masse on March 10, was critical in his drive toward the nomination.
Many Democrats also make a case for more involvement by party leaders as a kind of safety net to assure that the party ends up with an electable nominee. Much of the disgruntlement in the party last spring came from a sense of powerlessness, a sense that those with the greatest stake in choosing a strong nominee had the least to say in it.
Whenever blame is apportioned for this dispiriting season, the news media get an ample share. "There seemed to be a good deal of good intentions," said Mr. Buchanan, "but along came the Clinton character stuff, and we were off in paroxysms of that."
Gennifer Flowers was a driving force for much of the New Hampshire primary, producing what Marvin Kalb, director of the Joan Shorenstein Barone Center on Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University, calls the "tabloidization of the news." Health care and economic recovery plans paled beside the accusations of marital infidelity and avoiding the draft.
And while television coverage of the campaign began with a far more substantive tone, Mr. Kalb said, the candidates' soundbites shrank on the evening news as the horse race -- who's ahead, where and when -- once again became the driving concern.
But the voters also had something to do with the tone of the season. "People are so disdainful of politics and politicians now that this process almost by definition was going to be an unsatisfactory experience for the voters," argues Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster.
 
The Electorate Myth
 Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat, says: "Much of the critique of politics starts with the assumption that we have this quite well-informed, thoughtful electorate with well-formed preferences, and somehow the political system distorts that. One of the problems with the political system is it sometimes too accurately reflects the public's inconsistencies."
To wit, voters like the benefits of government spending and hate the costs. They like promises of tough, truth-telling leadership and dislike the details, as former Senator Paul E. Tsongas discovered. "I'm no Santa Claus" drew cheers in the abstract; when it got down to higher gas taxes and curtailing entitlements, much of the cheering stopped. Mr. Perot is still in the stage of abstractions: honesty, action, leadership.
As the next phase of the campaign begins, the test for all three men may be whether they can do more than simply reflect the voters' conflicted, cynical mood. For now, the primary season winds down with the ritualistic chorus: "There's got to be a better way."

HEADLINE: CONFERENCE IN RIO/The Rich Vs. the Poor;
Cooling the Globe Would be Nice, But Saving Lives Now May Cost Less

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
One of the frustrations for planners of the Earth Summit in Rio has been the inability of the world's nations to reach agreement on an idea that seems relatively obvious: that something must be done to keep the earth from slowly getting hotter.
Despite the possibility of floods, famines and droughts within the next 50 or 100 years -- though not all scientists are convinced that global warming is a real threat -- the pre-conference talks have already badly split on the issue. Rich nations want poor ones, with their rapid birth rates, to stop scrambling to get more factories and more cars, even if that means they will stay poorer for a while. Poor nations, by contrast, furious that the rich ones have produced far more pollution per person for the last 200 years, want the industrialized countries to be the ones to drive less, plug in less and put expensive scrubbers on their smokestacks -- and they want them to admit that it's more important for poor nations to get out of poverty than to be ecologically pristine. 
 Interestingly enough, many economists, including some outspoken liberals, think the poor nations are right.
The World Bank's 1992 "Development and the Environment" report argues strongly that eliminating poverty should remain the world's top goal. It recognizes that countries will use more energy and pollute more, but argues that growth is a powerful antidote for the kinds of pollution that are killing people right now.
Nearly 2 billion people live without clean water or sewers, and cholera, typhus and other diseases kill two million children a year. One billion live in cities with unsafe sulfur dioxide levels; coal-fired factories spread lung disease and acidify cropland. Leaded gasoline fumes leave many children retarded. Topsoil depletion costs the third world up to 1.5 percent of its annual gross domestic product, and farmers starve.
Sacrificing more people by slowing progress in order to forestall deaths in 50 or 100 years makes no sense, the report concludes.
"Poverty is already a worse killer than any foreseeable environmental distress," said Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist at the World Bank, who calculates that 34 million people a year -- more than live in California -- die of poverty-related causes. "Nobody should kid themselves that they are doing Bangladesh a favor when they worry about global warming."
These economists insist that it is cheaper and fairer for rich countries to shoulder the anti-warming effort. Any funds they spend in the third world should go for things like safe drinking water, sewers, cleaner smokestacks and engines and soil conservation. Education for girls should be another priority, some say, since studies have shown that girls in developing countries with high school educations have an average of three children, while those without average seven.
Economic growth increases pollution, economists admit, but they say that the pendulum eventually begins to swing back. By some estimates, once a nation's per capita income rises to about $4,000, it produces less of some pollutants per capita because it can afford technology like catalytic converters and sewage treatment. Solid waste and carbon dioxide emissions keep increasing, though. Some countries, like Mexico and Russia, are at that $4,000 threshold now.
Poor countries can still fight global warming, the economists say. But the most sensible steps for them to take first are relatively low-cost ones that will also help their economies. For example, eliminating government subsidies on coal and oil will force factories and utilities to become more efficient. Enforcing property rights can slow deforestation. Educating girls can slow population growth.
 
Small Results With High Prices
 "Scientists say there are all these neat things to do for free," said Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, an economics research group. "If it would do so much good now, why haven't we done them? The reasons are political."
In the industrialized world, he points out, even rudimentary steps like adopting taxes on pollution have often been stymied. In the United States, measures like the gas-guzzler tax on big cars and the creation of saleable air-pollution rights have had some effect, but gasoline is still cheap, so there is little incentive to conserve.
On another front, the economists argue that the high price of curbing global warming will yield only small gains.
The World Bank cites estimates that keeping American emissions of greenhouse gases at present levels would cost between 3 and 7 percent of the G.D.P. Three percent equals Federal health spending; 7 percent equals military spending.
The key question is: how much sacrifice is it worth? "You could get rid of highway fatalities if you reduced the speed limit to five miles per hour," said Mr. Hahn. "How much economic growth do you want to give up to buy insurance against global warming?"
 
Like a Recession
 In developing countries, the price might be twice as high, largely because they lack capital, rely heavily on cheap but dirty fuels like wood and charcoal, and have less flexibility since more energy goes for uses like cooking than for air-conditioning.
On the other hand, the economists argue, the costs of global warming, while large, are hardly infinite. William Cline of the Institute for International Economics and others estimate that if the United States's weather became 2 or 3 degrees hotter 50 years from now, the extra costs of adapting -- such as building seawalls and shifting crops -- would equal only 1 to 2 percent of G.D.P., the impact of a mild recession.
In developing countries, putting money into job-creating industries might make more sense, they argue. If every dollar invested today grows to $100 in 50 years, the higher incomes would make climate changes less painful, since people could afford safer housing, more farm irrigation and the like. "The evidence implies that investments with real rate of return as low as 5 percent do more for future generations than investments in large reductions of greenhouse gas emissions," the report said.
The scariest prospects involve the damage to agriculture. But as many economists have pointed out, most famines in recent centuries have been caused not by food shortages but by poverty. As a whole, the world grows more food than it can eat. With higher incomes, poor countries could buy more.
Economists with environmental groups say these estimates are too conservative, and, more important, that they miss the point.
"The approach that 'We'll be 1 to 6 percent less rich' leaves out the risk of catastrophe," said Mr. Cline. And models that rely on the American economy do not take into account the devastation of, for instance, hurricanes in Bangladesh after ocean levels rise.
"It's very difficult for economists to conceive of cataclysm," said David Batker, an economist for the environmental organization Greenpeace.
The debate is apt to continue long after the Rio meeting adjourns. "If science were more certain that we were going to hell in a handbasket," said Mr. Hahn, "you'd get more consensus."

HEADLINE: Dinkins and Council Reach Accord on $29 Billion Budget

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council reached an accord on the basics of a $29.5 billion budget for New York City yesterday, nearly a month ahead of schedule and three hours before Mr. Dinkins was to take off for Europe on an economic-development trip.
Mr. Dinkins and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone announced late yesterday afternoon that they had agreed to add $88 million for schools and other programs to the budget proposed by the Mayor last month, to be paid for by changes in revenue estimates and trims in administrative spending.
 
Police and Parks Gain
 But the settlement, the earliest in recent memory, represented only minor changes in the Mayor's plan. In some ways, its greatest significance lies in its being reached so early and so amicably, signs of an improvement in the city's fiscal picture and a consensus among Council leaders that the Mayor's budget proposal was sound. 
 In addition to money for schools, the Mayor and speaker said funds were being restored for police, parks, highway cleaning, cultural institutions and city colleges.
City officials said that to allow the Board of Education to keep elementary class sizes at 25 students, they restored $34 million to its budget. About $10 million was added back to allow the Police Department to go forward with a program of using civilians to replace officers at desk jobs, and $48 million was reinstated for park maintenance, highway cleaning, cultural institutions and services for college students.
The changes from the budget the Mayor proposed last month are to be paid for by $47 million in other cuts, mainly across-the-board administrative cuts at city agencies, $35 million in higher tax-revenue estimates in the 1993 fiscal year and $6 million in additional state aid.
Even with the restorations, the budget agreement still cuts city services by some $201 million, meaning fewer jail beds, bumpier roads, deferred sewer repairs, the elimination of a fire battalion and engine company and reduction of about 16,500 city jobs through attrition over four years.
The budget also cuts spending by $235 million through "streamlining" initiatives, like reducing administrative and office staffs at city agencies, and by $129 million through "restructuring" initiatives, like consolidating scofflaw towing and privatizing some city-owned housing.
Late yesterday, at a news conference at City Hall to announce the accord, the Mayor, surrounded by City Council members, acknowledged that the budget was not "going to please everybody."
 
A 'Prudent' Pact
 "But it is prudent, thoughtful and fair," he said. "It doesn't spend money we don't have -- nor does it begrudge New Yorkers the programs and services that make our city a decent, humane and livable place."
Mr. Vallone, in remarks that pointed to the contrast to last year's long and painful budget struggle, joked that the talks had been hurried up so that Council members could take advantage of new low air fares and accompany the Mayor. "This is the best I've seen in the years I've been here,' Mr. Vallone said of both the process and the budget itself.
Mr. Vallone had set an informal deadline of Mr. Dinkins's departure for the agreement, vowing that the Council would pass its own budget in his absence if no accord was reached.
The budget agreement, which goes before the full City Council for ratification later this week, is for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Budgets are usually not approved until the end of June, when the state has finally fashioned its budget and the city knows exactly how much money it can expect in state aid.
Since there was general agreement on the Mayor's spending proposal and the state approved its budget on time this year, Mr. Vallone strongly suggested that both sides reach an agreement by the June 5 deadline imposed in the City Charter, which is almost always bypassed, aides to the Speaker said.
 
Before European Trip
 Because the Mayor planned to be in Europe on June 5, it was decided late last week that the two sides would try to reach an agreement before his departure last night.
Participants on both sides of the negotiations said that the breakthrough in the talks came late Thursday when the Council and administration agreed that only about $41 million could actually be added to the spending plan. The compromise represented a retreat by Council budget officials, who had estimated earlier in the week that as much as $100 million in unanticipated revenue would be available.
In stark contrast to the city's last two budgets, which contained deep service cuts, the spending plan agreed to yesterday reflects a slight upswing in the city's economy that gives the Mayor and the Council a fiscal breathing spell, with the chance to restore some of the programs and services that were cut and to create new ones.
The Mayor had already been making use of the easing of gloom to make a series of announcements that represented some of the only good news he has had to publicize since tax revenues began to plummet as he took office. Last month, as he proposed his budget, the Mayor announced that libraries would be open for longer hours, new health clinics built, new tuberculosis programs created and other improvements in city services made. The final budget includes all these programs and in fact speeds up the timetable for libraries in all five boroughs to resume five-day service.
Perhaps the most important development has been the substantial surplus that budget officials predict the city will realize at the end of this fiscal year. The surplus -- projected at $515 million last week -- will allow the city to avoid borrowing to help balance the new budget and will offset hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal funds and new taxes that the city will not receive.
Mayor Dinkins had initially planned to close major gaps in the budget by borrowing $250 million with the help of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, but bond raters and fiscal monitors strongly resisted that plan, warning that such an arrangement could jeopardize the city's credit ratings.
 
Some Financing Fell Through
 The Mayor's spending plan also had assumed $200 million in Federal anti-recessionary funds that have not been forthcoming, and $115 million in new local taxes, which the City Council supported but both parties agreed to abandon last week when it became clear that the State Legislature would not approve them.
Mr. Dinkins had threatened to make deeper cuts in the budget, including layoffs, if the state did not approve the taxes, but as estimates for the city's budget surplus began to grow, the administration said that the surplus would more than make up for the proposed taxes.
The surplus comes from several sources, including deep spending cuts over the last two years, higher than expected city tax revenue, an untapped general reserve fund and money set aside for contracts that are no longer needed.
But the surplus also created some political problems for the Mayor. Chief among them is one that is not resolved by yesterday's agreement: Leaders of the city's municipal labor unions, which are working without contracts, demanded wage increases and accused the Mayor of distorting the budget outlook to win concessions from them. And the surplus killed any chance of winning approval in Albany for new taxes.
But Dinkins administration officials maintain that the city is not out of the woods yet financially and that this year's surplus may not occur next year, when the city must close equally large projected deficits.

HEADLINE: U.N. VOTES 13-0 FOR EMBARGO ON TRADE WITH YUGOSLAVIA; AIR TRAVEL AND OIL CURBED

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 30

 BODY:
Rejecting last-minute Serbian appeals for a delay, the Security Council voted overwhelmingly today to follow the Bush Administration's lead and impose tough economic sanctions on the Yugoslav Government in an effort to force Belgrade try to bring peace to Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In addition to calling for the establishment of a "security zone" around the Sarajevo airport to allow emergency supplies to be flown into the Bosnian capital, today's resolution committed the Council to "consider immediately, whenever necessary, further steps to achieve a peaceful solution in conformity with relevant resolutions of the Council." [Excerpts from the resolution, Page 8.]
 
U.S. to Seize Yugoslav Assets
 Although the resolution, which passed with 13 votes in favor and two abstentions, made no specific reference to using force, some Council members are informally discussing the possibility of a naval blockade of the Adriatic ports and closing Bosnian air space to Serbian planes that are supporting forces fighting there. In Sarajevo today, Bosnian Serbs and Muslim Slavs battled at an army barracks, but the Serbs were later reported to have ordered their troops to halt artillery fire.. 
 Tonight, President Bush ordered the Treasury Department to seize all Yugoslav Government assets in the United States by Monday. The White House said they amounted to about $200 million.
"The grave events in Serbia and Montenegro constitute an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security, foreign policy and economy of the United States," Mr. Bush said in a statement.
 
Loopholes Are Seen
 Together with the comprehensive ban on all commercial and financial links imposed on Iraq before the Persian Gulf war, today's decision by the Security Council represents the second time that it has taken punitive action against an aggressor nation since the end of the cold war.
In Belgrade, the capital of Serbia, economists and Western diplomats agreed that the sanctions would impose hardships on the republic but that contingency plans and loopholes were likely to enable the Serbian economy to function for a long time. [Page 8.]
Today's embargo, which closely resembles the sanctions against Iraq, requires all the countries of the world to cease trading in any commodity, including oil, with the Yugoslav federation formed by Serbia and Montenegro and to freeze all its foreign assets.
All air traffic links to and from the country must also be suspended and no one may repair, service, operate, insure or provide spare parts for aircraft registered in Serbia or Montenegro.
In addition, the resolution bans Serbia and Montenegro from participating in any international sporting events. It requires all countries to suspend cultural, scientific and technical contacts with Belgrade and to reduce the size of its foreign diplomatic missions.
Russia dropped its earlier reservations about the embargo and voted in favor of the sanctions. In a strong statement issued in Moscow today, Russia said Belgrade had "brought upon itself the United Nations sanctions by failing to heed the demands of the international community."
China, traditionally reluctant about Security Council interference in any country's internal affairs, abstained, but did not threaten to block sanctions with its veto as a permanent Council member. Zimbabwe, one of the Council's six third-world members, also abstained. But the other five, India, Cape Verde, Venezuela, Ecuador, and Morocco, one of the embargo's sponsors, supported the move, as did Austria and Japan. Other members voting for sanctions were the other sponsors of the resolution: the United States, Britain, France, Belgium and Hungary.
As the Council voted, Serbia began an eleventh hour bid to avert sanctions. In letters to President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia asked the United States and Russia to place "all the forces involved" in the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina under their joint command.
 
Serbs Appeal for Conference
 Earlier today the Serbian leadership cabled Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to ask him to propose an international conference on the Balkans crisis instead of sanctions.
"It's bobbing and weaving," said a Western diplomat in Belgrade. "The time for proposals like this has long passed. The Serbian side has to act quickly and unilaterally to stop the brutal destruction of Sarajevo and the aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina. Words are not enough."
The new sanctions package came some 10 days after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d lost patience with the European Community's efforts to negotiate a peace settlement in the former Yugoslav federation. He bluntly accused Serbia of stirring up a civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and said the Security Council should impose sanctions on Yugoslavia. At the time he pointedly refused to rule out international military intervention to end the fighting and allow relief supplies to reach suffering people.
After the United States sat on the sidelines for months, the Secretary of State's intervention, made at a conference in Lisbon, represented a reassertion of American leadership in the Balkans crisis and finally forced the hesitant Europeans to approve a separate, less onerous sanctions package against Belgrade earlier this week.
Explaining his decision on Yugoslav assets, Mr. Bush said, "The measures I have taken today express our outrage at the actions of the Serbian and Montegrin governments and will prevent those governments from drawing on monies and properties within U.S. control."
 
Weapons Deliveries Banned
 The Security Council has already banned all deliveries of weapons and other military material to any of the constituent republics of the former Yugoslav federation.
The aim of these sanctions, the resolution says, is to force the Serbian authorities in Belgrade to cooperate with the demands the Security Council laid out earlier this month in Resolution 752, which called for an immediate cease-fire and an end to ethnic oppression in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
This means Belgrade must cease all interference in Bosnia and Herzegovina and use its influence to promote a general cease-fire, oversee the disbanding and disarming of elements of the Yugoslav National Army and irregular forces and end efforts to create an purely Serbian enclave by driving out other ethnic groups.
 
Belgrade Condemned
 In the Security Council discussion, speaker after speaker condemned the authorities in Belgrade for deliberately encouraging ethnic conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"There is no doubt the principal responsibility lies with the civil and military authorities in Belgrade," said Sir David Hannay, the British representative. "Multiple rocket launchers are not found in Serbian peasants' barns. Somebody puts them there."
But while today's resolution is directed principally at Serbia, it also expresses concern at cease-fire violations and acts of racial discrimination in Croatia and calls on all parts of the former Yugoslav federation to cooperate with the European Community's peace conference for the region.
 
France Opposes Ban on Sports
 The vote was also delayed by a last-minute attempt by France to delete the ban on sports at the personal request of President Francois Mitterrand. But France eventually dropped its demand in return for language clarifying that the Serbs are not solely responsible for the crisis in the Balkans, diplomats said.
At least 2,200 people are known to have died in Bosnia and Herzegovina since Croats and Muslim Slavs, who together make up more than 60 percent of its 4.3 million people, voted in February to secede from the Yugoslav federation.
Bosnia's Serbs opposed independence and have fought with help from Belgrade and the Yugoslav Army to carve out an enclave for itself by driving away other ethnic groups.
The United Nations has already dispatched a large peacekeeping force to monitor the fragile truce that ended ethnic fighting in Croatia and Slovenia that broke out after they declared independence. But the organization was forced to withdraw its token presence from Sarajevo earlier this month as a result of the intense fighting there.
In addition, the United Nations and other relief agencies have been hindered and harassed in their efforts to help the more than 500,000 people driven from their homes by the fighting.
And the Secretary General has said that many of the warring factions there are actively trying to deny food and medicine to some civilians to force them to move elsewhere.
Sales of medicine and food were exempted from today's trade embargo, but the Security Council committee established to monitor compliance must be notified of such shipments.

Fighting Continues in Sarajevo
 BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30 (AP) -- Bosnian Serbs battled Muslim Slavs at an army barracks today in Sarajevo.
Apparently reacting to an appeal from President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, leaders of Bosnian Serbs said later that they were ordering their forces to halt artillery fire in the republic's capital, the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug reported.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Pressure Is Growing on President To Bring Baker In for Campaign

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
Warned by friends and advisers that his re-election is imperiled by Ross Perot's unexpected strength and a perception that he is not doing anything about the country's problems, President Bush is under growing pressure to call in Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to rescue his campaign.
Mr. Bush today denied published reports that a senior aide, Robert A. Mosbacher, the titular campaign chairman, had urged him to dismiss Samuel K. Skinner as chief of staff and replace him with Mr. Baker. 
 Friends and advisers of Mr. Bush, Administration officials and Republican strategists said the President had indeed made no decision to shake up a team that he rearranged six months ago in hopes of stopping his political slide.
 
Baker Reported Reluctant
 But Mr. Bush not only failed to rebound, he is also now facing a challenge from Mr. Perot that he had never taken into account. And a friend of the President said there was an "inexorable logic" building to have Mr. Baker leave the State Department and take over the White House and re-election teams, just as he resigned as Treasury Secretary in 1988 to salvage Mr. Bush's faltering campaign to succeed President Ronald Reagan.
 
Air of Expectancy
 The friend said Mr. Bush had not approached Mr. Baker and that the Secretary, who has been assiduously polishing his reputation as a statesman, "doesn't want this." But he said State Department officials were beginning to adjust to the notion that Mr. Baker would leave, and that if he did, it was expected that Lawrence S. Eagleburger, his deputy, would be made Secretary of State, as a caretaker during the election season.
The idea of bringing Mr. Baker into the campaign has been long discussed but now seems to have moved out of the realm of gossip to take on a new air of expectancy.
Calling in Mr. Baker would pose problems for Mr. Bush. It would raise questions about his often-declared commitment to policy over politics, especially in foreign affairs, and contribute to the notion that he is paralyzed politically without Mr. Baker.
"The last thing Bush wants is to be viewed as someone who can't get elected without his pal Jim Baker; that would be a humiliation," a longtime associate of Mr. Bush said today.
Traveling in California, Mr. Bush banged his hand on the roof of his limousine and said, "No. Absolutely not," when reporters asked if Mr. Mosbacher had urged Mr. Skinner's removal, as The Washington Post had reported.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, "The President's very satisfied with the conduct of the White House and campaign staffs." Mr. Skinner denied the rumors on Friday night, and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, said today that no staff changes were imminent.
It is impossible to assess such denials fully, since the White House flatly denies any major personnel change as a matter of routine, right up to the moment it is announced.
In recent weeks, Mr. Bush, Mr. Baker and other top Administration and campaign officials have been deluged with telephone calls complaining about the performance of the White House under Mr. Skinner and urging the President to replace him, officials and Republican strategists say.
"The message is that they can't make any kind of decision at the White House; they have no policy concept and no idea how to sell anything," a Bush adviser said, speaking, as most of the others did, on the basis that he not be identified.
 
Alarm Over Perot
 These long-smoldering complaints have been fanned by a showing by Mr. Perot that is far stronger than the White House had expected, by alarm among Bush advisers that the tepid economic recovery has so far not translated into a gain in Mr. Bush's popularity, and by a growing concern that Gov. Bill Clinton, while still struggling, may be recovering from his political wounds. That has undercut the central pillars of the Bush team's strategy.
Mr. Baker and Mr. Mosbacher, who has no real authority over the campaign, discussed the situation over a round of golf recently and concluded that some sort of change was needed, officials said.
Mr. Mosbacher was also said to have told friends about a recent fund-raising dinner in Texas at which an oilman who had contributed to Mr. Bush said he would not vote for the President this year.
Mr. Baker, Mr. Mosbacher, Vice President Dan Quayle and other senior officials were angered by the White House's confused response last week to a speech by Mr. Quayle in San Francisco in which he made his attack on the "Murphy Brown" television show. The White House issued a series of contradictory reactions to Mr. Quayle's accusation that the show had sent the wrong message by having its main character give birth to an illegitimate child.
Mr. Mosbacher expressed his concerns to Mr. Bush at a meeting last week after he returned from a trip to Spain, officials said. Several Bush aides dismissed these reports, saying that Mr. Mosbacher has little influence.
"I don't think anybody's happy with our progress in the polls," one aide said. "How could you be when the President's positives aren't going up and his negatives aren't going down? But it's nervous Nellies that get unnerved this early in the game and depart from the track you're on."
Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman, said Mr. Mosbacher had said nothing to him about a staff shake-up. "Mosbacher and I have had several conversations about the need to pick up the pace and get things moving faster," Mr. Teeter said.
 
Skinner and Bad Will
 A senior Bush aide said that Mr. Skinner had been talking to his own staff about "the need to restructure the way they operate." The aide said Mr. Skinner had generated some bad will by effectively demoting four or five White House aides and that there were complaints that he "delegates too much."
Noting that such complaints are not new, and that there have been several flurries of rumors about staff changes in the Bush team, a Republican strategist said: "What's different now is the high level of disappointment with the White House. It is striking when one travels around the country just how contemptuous the operatives, the state chairmen, the Bush-Quayle people are of the current team."
The strategist added: "One thing that has changed is the complacency that Perot was going to collapse and Clinton was dead, so even if we mess up we're going to win it. People do really believe now that we can lose the election."
White House aides were alarmed last week by reports that Mr. Perot was talking to a string of Washington political consultants, including several former aides to Mr. Bush or Mr. Reagan who had been shut out of the 1992 re-election organization. "It suddenly seemed like the Bush camp was driving Republicans into Perot's arms," one official said.
As for the Democrats, George Stephanopoulos, the communications director for the Clinton campaign, suggested the Administration was overreacting to Mr. Perot's threat.
"We are going to take Perot very seriously, but it's also important not to panic," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "The White House is in an uproar. We're going to continue to show people who Bill Clinton is, and the more people see of him, the more they'll like him."

HEADLINE: CBS Discloses Plan To Begin Charging Fees to Its Affiliates

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
CBS announced a plan yesterday that would radically alter the way the television network deals with its affiliate stations, by charging the stations fees to carry certain programs.
To explain the need for the change, the network cited low profits and increased competition from cable networks, the Fox network and program syndicators. 
 CBS executives say they must change certain fundamental procedures of the broadcasting business to respond to the new competition. "We are now in a leadership position and we have to institute changes," said a senior CBS executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "This will not be the last move we make to change the way the broadcasting business is conducted."
In an interview after a meeting of the affiliates in New York, Anthony Malara, the president of affiliate relations for CBS, called the plan "the most dramatic change in the economic relationship between a network and its affiliated stations in 25 years."
The move is expected to be vigorously opposed by many stations and could lead to some stations' seeking to leave CBS for a different network, or to stations' carrying fewer CBS programs than they did in the past.
"Some station owners are very upset and think we're crazy," Mr. Malara said. He conceded that the plan carries risks but added, "Retaliation by the stations could end up killing us both."
In various markets, if stations leave CBS, viewers might have to lose certain CBS programs, or look elsewhere for them.
Neither NBC nor ABC officials could be reached for comment, but in the past, when one network has changed its compensation system, the others have followed.
Although the network will continue to pay its affiliates compensation for carrying its programming, the move sets a precedent by establishing a payment to the networks. The networks pay the compensation to establish and maintain the coast-to-coast distribution needed to broadcast commercials nationally. The compensation has varied, depending on the size of a station's television market.
But for several years, as new owners have come to control the networks and as profits have diminished, many efforts have been made to change the system. Reductions have already taken place at all three networks.
CBS is in a position of strength now and apparently felt able to take this step because of the significant comeback in its performance, especially in prime time in the last year. The network is predicting that its programs will be even more popular in the next television season.
Despite its ratings success, the CBS network lost money last year, furthering the corporate pressure to seek the reductions in compensation payments.
Two years ago, CBS cut its compensation to its 200 stations from $150 million to $121 million. CBS said that amount still left the network paying the most in compensation, although it is generally thought to have the best lineup of stations. NBC instituted a plan to base compensation more on the individual performance of a station.
CBS's chairman, Laurence A. Tisch, has been among the most adamant in seeking to change the compensation system, which he has criticized as outdated. Mr. Tisch has been known to feel that the CBS stations already have the benefit of being able to sell local commercials on network programs and should not require further inducements to carry the network schedule.
 
Stations Also Hit Hard
 But stations have been as hard hit as the networks by a slump in television advertising, and they have resisted every effort to change compensation agreements. Talks between the stations and CBS about a new compensation plan ended when the stations walked out earlier this year.
CBS argued in its official statement of the new affiliate plan that the benefits of the network-affiliate partnership flow both ways, and that the stations should be willing to give something back to the network for programming and promotion costs, and news coverage.
Starting Jan. 1, the network intends to impose what it is calling an affiliation charge. Though the network also said it was not cutting the compensation it pays to stations, the charge amounts to a virtual exchange of dollars.
Stations would still get compensation from CBS, but they would then have to pay the charge to the network at a varying rate depending on market size. For the top 100 markets, the charge would be 25 percent of the overall compensation. For the next 50 stations in size the charge would be 20 percent, and the rest of the slightly more than 200 stations would have to give back 15 percent of their compensation.
 
Incentives for Weak Shows
 Another part of the agreement calls for a realignment of the way compensation is paid. CBS said it intended to maximize the incentive for stations to carry prime-time programs as opposed to shows in other parts of the day. That proposal could make CBS's morning news program vulnerable to pre-emptions by disgruntled stations.
But CBS also said very little would be paid for hit programs, which stations would presumably be loathe to pre-empt, but more would be paid for weaker programs that are often the target of syndicators who are now willing to pay compensation themselves to stations to carry those programs.
"Common sense says that we should not pay the same amount for '60 Minutes' or 'Murphy Brown' as opposed to other programs that are not so highly rated," Mr. Malara told the affiliates.
The network also plans to pull back from the stations what it calls soft commercial inventory, commercial spots that are difficult for stations to sell in certain sports, daytime and morning programs.
The network valued that commercial time at $4 million to $5 million. It said the overall value of the new agreement to CBS was in the range of $20 million to $25 million.
But the new agreements will require CBS to draw up new affiliation contracts with every single CBS station and presumably would open each station to the possibility of signing on with a different network.

HEADLINE: Rash of Brain Defects in Newborns Disturbs Border City in Texas

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 26

 BODY:
For three years babies have been born with missing or incomplete brains and other devastating neurological defects at a startling rate in this border city, and although the cause remains a mystery, United States officials are now investigating whether industrial pollution from Mexico might be at fault.
Since January 1989 at least 42 babies have been born in Cameron County, at the southeastern tip of Texas, with various manifestations of a condition known as neural-tube defect . That is about three times as many cases as would normally be expected, said Dr. Dennis Perrotta, chief of the epidemiology division of the Texas Department of Health. 
 In Brownsville, the outbreak has primarily involved anencephaly, a condition in which a baby is born with all or part of its brain missing. The victims are generally stillborn or die within days of birth. Some fetuses, however, developed spina bifida, an often survivable deformity of the spinal cord that causes paralysis and other severe neurological problems.
Across the border from Brownsville, in Matamoros, Mexican officials have reported 42 cases of neural-tube defects over an 18-month period that began at roughly the time as the outbreak on the United States side, Dr. Perrotta said. He said data were still being gathered to determine how the new cases in Matamoros differ from the average rate there.
On the Texas side, most of the babies have been born to Hispanic mothers living in poverty near the Rio Grande. Most of the births seem to have been in the spring. But Dr. Perrotta said that these patterns were tenuous and that no common factors in the parents' lives had been discovered to explain the outbreak.
 
U.S. to Test for Pollution
 Speculation has focused on the industries that have grown rapidly along the Mexican side of the Rio Grande as a result of cheap labor and special tariff provisions in Mexican law. Last week, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said it would conduct a two-year study to assess the presence of toxic chemicals and other pollutants in the Rio Grande along the 889-mile border it forms between the United States and Mexico.
"This study is urgent," William K. Reilly, the agency's administrator, said in making the announcement. "We need it, and we need it now, to find out whether environmental pollution is causing the high incidence of birth defects in the lower Rio Grande Valley and whether the health of residents along the border is at risk."
Environmental groups have sought such a study for several years. They say the industrial plants on the Mexican side of the river, many of them owned by United States companies, take advantage of lax enforcement of Mexican laws by releasing toxic chemicals into the river and the air.
The charges have taken on an added urgency since the Bush Administration began negotiating a free trade agreement with Mexico in the last year. Even if no link is established between the pollution and the birth defects, an official finding that toxic industrial wastes are entering the Rio Grande from Mexico could complicate the delicate politics underscoring negotiations on the free trade agreement.
Among many of Brownsville's 107,000 residents, those issues seem abstract compared with the very immediate fear that something unseen is attacking the unborn.
Teresa Salazar and her sister-in-law, who lives next door in a neighborhood of wood-frame shacks near the Rio Grande, were pregnant at the same time last year.
In March, Mrs. Salazar, who is 29 years old, delivered a stillborn child with a severe neural-tube defect; her sister-in-law later gave birth to a healthy child. Mrs. Salazar and her neighbors are troubled by the uncertainty about what caused the defects.
"The truth is, yes, there's a lot of worry," she said, "I have friends who want to get pregnant, yet they're afraid the same thing might happen to them."
Like other Mexican border cities, Matamoros, with a population of more than 400,000, has experienced rapid industrial development in recent years. Much of it consists of maquiladoras (pronounced ma-kee-la-DO-ras), plants built by United States companies to take advantage of special provisions of Mexican law allowing them to import equipment and raw materials from the United States and export their products back to the States virtually free of duties.
 
'Something Environmental'
 In Brownsville, a loosely knit group of professionals and local leaders has been trying to find out what is causing the brain defects.
All that is known about anencephaly is that it develops soon after conception, when the neural tube, an embryonic structure that normally develops into the brain and spinal cord, fails to close.
"There's no clear evidence to prove it, but until a better explanation comes up, it seems to me we're dealing with something environmental," said Dr. Timothy P. Thurber, a pediatrician who is part of the group. "Especially because the majority of the women live in a part of town that is close to the river and where the prevailing winds carry the vapors from the plants on the other side."
Last year the National Toxic Campaign, an environmental group based in Boston, said its monitoring had revealed toxic discharges far in excess of American standards coming from maquiladoras in Matamoros and elsewhere along the border.
 
No Scientific Consensus
 About 4,000 babies a year are born in the United States with neural-tube defects, and in 90 to 95 percent of the cases no clear cause can be pinpointed, said Dr. Joe Leigh Simpson, chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Tennessee at Memphis.
"Industrial pollutants have been touted as a cause in some studies, but it is fair to say that there is no consensus in the scientific community on this," said Dr. Simpson, who has conducted extensive research on neural-tube defects, although he has not taken part in the Brownsville investigations. The detective work is further complicated because the genetic makeup of individual women, or groups of women, may make them more susceptible than others to environmental, nutritional or other potential causes of the defects, the experts say.
"To come in and exonerate any one factor or to conclude that the answer lies in the fact that women live within a mile of a particular plant, is to offer a simplistic answer to an extremely complicated problem," Dr. Simpson said.
In Brownsville, Dr. Perrotta said his office had calculated that neural-tube defects are occurring in the Brownsville area at a rate of 15 for every 10,000 births, compared with the national average of 4 to 5 for 10,000 births.
But he said, "For all the speculation going around, our studies have not found a smoking gun."

HEADLINE: Bush Says He Seeks Balance on the Environment

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRESNO, Calif., May 30

 BODY:
President Bush today defended his rejection of a treaty to protect biological species that will have broad support at the Earth Summit opening next week in Rio de Janeiro, saying he is "fighting for balance" between environmental needs and the health of the American economy.
"We cannot accept standards that are not based on the soundest of science," Mr. Bush said. "And we cannot shut down the lives of thousands of Americans by going to extremes" on environmental policy. 
 He spoke a day after the Administration announced that it would not sign a global convention on preserving biological diversity, to be offered at the Earth Summit because of concern that it would require the United States to strengthen laws protecting endangered species.
The Administration has recently increased efforts to limit the Endangered Species Act, one of the oldest American environmental laws.
In recent years, the timber industry and others have campaigned against the law, arguing that it does not fairly balance environmental and economic interests.
The State Department issued a written defense today of the decision not to sign the biodiversity treaty.
It argued that the United States' record in preserving threatened plants and animals is "unparalleled" and that the treaty, which was negotiated with the approval of 98 nations last week, violates earlier agreements on the means by which developed nations would help finance environmental programs in poorer countries.
"The United States is prepared to help others protect our world's biological resources," the statement said, "but the funding must be workable."
The State Department said the proposed treaty would impinge on world patent and copyright agreements and would unfairly penalize the developing biotechnology industry.
The White House said on Friday that Mr. Bush would attend the Earth Summit in mid-June, a day or two after a stop in Panama on June 11.
Mr. Bush responded to questions here in Fresno, in the San Joaquin Valley of California, one of the nation's most productive agricultural areas. He said he had earlier withheld a decision on whether to attend the Earth Summit because he "also wanted sound economic policy" to be written into its treaties.
The President said he would attend after negotiators agreed to strike language in a second treaty, aimed at curbing global warming, that would have set goals and timetables for nations to cut their emissions of certain industrial pollutants.
Mr. Bush said today that the United Nations-sponsored conference "started off getting requirements that nobody could keep" because they were unreasonably stringent. But now, he said, "we've got something really sound" to which he could pledge adherence.
Mr. Bush has come under sharp criticism from some environmental leaders in this country and abroad for his positions. Critics say the United States' refusal to support stronger controls on pollution and other environmental hazards has undercut a consensus among most of the world's other nations to slow or reverse damage to the environment.
Mr. Bush disagreed today. "My general philosophy is that we've got a good, sound environmental practice," he said. "I think we've got something to be really proud of and to take to Rio."
The President also announced a program that would encourage property owners to restore wetlands lost to development.
The Administration has proposed spending $160.9 million in Agriculture Department funds next year on the program, which would purchase up to a million acres in land easements from property owners who agree to convert unused acreage to the original wetlands state.
The pilot program would cover nine states and restore about 50,000 acres of wetlands.
The White House said that the United States has lost about half its 221 million acres of wetlands since colonists began arriving in the 17th century.
