HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Perot Petition Embraced As Manifesto of Change

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., May 29

 BODY:
Ross Perot has struck political gold here in the San Fernando Valley, and the rush is on. By the thousands, people are signing petitions to put him on the November Presidential ballot, not merely affixing their names but appending a "Yes!" A rap on the table. An "All right!" A grin that says they are up to mischief and are proud of it.
"This makes me feel good; this makes me feel very good," Clayton Zonshine, a 40-year-old Democrat who voted for Michael S. Dukakis four years ago, said as he signed a Perot petition. "Bush, Clinton are politicians. They talk out of both sides of their mouths. Mr. Perot gets things done." 
 With the primary less than a week away in this, the most populous state, these days ought to belong to the presumed Democratic and Republican standard-bearers, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and President Bush. But here, as in much of the country, they belong to Mr. Perot.
 
Declaration for Independent
 Two, 10, 20 at a time, people are lining up at shopping malls and on street corners to sign petitions for a candidate who is not on the ballot Tuesday and for whom write-in votes will not be counted. This is John Hancock 1992, the signature as protest and empowerment, writ large so as to be not just a name but a shout.
"I hope Bush and Clinton read this," Gypsi Luck-Morford, a 30-year-old psychology student at California State University at Northridge, said as she signed. "Really, I do. I want them to see my name. I hate politicians. It's all lip-service and no action. I want a doer. I don't know anything about Perot except that he's not a politician. That's enough for me."
In five days of interviews and chats with about 100 voters in the San Fernando Valley north of downtown Los Angeles, the support for Mr. Perot seemed almost a fervor. His backing appeared to draw from Democrats and Republicans, young and old, men and women.
But Mr. Perot was also something of a blank screen onto which people projected what they hoped to find in a President. In the same line of petition signers, a 67-year-old Republican praised Mr. Perot as a friend to business while a 22-year-old Democrat said he would be good "for the karma of the country."
 
Old Fashioned Populism
 On television, Mr. Clinton's image is pervasive, thanks to campaign commercials, but on the streets there's no sign of his candidacy or Mr. Bush's, as if the energy has been sapped. The Perot campaign, on the other hand, is everywhere to be seen, an old-fashioned political revival of buttons and T-shirts, rallies and posters, brass bands and bumper stickers.
Mr. Perot is paying the rent for some of the larger store fronts, but the impression is of a campaign by the people. It is led by a volunteer corps of students, housewives, retired businessmen and the unemployed, most of whom said they had never been politically active. Most of the costs are covered by donations and the sale of campaign items.
It all has a spark of fun to it, of being part of a movement that is turning the political establishment on its ear. And that includes the news media, which many of Mr. Perot's supporters seem to feel have put themselves above the people, dictating for whom citizens will and will not vote.
"The press doesn't like him," 62-year-old Harry Rosen said with devilish delight. "He screwed up their plans. He interrupts them. He's not interested in the bull from Sam Donaldson."
 
To Each, His Own Perot
 In some ways, Mr. Perot is getting the treatment voters gave a decade ago to Ronald Reagan, a man who caught their spirit and in whom they were willing to overlook flaws. Most people acknowledge that they know little about him, saying they are drawn to his business accomplishments, to his unvarnished folksy ways and to a give-'em-Hell style that many petition signers compared to Harry S. Truman's. People are doing very nicely concocting their own vision of Mr. Perot, thank you, and they don't want anyone tinkering with it.
"George Bush is a good ol' boy from Texas who made a lot of money in oil and has lost touch," said 43-year-old Marilyn Johnston.
Asked if that did not apply to Mr. Perot, too, she became indignant. "No, not at all," she said. After a few seconds of thought, she added, "I suppose Mr. Perot may be a good ol' boy, but he went out and made his own money, started from nothing. God bless him. Bush was born into money."
 
Amazed He Wants the Job
 One of the paradoxes of the Perot campaign is that in an age when many people are fed up with the extravagances and greed that marked the Reagan years, they nonetheless embrace the billionaire from Texas, finding it almost noble that a man who is what they aspire to be would deign to consider the Presidency. The other candidates are referred to as "Bush" and "Clinton," but more often than not, the billionaire is called "Mr. Perot".
"Mr. Perot's his own man," said 64-year-old Dolores Flanigan. "He doesn't owe special interests anything. You wonder why a man of his accomplishment would want the job."
In a throwback to the 1920's, many seem to feel that the business of the country is exactly that: business, perhaps best left to someone with that background, even during a crisis like the Los Angeles riots.
"I don't know what Ross Perot is going to do about the inner cities," said Mr. Rosen. "But he's a smart man. He'll figure it out. If you can make billions of dollars, you must be doing something right, yes?"
Said Richard Irby, a 22-year-old student at Los Angeles Pierce College in Woodland Hills: "Maybe what we need is a businessman. Let's give him the shot. He can't do any worse than the politicians have.
Mr. Irby added: "Perot said he would have come right away when the riots started. He sounded sincere. Bush just came to get his picture taken."
Asked about Mr. Clinton, he said, "I don't have any sense of him. He's like mush."
 
Competence and Strength
 Throughout the interviews with Mr. Perot's supporters, Mr. Bush was often described as inept, while Mr. Clinton was described as spineless. The questions of character that dogged Mr. Clinton in earlier state primaries, like whether he had engaged in an extramarital affair, are almost never being raised here.
"Perot took on General Motors; he took on the high-school football interests in Texas," said Stephanie Claxton, a 32-year-old Republican who said she voted for Mr. Dukakis four years ago. "Every time I see Bush I think less of him. Clinton means well, but what's he stand for? He's always looking over his shoulder at who he might offend."
To be sure, not everyone here is on the Perot bandwagon. A few said they saw fascist overtones in the nation's longing for a strong leader, like Mr. Perot, who would sweep aside critics and tell the nation what to do.
"I'm frightened by him, by his power," said Arlette Coblenz. "It's dictatorship."
 
Some Signers Skeptical
 Others said that while they were intrigued by Mr. Perot, they were awaiting specific proposals. "When he comes up with a platform, we'll see,' said 30-year-old Robin Johnson.
Like many others, Mrs. Johnson was concerned that Mr. Perot would corrupt himself, that he would turn into the very kind of politician he denounces. "I'm concerned it's taking him so long to come up with a platform," she said. "It makes me think he's listening to handlers who are trying to shape him."
It is not clear how many people who sign the petitions will remain loyal through the election. A big part of the pitch by petition gatherers is that a signature is not a commitment to vote for Mr. Perot in November.
That argument won over Mrs. Johnson, and she signed at the Fallbrook Mall, where the Perot kiosk was doing more business than the stores. The volunteers used up their initial allocation of 500 petition forms on the day the kiosk opened, a week ago. Trying to borrow more from the Perot volunteers across the street proved futile; they, too, had gone through their 500 the same day.
With 134,781 signatures needed statewide by the Aug. 7 deadline, Perot organizers say they have already collected 530,000. And each day the lines continue to form here for Ross Perot.

HEADLINE: From Budget Doomsday to Surplus and Smiles

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Last year, it was Doomsday and deadlines. This year, it was surplus and surprise.
New York City officials wrapped up an agreement on a new city budget yesterday in record time, and they attributed their swift success to an essential fact: everyone involved understood that the government had a little extra money to spend, but not too much. 
 The slight upturn in the city's fiscal fortunes, after three years of severe recession and uniformly grim budget developments, made it possible for Mayor David N. Dinkins and the leaders of the City Council to dispense a few goodies to important constituencies, from the Board of Education to the libraries and parks.
But the shared sense that the city was still reeling from the economic decline of the last three years apparently restrained some of the budget brinksmanship that often prevails when the city's budget is either very lean, as it was in recent years, or very fat, as it was during the boom of the 1980's.
To anyone familiar with the bruising and prolonged battles that ordinarily accompany the passage of the city's budget every June, the alacrity with which the Mayor and Council leaders came together over the last few days was startling. The city's top elected officials usually camp out in City Hall for days in the brutal heat of late June, maneuvering and threatening until, in sheer exhaustion late at night, they finally compromise just hours before the new fiscal year begins on July 1.
 
A Happy Announcement
 Yesterday, a full month before the deadline, the Mayor and Council leaders assembled in the late afternoon to announce that they had reached a budget accord. It was the earliest date in memory that an agreement had been reached, and it was apparently achieved with such relative good humor that Norman Steisel, the crusty first deputy mayor, was seen smiling and joking and smoking a cigar in the corridors of City Hall during the last two days.
"Underlying it all is the fact that the fiscal situation has eased a little bit, but not a lot," said Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, a veteran of nearly 20 years of budget politics. "There is some money there to do a little bit, but everybody knows that it is circumscribed. There was a little space here for each faction to address some of its greatest concerns."
Many other factors also contributed to the quick resolution. There were no overriding differences separating the Mayor and the Council. Last year, for example, they locked horns over Mr. Dinkins's proposal to increase the property tax to help the city through its extreme fiscal duress; they did not reach a compromise over the tax increase and the overall budget until late in the evening of the final day of June.
The Mayor and Council also did not find themselves stuck waiting for action by the State Legislature, as they often have. This year, for the first time in nearly a decade, the Legislature approved its own budget on time, by the end of March, putting some pressure on city officials to act decisively, as well.
"Once we knew exactly what we were getting from the state, it made our work that much easier," said Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker. "Even though we would like to get more, at least we knew what we were getting."
City officials had also been seeking approval from the Legislature of a proposed package of $115 million in new taxes, including an increase in the commuter tax. But on Tuesday, bowing to the obvious reluctance of the lawmakers to approve the plan, Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone withdrew the proposal. The administration said that higher-than-anticipated revenues in two taxes -- the banking and general corporation taxes -- and constrained spending had made it possible to balance the spending plan without the proposed new taxes. That decision removed another potential obstacle to a settlement.
 
Surplus Will Ease Borrowing
 Politics of course also played a significant role. After being criticized extensively during his first two years in office for his stewardship of the budget, Mr. Dinkins earned broad praise in the last month for the cautious revenue estimates and spending restraint that had enabled the administration to amass a surplus in the current year that is now estimated at $515 million. Much of that money will be used in the next year to enable the city to avoid borrowing money for expenditures -- a plan that had raised many eyebrows in the financial world and among fiscal monitors.
Weeks of protracted and abrasive negotiations with the Council might have removed some of the luster from the Mayor's recent budgetary achievements.
Mr. Vallone also had political motives for coming to an agreement quickly. The Council, now expanded to 51 members, many of them brand new, could easily have fallen into bickering had the budget talks dragged on.
The surplus does not signify that the city's economy is now robust and that the free-spending of the 1980's can return. But countless interest groups, each with legitimate but competing needs, have viewed the slightly brighter fiscal horizon as an occasion for restoring some of the Draconian service cuts of recent years. Leaders of the city's labor unions, the Board of Education, social service agencies and many others were in the corridors of City Hall the last two days, seeking the attention of Council members to press their cause.
Had the budget negotiations languished for weeks, Mr. Vallone might have been under far more pressure to increase city spending further, several Council members and staff members said. Prolonged negotiations also would have made it more difficult for the Speaker to keep restive members from pursuing their own agendas, they said.
The Speaker and his allies, who maintain a tight control over the Council, clearly made most of the major decisions themselves. At a public meeting on Friday afternoon, some members complained to Mr. Vallone that they did not know the details of the budget negotiations, and some even said they were unaware of the leadership's position on broad matters, such as the Council's position on adding money for recycling.
In many ways, it was Mr. Vallone who pushed hardest to complete the budget talks quickly. He set the pace by suggesting publicly on Thursday that both sides try to resolve their differences by last night, when the Mayor was to leave for a one-week trade mission to Europe. The Speaker also threatened that, if an accord could not be reached, the Council would pass a budget on its own this week.
"This is the first year literally that everything is on time," Mr. Vallone told his colleagues, with obvious pride, on Friday night.
Mr. Steisel said he thought the talks had been amicable "on the whole" because both the Council leaders and the Mayor "had an interest to get it done quickly."
"Once you get to the point where everybody says, 'There are some important things we both want to do and there are limited resources with which to do it,' why schlep this out over a period of weeks?" Mr. Steisel said.

Herbert Berman, finance committee chairman, left, and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, center, listened. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Financing;
Despite Many Distractions, Cash Flows Steadily Into Party Coffers

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 29

 BODY:
The economy is a little sluggish, Ross Perot is a large distraction and the voting here counts for little in this year's Presidential primary season, yet the flow of political money remains strong in New Jersey.
This is one of the nation's wealthiest states, and the interest in politics here is keen. So in the Presidential primary campaigns New Jersey has become a net exporter of cash, and in the Congressional contests, the candidates have been able to find plenty of money. 
 "I hope Gov. Pete Wilson enjoys spending our money," William Palatucci, executive director of the Bush campaign in New Jersey, said of California's Governor, who is leading the Bush campaign there. He said about $800,000 would be raised for the Republican President's campaign, but only about $100,000 would be spent locally, since Mr. Bush had already clinched the nomination.
On the Democratic side, Clay Constantinou, state finance chairman for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, said the New Jersey effort would raise about $1 million, the third or fourth highest total of any state. The ability of New Jersey Democrats to attract about $275,000 early this year helped Mr. Clinton stay in the race when his fortunes were rising and falling.
 
Help in New Hampshire
 "They were ready to lower the coffin in New Hampshire," he said. But he said that as a result of the money from New Jersey "the campaign was able to use direct mail and to send 20,000 videos to households in the state to keep his message alive."
With Governor Clinton closing in on the Democratic nomination, his national campaign has earmarked only about $147,000 for his New Jersey effort out of the $1 million raised here, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.
Both Mr. Palatucci and Mr. Constantinou said the effect of Mr. Perot's petition gathering on their campaigns has been more psychological than financial, so far. The big economic drain, they said, has been the sluggish real estate market. "A lot of traditional contributors to both parties engaged in development: contractors, lawyers, accountants, engineers and environmental consultants," said Mr. Palatucci. And they "haven't been contributing."
 
More Candidates Than Usual
 New Jersey lost 1 of its 14 Congressional seats because of population shifts found in the 1990 census. The resulting reapportionment and decisions by three incumbents to retire have inspired fields of candidates that are larger than usual in a few districts. With the larger fields has come a need for more campaign contributions.
But there is no shortage of money. Reports to the Federal Election Commission show that a number of candidates had raised $200,000 with a month to go before the primary. Prof. Stephen A. Salmore, a political science expert at Rutgers University, said the lack of a Senate race makes fund raising for House seats easier.
Redistricting has affected the campaign of Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Long Branch Democrat who has represented the Third District along New Jersey's north shore for two terms. But this year he is running for the party's nomination in the new Sixth District, which includes a large part of Middlesex County from the old Sixth District.
Fund-raising became a last-minute issue between Mr. Pallone and Bob Smith, a State Assemblyman from Piscataway who is considered to be Mr. Pallone's chief rival for the Democratic nomination. Mr. Pallone, whose campaign contribution list includes gifts from a large number of political action committees of labor unions, cried foul when Mr. Smith transferred about $120,000 from his state legislative fund-raising committee to his Federal campaign account.
Mr. Pallone said that more than $67,000 of the transfer was illegal since much of it had already been committed in his state races, or included individual gifts of more than $1,000. Mr. Smith said the transfers were legitimate and accused Mr. Pallone of trying a last-minute campaign smear.

HEADLINE: Compromise on Urban Aid Plan Is Reported Near

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
A month after the Los Angeles riots, the Bush Administration is cautiously moving toward granting more emergency aid to the cities than it had planned, Republicans in Congress say.
Although disputes over philosophy and money continue to doom any but the most modest initiatives in urban policy, Congressional and White House negotiators have managed to bridge their differences on the outlines of a package worth up to $2 billion. 
 Those close to the negotiations say the package would include emergency aid to Los Angeles and a sprinkling of money for summer jobs, Head Start and other educational initiatives, and law-enforcement programs for more than 70 other cities, including New York.
"Bush accepts it," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah and the leading conservative proponent of increased aid. "There's been a battle in the Administration, but enough officials accept it now. I'd like to do more, but it's going to be difficult in this budget year to do more."
 
Two Versions of Bill
 Publicly, the White House still supports a bill passed by the House that would provide $822 million in emergency grants and loans to Los Angeles and to Chicago, to repair damage from a downtown flood in April. It says the Senate version, which adds $1.5 billion in mostly summer job money and law-enforcement aid for the nation's largest cities, is too expensive.
But senior Republicans said White House negotiators were likely to agree this week to most of the Senate version. The Administration wants to drop a provision that would exempt local governments from having to contribute matching funds for Federal highway construction. It also wants the price tag on some items reduced, and President Bush insists on retaining broad discretion on allocating the money.
The White House and Congressional negotiators will resume talks on Monday in a session that both parties say is a test of whether they can iron out details without adding provisions unacceptable to either side. Senior Republicans close to the negotiations say splits in the Cabinet over how far to compromise with Democrats may still sabotage an agreement.
Those close to the negotiations say Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has warned against falling into a trap in which the President would agree to a package only to have the Democrats, at the final hour, add spending or tax provisions that would force Mr. Bush into a politically embarrassing veto. At the same time, they say, Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has wavered in his enthusiasm for the negotiations because Democrats refuse to accept Administration proposals on education.
A White House official who deals with urban issues said that such resistance had an impact on Mr. Bush but that "the President wants to get things done."
"There's a lot of room for agreement," the official said. "The quicker we move the better."
Congressional leaders say they are prepared to spread some of the aid to rural areas to make the compromise more palatable to House Republicans who have charged that the aid is nothing more than a reward to urban rioters.
New York City stands to gain up to $50 million in aid, a small contribution to the city's total $30 billion budget.
 
The Democrats' Strategy
 Congressional Democratic leaders said they were leaning toward accepting the compromise and then defining their differences with the Republicans by proposing an additional $9 billion package of education, family services and public works programs that they do not expect Mr. Bush to support. Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, called this a "two-track strategy" and said he understood that Gov. Bill Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, supported it.
"Much larger efforts have to be made than I think the Administration will be likely to commit to," Mr. Foley said. But he added that Congress and the White House were likely to agree on an emergency aid package "to bring some immediate help not only to urban areas around the country but to Americans who are falling out of the cycle of education and employment."
Congressional Democrats and the Administration would both gain something in the compromise. Democrats like the $675 million in the Senate version devoted to summer jobs, a provision that a White House official said the Administration could accept if "the people who get the jobs leave with skills to take them forward."
The primary selling point for the Administration is $250 million for Mr. Bush's proposed "weed and seed" program, although the White House official said the President would like to see twice that amount. Under the program, part of a six-point urban plan that Mr. Bush dusted off after the riots, specially trained police detectives and SWAT teams would rid neighborhoods of gangs and drug dealers to provide security as new educational and other social programs are instituted.
Administration officials and Democratic leaders say that there is also hope they can agree on the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's plan, urban enterprise zones, but that it is not part of the emergency bill.
 
Urban Enterprise Zones
 The Administration argues that eliminating capital gains taxes on businesses willing to set up in designated poor inner city areas will flood those zones with new capital and an enhanced entrepreneurial spirit. More and more Democrats agree, but the proposal must go through the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. In both, the plan is likely to be linked to tax measures the White House will find unacceptable.
Democratic Congressional leaders are refusing to consider other components of Mr. Bush's program, especially the granting of subsidies to parents who wish to send their children to private schools.
And they express major doubts about a component that would help public-housing tenants buy their homes from the Government. Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, estimated that it would cost the Government $150,000 to $175,000 to rehabilitate some housing units before they could be sold, at a time when the waiting lists for people wanting to enter public housing are growing.
Similarly, Republicans and Democrats take divergent positions on changes in the welfare system, although almost all officials say some change is needed.

HEADLINE: Charting the Delaware's Future Course

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARRYVILLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Bill Hupalo loves the upper Delaware River for its bountiful shad fishing. And he fully supports a far-reaching plan to preserve the high quality of the water in the river's northernmost 121 miles, even if the plan curbs development along the rural southern fringes of the Catskills.
"If they could protect this river, it's worth every cent to keep buildings and sewers out, because you can never bring a river back," said Mr. Hupalo, who lives in Swan Lake, 20 miles from here. "You've got to give up something to preserve something." 
The situation is different for Don Rupp, who lives just upstream of Rose Eddy, which is Mr. Hupalo's favorite shad-fishing spot. He grumbles in his riverfront home about how the plan would mean a loss of local control, erosion of homeowners' rights and more heavy-handedness by the National Park Service, which helps regulate the river.
"They want jurisdiction over the total waterway," he said of the park service. "The river has never deteriorated before. We've protected it for 100 years. What needs to be protected now?"
The answer, the Delaware River Basin Commission says, is the river itself, from the Delaware Water Gap north to Hancock, and the $60 million a year in recreational spending that it helps generate.
The commission, whose members represent Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and the Federal Interior Department, worked with the park agency to draft a proposal calling for "no measurable change" in the upper Delaware water quality, which the commission says is among the purest of any major urban river in the Northeast.
Under the Federal Clean Water Act, purity levels are allowed to deteriorate to designated "safe" levels for fishing and swimming. The proposed rules would prohibit any major slippage, but would permit some fluctuations from the current 14 benchmarks of a river's health. The commission says those ranges allow enough latitude for continued development of the river.
Millions of people live within a two-hour drive of the upper Delaware, which Congress placed under the protection of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers Act in the late 1970's. The law spares free-flowing rivers of scenic and recreational value from overdevelopment and new dams.
 
Park Land in Jersey
 In the 80's the population in the three New York counties bordering the upper Delaware -- Delaware, Orange and Sullivan -- increased, from 373,000 to 424,000. The bordering counties in Pennsylvania -- Pike, Monroe and Wayne -- grew, from 122,917 to 163,819. In Sussex County, N.J., much of the land along the river is already Federal and state park land largely off limits to developers.
The new plan calls for tougher controls on sewage and effluents flowing into the river and its 70 tributaries and new controls on storm-water runoff, which is rich in nutrients like phosphorus and nitrogen that spur plant growth, algae and, eventually, stagnation in the water.
The plan discourages the traditional discharges of treated sewage into the river and its tributaries and calls for disposing the material on land by spraying the waste in woods and fields.
New or expanded sewage plants would be banned, unless alternative land disposal was found to be technically and economically unfeasible. New or expanded plants would be required to institute higher treatment levels. The allowable levels of the fecal coliform bacteria in sewage would be cut, from 200 to 50 a milliliter of water. Nitrogen and phosphorus would have to be removed for the first time.
The plan would also require builders to tell the commission how they would keep their runoffs, which officials believe account for half the pollution in the river, from adding to the current runoff.
Environmentalists are ecstatic about the plan, which was proposed in February and is months from enactment. Kevin Coyle, president of American Rivers, a conservation group in Washington, said perhaps two-thirds of the river miles in the country had waters purer than the standards of the Clean Water Act. "But there's no well-established program to keep clean pristine waters that way," Mr. Coyle said. "For a river this size, in so highly developed an area, this is a real first."
A spokeswoman for the Watershed Association of the Delaware River, Cynthia Poten, said the commission was the first agency in the country to propose that existing water quality be the standard to set limits on discharges. "It's a major innovation," she said.
Developers did not voice open hostility to the proposal at hearings this month. "The river is a vital part of our economy, and any source of pollution has to be controlled," said Edward Nikles, a developer in Pike County and a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Builders Association. "Developers will have to pay some more, but I think that's well worth the price if it will protect the water."
A real-estate agent in Pike, Davis Chant, said: "We're all for the river. But we just don't want things so overdone that it eliminates any future development."
Down river from Mr. Hupalo's fishing spot, officials in Dingman Township, Pa., are worrying about the higher costs for tighter sewage and pollution controls. The officials contend that weekend or vacation users would enjoy a clean river and that local residents and developers would end up paying the bill for the tougher regulations and continued purity.

HEADLINE: Chronicling the Spread of AIDS Throughout Brooklyn

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
The man flipped on his tape recorder and turned to the woman sitting cross-legged on a couch. "O.K.," he began, scanning a long list of questions, "why don't you tell me a little bit about how you found out you're H.I.V.-positive."
For the next two hours, the woman spoke of her life before and after she learned she had the virus that causes AIDS. She told of a 17-year relationship with a man she thinks was infected by another lover before passing the virus to her. She talked of days punctuated by visits to a doctor, an AIDS counselor and an herbalist who sells "healing" teas. Then there were the hours spent trying to start an AIDS newsletter for Crown Heights, her Brooklyn neighborhood. 
 "The level of ignorance in the community is abysmal," said the woman, a 42-year-old former administrative assistant who requested anonymity, saying she had not told neighbors she has AIDS. "Most of the information is still being addressed to people with alternative lifestyles -- gay people, people who use intravenous drugs, people who are prostitutes. What about the rest of the people?"
Now, the Brooklyn Historical Society is collecting this woman's chronicle, along with scores of other oral histories, photographs, medical records, journals, T-shirts and telephone bills in an ususual effort to grapple with her complaint. The show is scheduled to open early next year at the Historical Society in Brooklyn Heights.
The project, turning the techniques of oral history to the AIDS epidemic in Brooklyn, is thought to be the first attempt by a museum or historical society to explore the material culture of AIDS in exhibition form.
 
Borough's AIDS Profile
 By focusing narrowly on Brooklyn -- home to 2.3 million people and some 90 ethnic groups -- the exhibit will also strive to give visitors an in-depth look at the growing number of ways AIDS is affecting the social, political and economic fabric of urban America.
Though second to Manhattan in total number of cases, Brooklyn's AIDS profile shows how the disease has moved from gay men, prostitutes and intravenous drug users to an increasing number of women and children.
"Every neighborhood, from Brooklyn Heights to Bedford-Stuyvesant to Bensonhurst has been hit by the epidemic," said Ellen Snyder-Grenier, the chief curator of the historical society. "Part of the point is that its not just someone else's problem. It's everyone's problem."
Brooklyn, with the largest population of the city's five boroughs, has more AIDS-infected women than any other borough or city in the state, with 1,811, according to a recent study by the New York City AIDS Surveillance Unit. About two-thirds of those women believe they contracted the disease through intravenous drug use. A growing number of others, however, believe they were infected by a boyfriend or husband.
Brooklyn also has the highest number of infected teen-agers and is third behind Manhattan and the Bronx in the number of children with the virus, according to the study.
 
Mark on Entire Communities
 Like epidemics of years gone by, such as polio and yellow fever, AIDS is leaving its mark not just on individual lives, but entire communities. Documenting that impact is the mission of this exhibit. It is also the latest effort in recent years by the Brooklyn Historical Society and its executive director, David M. Kahn, to blow dust from its tradition-bound, research-oriented doorstep with innovative exhibitions that explore the changing culture of the borough.
"My sense is that they are doing something that nobody else is doing," Gary Kulik, the assistant director for academic programs at the National Museum of American History in Washington, said of the AIDS project.
The exhibition, which is being researched and produced by the guest curator and Brooklyn-based filmmaker, Robert Rosenberg, should be an eclectic display.
From the woman in Crown Heights, Mr. Rosenberg has collected empty bottles from the herbalist, a pamphlet from a workshop for people with AIDS and two hours of her interview to be edited and played through special telephones.
Her story, one of several already collected by Mr. Rosenberg, is one of broken stereotypes. A graduate of Bronx High School of Science, she earned an associates degree in administration and was working at a local taxi company when she met the man who would become her longtime boyfriend.
"I had been in what I thought was a monogomous relationship for 17 years," she told Mr. Rosenberg.
 
Moved Back Home for Care
 In 1987, however, the two broke up, and in despair, she moved to California to work. Four years later, she said, she contracted pneumonia and her lungs collapsed. Her doctor diagnosed her as H.I.V.-positive. Horrified, she was told that her ex-boyfriend had been diagnosed months before with the virus.
Ill and unable to work, she came back to Brooklyn almost two years ago so her family could take care of her. Though she feels fine most days, she now has full-fledged AIDS. Dark circles cut under her eyes. Once a vigorous woman, she now collects Medicaid and Social Security checks. Once a great fan of street corner shish kebob, she now must carefully prepare her own food.
As for subways and buses: "I don't ride public transporation because there's a TB epidemic and I have no defenses against it," she said. "I walk or take a taxi."
Another contributor to the exhibit is Ivan Weinstein, a 30-year-old Flatbush resident, who has donated several AIDS-related books, T-shirts and fliers from AIDS-awareness events and a copy of a lawsuit that charges a Brooklyn hospital with discriminatory treatment.
"I can tell you, rotten treatment still exists," Mr. Weinstein said during a recent interview with Mr. Rosenberg, referring to his treatment in Brooklyn.
 
Trying to Increase Awareness
 Like many other gay Brooklyn residents who suffer from AIDS, Mr. Weinstein said he prefers the hospitals, clinics and doctors in Manhattan, where the greatest concentration of the city's AIDS-related care-givers is located.
Since he was diagnosed as H.I.V.-positive, Mr. Weinstein, who now has full-fledged AIDS, has joined a local acting group, the AIDS Theater Project, which performs for schools and community organizations to help educate others about the disease.
The information packets and pictures from the shows are being submitted to the Historical Society in hopes, he said, that they will increase awareness among his neighbors and larger political circles as well.
"I think if the government or anyone else woke up 10 years ago, then I think they would have had a headstart on this," he said. "At least they could have done much more than what's been done."

Ivan Weinstein, a Flatbush resident with AIDS, talked to Robert Rosenberg, a Brooklyn-based filmmaker. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: City of Pain and Rapture: Reflections in an Urban Eye

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES; The writer of this article, who wrote the About New York column from 1976 to 1979, has returned to New York after spending 13 years in Times bureaus in Washington, London and Moscow.

 BODY:
"I was explaining to you about the rapture," the tall, Bible-toting black man suddenly announced, standing solemn as Socrates within the Lexington Avenue local as he moved through another day of subway proselytizing. "What is the rapture?" the handsome, thin-faced man asked rhetorically of riders clinging fervidly to their various inattentions. The doors slid shut and he rode on out of the station with his answer lost in the steely noise of the city.
The passing reminder that there might be rapture for someone in the toughness of New York, and that a man felt compelled to move through the city's innards to tell about this, was weird welcome enough for a reporter returning home to the city after 13 years. On renewed sight, the city seems as good and sad and true as ever, when viewed in all its shards, and the search for rapture is understandable.
 
Ruthless Regeneration
 The city remains regenerative in a certain ruthless way, as out in the marshes beyond the runways of Kennedy International Airport, where the Norway rat breeds better than the snowy owl in the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge. There, Don Riepe, city born and bred in the Ozone Park shadows of Aqueduct Race Track, has chosen a strange life in the city, reigning as chief ranger for the wildlife refuge. 
 In this job, he attends to such minor poetic justices as helping his fellow ranger, Bob Cook, cart garter snakes and green snakes back from suburban development tracts to the 9,000-acre marshland refuge in Queens, where such snakes were last seen hieing from vacant lots when the postwar building boom finished off the borough's last green swatches four decades ago.
In the magnificent National Park Service refuge, where a lethally beaked greater yellowlegs can poise still and graceful as the World Trade Center on the western horizon, Mr. Riepe watches for warblers, egrets and ospreys. Then again, he occasionally spies a floater, a human corpse dispatched by killers in the underworld to bob amid the bay reeds.
"At least 8 in the past 12 years," Mr. Riepe says as if they were a special New York fauna, corpus urbanus, to be tallied along with the even rarer sooty tern and the rufus-necked stint. He speaks with a flat Queens accent that sounds refreshing from someone in a traditional ranger's uniform who wants no part of working the Rockies or any other great outdoors beyond the city's wildlife preserve out where the A train ends.
"When I want to get away from this I go flamenco dancing in Manhattan," says the ranger. He really is known for organizing flamenco exhibitions with fellow enthusiasts at such Queens places as Danny's Szechuan Garden on Cross Bay Boulevard.
 
Ebb Tide Music On Sunwashed Piers
 So goes the ranger's rapture. Further west along the city shore, other humans teem differently on a hot and sunny day out along the old Steeplechase pier on Coney Island, off West 17th Street. They are crabbing with chicken legs as bait and with boomboxes full of Latin music to spice the city's ebb tide. To a returning New Yorker, the scene contains the reassurance that the poor retain the knack for having more varied public fun together in larger crowds of far more rambling families than the rich usually do.
They dance on the pier in different groups to different songs, cooking sizzling dishes above the ocean. They gamble cheaply in the breeze at their own illicit gaming tables, quenching thirsts with cold beers and elaborate rum and fruit-punch drinks made by a happily profiteering vendor tending bar from a converted Good Humor cart.
Nostalgia has long since ravaged Coney Island, with weeds lushly growing up a rusted roller coaster that stands oddly amid the later world of public housing. The pier scene, with the laughter and flavor of fresh immigrants, is a remembrance that liberalism and left-wing politics used to flourish in the city for people such as these.
"Socialism is dead and liberalism is discombobulated," Raymond S. Franklin says flatly, as if the city were a noir tale with the denouement finally as clear as wet asphalt at night.
This New Yorker talks not quite like the Queens College professor of economics that he is as founder and director of the Michael Harrington Center. This is a scholarly research memorial to the city's late, last Socialist, Mr. Franklin's drinking buddy from the old days when the antipoverty program was generating hope and community organization among the ghetto poor.
"I can't go out in the morning without a dozen quarters," says the professor, less a social strategist these days than a confessed easy touch for the waves of beggars who have taken unabashed hold of the city's streets. "They're unbelievable," he admits. "Still, they put in a day."
As a professor, Mr. Franklin measures this phenomenon mainly as another jagged New York irony: He traces it to the end of the old single-room-occupancy hotel problem of his Upper West Side Manhattan neighborhood, with the poor retreating from real-estate developers only to return as the current plague of homeless.
One of these beggars, a bearded man who calls himself Vincent, says that while he would have been too ashamed to beg five years ago, he came to recognize a kind of peer-group protection among so many city poor rising up publicly across the Reagan years. So Vincent took up the street cup.
"You think it would be better if I robbed you?" he asks. "This is kind of like a job," he says, patiently opening the door to a bank office for each working New Yorker making a visit on payday.
Professor Franklin and Vincent share meaner streets. Vincent insistently jangles his coin cup, and the professor shifts across the years from idealizing as an East Harlem antipoverty consultant in something called the Human Dynamics Corporation, to organizing conferences now on such themes as "London and New York: Two Cities in Decay."
Seeking financing, not idealizing, proved the ultimate antipoverty lesson for the poor, he has concluded, offering a rough maxim for the city: "When you want to change society, you can't imitate your oppressors too soon."
As always, the city's working poor don't need a professor to teach them that.
 
Street Lesson: Move or Get Stuck
 "It goes up and down," says Shirley Mack, surveying the kaleidoscopic scene along Flatbush Avenue in south Brooklyn, where the poor shop in cut-rate stores that, amid their nonstop sale signs, discreetly post window warnings to potential burglars: "Steel-plated roof and walls."
"Macy's leaving don't mean nothing," says Mrs. Mack, a long-ago migrant from North Carolina who works six days in the Rich Rach women's boutique near Church Avenue and says she somehow never quite realizes her vow to move on, to move up.
"You know how it's, just, sometimes you get some place and you get stuck?" she asks. "Hitting the lottery is the only way I'll get out of here."
Macy's, three blocks south on Tilden Avenue, will indeed be closing the Flatbush store as executives tend to profit margins. The store already is tomblike within, with a big security desk watching at the entrance and the air-conditioning lending a sepulchral chill.
It's more warm and welcoming out on the street. In this part of the city, whites are the minority as crowds of blacks shop the small stores that seem the stuff of occasional bargains in hope.
"This block is really is a zoo, can't you feel that?" a clerk in a notions store conspiratorially asks a fellow white. "You feel safe? Walk at night here after 7 o'clock and see."
The man, identifying himself as Ilan, an immigrant from Israel, is bitter after two years of failing to make economic progress in the city. "For me the American dream is over," he says, cursing the unknown people who broke into his car last week. "Here, I've seen people die in the streets. I'm going back to Israel because at least nobody dies in the streets there," he says, overlooking the mortal tally in the clashes there with the Palestinian community.
 
Seeds of Hope In Stony Despair
 At that, the man's imagination seems daunted more by the counters of petty notions he tends rather than his selective comparisons of home and New York. Around the corner on Church Street labors a counterbalancing agent, Yvonne Graham, an immigrant from Jamaica, who landed in East Flatbush 12 years ago.
"It's hard to take root," she says, "You must till and nurture the soil in this city. At first I suffered the cultural shock of all immigrant groups, but now I like the city for its cultural diversity."
Miss Graham is entitled to some optimism. The storefront program she founded, the Caribbean Women's Health Association, has grown from four part-time volunteers and a $82,000 budget 10 years ago to 37 full-time workers and $1.5 million offering 10 community programs to thousands of residents.
Even so, a sense of success must apparently remain a luxury in East Flatbush. "We're part of the Crown Heights troubles," Miss Graham says, referring to the street troubles between blacks and Hasidic Jews last summer and the simmering social aftermath.
"There's lots of tension left," she says warily about the mix of hot weather, unemployment and routine street despair. The Presidential political year, with the candidates' attempts at stirring promises and hope, has not touched the neighborhood, she says.
This is not new. The city always seems to hunker unbelieving through the Oz-like show of Presidential politics, as if it knows there are terrible things happening routinely here that cannot, maybe should not, be accounted for in mere human debate.
Most ineffable among these in the eyes of a returning witness is the sight of the growing communities of AIDS babies, the children of diseased parents who most unfairly bear the latest mark of Cain that humanity has invented for itself.
 
Mortal Weariness In the Age of AIDS
 A New Yorker looking for fresh life in the city cannot afford to linger long watching them play in such a sanctuary as the preschool day-care center at Bronx Municipal Hospital, where two dozen toddlers bear the AIDS virus and its perpetual threat of having no mortal defense against mundane illness. One boy whose health fails chronically and cruelly these days worries the staff most. He smiles like the little boy he is in joining the others to make pizza for a simple picnic; but he has a touch of adult weariness, too, that remains haunting in remembrance.
All about him, the staff fights to present ordinary childhood, nothing more, day after day to the children. There is a "family kitchen" designed for staff workers to mingle over coffee with the AIDS parents to show "we're not afraid to break bread with people who have the disease," says a worker.
Still does the city urgently wield bread and continuing life even as it must bear despair and death.
Morris Hershman, a man interviewed two years ago in Moscow, said then that he was fighting to emigrate from the Soviet Union simply to get to New York and die here.
He was born in the city and kidnapped six decades ago as a 5-year-old by his Marxist father, who ran off to join the Bolshevik revolution. The boy was orphaned and spent much of his life in prisons and camps in the Soviet Union for being "Yanky," a suspect, a misfit.
Finally, world weary and living in Brooklyn, Mr. Hershman has received a note of congratulations from "your fellow inmate" and old friend, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the dissident master of Russian literature, who encourages him to write his memoirs for his two granddaughters.
In his second year in Brooklyn, Mr. Hershman was nostalgic and visited Moscow last month.
"It was awful," he says. "No hope there."
"Please correct my story to say I no longer want to die in New York," he pleads. "Show me smiling now. There is light here," he says, holding his hands toward the window of his apartment off Ocean Parkway.
"In Moscow is anger, boiling anger; in New York is life, boiling life," he says, threatening New York with more talk of the rapture.

HEADLINE: U.S. Remains Moscowcentric on Once-Soviet Asia

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was trying to persuade former Soviet republics in recent weeks to give up their nuclear weapons, the only holdout was Kazakhstan. Though it ultimately went along, the largest nation of Central Asia was toying with the idea of using nuclear weapons as political bargaining chips to get international attention.
The affairs of Kazakhstan, along with those of the other four former Soviet republics of Central Asia, have been largely overshadowed by developments in republics like Russia or Ukraine, which are better known outside the former Soviet Union. With their Islamic, often anti-Russian populations, moreover, the Central Asia countries -- nicknamed the "stans" after their common suffix -- are emerging from the collapse of the Soviet empire as a world apart from Moscow, policy analysts and area specialists say. 
 Despite their separate identities, these nations continue to be treated by the United States as branch offices of Russia, said Paul Goble, a former State Department adviser on Soviet nationalities. "We're acting as if the Soviet Union still lives," said Mr. Goble, now a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
In policy research organizations and embassies, analysts are questioning whether the Bush Administration is responding with sufficiently new ideas and policies for the region. Many view Washington's approach as simplistic and old-world, focusing on nuclear issues and promoting Turkey as a secular model for a region whose Muslim populations raise fears in the West of Islamic militancy.
 
Closer to the South
 Culturally, the area -- which encompasses Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Kyrgyzstan -- is non-European and traditionally closer to the broad band of nations to the south, stretching from Iran through Afghanistan, Pakistan, India and into western China.
The State Department, however, still classifies the region bureaucratically as part of Europe.
The Administration's decision to leave Central Asia in the State Department's European bureau with other remnants of the former Soviet Union was not a casual one, a State Department spokeswoman said. It was made to keep the Central Asians in the sphere of European organizations, especially the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which sets standards for political and human rights.
Nonetheless, Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the New York Democrat who wrote legislation that recently created a new South Asian bureau for the State Department, said there is "some merit" in considering inclusion of the Central Asian nations under the purview of the new bureau, which is still in its formative stages.
 
Searching for Ports
 The new countries' developing economic links and search for ports, for example, are likely to draw them closer to Asian neighbors. Iran, Pakistan, India and China have an interest in the future of the region, which is also poised to influence Afghanistan and the independence movement in Indian Kashmir.
Several of the five nations have approached the Asian Development Bank about membership. Pakistanis, Iranians and Indians have moved aggressively to develop business relations in the Central Asian capitals. Pakistani textile mills hope, for instance, to draw on the cotton grown in the region.
Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, who recently toured Central Asia and has been active in questioning the Administration on its aid plans for the region, praises Secretary Baker for taking the lead in opening embassies there. But the Senator said in an interview that he is concerned that Washington is listening too closely to fears of Islamic revivalism voiced for political reasons by old-guard Communists still in power in several new states.
Mr. DeConcini is also critical of the Administration's decision to meet the threat of Islamic militancy through a policy of encouraging Turkey as a model for Central Asia. Administration officials say they have agreed on a joint technical pact with Turkey, which is Islamic but secular, to "foster democratic and market reforms, and orient their trade and other ties westward."
"Turkey has immense problems, including in human rights," the Senator said.
 
'Cold War Pattern' Faulted
 Barnett Rubin, director of the recently revived Center for the Study of Central Asia at Columbia University, said: "The main obstacle to intelligent policymaking in Central Asia is the repetition of the cold war pattern of looking for a threat and for a partner against that threat -- and then finding that the partner has a regional agenda that isn't yours." In this case, it is the spread of Turkic influence across the region.
"At the moment, the new threat perception is some kind of Iranian fundamentalism, and our partner is so-called secular Turkey," Mr. Rubin said in an interview. "I think that the Central Asian nations are not going to be the passive recipients of somebody else's models."
Edward Allworth, also of the Columbia center, said making Turkey the model was "a simple-minded solution to a very complex problem." He said that the five Central Asian nations were all different in various ways, but that at the grass-roots level it appeared that the urge to adopt an Asian Islamic identity was strong.
Firuz Kazemzadeh, professor of history at Yale University, told a Congressional subcommittee recently: "Central Asia is not well known in the Western world. Even the term itself has no universally accepted definition."
 
A Range of Islam
 Professor Kazemzadeh, a scholar of the Russian empire and the nationalities it absorbed over the centuries, said any post-Communist revival of Islam would take different forms -- ranging from Kazakhstan, with a large non-Muslim, ethnic Russian population, to Uzbekistan and Tajikistan, whose cities were centers of Islamic scholarship.
But he added, "Islam has had a stronger hold on the masses of Central Asia than Orthodox Christianity had on the Russians." He advised American policymakers to be prepared to accept some aspects of government there that might not be tolerated at home, including limited electoral franchise and a central involvement of religion in the state.
"Conducting relations with Central Asia will not be easy," he said, even with a great deal of interest among Central Asians in closer ties to the West. "Yet the United States stands at a propitious moment for influencing the future of that remote and very significant part of the world."

HEADLINE: Arson Rate, After Decline in 80's, Jumps in Northeast Recession

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
Firefighters and insurance-claims adjusters say they can track a recession as well as any economist. If arson is up, business is down.
Arson, which declined in the prosperous 1980's, has jumped in states like New York and New Jersey that have been hit hard by the weak economy, adjusters say. The Northeast leads the nation in fires deliberately set to destroy failing businesses, as well as houses, cars and boats. 
 "My office map showing the location of suspicious fire claims has clusters of pins all over the Northeast, Texas and Oklahoma, the regions with the longest-running economic downturns," said John Barracato, a former deputy fire commissioner in New York City who heads the fire-investigation unit at Aetna Life and Casualty. He said that houses in the $80,000-to-$145,000 range led the list of properties involved in suspect fires and that policyholders filed inflated claims for the loss of household contents.
He estimated that claims to Aetna involving suspicious fires rose more than 20 percent in the last two years and that the claims for a wider range of losses covered by homeowners' insurance had increased even more.
The chief of special investigations for the CNA Insurance Company of Chicago, Jay Williams, said: "Arson is a continual problem, but much more so during a recession. People don't burn their homes or business until they are in dire financial straits."
Mr. Williams said the number of suspicious claims on all CNA policies, including fire, automobile theft and workers' compensation, had risen 63 percent in the last year. "Separate claims on fires are notoriously slow in coming in because of the time needed to investigate them," he added. "The data on 1991 are still being processed."
In New York State, the number of incendiary fires, the term used to describe deliberately set fires, was 13.7 percent higher in 1990 than in 1987, the year of the Wall Street crash.
"This and other data support the belief that arson is on the rise," State Fire Administrator Francis A. McGarry said. "Given the economic climate, we suspect it is continuing. People can be pressured by the economy to do some pretty crazy things."
In New Jersey the number of incendiary fires climbed, from 2,509 in 1989 to 2,991 in 1990, a 19 percent increase, according to Sgt. Daniel Cosgrove of the state police.
In Connecticut, a state with a reputation for aggressive arson investigation and training, the level appears to be holding steady, said Sgt. James Butterworth of the state police, who is assigned to the State Fire Marshal's office. "There definitely is an economic fire situation out there, because everyone is mortgaged to the hilt, and they see values going down," Sergeant Butterworth said. "Some people just drive away and let the bank foreclose. Others torch it."
Fire statistics for last year, when the recession deepened, are not available in the New York metropolitan region. But anecdotal evidence is strong that problems with arson continue, for reasons that sometimes go beyond the economy.
Investigators say street gangs and drug rings are increasingly using firebombs as weapons for intimidation, revenge and terror. "We are seeing the use of firebombs by drug gangs as part of an ascending spiral of violence that is topped by the use of explosives," said Jack Killorin, a fire investigator who is a spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. "It is a phenomenon of the last three years that has become national in scope."
 
Difficulty in Counting
 Jack Ward, who stepped down this month as president of the 7,000-member International Association of Arson Investigators, said: "Every investigator I talk with has been extremely busy. We have an exceptional number of fires to work, not counting the Los Angeles situation. And when private investigators like us are busy, you can bet the local fire departments have their hands full."
Not only do local fire departments have their hands full, but some also complain that their hands are tied by budget constraints that limit investigations even as the number of suspect fires increases. In New York City, fire officials say that because of such constraints, they cannot give precise figures on the number of fires that they believe were intentionally set.
The city's Chief Fire Marshal, John J. Stickevers, said that budget cuts had halved his force of 350 marshals, but that 45 marshals were recently added, putting total at 198. He said the Fire Department was now responsible for controlling illegal social clubs, a police function until the Happy Land Social Club fire that killed 87 people in the Bronx in 1989, further stretching manpower.
Mr. Stickevers acknowledged that even in prosperous times the Fire Department had to limit the number of suspicious fires it pursued. In a recession, with more fires occurring but with fewer resources, the problem only deepens, he said.
"Store fires are an indication of people in financial trouble, and small stores are the first to go," he added.
Last year, Mr. Stickevers said, the number of fires in "mom and pop" stores rose 14 percent over 1990, "but how many were intentionally set we'll never know."
He said the department pressed hard on "provocative" fires that drew public attention or incurred significant financial losses. But fires in vacant buildings, small businesses and houses were less likely to be investigated, unless there were compelling reasons to do. "There were 2,300 fires in the city last year we didn't investigate and should have," the Chief said.
 
The Need for Training
 Another city fire official, who insisted on anonymity, said recent New York arson statistics were meaningless because of the budget cuts. "A fire isn't arson unless a fire marshal calls it arson," the official said. "Cutting back on fire marshals means fewer fires are investigated, which means the number of arsons goes down, which prompts the Office of Management and Budget to say since arsons are going down, the city doesn't need so many fire marshals."
A New York fire marshal is a firefighter, who, after taking a Civil Service test, receives nine weeks of training and works in the field under the tutelage of an experienced officer.
"If you don't investigate with trained people, you can't know what the arson problem is," Mr. Stickevers said. "Even with trained people, we get beat, and we get beat more often than we like to admit."

HEADLINE: Students Plunge Into Crowded Labor Pool

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
As coordinator of the jobs programs for the City University of New York, Daniel E. Powers keeps students at the 17 campuses appraised of summer job openings. These days, he does not have too much to do.
"In the late 80's, we would be under paper, with so many jobs coming in," he said recently. "Last year I thought was the all-time low, but this is even lower. I've been here 15 years, and this is the worst I've seen it." 
 Some economists, job counselors and college students are more upbeat than Mr. Powers, but most predict frustration for young people who are hoping to use the summer to help pay rising tuition costs or to strengthen their resumes for the increasingly competitive job market.
Because of the sluggish economy, sectors of the city job market that usually swell in summer, like tourism and recreation, will probably remain slack this year. Given a city unemployment rate of 9.5 percent in April (compared with 7.2 percent nationwide), college students hoping to do everything, or anything, from painting houses to unloading trucks must plunge into a labor pool already crowded with experienced workers to claw for the few opportunities.
 
Lots of Competition
 "This year, students can expect to be competing with a lot of unemployed people who will be willing to take basically anything," said James Brown, an associate economist with the State Department of Labor who focuses on New York City. "It's going to be a very hard summer." Mr. Brown said he expected up to 60,000 16- to 19-year-olds to enter the job market this summer, joining 312,000 New Yorkers already hunting for work.
On the supply side, Mr. Brown expects the number of seasonal jobs, like waiting tables and working at beaches, to total 15,000, a figure that understates the volume of summer work because it omits temporary jobs that open up as permanent employees go on vacation. Over all, Mr. Brown said he expected the job market to be a little better than last year's.
"But that's damning with faint praise," Mr. Brown said. "Last summer was disastrous. This will be the second-worst year in a decade."
Isaac Jordan, a student at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, would seem to have an edge. Now 30 years old, he already had seven years of clerical and computer experience when he began college.
Mr. Jordan has not been particular, trying temporary agencies, department stores, catering and messenger services. So far, no good. "It's tough," he said. "It's been really tough."
Even for employers who are hiring, bringing in untrained college students can be a low priority. The city's Department of Parks and Recreation has traditionally been a major employer of students hoping to make some money over the summer. But since 1988, the number of temporary jobs has dropped about 40 percent, to just over 2,000, and the department has stopped recruiting, said Stewart Desmond, a department spokesman.
The slump has created what Greg J. Pappas, dean of student services at Fordham University, calls a trickle-up effect, in which low-skill, low-wage jobs are snatched up by more experienced workers. With graduates poaching college students' jobs, he said, the college students, like Mr. Jordan, are hunting in high school students' territory.
"High school students traditionally would work in retail, but now you're seeing more college students working in retail," Mr. Pappas said. "You're seeing more 15- and 16-year-olds unemployed, because their jobs are being taken by college students."
For many college students, he said, the problem this pecking order creates is that they they cannot use the summer to gain experience in the professional fields they want to pursue after graduation, experience they need more than ever.
One apparent solution to this problem is internships, temporary training slots targeted at young people. "Students are more interested in internships," said Thomas L. Thomas, director of Career Development Services at Hunter College and president of the Career Counseling and Placement Association of CUNY. "A student who has one or two internships when he graduates is much more marketable than a student who just has the degree."
And companies in recent years have become more interested in hiring interns, said Victor R. Lindquist, a dean at Northwestern University who surveys mid- to large-size businesses each year about their hiring plans. Through internships, companies can give prospective employees a tryout period.
But companies are cutting back on paid internships, expecting students to work for free in exchange for the experience and credential, career counselors said. And competition for even the unpaid positions is getting stiffer.
"Many students who have graduated and can't find jobs or even part-time jobs are now looking for internships, which they never did before," said Shelly Shapiro, internship coordinator and director of the corporate careers program at Brooklyn College. "The pool out there is just overwhelming."
 
Lowered Expectations
 Ewa Wieczorek, a 23-year-old Polish immigrant who worked her way through her freshman year at Hunter College as a receptionist, hoped to find an internship this summer in her chosen field, physical therapy. But she quickly learned she could not beat the competition and lowered her expectations.
"I called every hospital in New York City to find a job as a volunteer," she said. "I wanted to work in a hospital to get the experience to get the internship."
But she found that no one wanted her, even to clean rooms or to answer telephones for free. "They said no, no, no -- they all said no," she said. "I'd call back, hear a different voice, and hope maybe this time -- but no way." After a month of searching, she got a volunteer job by pleading with the chairman of the physical therapy department at one hospital.
"They're closing the door for people," she said. "They said I needed experience, but how can I get the experience if no one wants to hire me?"

HEADLINE: Arson Figures Are Difficult To Compile

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
Arson is regarded as one of the most underreported crimes. Historically it has been difficult to track.
Two Federal agencies and one private group collect national statistics on arson, and they have reservations about the completeness of the information, especially on arson for profit. 
 The problem is threefold. A blaze and the efforts to extinguish it can obliterate the evidence of arson, although technological advances and training have made that more unlikely. Second, overlapping police and fire jurisdictions in an investigation can create a tangle of conflicting conclusions about whether the cause of a fire was arson, a prosecutable felony or a case that can be attributed to a less clear description like "suspicious," "incendiary," "deliberate" or "unknown."
Even the legal definitions of arson can vary from state to state.
 
Trends Rather Than Details
 Collecting and analyzing fire reports is slow. The latest national figures are for 1990. The United States Fire Administration has a data center that gathers and analyzes information drawn from 13,023 fire departments in 40 states and 27 cities -- there are 33,000 professional and volunteer fire companies in the country -- to provide a picture of trends rather than complete national figures.
The Uniformed Crime Report compiled yearly by the Federal Bureau of Investigation based on records supplied by law-enforcement agencies has a section on arson as a major crime. But it is filled with footnotes that bluntly acknowledge that the information is incomplete and not totally reliable. The F.B.I. reports that 1 in 6 arsons involves an arrest.
The National Fire Protection Association in Quincy, Mass., a group that helps set safety standards, publishes national statistics provided by fire departments. Dr. John T. Hall Jr., who is in charge of fire analysis and research, says arson for profit is just a small part of fires that are deliberately set. Juveniles playing with matches are the largest single group, and those who set fires for revenge are another. The umbrella category of arson, therefore, does not show great movement with economic cycles, he said, but a sustained recession can contribute to "regional spiking."
According to the latest figures from the association, there were 97,000 structural fires in 1990 classified as "deliberately set or suspicious" and causing an estimated $1.394 billion in property damage.
